text: <Disease>A common human skin tumour is caused by activating mutations in beta-catenin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>WNT signalling orchestrates a number of developmental programs.</Disease>
<Disease>In response to this stimulus, cytoplasmic beta-catenin (encoded by CTNNB1) is stabilized, enabling downstream transcriptional activation by members of the LEF/TCF family.</Disease>
<Disease>One of the target genes for beta-catenin/TCF encodes c-MYC, explaining why constitutive activation of the WNT pathway can lead to cancer, particularly in the colon.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Most colon cancers arise from mutations in the gene encoding adenomatous polyposis coli (APC), a protein required for ubiquitin-mediated degradation of beta-catenin, but a small percentage of colon and some other cancers harbour beta-catenin-stabilizing mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, we discovered that transgenic mice expressing an activated beta-catenin are predisposed to developing skin tumours resembling pilomatricomas.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Given that the skin of these adult mice also exhibits signs of de novo hair-follicle morphogenesis, we wondered whether human pilomatricomas might originate from hair matrix cells and whether they might possess beta-catenin-stabilizing mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here, we explore the cell origin and aetiology of this common human skin tumour.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We found nuclear LEF-1 in the dividing tumour cells, providing biochemical evidence that pilomatricomas are derived from hair matrix cells.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>At least 75% of these tumours possess mutations affecting the amino-terminal segment, normally involved in phosphorylation-dependent, ubiquitin-mediated degradation of the protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This percentage of CTNNB1 mutations is greater than in all other human tumours examined thus far, and directly implicates beta-catenin/LEF misregulation as the major cause of hair matrix cell tumorigenesis in humans..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>HFE mutations analysis in 711 hemochromatosis probands: evidence for S65C implication in mild form of hemochromatosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hereditary hemochromatosis (HH) is a common autosomal recessive genetic disorder of iron metabolism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The HFE candidate gene encoding an HLA class I-like protein involved in HH was identified in 1996.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two missense mutations have been described  C282Y, accounting for 80% to 90% of HH chromosomes, and H63D, which is associated with a milder form of the disease representing 40% to 70% of non-C282Y HH chromosomes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report here on the analysis of C282Y, H63D, and the 193A-- > T substitution leading to the S65C missense substitution in a large series of probands and controls.</Disease>

<Disease>The results confirm that the C282Y substitution was the main mutation involved in hemochromatosis, accounting for 85% of carrier chromosomes, whereas the H63D substitution represented 39% of the HH chromosomes that did not carry the C282Y mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, our screening showed that the S65C substitution was significantly enriched in probands with at least one chromosome without an assigned mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>This substitution accounted for 7. 8% of HH chromosomes that were neither C282Y nor H63D.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This enrichment of S65C among HH chromosomes suggests that the S65C substitution is associated with the mild form of hemochromatosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Germline BRCA1 alterations in a population-based series of ovarian cancer cases.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The objective of this study was to provide more accurate frequency estimates of breast cancer susceptibility gene 1 (BRCA1) germline alterations in the ovarian cancer population.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To achieve this, we determined the prevalence of BRCA1 alterations in a population-based series of consecutive ovarian cancer cases.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This is the first population-based ovarian cancer study reporting BRCA1 alterations derived from a comprehensive screen of the entire coding region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One hundred and seven ovarian cancer cases were analyzed for BRCA1 alterations using the RNase mismatch cleavage assay followed by direct sequencing.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two truncating mutations, 962del4 and 3600del11, were identified.</Disease>
<Disease>Both patients had a family history of breast or ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Several novel as well as previously reported uncharacterized variants were also identified, some of which were associated with a family history of cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The frequency distribution of common polymorphisms was determined in the 91 Caucasian cancer cases in this series and 24 sister controls using allele-specific amplification.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The rare form of the Q356R polymorphism was significantly (P = 0. 03) associated with a family history of ovarian cancer, suggesting that this polymorphism may influence ovarian cancer risk.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In summary, our data suggest a role for some uncharacterized variants and rare forms of polymorphisms in determining ovarian cancer risk, and highlight the necessity to screen for missense alterations as well as truncating mutations in this population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of APC2, a homologue of the adenomatous polyposis coli tumour suppressor.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumour-suppressor protein controls the Wnt signalling pathway by forming a complex with glycogen synthase kinase</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>3beta (GSK-3beta), axin/conductin and betacatenin.</Disease>
<Disease>Complex formation induces the rapid degradation of betacatenin.</Disease>
<Disease>In colon carcinoma cells, loss of APC leads to the accumulation of betacatenin in the nucleus, where it binds to and activates the Tcf-4 transcription factor (reviewed in [1]</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>[2]).</Disease>
<Disease>Here, we report the identification and genomic structure of APC homologues.</Disease>

<Disease>Mammalian APC2, which closely resembles APC in overall domain structure, was functionally analyzed and shown to contain two SAMP domains, both of which are required for binding to conductin.</Disease>
<Disease>Like APC, APC2 regulates the formation of active betacatenin-Tcf complexes, as demonstrated using transient transcriptional activation assays in APC -/- colon carcinoma cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Human APC2 maps to chromosome 19p13.</Disease>
<Disease>3. APC and APC2 may therefore have comparable functions in development and cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial deficiency of the seventh component of complement associated with recurrent bacteremic infections due to Neisseria.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The serum of a 29-year old woman with a recent episode of disseminated gonococcal infection and a history of meningococcal meningitis and arthritis as a child was found to lack serum hemolytic complement activity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The seventh component of complement (C7) was not detected by functional or immunochemical assays, whereas other components were normal by hemolytic and immunochemical assessment.</Disease>

<Disease>Her fresh serum lacked complement-mediated bactericidal activity against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, but the addition of fresh normal serum or purified C7 restored bactericidal activity as well as hemolytic activity.</Disease>
<Disease>The absence of functional C7 activity could not be accounted for on the basis of an inhibitor.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Opsonization and generation of chemotactic activity functioned normally.</Disease>

<Disease>Complete absence of C7 was also found in one sibling who had the clinical syndrome of meningococcal meningitis and arthritis  as a child and in this siblings clinically well eight-year-old son.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>HLA histocompatibility typing of the family members did not demonstrate evidence for genetic linkage of C7 deficiency with the major histocompatibility loci.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This report represents the first cases of C7 deficiency associated with infectious complications and suggests that bactericidal activity may be important in host defense against bacteremic neisseria infections.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>GCH1 mutation in a patient with adult-onset oromandibular dystonia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The authors report a mutation in exon 5 of GCH1 in a patient with adult-onset oromandibular dystonia and no obvious family history of dystonia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The patient responded positively to treatment with L-dopa.</Disease>
<Disease>These findings demonstrate that GCH1 mutations must be considered even in patients with dystonic symptoms not typical of dopa-responsive dystonia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The hereditary hemochromatosis protein, HFE, specifically regulates transferrin-mediated iron uptake in HeLa cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>HFE is the protein product of the gene mutated in the autosomal recessive disease hereditary hemochromatosis (Feder, J. N., Gnirke, A., Thomas, W., Tsuchihashi, Z., Ruddy, D. A., Basava, A., Dormishian, F., Domingo, R. J., Ellis, M. C., Fullan, A., Hinton, L. M., Jones, N. L., Kimmel, B. E., Kronmal, G. S., Lauer, P., Lee, V. K., Loeb, D. B., Mapa, F. A., McClelland, E., Meyer, N. C., Mintier, G. A., Moeller, N., Moore, T., Morikang, E., Prasss, C. E ., Quintana, L., Starnes, S. M ., Schatzman, R. C ., Brunke, K. J ., Drayna, D. T., Risch, N. J ., Bacon, B. R ., and Wolff, R. R .</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>(1996) Nat. Genet. 13, 399-408).</Disease>

<Disease>At the cell surface, HFE complexes with transferrin receptor (TfR), increasing the dissociation constant of transferrin (Tf) for its receptor 10-fold (Gross, C. N ., Irrinki, A., Feder, J. N ., and Enns, C. A .</Disease>
<Disease>(1998) J. Biol.</Disease>
<Disease>Chem.</Disease>
<Disease>273, 22068-22074; Feder, J. N., Penny, D. M., Irrinki, A., Lee, V. K., Lebron, J. A., Watson, N., Tsuchihashi, Z., Sigal, E., Bjorkman, P. J., and Schatzman, R. C. (1998) Proc.</Disease>
<Disease>Natl .</Disease>
<Disease>Acad.</Disease>
<Disease>Sci.</Disease>
<Disease>U S</Disease>
<Disease>A 95, 1472-1477).</Disease>
<Disease>HFE does not remain at the cell surface, but traffics with TfR to Tf-positive internal compartments (Gross et al., 1998).</Disease>

<Disease>Using a HeLa cell line in which the expression of HFE is controlled by tetracycline, we show that the expression of HFE reduces 55Fe uptake from Tf by 33% but does not affect the endocytic or exocytic rates of TfR cycling.</Disease>
<Disease>Therefore, HFE appears to reduce cellular acquisition of iron from Tf within endocytic compartments.</Disease>
<Disease>HFE specifically reduces iron uptake from Tf, as non-Tf-mediated iron uptake from Fe-nitrilotriacetic acid is not altered.</Disease>
<Disease>These results explain the decreased ferritin levels seen in our HeLa cell system and demonstrate the specific control of HFE over the Tf-mediated pathway of iron uptake.</Disease>

<Disease>These results also have implications for the understanding of cellular iron homeostasis in organs such as the liver, pancreas, heart, and spleen that are iron loaded in hereditary hemochromatotic individuals lacking functional HFE.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation and haplotype studies of familial Mediterranean fever reveal new ancestral relationships and evidence for a high carrier frequency with reduced penetrance in the Ashkenazi Jewish population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a recessive disorder characterized by episodes of fever with serositis or synovitis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The FMF gene (MEFV) was cloned recently, and four missense mutations were identified.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here we present data from non-Ashkenazi Jewish and Arab patients in whom we had not originally found mutations and from a new, more ethnically diverse panel.</Disease>
<Disease>Among 90 symptomatic mutation-positive individuals, 11 mutations accounted for 79% of carrier chromosomes.</Disease>
<Disease>Of the two mutations that are novel, one alters the same residue (680) as a previously known mutation, and the other (P369S) is located in exon 3.</Disease>

<Disease>Consistent with another recent report, the E148Q mutation was observed in patients of several ethnicities and on multiple microsatellite haplotypes, but haplotype data indicate an ancestral relationships between non-Jewish Italian and Ashkenazi Jewish patients with FMF and other affected populations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Among approximately 200 anonymous Ashkenazi Jewish DNA samples, the MEFV carrier frequency was 21%, with E148Q the most common mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>Several lines of evidence indicate reduced penetrance among Ashkenazi Jews, especially for E148Q, P369S, and K695R.</Disease>
<Disease>Nevertheless, E148Q helps account for recessive inheritance in an Ashkenazi family previously reported as an unusual case of dominantly inherited FMF.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The presence of three frequent MEFV mutations in multiple Mediterranean populations strongly suggests a heterozygote advantage in this geographic region.</Disease>
<Disease>Autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome  with defective Fas: genotype influences penetrance.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) is a disorder of lymphocyte homeostasis and immunological tolerance.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Most patients have a heterozygous mutation in the APT1 gene, which encodes Fas (CD95, APO-1), mediator of an apoptotic pathway crucial to lymphocyte homeostasis.</Disease>
<Disease>Of 17 unique APT1 mutations in unrelated ALPS probands, 12 (71%) occurred in exons 7-9, which encode the intracellular portion of Fas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In vitro, activated lymphocytes from all 17 patients showed apoptotic defects when exposed to an anti-Fas agonist monoclonal antibody.</Disease>
<Disease>Similar defects were found in a Fas-negative cell line transfected with cDNAs bearing each of the mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>In cotransfection experiments, Fas constructs with either intra- or extracellular mutations caused dominant inhibition of apoptosis mediated by wild-type Fas.</Disease>
<Disease>Two missense Fas variants, not restricted to patients with ALPS, were identified.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Variant A (-1) T at the Fas signal-sequence cleavage site, which mediates apoptosis less well than wild-type Fas and is partially inhibitory, was present in 13% of African American alleles.</Disease>

<Disease>Among the ALPS-associated Fas mutants, dominant inhibition of apoptosis was much more pronounced in mutants affecting the intracellular, versus extracellular, portion of the Fas receptor.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations causing disruption of the intracellular Fas death domain also showed a higher penetrance of ALPS phenotype features in mutation-bearing relatives.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Significant ALPS-related morbidity occurred in 44% of relatives with intracellular mutations, versus 0% of relatives with extracellular mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, the location of mutations within APT1 strongly influences the development and the severity of ALPS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutational analysis and genotype-phenotype correlation of 29 unrelated Japanese patients with X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND  X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) is an inherited disease characterized by progressive neurologic dysfunction, occasionally associated with adrenal insufficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The classic form of ALD usually has onset in childhood (childhood cerebral ALD), with rapid neurologic deterioration leading to a vegetative state.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Adult-onset cerebral ALD also presents with rapidly progressive neurologic dysfunction.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Milder phenotypes such as adrenomyeloneuropathy and Addison disease only also have been recognized.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Despite discovery of the causative gene, a molecular basis for the diverse clinical presentations remains to be elucidated.</Disease>

<Disease>OBJECTIVES  To conduct mutational analyses in 29 Japanese patients with ALD from 29 unrelated families, to obtain knowledge of the spectrum of mutations in this gene, and to study genotype-phenotype correlations in Japanese patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  </Disease>
<Disease>The 29 patients comprised 13 patients with childhood cerebral ALD, 11 patients with adult-onset cerebral ALD, and 5 patients with adrenomyeloneuropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We conducted detailed mutational analyses of 29 unrelated Japanese patients with ALD by genomic Southern blot analysis and direct nucleotide sequence analysis of reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction products derived from total RNA that was extracted from cultured skin fibroblasts, lymphoblastoid cells, or peripheral blood leukocytes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS  Three patients with adult-onset cerebral ALD were identified as having large genomic rearrangements.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The remaining 26 patients were identified as having 21 independent mutations, including 12 novel mutations resulting in small nucleotide alterations in the ALD gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Eighteen (69%) of 26 mutations were missense mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>Most missense mutations involved amino acids conserved in homologous gene products, including PMP70, mALDRP, and Pxa1p.</Disease>

<Disease>The AG dinucleotide deletion at position 1081-1082, which has been reported previously to be the most common mutation in white patients (12% -17%), was also identified as the most common mutation in Japanese patients (12%).</Disease>
<Disease>All phenotypes were associated with mutations resulting in protein truncation or subtle amino acid changes.</Disease>
<Disease>There were no differences in phenotypic expressions between missense mutations involving conserved amino acids and those involving nonconserved amino acids.</Disease>

<Disease>CONCLUSIONS  There are no obvious correlations between the phenotypes of patients with ALD and their genotypes, suggesting that other genetic or environmental factors modify the phenotypic expressions of ALD..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Absence of the seventh component of complement in a patient with chronic meningococcemia presenting as vasculitis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A previously healthy 40-year-old man presenting with fever, arthritis, and cutaneous vasculitis was found to have chronic meningococcemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Evaluation of his complement system showed an absence of functional and antigenic C7, compatible with a complete deficiency of the seventh component of complement.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Study of the patients family spanning four generations showed heterozygous deficiency of C7 in five members.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chronic neisserial infection can be associated with C7 deficiency and must be distinguished from other causes of cutaneous vasculitis..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Genotype and phenotype in patients with dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD) deficiency is an autosomal recessive disease characterised by thymine-uraciluria in homozygous deficient patients and has been associated with a variable clinical phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In order to understand the genetic and phenotypic basis for DPD deficiency, we have reviewed 17 families presenting 22 patients with complete deficiency of DPD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this group of patients, 7 different mutations have been identified, including 2 deletions [295-298delTCAT, 1897delC], 1 splice-site mutation [IVS14 + 1G > A)] and 4 missense mutations (85T > C, 703C > T, 2658G > A, 2983G > T).</Disease>
<Disease>Analysis of the prevalence of the various mutations among DPD patients has shown that the G-- ></Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A point mutation in the invariant splice donor site is by far the most common (52%), whereas the other six mutations are less frequently observed.</Disease>
<Disease>A large phenotypic variability has been observed, with convulsive disorders, motor retardation and mental retardation being the most abundant manifestations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A clear correlation between the genotype and phenotype has not been established.</Disease>
<Disease>An altered beta-alanine, uracil and thymine homeostasis might underlie the various clinical abnormalities encountered in patients with DPD deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular characterization of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency by natural and amplification created restriction sites: five mutations account for most G6PD deficiency cases in Taiwan.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have developed a rapid and simple method to diagnose the molecular defects of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency in Chinese in Taiwan.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This method involves the selective amplification of a DNA fragment from human G6PD gene with specific oligonucleotide primers followed by digestion with restriction enzymes that recognize artificially created or naturally occurring restriction sites.</Disease>
<Disease>Ninety-four Chinese males with G6PD deficiency were studied.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results show that 50% (47 of 94) were G to T mutation at nucleotide (nt) 1376, 21. 3% (20 of 94) were G to A mutation at nt 1388, 7. 4% (7 of 94) were A to G mutation at nt 493, 7. 4% (7 of 94) were A to G mutation at nt 95, 4. 2% (4 of 94) were C to T mutation at nt 1024, 1. 1% (1 of 94) was G to T mutation at nt 392, and 1. 1% (1 of 94) was G to A mutation at nt 487.</Disease>
<Disease>These results show that the former five mutations account for more than 90% of G6PD deficiency cases in Taiwan.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aside from showing that G to T change at nt 1376 is the most common mutation, our research indicates that nt 493 mutation is a frequent mutation among Chinese in Taiwan.</Disease>
<Disease>We compared G6PD activity among different mutations, without discovering significant differences between them.</Disease>
<Disease>Homozygous hypobetalipoproteinemia: a disease distinct from abetalipoproproteinemia at the molecular level.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>apoB DNA, RNA, and protein from two patients with homozygous hypobetalipoproteinemia (HBL) were evaluated and compared with normal individuals.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Southern blot analysis with 10 different cDNA probes revealed a normal gene without major insertions, deletions, or rearrangements.</Disease>
<Disease>Northern and slot blot analyses of total liver mRNA from HBL patients documented a normal size apoB mRNA that was present in greatly reduced quantities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>ApoB protein was detected within HBL hepatocytes utilizing immunohistochemical techniques; however, it was markedly reduced in quantity when compared with control samples.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No apoB was detectable in the plasma of HBL individuals with an ELISA assay.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These data are most consistent with a mutation in the coding portion of the apoB gene in HBL patients, leading to an abnormal apoB protein and apoB mRNA instability.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results are distinct from those previously noted in abetalipoproteinemia, which was characterized by an elevated level of hepatic apoB mRNA and accumulation of intracellular hepatic apoB protein..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A population-based study of the clinical expression of the hemochromatosis gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND AND METHODS  Hereditary hemochromatosis is associated with homozygosity for the C282Y mutation in the hemochromatosis (HFE) gene on chromosome 6, elevated serum transferrin saturation, and excess iron deposits throughout the body.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To assess the prevalence and clinical expression of the HFE gene, we conducted a population-based study in Busselton, Australia.</Disease>

<Disease>In 1994, we obtained blood samples for the determination of serum transferrin saturation and ferritin levels and the presence or absence of the C282Y mutation and the H63D mutation (which may contribute to increased hepatic iron levels) in 3011 unrelated white adults.</Disease>
<Disease>We evaluated all subjects who had persistently elevated transferrin-saturation values (45 percent or higher) or were homozygous for the C282Y mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>We recommended liver biopsy for subjects with serum ferritin levels of 300 ng per milliliter or higher.</Disease>
<Disease>The subjects were followed for up to four years.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS  Sixteen of the subjects (0. 5 percent) were homozygous for the C282Y mutation, and 424 (14. 1 percent) were heterozygous.</Disease>
<Disease>The serum transferrin saturation was 45 percent or higher in 15 of the 16 who were homozygous; in 1 subject it was 43 percent.</Disease>
<Disease>Four of the homozygous subjects had previously been given a diagnosis of hemochromatosis, and 12 had not.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Seven of these 12 patients had elevated serum ferritin levels in 1994; 6 of the 7 had further increases in 1998, and 1 had a decrease, although the value remained elevated.</Disease>
<Disease>The serum ferritin levels in the four other homozygous patients remained in the normal range.</Disease>

<Disease>Eleven of the 16 homozygous subjects underwent liver biopsy; 3 had hepatic fibrosis, and 1, who had a history of excessive alcohol consumption, had cirrhosis and mild microvesicular steatosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Eight of the 16 homozygous subjects had clinical findings that were consistent with the presence of hereditary hemochromatosis, such as hepatomegaly, skin pigmentation, and arthritis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS  In a population of white adults of northern European ancestry, 0. 5 percent were homozygous for the C282Y mutation in the HFE gene.</Disease>
<Disease>However, only half of those who were homozygous had clinical features of hemochromatosis, and one quarter had serum ferritin levels that remained normal over a four-year period.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Overexpression of DM20 messenger RNA in two brothers with Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is a rare, sex-linked recessive, dysmyelinating disease of the central nervous system that has been associated with mutations in the myelin proteolipid protein (PLP) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Only 25% of patients studied with Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease have exonic mutations in this gene, the underlying cause of the disease in the remaining patients is unknown.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The PLP gene encodes two major alternatively spliced transcripts called PLP and DM20.</Disease>
<Disease>PLP messenger RNA is specifically expressed in central nervous system tissue, whereas DM20 messenger RNA is found in central nervous system, cardiac, and other tissues.</Disease>
<Disease>We studied cultured skin fibroblasts from 2 brothers with Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease who exhibited no detectable exonic mutation of the PLP gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Examination of RNA from these cells showed that the level of DM20 messenger RNA is elevated sixfold relative to male control skin fibroblasts.</Disease>
<Disease>An unrelated female carrier, also with no detectable exonic mutation, showed a threefold increase in DM20 messenger RNA in cultured skin fibroblasts.</Disease>

<Disease>Our findings suggest that in some patients, Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is caused by overexpression of PLP gene transcripts, and that in these families a 50% increase of DM20 messenger RNA in females, relative to the increase in affected males, can identify a female carrier..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Homozygosity for a novel DTDST mutation in a child with a 'broad bone-platyspondylic' variant of diastrophic dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Atypical or variant forms of well-known chondrodysplasias may pose diagnostic problems.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report on a girl with clinical features suggesting diastrophic dysplasia but with unusual radiographic features including severe platyspondyly, wide metaphyses, and fibular overgrowth, which are partially reminiscent of metatropic dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The diagnosis was clarified by molecular analysis of the DTDST gene, which revealed homozygosity for a previously undescribed mutation leading to a Q454P substitution in the 10th transmembrane domain of the DTDST sulfate transporter.</Disease>
<Disease>Molecular analysis may be of particular value in such atypical cases..</Disease>
<Disease>Carrier detection and prenatal diagnosis of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease using a combination of anonymous DNA polymorphisms and the proteolipid protein (PLP) gene cDNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report carrier identification and a prenatal diagnosis using DNA polymorphisms in 2 families with X-linked Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In both families, the proteolipid protein (PLP) gene in the single affected male could be traced back to his unaffected maternal grandfather.</Disease>
<Disease>Therefore, each family contains a new mutation.</Disease>

<Disease>In the case of the prenatal diagnosis, the fetus was shown by cytogenetic analysis to be a female, who we predict will be a noncarrier of PMD based on her genotype with the PLP intragenic polymorphism..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Gardner syndrome in a boy with interstitial deletion of the long arm of chromosome 5.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We described a 15-year-old boy with Gardner syndrome (GS), mental retardation, and craniofacial abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>High-resolution banding analysis showed an interstitial deletion of the long arm of chromosome 5 (q22. 1----q31 1----q31. 1).</Disease>

<Disease>The breakpoints in the present case and in 3 previously reported 5q- patients with adenomatous polyposis coli suggest that the gene responsible for GS/or familial polyposis coli (FPC) is in the 5q22 region, a result consistent with the findings of linkage studies</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Type I human complement C2 deficiency. A 28-base pair gene deletion causes skipping of exon 6 during RNA splicing.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two variants of a genetic deficiency of complement protein C2 (C2D) have been previously identified.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No C2 protein translation is detected in type I deficiency, while type II deficiency is characterized by a selective block in C2 secretion.</Disease>

<Disease>Type I C2 deficiency was described in a family in which the C2 null allele (C2Q0) is associated with the major histocompatibility haplotype/complotype HLA-A25, B18, C2Q0, BfS, C4A4, C4B2, Drw2; this extended haplotype occurs in over 90% of C2-deficient individuals (common complotype/haplotype).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To determine the molecular basis of type I C2 deficiency, the C2 gene and cDNA were characterized from a homozygous type I C2-deficient individual with the common associated haplotype/complotype.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We found a 28-base pair deletion in the type I C2Q0 gene, beginning 9 base pairs upstream of the 3-end of exon 6, that generates a C2 transcript with a complete deletion of exon 6 (134 base pair) and a premature termination codon.</Disease>

<Disease>In studies of eight kindred, the 28-base pair deletion was observed in all C2Q0 alleles associated with the common type I deficient complotype/haplotype; this deletion was not present in normal C2 nor in type II C2-deficient genes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These data demonstrate that  1) type I human complement C2 deficiency is caused by a 28-base pair genomic deletion that causes skipping of exon 6 during RNA splicing, resulting in generation of a premature termination codon, 2) the 28-base pair deletion in the type I C2Q0 gene is strongly associated with the HLA haplotype/complotype A25, B18, C2Q0, BfS, C4A4, C4B2, Drw2, suggesting that all C2-deficient individuals with this haplotype/complotype will harbor the 28-base pair C2 gene deletion, and 3) type II C2 deficiency is caused by a different, as yet uncharacterized, molecular genetic defect..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>(Over)correction of FMR1 deficiency with YAC transgenics: behavioral and physical features.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fragile X syndrome is a common cause of mental retardation involving loss of expression of the FMR1 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The role of FMR1 remains undetermined but the protein appears to be involved in RNA metabolism.</Disease>
<Disease>Fmr1 knockout mice exhibit a phenotype with some similarities to humans, such as macroorchidism and behavioral abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>As a step toward understanding the function of FMR1 and the determination of the potential for therapeutic approaches to fragile X syndrome, yeast artificial chromosome (YAC) transgenic mice were generated in order to determine whether the Fmr1 knockout mouse phenotype could be rescued.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Several transgenic lines were generated that carried the entire FMR1 locus with extensive amounts of flanking sequence.</Disease>

<Disease>We observed that the YAC transgene supported production of the human protein (FMRP) which was present at levels 10 to 15 times that of endogenous protein and was expressed in a cell- and tissue-specific manner.</Disease>
<Disease>Macro-orchidism was absent in knockout mice carrying the YAC transgene indicating functional rescue by the human protein.</Disease>

<Disease>Given the complex behavioral phenotype in fragile X patients and the mild phenotype previously reported for the Fmr1 knockout mouse, we performed a more thorough evaluation of the Fmr1 knockout phenotype using additional behavioral assays that had not previously been reported for this animal model.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mouse displayed reduced anxiety-related responses with increased exploratory behavior.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>FMR1 YAC transgenic mice overexpressing the human protein did produce opposing behavioral responses and additional abnormal behaviors were also observed.</Disease>
<Disease>These findings have significant implications for gene therapy for fragile X syndrome since overexpression of the gene may harbor its own phenotype..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fabry disease: identification of novel alpha-galactosidase A mutations and molecular carrier detection by use of fluorescent chemical cleavage of mismatches.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fabry disease (FD) (angiokeratoma corporis diffusum) is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism caused by defects in the lysosomal alpha-galactosidase A gene (GLA).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The enzymatic defect leads to the systemic accumulation of neutral glycosphingolipids with terminal alpha-galactosyl moieties.</Disease>
<Disease>Clinically, affected hemizygous males have angiokeratoma, severe acroparesthesia, renal failure, and vasculopathy of the heart and brain.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>While demonstration of alpha-galactosidase deficiency in leukocytes is diagnostic in affected males, enzymatic detection of female carriers is often inconclusive, due to random X-chromosomal inactivation, underlining the need of molecular investigations for accurate genetic counseling.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>By use of chemical cleavage of mismatches adapted to fluorescence-based detection systems, we have characterized the mutations underlying alpha-Gal A deficiency in 16 individuals from six unrelated families with FD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mutational spectrum included five missense mutations (C202W, C223G, N224D, R301Q, and Q327K) and one splice-site mutation [IVS3 G (-1) -- > C].</Disease>

<Disease>Studies at the mRNA level showed that the latter led to altered pre-mRNA splicing with consequent alteration of the mRNA translational reading frame and generation of a premature termination codon of translation.</Disease>
<Disease>By use of this strategy, carrier status was accurately assessed in all seven at-risk females tested, whereas enzymatic dosages failed to diagnose or exclude heterozygosity..</Disease>
<Disease>Evidence for linkage of bipolar disorder to chromosome 18 with a parent-of-origin effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A susceptibility gene on chromosome 18 and a parent-of-origin effect have been suggested for bipolar affective disorder (BPAD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have studied 28 nuclear families selected for apparent unilineal transmission of the BPAD phenotype, by using 31 polymorphic markers spanning chromosome 18.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Evidence for linkage was tested with affected-sib-pair and LOD score methods under two definitions of the affected phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>The affected-sibpair analyses indicated excess allele sharing for markers on 18p within the region reported previously.</Disease>
<Disease>The greatest sharing was at D18S37  64% in bipolar and recurrent unipolar (RUP) sib pairs (P =. 0006).</Disease>

<Disease>In addition, excess sharing of the paternally, but not maternally, transmitted alleles was observed at three markers on 18q  at D18S41, 51 bipolar and RUP sib pairs were concordant for paternally transmitted alleles, and 21 pairs were discordant (P = 0004).</Disease>
<Disease>The evidence for linkage to loci on both 18p and 18q was strongest in the 11 paternal pedigrees, i. e e., those in which the father or one of the fathers sibs is affected.</Disease>
<Disease>In these pedigrees, the greatest allele sharing (81%; P =. 00002) and the highest LOD score (3. 51; phi = 0. 0) were observed at D18S41.</Disease>
<Disease>Our results provide further support for linkage of BPAD to chromosome 18 and the first molecular evidence for a parent-of-origin effect operating in this disorder.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The number of loci involved, and their precise location, require further study</Disease>
<Disease>BRCA1 mutations in a population-based sample of young women with breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND.</Disease>
<Disease>Inherited mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer in some families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, little is known about the contribution of BRCA1 mutations to breast cancer in the general population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We analyzed DNA samples from women enrolled in a population-based study of early-onset breast cancer to assess the spectrum and frequency of germ-line BRCA1 mutations in young women with breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS.</Disease>
<Disease>We studied 80 women in whom breast cancer was diagnosed before the age of 35, and who were not selected on the basis of family history.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Genomic DNA was studied for BRCA1 mutations by analysis involving single-strand conformation polymorphisms and with allele-specific assays.</Disease>
<Disease>Alterations were defined by DNA sequencing.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS.</Disease>
<Disease>Germ-line BRCA1 mutations were identified in 6 of the 80 women.</Disease>
<Disease>Four additional rare sequence variants of unknown functional importance were also identified.</Disease>
<Disease>Two of the mutations and three of the rare sequence variants were found among the 39 women who reported no family history of breast or ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>None of the mutations and only one of the rare variants was identified in a reference population of 73 unrelated subjects.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS.</Disease>
<Disease>Alterations in BRCA1 were identified in approximately 10 percent of this cohort of young women with breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The risk of harboring a mutation was not limited to women with family histories of breast or ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results represent a minimal estimate of the frequency of BRCA1 mutations in this population.</Disease>
<Disease>Comprehensive methods of identifying BRCA1 mutations and understanding their importance will be needed before testing of women in the general population can be undertaken..</Disease>
<Disease>Retinoschisin, the X-linked retinoschisis protein, is a secreted photoreceptor protein, and is expressed and released by Weri-Rb1 cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>X-linked retinoschisis is characterized by microcystic-like changes of the macular region and schisis within the inner retinal layers, leading to visual deterioration in males.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Many missense and protein-truncating mutations of the causative gene RS1 have now been identified and are thought to be inactivating.</Disease>
<Disease>RS1 encodes a 224 amino acid protein, retinoschisin, which contains a discoidin domain but is of unknown function.</Disease>

<Disease>We have generated a polyclonal antibody against a peptide from a unique region within retinoschisin, which detects a protein of approximately 28 kDa in retinal samples reduced with dithiothreitol, but multimers sized > 40 kDa under non-reducing conditions.</Disease>
<Disease>A screen of human tissues with this antibody reveals retinoschisin to be retina specific and the antibody detects a protein of similar size in bovine and murine retinae.</Disease>
<Disease>We investigated the expression pattern in the retina of both RS1 mRNA (using in situ hybridization with riboprobes) and retinoschisin (using immunohistochemistry).</Disease>

<Disease>The antisense riboprobe detected RS1 mRNA only in the photoreceptor layer but the protein product of the gene was present both in the photoreceptors and within the inner portions of the retina.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, differentiated retinoblastoma cells (Weri-Rb1 cells) were found to express RS1 mRNA and to release retinoschisin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggest that retinoschisin is released by photo-receptors and has functions within the inner retinal layers.</Disease>

<Disease>Thus, X-linked retinoschisis is caused by abnormalities in a putative secreted photoreceptor protein and is the first example of a secreted photo-receptor protein associated with a retinal dystrophy..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Aberrant splicing of the CHM gene is a significant cause of choroideremia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Choroideremia (CHM) is an X-linked progressive degeneration of the choroid and retina.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>12% of unrelated male patients carry deletions of the partially cloned CHM gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In Finland, there are more than 120 living CHM patients belonging to eight apparently unrelated pedigrees.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular deletions involving the CHM gene have been detected in three families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have screened the remaining five families for point mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>In one large family a single nucleotide (T) insertion into the donor splice site of exon C leads to two aberrantly spliced mRNAs both producing a premature stop codon.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutation can be assayed easily by amplification and digestion with Msel.</Disease>
<Disease>Our findings provide additional evidence for the pathogenetic role of CHM mutations and provide a diagnostic tool for one fifth of the worlds known CHM patients..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD): a novel mutation of the ALD gene in 6 members of a family presenting with 5 different phenotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Fragments of the adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) cDNA from a patient with adolescent ALD were amplified by polymerase chain reaction and subcloned.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Bidirectional sequencing of the entire coding ALD gene disclosed a cytosine to guanine transversion at nucleotide 1451 in exon five, resulting in substitution of proline 484 by arginine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Five of nine siblings of the patient, comprising two cerebral ALD, one adrenomyeloneuropathy, one Addison only as well as the symptomatic mother (all accumulating very long chain fatty acids) carried this mutation, which was not found in the unaffected persons, in five unrelated ALD patients, and in twenty controls.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We propose that this missense mutation generated the disease per se as well as the metabolic defect; the different phenotypes, however, must have originated by means of additional pathogenetic factors..</Disease>
<Disease>Statistical analysis of the two stage mutation model in von Hippel-Lindau disease, and in sporadic cerebellar haemangioblastoma and renal cell carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Analysis of the age incidence curves for unilateral and bilateral retinoblastoma led Knudson to propose that hereditary tumours may arise by a single event and sporadic tumours by a two stage mutation process.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It has been suggested recently that sporadic renal cell carcinoma may arise from a two stage mutation process.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We analysed the age incidence curves for symptomatic renal cell carcinoma (n = 26) and cerebellar haemangioblastoma (n = 68) in 109 patients with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, and compared them to 104 patients with sporadic renal cell carcinoma and 43 patients with sporadic cerebellar haemangioblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The age incidence curves for renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar haemangioblastoma in VHL disease were compatible with a single mutation model, whereas the age incidence curves for sporadic renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar haemangioblastoma suggested a two stage mutation process.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These data are compatible with the VHL gene functioning as a recessive tumour suppressor gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Sporadic cerebellar haemangioblastoma and some renal cell carcinoma may arise from somatic mutations inactivating both alleles at the VHL locus..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Characterization of a germline mosaicism in families with Lowe syndrome, and identification of seven novel mutations in the OCRL1 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The oculocerebrorenal syndrome of Lowe (OCRL) is an X-linked disorder characterized by major abnormalities of eyes, nervous system, and kidneys.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the OCRL1 gene have been associated with the disease.</Disease>
<Disease>OCRL1 encodes a phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-biphosphate (PtdIns [4, 5] P2) 5-phosphatase.</Disease>
<Disease>We have examined the OCRL1 gene in eight unrelated patients with OCRL and have found seven new mutations and one recurrent in-frame deletion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Among the new mutations, two nonsense mutations (R317X and E558X) and three other frameshift mutations caused premature termination of the protein.</Disease>
<Disease>A missense mutation, R483G, was located in the highly conserved PtdIns (4, 5) P2 5-phosphatase domain.</Disease>
<Disease>Finally, one frameshift mutation, 2799delC, modifies the C-terminal part of OCRL1, with an extension of six amino acids.</Disease>
<Disease>Altogether, 70% of missense mutations are located in exon 15, and 52% of all mutations cluster in exons 11-15.</Disease>
<Disease>We also identified two new microsatellite markers for the OCRL1 locus, and we detected a germline mosaicism in one family.</Disease>
<Disease>This observation has direct implications for genetic counseling of Lowe syndrome families..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aminoglycoside antibiotics restore dystrophin function to skeletal muscles of mdx mice.</Disease>
<Disease>Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, leading to the absence of the dystrophin protein in striated muscle.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A significant number of these mutations are premature stop codons.</Disease>

<Disease>On the basis of the observation that aminoglycoside treatment can suppress stop codons in cultured cells, we tested the effect of gentamicin on cultured muscle cells from the mdx mouse - an animal model for DMD that possesses a premature stop codon in the dystrophin gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Exposure of mdx myotubes to gentamicin led to the expression and localization of dystrophin to the cell membrane.</Disease>
<Disease>We then evaluated the effects of differing dosages of gentamicin on expression and functional protection of the muscles of mdx mice.</Disease>

<Disease>We identified a treatment regimen that resulted in the presence of dystrophin in the cell membrane in all striated muscles examined and that provided functional protection against muscular injury.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To our knowledge, our results are the first to demonstrate that aminoglycosides can suppress stop codons not only in vitro but also in vivo.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, these results raise the possibility of a novel treatment regimen for muscular dystrophy and other diseases caused by premature stop codon mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This treatment could prove effective in up to 15% of patients with DMD..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular and metabolic basis for the metabolic disorder normotriglyceridemic abetalipoproteinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have previously described a disorder, normotriglyceridemic abetalipoproteinemia, that is characterized by the virtual absence of plasma low density lipoproteins and complete absence of apoB-100, but with apparently normal secretion of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins containing apoB-48.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The patients plasma lipoproteins were shown on polyacrylamide gels and by antibody mapping to have a new truncated apoB variant, apoB-50, circulating along with her apoB-48.</Disease>
<Disease>We have found this individual to be homozygous for a single C-to-T nucleotide substitution at apoB codon 2252, which produces a premature in-frame stop codon.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, this is a rare example of homozygous hypobetalipoproteinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Electron photomicrographs revealed that the diameters of particles in the d less than 1. 006</Disease>
<Disease>g/ml lipoprotein fraction, in both the postprandial and postabsorptive state, are bimodally distributed.</Disease>
<Disease>The molar ratio of apoE to apoB in these particles is 3. 5  1, similar to normal VLDL.</Disease>
<Disease>The plasma LDL interval contains both spherical and cuboidal particles.</Disease>

<Disease>Autologous reinfusion of labeled d less than 1. 006 g/ml lipoproteins showed exponential disappearance from plasma, with an apparent half-removal time of 50 min, somewhat slower than for normal chylomicrons but within the normal range for VLDL.</Disease>
<Disease>The calculated production rate for apoB was within the normal range in this subject.</Disease>
<Disease>von Willebrand disease type B: a missense mutation selectively abolishes ristocetin-induced von Willebrand factor binding to platelet glycoprotein Ib.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>von Willebrand factor (vWF) is a multimeric glycoprotein that mediates the adhesion of platelets to the subendothelium by binding to platelet glycoprotein Ib.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>For human vWF, this interaction can be induced in vitro by the antibiotic ristocetin or the snake venom protein botrocetin.</Disease>

<Disease>A missense mutation, Gly-561-- > Ser, was identified within the proposed glycoprotein Ib binding domain of vWF in the proband with von Willebrand disease type B, a unique variant characterized by no ristocetin-induced, but normal botrocetin-induced, binding to glycoprotein Ib.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The corresponding mutant recombinant protein, rvWF (G561S), formed normal multimers and exhibited the same functional defect as the patients plasma vWF, confirming that this mutation causes von Willebrand disease type B. These data show that botrocetin and ristocetin cofactor activities of vWF can be dissociated by a point mutation and confirm that these mediators promote vWF binding to platelets by different mechanisms.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The normal botrocetin-induced binding and the defective ristocetin-induced binding of rvWF (G561S) suggest that the primary defect in von Willebrand disease type B may be a failure of normal allosteric regulation of the glycoprotein Ib binding function of vWF..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A high incidence of BRCA1 mutations in 20 breast-ovarian cancer families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have analyzed 20 breast-ovarian cancer families, the majority of which show positive evidence of linkage to chromosome 17q12 for germ-line mutations in the BRCA1 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BRCA1 mutations cosegregating with breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility were identified in 16 families, including 1 family with a case of male breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nine of these mutations have not been reported previously.</Disease>
<Disease>The majority of mutations were found to generate a premature stop codon leading to the formation of a truncated BRCA1 protein of 2% -88% of the expected normal length.</Disease>
<Disease>Two mutations altered the RING finger domain.</Disease>

<Disease>Sequencing of genomic DNA led to the identification of a mutation in the coding region of BRCA1 in 12 families, and cDNA analysis revealed an abnormal or missing BRCA1 transcript in 4 of the 8 remaining families.</Disease>
<Disease>A total of eight mutations were associated with a reduced quantity of BRCA1 transcript.</Disease>
<Disease>We were unable to detect BRCA1 mutations in 4 of the 20 families, but only 1 of these was clearly linked to BRCA1.</Disease>
<Disease>It is expected that the majority of clear examples of the breast-ovarian syndrome will be associated with germ-line mutations in the coding region of BRCA1..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Assignment of the human Na+/glucose cotransporter gene SGLT1 to chromosome 22q13.1.</Disease>
<Disease>The Na +/glucose cotransporter gene SGLT1 encodes the primary carrier protein responsible for the uptake of the dietary sugars glucose and galactose from the intestinal lumen.</Disease>
<Disease>SGLT1 transport activity is currently exploited in oral rehydration therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>The 75-kDa glycoprotein is localized in the brush border of the intestinal epithelium and is predicted to comprise 12 membrane spans.</Disease>

<Disease>In two patients with the autosomal recessive disease glucose/galactose malabsorption, the underlying cause was found to be a missense mutation in SGLT1, and the Asp28-- > Asn change was demonstrated in vitro to eliminate SGLT1 transport activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The SGLT1 gene was previously shown to reside on the distal q arm of chromosome 22 (11. 2-- > qter).</Disease>
<Disease>We have used a cosmid probe for fluorescence in situ hybridization, which refines the localization to 22q13.</Disease>
<Disease>1, and provide an example of the utility of the SGLT1 probe as a diagnostic for genetic diseases associated with translocations of chromosome 22.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A pseudodeficiency allele common in non-Jewish Tay-Sachs carriers: implications for carrier screening.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Deficiency of beta-hexosaminidase A (Hex A) activity typically results in Tay-Sachs disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, healthy subjects found to be deficient in Hex A activity (i. e., pseudodeficient) by means of in vitro biochemical tests have been described.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We analyzed the HEXA gene of one pseudodeficient subject and identified both a C739-to-T substitution that changes Arg247----Trp on one allele and a previously identified Tay-Sachs disease mutation on the second allele.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Six additional pseudodeficient subjects were found to have the C739-to-T mutation.</Disease>

<Disease>This allele accounted for 32% (20/62) of non-Jewish enzyme-defined Tay-Sachs disease carriers but for none of 36 Jewish enzyme-defined carriers who did not have one of three known mutations common to this group.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The C739-to-T allele, together with a " true " Tay-Sachs disease allele, causes Hex A pseudodeficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Given both the large proportion of non-Jewish carriers with this allele and that standard biochemical screening cannot differentiate between heterozygotes for the C739-to-T mutations and Tay-Sachs disease carriers, DNA testing for this mutation in at-risk couples is essential.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The presence of two different infantile Tay-Sachs disease mutations in a Cajun population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A study was undertaken to characterize the mutation (s) responsible for Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) in a Cajun population in southwest Louisiana and to identify the origins of these mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Eleven of 12 infantile TSD alleles examined in six families had the beta-hexosaminidase A (Hex A) alpha-subunit exon 11 insertion mutation that is present in approximately 70% of Ashkenazi Jewish TSD heterozygotes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation in the remaining allele was a single-base transition in the donor splice site of the alpha-subunit intron 9.</Disease>

<Disease>To determine the origins of these two mutations in the Cajun population, the TSD carrier status was enzymatically determined for 90 members of four of the six families, and extensive pedigrees were constructed for all carriers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A single ancestral couple from France was found to be common to most of the carriers of the exon 11 insertion.</Disease>
<Disease>Pedigree data suggest that this mutation has been in the Cajun population since its founding over 2 centuries ago and that it may be widely distributed within the population.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, the intron 9 mutation apparently was introduced within the last century and probably is limited to a few Louisiana families..</Disease>
<Disease>Canavan disease: genomic organization and localization of human ASPA to 17p13-ter and conservation of the ASPA gene during evolution.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Canavan disease, or spongy degeneration of the brain, is a severe leukodystrophy caused by the deficiency of aspartoacylase (ASPA).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, a missense mutation was identified in human ASPA coding sequence from patients with Canavan disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The human ASPA gene has been cloned and found to span 29 kb of the genome.</Disease>
<Disease>Human aspartoacylase is coded by six exons intervened by five introns.</Disease>
<Disease>The exons vary from 94 (exon III) to 514 (exon VI) bases.</Disease>
<Disease>The exon/intron splice junction sites follow the gt/ag consensus sequence rule.</Disease>
<Disease>Southern blot analysis of genomic DNA from human/mouse somatic cell hybrid cell lines localized ASPA to human chromosome 17.</Disease>
<Disease>The human ASPA locus was further mapped in the 17p13-ter region by fluorescence in situ hybridization.</Disease>
<Disease>The bovine aspa gene has also been cloned, and its exon/intron organization is identical to that of the human gene.</Disease>
<Disease>The 500-base sequence upstream of the initiator ATG codon in the human gene and that in the bovine gene are 77% identical.</Disease>
<Disease>Human ASPA coding sequences cross-hybridize with genomic DNA from yeast, chicken, rabbit, cow, dog, mouse, rat, and monkey.</Disease>
<Disease>The specificity of cross-species hybridization of coding sequences suggests that aspartoacylase has been conserved during evolution.</Disease>
<Disease>It should now be possible to identify mutations in the noncoding genomic sequences that lead to Canavan disease and to study the regulation of ASPA..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Adrenoleukodystrophy: survey of 303 cases: biochemistry, diagnosis, and therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) is a genetically determined disorder associated with progressive central demyelination and adrenal cortical insufficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All affected persons show increased levels of saturated unbranched very-long-chain fatty acids, particularly hexacosanoate (C26  0), because of impaired capacity to degrade these acids.</Disease>

<Disease>French Machado-Joseph disease patients do not exhibit gametic segregation distortion: a sperm typing analysis.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Segregation distortion has been reported to occur in a number of the trinucleotide repeat disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>On the basis of a sperm typing study performed in patients of Japanese descent with Machado-Joseph disease (MJD), it was reported that disease alleles are preferentially transmitted during meiosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We performed a sperm typing study of five MJD patients of French descent and analysis of the pooled data shows a ratio of mutant to normal alleles of 379  436 (46. 5  53. 5%), which does not support meiotic segregation distortion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To confirm these results, sperm typing analysis was also performed using a polymorphic marker, D14S1050, closely linked to the MJD1 gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Among 910 sperm analyzed, the allele linked to the disease chromosome was detected in 50.</Disease>
<Disease>3% of the samples and the allele linked to the normal chromosome was found in 49.</Disease>
<Disease>6% of the sperm.</Disease>
<Disease>The difference in frequency of these two alleles is not significant (P = 0. 8423).</Disease>

<Disease>Likelihood-based analysis of segregation distortion in the single sperm data using the SPERMSEG program also showed no support for segregation distortion at the gamete level in this patient population.</Disease>

<Disease>The previous report on the Japanese patients also suggested that disease allele stability may be influenced by a trans effect of an intragenic polymorphism (987 G/C) in the wild-type allele.</Disease>
<Disease>All of the French patients were heterozygous for this polymorphism.</Disease>

<Disease>However, analysis of the variance in repeat number in sperm from the French MJD patients overlapped significantly with the variance in repeat number observed in the C/C homozygous Japanese patients.</Disease>

text: <Disease>To determine the prevalence of heterozygous carriers of the Arg95Stop mutation in a Japanese population, we collected DNA samples from 300 individuals in two of the four main islands of Japan.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Molecular analysis of a female Lesch-Nyhan patient.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report the identification of a female patient with the X-linked recessive Lesch-Nyhan syndrome (hypoxanthine phosphoribosyltransferase [HPRT] deficiency).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cytogenetic and carrier studies revealed structurally normal chromosomes for this patient and her parents and demonstrated that this mutation arose through a de novo gametic event.</Disease>

<Disease>Comparison of this patients DNA with the DNA of her parents revealed that a microdeletion, which occurred within a maternal gamete and involved the entire HPRT gene, was partially responsible for the disease in this patient.</Disease>

<Disease>Somatic cell hybrids, generated to separate maternal and paternal X chromosomes, showed that expression of two additional X-linked enzymes, phosphoglycerate kinase and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, were expressed only in cells that contained the maternal X chromosome, suggesting the presence of a functionally inactive paternal X chromosome.</Disease>

<Disease>Furthermore, comparison of methylation patterns within a region of the HPRT gene known to be important in gene regulation revealed differences between DNA from the father and the patient, in keeping with an active HPRT locus in the father and an inactive HPRT locus in the patient.</Disease>

<Disease>Together these data indicate that nonrandom inactivation of the cytogenetically normal paternal X chromosome and a microdeletion of the HPRT gene on an active maternal X chromosome were responsible for the absence of HPRT in this patient..</Disease>
<Disease>Changes at P183 of emerin weaken its protein-protein interactions resulting in X-linked Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EDMD) is an X-linked recessive muscular dystrophy characterized by early contractures of the elbows, Achilles tendons and spine, slowly progressive muscle wasting and weakness, and cardiomyopathy associated with cardiac conduction defects.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>The emerin gene has been mapped to Xq28 and encodes a 34-kDa serine-rich protein, emerin, which has been localized to the nuclear envelope in a wide variety of tissues, including skeletal and cardiac muscle.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations spanning the emerin gene have been identified in patients with EDMD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We present here the effect, on emerin protein expression, of two missense mutations identified in unrelated EDMD patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These alterations predict the replacement of a proline residue at position 183 with either a histidine or a threonine.</Disease>

<Disease>Biochemical analysis has demonstrated that the mobility and expression levels of the mutant forms of emerin are indistinguishable from that of wild-type emerin, but that they have weakened interactions with nuclear lamina components.</Disease>

<Disease>In comparison with the usual EDMD phenotype, patients with P183 missense mutations have a later age at onset of first symptoms, elbow contractures, ankle contractures, upper limb weakness and lower limb weakness, but there is no difference for the age at onset of cardiac involvement.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This is the first report of protein studies on patients with missense mutations resulting in the clinical features of EDMD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These studies demonstrate the importance of proline 183 for the proper structure/function of emerin..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Our findings revealed the following characteristics of the germ-line mutations of APC  1) the great majority of the mutations were found to truncate the APC product; 2) almost all of the mutations were located within the first half of the coding region; 3) no correlation was observed between the locations of germ-line mutations and extracolonic manifestations in FAP patients; 4) more than 80% of base substitutions in the APC gene were from cytosine to other nucleotides, nearly one-third of which occurred at the GpG site.</Disease>

text: <Disease>hCds1-mediated phosphorylation of BRCA1 regulates the DNA damage response.</Disease>

<Disease>Mutations in the BRCA1 (ref. 1) tumour suppressor gene are found in almost all of the families with inherited breast and ovarian cancers and about half of the families with only breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although the biochemical function of BRCA1 is not well understood, it is important for DNA damage repair and cell-cycle checkpoint.</Disease>
<Disease>BRCA1 exists in nuclear foci but is hyperphosphorylated and disperses after DNA damage.</Disease>
<Disease>It is not known whether BRCA1 phosphorylation and dispersion and its function in DNA damage response are related.</Disease>
<Disease>In yeast the DNA damage response and the replication-block checkpoint are mediated partly through the Cds1 kinase family.</Disease>
<Disease>Here we report that the human Cds1 kinase (hCds1/Chk2) regulates BRCA1 function after DNA damage by phosphorylating serine 988 of BRCA1.</Disease>
<Disease>We show that hCds1 and BRCA1 interact and co-localize within discrete nuclear foci but separate after gamma irradiation.</Disease>
<Disease>Phosphorylation of BRCA1 at serine 988 is required for the release of BRCA1 from hCds1.</Disease>
<Disease>This phosphorylation is also important for the ability of BRCA1 to restore survival after DNA damage in the BRCA1-mutated cell line HCC1937..</Disease>
<Disease>Ataxin-3 with an altered conformation that exposes the polyglutamine domain is associated with the nuclear matrix.</Disease>
<Disease>Spinocerebellar ataxia type-3 or Machado-Joseph disease (SCA3/MJD) is a member of the CAG/polyglutamine repeat disease family.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this family of disorders, a normally polymorphic CAG repeat becomes expanded, resulting in expression of an expanded polyglutamine domain in the disease gene product.</Disease>

<Disease>Experimental models of polyglutamine disease implicate the nucleus in pathogenesis; however, the link between intranuclear expression of expanded polyglutamine and neuronal dysfunction remains unclear.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here we demonstrate that ataxin-3, the disease protein in SCA3/MJD, adopts a unique conformation when expressed within the nucleus of transfected cells.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The monoclonal antibody 1C2 is known preferentially to bind expanded polyglutamine, but we find that it also binds a fragment of ataxin-3 containing a normal glutamine repeat.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, expression of ataxin-3 within the nucleus exposes the glutamine domain of the full-length non-pathological protein, allowing it to bind the monoclonal antibody 1C2.</Disease>

<Disease>Fractionation and immunochemical experiments indicate that this novel conformation of intranuclear ataxin-3 is not due to proteolysis, suggesting instead that association with nuclear protein (s) alters the structure of full-length ataxin-3 which exposes the polyglutamine domain.</Disease>
<Disease>This conformationally altered ataxin-3 is bound to the nuclear matrix.</Disease>
<Disease>The pathological form of ataxin-3 with an expanded polyglutamine domain also associates with the nuclear matrix.</Disease>
<Disease>These data suggest that an early event in the pathogenesis of SCA3/MJD may be an altered conformation of ataxin-3 within the nucleus that exposes the polyglutamine domain..</Disease>

<Disease>Subjects were from multiple geographic regions within Spain, and all suffered from hemolytic anemia, either acute (34 cases) or chronic nonspherocytic (2 cases).</Disease>

text: <Disease>Almost all the variants studied presented residual erythrocyte G6PD activity ranging from 0 to 10% of normal, and five different mutants were responsible for the deficient phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>Three variants were similar to others previously described  G6PD Mediterranean (11 cases), G6PD Athens-like (3 cases), and G6PD Union (2 cases).</Disease>
<Disease>The remaining variants were different from the numerous variants already reported and have been considered as new mutants.</Disease>
<Disease>Provisionally they are called G6PD Betica (19 cases) and G6PD Menorca (1 case).</Disease>

<Disease>The present study constitutes the first attempt to characterize the deficient G6PD variants found in Spain and supplies new data on the relationship between molecular characteristics of deficient variants and their clinical manifestations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The most important findings can be summarized as follows  (1) The Spanish population is characterized by an important heterogeneity in G6PD deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>(2) Although G6PD Mediterranean is very frequent, it presents a relatively high degree of polymorphism.</Disease>
<Disease>(3) Favism has been observed associated with all kinds of variants described here.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>(4) G6PD Betica, which is the most frequent variant found in subjects of Southern Spanish origin, has been observed associated with favism in all cases except one.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Early onset of X-linked Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy in a boy with emerin gene deletion.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Muscle computed tomography scanning revealed changes characteristic of muscle involvement.</Disease>
<Disease>Emerin was not detected in the biopsied muscle, and RT-PCR and PCR-based genomic DNA analyses of the emerin gene demonstrated no amplification product in the patient.</Disease>

<Disease>These results confirmed the diagnosis of X-linked Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EDMD), and reinforce the necessity of molecular genetic diagnosis of the membrane protein emerin in younger patients with possible EDMD before appearance of the typical symptoms, to avoid sudden cardiac death..</Disease>

text: <Disease>PRAD1, a candidate BCL1 oncogene: mapping and expression in centrocytic lymphoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Rearrangement of the BCL1 (B-cell lymphoma 1) region on chromosome 11q13 appears to be highly characteristic of centrocytic lymphoma and also is found infrequently in other B-cell neoplasms.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Rearrangement is thought to deregulate a nearby protooncogene, but transcribed sequences in the immediate vicinity of BCL1 breakpoints had not been identified.</Disease>

<Disease>PRAD1, previously designated D11S287E, was identified on 11q13 as a chromosomal breakpoint region rearranged with the parathyroid hormone gene in a subset of parathyroid adenomas; this highly conserved putative oncogene, which encodes a novel cyclin, has been linked to BCL1 and implicated also in subsets of breast and squamous cell neoplasms with 11q13 amplification.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report pulsed-field gel electrophoresis data showing BCL1 and PRAD1 to be no more than 130 kilobases apart.</Disease>
<Disease>PRAD1 mRNA is abundantly expressed in seven of seven centrocytic lymphomas (Kiel classification), in contrast to 13 closely related but noncentrocytic lymphomas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Three of the seven centrocytic lymphomas had detectable BCL1 DNA rearrangement.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Also, two unusual cases of CLL with BCL1 rearrangement overexpressed PRAD1, in contrast to five CLL controls.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, PRAD1 is an excellent candidate " BCL1 oncogene. "</Disease>
<Disease>Its overexpression may be a key consequence of rearrangement of the BCL1 vicinity in B-cell neoplasms and a unifying pathogenetic feature in centrocytic lymphoma.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD; EC 1. 1. 1. 49) -deficient red blood cells from male hemizygotes and female heterozygotes from the island of Sardinia were studied for their ability to support growth in vitro of the malaria-causing organism Plasmodium falciparum.</Disease>

<Disease>Association of BRCA1 with the hRad50-hMre11-p95 complex and the DNA damage response.</Disease>
