label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here, it is shown that BRCA1 interacts in vitro and in vivo with hRad50, which forms a complex with hMre11 and p95/nibrin.</Disease>
<Disease>Upon irradiation, BRCA1 was detected in discrete foci in the nucleus, which colocalize with hRad50.</Disease>

<Disease>Formation of irradiation-induced foci positive for BRCA1, hRad50, hMre11, or p95 was dramatically reduced in HCC/1937 breast cancer cells carrying a homozygous mutation in BRCA1 but was restored by transfection of wild-type BRCA1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Ectopic expression of wild-type, but not mutated, BRCA1 in these cells rendered them less sensitive to the DNA damage agent, methyl methanesulfonate.</Disease>

<Disease>Nebulin and titin expression in Duchenne muscular dystrophy appears normal.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy kinase is a component of neuromuscular junctions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The clinical manifestation of myotonic dystrophy (DM) is correlated to the extent of expansion of an unstable [CTG] n DNA motif.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recent studies have demonstrated that this trinucleotide motif forms part of the last, 3 untranslated exon of a gene which potentially encodes multiple protein isoforms of a serine/threonine protein kinase (myotonic dystrophy protein kinase, DM-PK).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report here on the development of antisera against synthetic DM-PK peptide antigens and their use in biochemical and histochemical studies.</Disease>
<Disease>Immunoreactive DM-kinase protein of 53 kD is present at low levels in skeletal and cardiac muscle extracts of DM patients and normal controls.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Immunohistochemical staining revealed that DM-PK is localised prominently at sites of neuromuscular and myotendinous junctions (NMJs and MTJs) of human and rodent skeletal muscles.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, very low levels of immunoreactive DM-PK protein are present in the sarcoplasm of predominantly type I fibres in various muscles.</Disease>
<Disease>Strikingly, presence of the protein can also be demonstrated for NMJs of muscular tissues of adult and congenital cases of DM, with no gross changes in structural organisation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our findings provide a basis for further characterisation of the role of the kinase in protein assembly processes or signal mediation at synaptic sites and ultimately for the understanding of the complex pathophysiology of DM..</Disease>

text: <Disease>ATM-heterozygous germline mutations contribute to breast cancer-susceptibility.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Approximately 0.</Disease>
<Disease>5% -1% of the general population has been estimated to be heterozygous for a germline mutation in the ATM gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations in the ATM gene are responsible for the autosomal recessive disorder ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T) (MIM 208900).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The finding that ATM-heterozygotes have an increased relative risk for breast cancer was supported by some studies but not confirmed by others.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In view of this discrepancy, we examined the frequency of ATM germline mutations in a selected group of Dutch patients with breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have analyzed ATM germline mutations in normal blood lymphocytes, using the protein-truncation test followed by genomic-sequence analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>A high percentage of ATM germline mutations was demonstrated among patients with sporadic breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The 82 patients included in this study had developed breast cancer at age < 45 and had survived >/= 5 years (mean 15 years), and in 33 (40%) of the patients a contralateral breast tumor had been diagnosed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Among these patients we identified seven (8. 5%) ATM germline mutations, of which five are distinct.</Disease>
<Disease>One splice-site mutation (IVS10-6T-- > G) was detected three times in our series.</Disease>
<Disease>Four heterozygous carriers were patients with bilateral breast cancer.</Disease>

<Disease>Our results indicate that the mutations identified in this study are " A-T disease-causing " mutations that might be associated with an increased risk of breast cancer in heterozygotes.</Disease>

<Disease>We conclude that ATM heterozygotes have an approximately ninefold-increased risk of developing a type of breast cancer characterized by frequent bilateral occurrence, early age at onset, and long-term survival.</Disease>
<Disease>The specific characteristics of our population of patients may explain why such a high frequency was not found in other series.</Disease>
<Disease>Autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) in a child from consanguineous parents: a dominant or recessive disease?</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) is characterized by autoimmune features and lymphoproliferations and is generally caused by defective Fas-mediated apoptosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This report describes a child with clinical features of ALPS without detectable Fas expression on freshly isolated blood leukocytes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Detection of FAS transcripts via real-time quantitative PCR made a severe transcriptional defect unlikely.</Disease>
<Disease>Sequencing of the FAS gene revealed a 20-nucleotide duplication in the last exon affecting the cytoplasmic signaling domain.</Disease>
<Disease>The patient was homozygous for this mutation, whereas the consanguineous parents and the siblings were heterozygous.</Disease>

<Disease>The patient reported here is a human homologue of the Fas-null mouse, inasmuch as she carries an autosomal homozygous mutation in the FAS gene and she shows the severe and accelerated ALPS phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The heterozygous family members did not have the ALPS phenotype, indicating that the disease-causing FAS mutation in this family is autosomal recessive..</Disease>

text: <Disease>A prevalent mutation for galactosemia among black Americans.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE  To define the mutation causing galactosemia in patients of black American origin who have no galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) activity in erythrocytes but good clinical outcome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  </Disease>
<Disease>We discovered a mutation caused by a C-- > T transition at base-pair 1158 of the GALT gene that results in a serine-to-leucine substitution at codon 135 (S135L).</Disease>
<Disease>We developed a method with which to screen populations for its prevalence.</Disease>

<Disease>We compared galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase among erythrocytes, leukocytes, and transformed lymphoblasts, as well as total body oxidation of D- (13C) -galactose to 13CO2 among three genotypes for GALT (S135L/S135L, Q188R/Q188R, and Normal/Normal).</Disease>

<Disease>RESULTS  We found a 48% prevalence of the S135L mutation among 17 black American patients with classic galactosemia and a 1% prevalence in a population of 50 black Americans without galactosemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The S135L mutation was not found in 84 white patients with G/G galactosemia nor in 87 white control subjects without galactosemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We found normal whole body oxidation of D- (13C) -galactose by the patient homozygous for S135L and various degrees of enzyme impairment among different tissues.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS  The S135L mutation in the GALT gene is a prevalent cause of galactosemia among black patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Because GALT activity varies in different tissues of patients homozygous for S135L, they may have a better clinical outcome than patients who are homozygous for Q188R when both are treated from infancy..</Disease>
<Disease>Constitutive and regulated modes of splicing produce six major myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) isoforms with distinct properties.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is the most prevalent inherited neuromuscular disease in adults.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The genetic defect is a CTG triplet repeat expansion in the 3-untranslated region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene, consisting of 15 exons.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Using a transgenic DMPK-overexpressor mouse model, we demonstrate here that the endogenous mouse DMPK gene and the human DMPK transgene produce six major alternatively spliced mRNAs which have almost identical cell type-dependent distribution frequencies and expression patterns.</Disease>

<Disease>Use of a cryptic 5 splice site in exon 8, which results in absence or presence of 15 nucleotides specifying a VSGGG peptide motif, and/or use of a cryptic 3 splice site in exon 14, which leads to a frameshift in the mRNA reading frame, occur as independent stochastic events in all tissues examined.</Disease>

<Disease>In contrast, the excision of exons 13/14 that causes a frameshift and creates a C-terminally truncated protein is clearly cell type dependent and occurs predominantly in smooth muscle.</Disease>

<Disease>We generated all six full-length mouse cDNAs that result from combinations of these three major splicing events and show that their transfection into cells in culture leads to production of four different approximately 74 kDa full-length (heart-, skeletal muscle- or brain-specific) and two C-terminally truncated approximately 68 kDa (smooth muscle-specific) isoforms.</Disease>
<Disease>Information on DMPK mRNA and protein isoform expression patterns will be useful for recognizing differential effects of (CTG) (n) expansion in DM manifestation..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Linkage analysis in a large Brazilian family with van der Woude syndrome suggests the existence of a susceptibility locus for cleft palate at 17p11.2-11.1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>van der Woude syndrome (VWS), which has been mapped to 1q32-41, is characterized by pits and/or sinuses of the lower lip, cleft lip/palate (CL/P), cleft palate (CP), bifid uvula, and hypodontia (H).</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The expression of VWS, which has incomplete penetrance, is highly variable.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Both the occurrence of CL/P and CP within the same genealogy and a recurrence risk < 40% for CP among descendants with VWS have suggested that the development of clefts in this syndrome is influenced by modifying genes at other loci.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To test this hypothesis, we have conducted linkage analysis in a large Brazilian kindred with VWS, considering as affected the individuals with CP, regardless of whether it is associated with other clinical signs of VWS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our results suggest that a gene at 17p11.</Disease>
<Disease>2-11 2-11. 1, together with the VWS gene at 1p32-41, enhances the probability of CP in an individual carrying the two at-risk genes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>If this hypothesis is confirmed in other VWS pedigrees, it will represent one of the first examples of a gene, mapped through linkage analysis, which modifies the expression of a major gene.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Diverse point mutations in the human glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase gene cause enzyme deficiency and mild or severe hemolytic anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD; EC 1. 1. 1. 49) deficiency is a common genetic abnormality affecting an estimated 400 million people worldwide.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Clinical and biochemical analyses have identified many variants exhibiting a range of phenotypes, which have been well characterized from the hematological point of view.</Disease>
<Disease>However, until now, their precise molecular basis has remained unknown.</Disease>
<Disease>We have cloned and sequenced seven mutant G6PD alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>In the nondeficient polymorphic African variant G6PD A we have found a single point mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>The other six mutants investigated were all associated with enzyme deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In one of the commonest, G6PD Mediterranean, which is associated with favism among other clinical manifestations, a single amino acid replacement was found (serine----phenylalanine)  it must be responsible for the decreased stability and the reduced catalytic efficiency of this enzyme.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Single point mutations were also found in G6PD Metaponto (Southern Italy) and in G6PD Ilesha (Nigeria), which are asymptomatic, and in G6PD Chatham, which was observed in an Indian boy with neonatal jaundice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In G6PD " Matera, " which is now known to be the same as G6PD A-, two separate point mutations were found, one of which is the same as in G6PD A.</Disease>
<Disease>In G6PD Santiago, a de novo mutation (glycine----arginine) is associated with severe chronic hemolytic anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mutations observed show a striking predominance of C----T transitions, with CG doublets involved in four of seven cases.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, diverse point mutations may account largely for the phenotypic heterogeneity of G6PD deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Increased high-density lipoprotein levels caused by a common cholesteryl-ester transfer protein gene mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>BACKGROUND AND METHODS.</Disease>
<Disease>The plasma cholesteryl-ester transfer protein (CETP) catalyzes the transfer of cholesteryl esters from high-density lipoprotein (HDL) to other lipoproteins.</Disease>
<Disease>We recently described a Japanese family with increased HDL levels and CETP deficiency due to a splicing defect of the CETP gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To assess the frequency and phenotype of this condition, we screened 11 additional families with high HDL levels by means of a radioimmunoassay for CETP and DNA analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS.</Disease>
<Disease>We found the same CETP gene mutation in four families from three different regions of Japan.</Disease>
<Disease>Analysis of restriction-fragment-length polymorphisms of the mutant CETP allele showed that all probands were homozygous for the identical haplotype.</Disease>
<Disease>Family members homozygous for CETP deficiency (n = 10) had moderate hypercholesterolemia (mean total cholesterol level [+/- SD], 7. 01 +/- 0.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>83 mmol per liter), markedly increased levels of HDL cholesterol (4. 24 +/- 1. 01 mmol per liter) and apolipoprotein A-I, and decreased levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (1. 99 +/- 0. 80 mmol per liter) and apolipoprotein B. Members heterozygous for the deficiency (n = 20), whose CETP levels were in the lower part of the normal range, had moderately increased levels of HDL cholesterol and apolipoprotein A-I and an increased ratio of HDL subclass 2 to HDL subclass 3, as compared with unaffected family members (1. 5 +/- 0. 8 vs. 0.</Disease>
<Disease>7 +/- 0.</Disease>
<Disease>4).</Disease>
<Disease>CETP deficiency was not found in six unrelated subjects with elevated HDL cholesterol levels who were from different parts of the United States.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS.</Disease>
<Disease>CETP deficiency appears to be a frequent cause of increased HDL levels in the population of Japan, possibly because of a founder effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results that we observed in heterozygotes suggest that CETP normally plays a part in the regulation of levels of HDL subclass 2.</Disease>
<Disease>There was no evidence of premature atherosclerosis in the families with CETP deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In fact, the lipoprotein profile of persons with CETP deficiency is potentially antiatherogenic and may be associated with an increased life span.  </Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hereditary deficiency of the seventh component of complement and recurrent meningococcal infection: investigations of an Irish family using a novel haemolytic screening assay for complement activity and C7 M/N allotyping.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Terminal complement component deficiency predisposes to meningococcal infection and is inherited in an autosomal co-dominant manner.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An Irish family is described, in which 2 of 3 brothers had recurrent meningococcal infection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A novel screening assay was used to investigate for terminal complement deficiency and the 2 affected brothers were found to be completely deficient in the seventh component of complement (C7).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for C7 revealed lower than normal levels in the remaining brother and parents.</Disease>

<Disease>C7 M/N protein polymorphism allotyping, used to investigate the segregation of the C7 deficiency genes, showed that the apparently complement sufficient brother was heterozygous C7 deficient and a carrier of one of the deficiency genes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Complement screening should be carried out in any individual suffering recurrent meningococcal infection or infection with an uncommon meningococcal serogroup.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Identification of complement deficient patients allows the implementation of strategies to prevent recurrent infection..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Mild and severe muscular dystrophy associated with deletions in Xp21 of the human X chromosome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have analysed over 300 patients suffering from Duchenne or Becker muscular dystrophy (DMD or BMD).</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>Deletions have been characterised which encompass either the pERT87 (DXS164) locus only, the XJ1.</Disease>
<Disease>1 (DXS206) and HIP25 loci only, or all three loci.</Disease>
<Disease>These loci have been shown to lie within the DMD region covering several hundred kilobases (kb) of DNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One mildly affected BMD patient possesses a deletion of at least 110 kb including exons of the DMD gene.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Other patients with similar exon deletions, or smaller deletions, show the more severe phenotype typical of DMD.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We conclude from these studies that the severity of the clinical phenotype cannot be explained on the basis of the size of the deletion.</Disease>

<Disease>Meiotic segregation analysis of RB1 alleles in retinoblastoma pedigrees by use of single-sperm typing.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In hereditary retinoblastoma, different epidemiological studies have indicated a preferential paternal transmission of mutant retinoblastoma alleles to offspring, suggesting the occurrence of a meiotic drive.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To investigate this mechanism, we analyzed sperm samples from six individuals from five unrelated families affected with hereditary retinoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Single-sperm typing techniques were performed for each sample by study of two informative short tandem repeats located either in or close to the retinoblastoma gene (RB1).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The segregation probability of mutant RB1 alleles in sperm samples was assessed by use of the SPERMSEG program, which includes experimental parameters, recombination fractions between the markers, and segregation parameters.</Disease>
<Disease>A total of 2, 952 single sperm from the six donors were analyzed.</Disease>
<Disease>We detected a significant segregation distortion in the data as a whole (P =. 0099) and a significant heterogeneity in the segregation rate across donors (. 0092).</Disease>

<Disease>Further analysis shows that this result can be explained by segregation distortion in favor of the normal allele in one donor only and that it does not provide evidence of a significant segregation distortion in the other donors.</Disease>

<Disease>The segregation distortion favoring the mutant RB1 allele does not seem to occur during spermatogenesis, and, thus, meiotic drive may result either from various mechanisms, including a fertilization advantage or a better mobility in sperm bearing a mutant RB1 gene, or from the existence of a defectively imprinted gene located on the human X chromosome.</Disease>
<Disease>Functional differences of the PDS gene product are associated with phenotypic variation in patients with Pendred syndrome and non-syndromic hearing loss (DFNB4).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The PDS gene encodes a transmembrane protein, known as pendrin, which functions as a transporter of iodide and chloride.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in this gene are responsible for Pendred syndrome and autosomal recessive non-syndromic hearing loss at the DFNB4 locus on chromosome 7q31.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A screen of 20 individuals from the midwestern USA with non-syndromic hearing loss and dilated vestibular aqueducts identified three people (15%) with PDS mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To determine whether PDS mutations in individuals with Pendred syndrome differ functionally from PDS mutations in individuals with non-syndromic hearing loss, we compared three common Pendred syndrome allele variants (L236P, T416P and E384G), with three PDS mutations reported only in individuals with non-syndromic hearing loss (V480D, V653A and I490L/G497S).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mutations associated with Pendred syndrome have complete loss of pendrin-induced chloride and iodide transport, while alleles unique to people with DFNB4 are able to transport both iodide and chloride, albeit at a much lower level than wild-type pendrin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We hypothesize that this residual level of anion transport is sufficient to eliminate or postpone the onset of goiter in individuals with DFNB4.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We propose a model for pendrin function in the thyroid in which pendrin transports iodide across the apical membrane of the thyrocyte into the colloid space..</Disease>
<Disease>Late-onset metachromatic leukodystrophy: molecular pathology in two siblings.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report on a new allele at the arylsulfatase A (ARSA) locus causing late-onset metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In that allele arginine84, a residue that is highly conserved in the arylsulfatase gene family, is replaced by glutamine.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast to alleles that cause early-onset MLD, the arginine84 to glutamine substitution is associated with some residual ARSA activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A comparison of genotypes, ARSA activities, and clinical data on 4 individuals carrying the allele of 81 patients with MLD examined, further validates the concept that different degrees of residual ARSA activity are the basis of phenotypical variation in MLD..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Defective CD95/APO-1/Fas signal complex formation in the human autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, type Ia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Heterozygous mutations in the CD95 (APO-1/Fas) receptor occur in most individuals with autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) and dominantly interfere with apoptosis by an unknown mechanism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We show that local or global alterations in the structure of the cytoplasmic death domain from nine independent ALPS CD95 death-domain mutations result in a failure to bind the FADD/MORT1 signaling protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Despite heterozygosity for the abnormal allele, lymphocytes from ALPS patients showed markedly decreased FADD association and a loss of caspase recruitment and activation after CD95 crosslinking.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These data suggest that intracytoplasmic CD95 mutations in ALPS impair apoptosis chiefly by disrupting death-domain interactions with the signaling protein FADD/MORT1..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Classical galactosemia and mutations at the galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Classical galactosemia is caused by a deficiency in activity of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT), which, in turn, is caused by mutations at the GALT gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The disorder exhibits considerable allelic heterogeneity and, at the end of 1998, more than 150 different base changes were recorded in 24 different populations and ethnic groups in 15 countries worldwide.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutations most frequently cited are Q188R, K285N, S135L, and N314D. Q188R is the most common mutation in European populations or in those predominantly of European descent.</Disease>
<Disease>Overall, it accounts for 60-70% of mutant chromosomes, but there are significant differences in its relative frequency in individual populations.</Disease>

<Disease>Individuals homoallelic for Q188R tend to have a severe phenotype and this is in keeping with the virtually complete loss of enzyme activity observed in in vitro expression systems.</Disease>
<Disease>Globally, K285N is rarer, but in many European populations it can be found on 25-40% of mutant chromosomes.</Disease>
<Disease>It is invariably associated with a severe phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>S135L is found almost exclusively in African Americans.</Disease>
<Disease>In vitro expression results are discrepant, but some individuals carrying S135L appear to exhibit GALT activity in some tissues.</Disease>

<Disease>Duarte 1 (or Los Angeles) and Duarte 2 (or Duarte) variants carry the same amino acid substitution, N314D, even though D1 is associated with increased erythrocyte GALT activity and D2 with reduced activity.</Disease>
<Disease>N314D is in linkage disequilibrium with other base changes that differ on the D1 and D2 alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>N314D does not impair GALT activity in in vitro expression systems.</Disease>
<Disease>However, there are differences in the abundance of GALT protein in lymphoblastoid cells lines from D2 and D1 individuals.</Disease>
<Disease>It is unclear whether the specific molecular changes that distinguish the D1 and D2 alleles account for the different activities.</Disease>
<Disease>The considerable genetic heterogeneity documented to date undoubtedly contributes to the phenotypic heterogeneity that is observed in galactosemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The additional effects of nonallelic variation and other constitutional factors on phenotypic variability remain to be elucidated..</Disease>
<Disease>X-linked retinoschisis with point mutations in the XLRS1 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND  X-linked retinoschisis (XLRS) is a relatively rare vitreoretinal dystrophy that causes visual loss in young men.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, a gene responsible for this disease, designated XLRS1, was identified, and several deleterious gene mutations were reported.</Disease>
<Disease>OBJECTIVE  To analyze Japanese patients clinically diagnosed as having XLRS formutational changes in the XLRS1 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  Ten patients with XLRS underwent full ophthalmologic examination, including slitlamp biomicroscopy and dilated funduscopy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Genomic DNA was isolated from leukocytes, and all exons of the XLRS1 gene were amplified by polymerase chain reaction and analyzed using a direct sequencing method.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS  Point mutations in the XLRS1 gene were identified in all 10 patients.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutations were identical in each of 2 pairs of brothers.</Disease>
<Disease>Six of the point mutations represented missense mutations, 1 was a nonsense mutation, and 1 was a frameshift mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>Five of the mutations are newly reported herein.</Disease>

<Disease>CONCLUSIONS  The discovery of new point mutations in this study increases the available information regarding the spectrum of genetic abnormalities and clinical manifestations of XLRS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, the limited data failed to reveal a correlation between mutation and disease phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>CLINICAL</Disease>

<Disease>RELEVANCE  Identification of mutations in the XLRS1 gene and expanded information on clinical manifestations will facilitate early diagnosis, appropriate early therapy, and genetic counseling regarding the prognosis of XLRS..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Relationship among genotype, biochemical phenotype, and cognitive performance in females with phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency: report from the Maternal Phenylketonuria Collaborative Study.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE  To examine the relationship of phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) genotypes to biochemical phenotype and cognitive development in maternal phenylketonuria (PKU).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODOLOGY  PAH gene mutations were examined in 222 hyperphenylalaninemic females enrolled in the Maternal PKU Collaborative Study (MPKUCS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A total of 84 different mutations were detected, and complete genotype was obtained in 199 individuals.</Disease>

<Disease>Based on previous knowledge about mutation-phenotype associations, 78 of the mutations could be assigned to one of four classes of severity (severe PKU, moderate PKU, mild PKU, and mild hyperphenylalaninemia [MHP]).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Then, 189 MPKUCS subjects were grouped according to the various combinations of mutation classifications.</Disease>
<Disease>The sample sizes were large enough for statistical testing in four groups with at least one mutation that completely abolishes enzyme activity.</Disease>
<Disease>These patients are considered functionally hemizygous.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS  The biochemical phenotype predicted from the genotype in functionally hemizygous patients was related significantly to the assigned phenylalanine level.</Disease>
<Disease>Cognitive performance (IQ) was also significantly related to genotype.</Disease>

<Disease>The IQ of PAH-deficient mothers with a severe PKU mutation in combination with a MHP mutation or a mild PKU mutation was 99 and 96, respectively, whereas the IQ of PKU mothers with two severe PKU mutations or with one severe and one moderate PKU mutation was 83 and 84, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Of the patients with PKU, 92% had been treated during childhood.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Those who were untreated or treated late had lower than average IQ scores for their group of mutation combinations.</Disease>
<Disease>Females with moderate or mild PKU who were treated early and treated for > 6 years showed IQ scores 10 points above average for their group.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS  The reproductive outcome in maternal phenylketonuria is dependent on prenatal metabolic control and postnatal environmental circumstances.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Both factors depend on the intellectual resources of the mother with PKU.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The significant relationship among genotype, biochemical phenotype, and cognitive performance observed in the present study is of importance for the development of an optimal strategy for future treatment of females with PKU who plan pregnancy..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Uncoupling of hypomyelination and glial cell death by a mutation in the proteolipid protein gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Proteolipid protein (PLP; M (r) 30, 000) is a highly conserved major polytopic membrane protein in myelin but its cellular function remains obscure.</Disease>
<Disease>Neurological mutant mice can often provide model systems for human genetic disorders .</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations of the X-chromosome-linked PLP gene are lethal, identified first in the jimpy mouse and subsequently in patients with Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The unexplained phenotype of these mutations includes degeneration and premature cell death of oligodendrocytes with associated hypomyelination.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here we show that a new mouse mutant rumpshaker is defined by the amino-acid substitution Ile-to-Thr at residue 186 in a membrane-embedded domain of PLP.</Disease>
<Disease>Surprisingly, rumpshaker mice, although myelin-deficient, have normal longevity and a full complement of morphologically normal oligodendrocytes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hypomyelination can thus be genetically separated from the PLP-dependent oligodendrocyte degeneration.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We suggest that PLP has a vital function in glial cell development, distinct from its later role in myelin assembly, and that this dichotomy of action may explain the clinical spectrum of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutational analysis of the HGO gene in Finnish alkaptonuria patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Alkaptonuria (AKU), the prototypic inborn error of metabolism, has recently been shown to be caused by loss of function mutations in the homogentisate-1, 2-dioxygenase gene (HGO).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>So far 17 mutations have been characterised in AKU patients of different ethnic origin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We describe three novel mutations (R58fs, R330S, and H371R) and one common AKU mutation (M368V), detected by mutational and polymorphism analysis of the HGO gene in five Finnish AKU pedigrees.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The three novel AKU mutations are most likely specific for the Finnish population and have originated recently..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Putative X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy gene shares unexpected homology with ABC transporters.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) is an X-linked disease affecting 1/20, 000 males either as cerebral ALD in childhood or as adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) in adults.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Childhood ALD is the more severe form, with onset of neurological symptoms between 5-12 years of age.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Central nervous system demyelination progresses rapidly and death occurs within a few years.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>AMN is a milder form of the disease with onset at 15-30 years of age and a more progressive course.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Adrenal insufficiency (Addisons disease) may remain the only clinical manifestation of ALD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The principal biochemical abnormality of ALD is the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) because of impaired beta-oxidation in peroxisomes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The normal oxidation of VLCFA-CoA in patients fibroblasts suggested that the gene coding for the VLCFA-CoA synthetase could be a candidate gene for ALD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here we use positional cloning to identify a gene partially deleted in 6 of 85 independent patients with ALD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In familial cases, the deletions segregated with the disease.</Disease>
<Disease>An identical deletion was detected in two brothers presenting with different clinical ALD phenotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Candidate exons were identified by computer analysis of genomic sequences and used to isolate complementary DNAs by exon connection and screening of cDNA libraries.</Disease>

<Disease>The deduced protein sequence shows significant sequence identity to a peroxisomal membrane protein of M (r) 70K that is involved in peroxisome biogenesis and belongs to the ATP-binding cassette superfamily of transporters..</Disease>
<Disease>Cardiac Na(+) channel dysfunction in Brugada syndrome is aggravated by beta(1)-subunit.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND  Mutations in the gene encoding the human cardiac Na (+) channel alpha-subunit (hH1) are responsible for chromosome 3-linked congenital long-QT syndrome (LQT3) and idiopathic ventricular fibrillation (IVF).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>An auxiliary beta (1) -subunit, widely expressed in excitable tissues, shifts the voltage dependence of steady-state inactivation toward more negative potentials and restores normal gating kinetics of brain and skeletal muscle Na (+) channels expressed in Xenopus oocytes but has little if any functional effect on the cardiac isoform.</Disease>
<Disease>Here, we characterize the altered effects of a human beta (1) -subunit (hbeta (1)) on the heterologously expressed hH1 mutation (T1620M) previously associated with IVF.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS AND RESULTS  When expressed alone in Xenopus oocytes, T1620M exhibited no persistent currents, in contrast to the LQT3 mutant channels, but the midpoint of steady-state inactivation (V (1/2)) was significantly shifted toward more positive potentials than for wild-type hH1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Coexpression of hbeta (1) did not significantly alter current decay or recovery from inactivation of wild-type hH1; however, it further shifted the V (1/2) and accelerated the recovery from inactivation of T1620M. Oocyte macropatch analysis revealed that the activation kinetics of T1620M were normal.</Disease>

<Disease>CONCLUSIONS  It is suggested that coexpression of hbeta (1) exposes a more severe functional defect that results in a greater overlap in the relationship between channel inactivation and activation (window current) in T1620M, which is proposed to be a potential pathophysiological mechanism of IVF in vivo.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One possible explanation for our finding is an altered alpha-/beta (1) -subunit association in the mutant..</Disease>
<Disease>Autosomal recessive familial neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus with continued secretion of mutant weakly active vasopressin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by post-natal development of arginine vasopressin (AVP) deficiency due to mutations in the AVP gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All published mutations affect the signal peptide or the neurophysin-II carrier protein and are presumed to interfere with processing of the preprohormone, leading to neuronal damage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We studied an unusual Palestinian family consisting of asymptomatic first cousin parents and three children affected with neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus, suggesting autosomal recessive inheritance.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All three affected children were homozygous and the parents heterozygous for a single novel mutation (C301- > T) in exon 1, replacing Pro7 of mature AVP with Leu (Leu-AVP).</Disease>
<Disease>Leu-AVP was a weak agonist with approximately 30-fold reduced binding to the human V2 receptor.</Disease>

<Disease>Measured by radioimmunoassay with a synthetic Leu-AVP standard, serum Leu-AVP levels were elevated in all three children and further increased during water deprivation to as high as 30 times normal.</Disease>

<Disease>The youngest child (2 years old) was only mildly affected but had Leu-AVP levels similar to her severely affected 8-year-old brother, suggesting that unknown mechanisms may partially compensate for a deficiency of active AVP in very young children..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Autosomal dominant aniridia linked to the chromosome 11p13 markers catalase and D11S151 in a large Dutch family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In a large pedigree with autosomal dominant aniridia, we found close linkage between the aniridia locus AN2 and the markers catalase (CAT) (zeta = 7. 27 at theta = 0. 00) and D11S151 (zeta = 3. 86 at theta = 0. 10) flanking the AN2 locus on 11p13.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Positive lod scores were also obtained for the 11p13----11p14 markers D11S16 and FSHB with the linkage group CAT/AN2/D11S151.</Disease>
<Disease>We conclude that the autosomal dominant aniridia in this family is due to a mutation at the AN2 locus on 11p13.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have excluded linkage (zeta less than -2 at theta less than 0. 18) between the aniridia and the chromosome 2p25 marker D2S1 (linked to ACP1).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Knobloch syndrome involving midline scalp defect of the frontal region.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report on a 4-year-old boy with Knobloch syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>He has vitreoretinal degeneration, high myopia, cataract, telecanthus, hypertelorism, and a high-arched palate.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>He also has a defect of the anterior midline scalp with involvement of the frontal bone as documented by a computed tomography (CT) scan.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The brain was normal on CT scan and magnetic resonance imaging.</Disease>
<Disease>We present a review of the 23 published cases with this syndrome.</Disease>
<Disease>Our patient illustrates the importance of investigating for underlying ocular and central nervous system pathology whenever midline scalp defects are present..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pendred syndrome: phenotypic variability in two families carrying the same PDS missense mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pendred syndrome comprises congenital sensorineural hearing loss, thyroid goiter, and positive perchlorate discharge test.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, this autosomal recessive disorder was shown to be caused by mutations in the PDS gene, which encodes an anion transporter called pendrin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular analysis of the PDS gene was performed in two consanguineous large families from Southern Tunisia comprising a total of 23 individuals affected with profound congenital deafness; the same missense mutation, L445W, was identified in all affected individuals.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A widened vestibular aqueduct was found in all patients who underwent computed tomography (CT) scan</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>exploration of the inner ear.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, goiter was present in only 11 affected individuals, who interestingly had a normal result of the perchlorate discharge test whenever performed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The present results question the sensitivity of the perchlorate test for the diagnosis of Pendred syndrome and support the use of a molecular analysis of the PDS gene in the assessment of individuals with severe to profound congenital hearing loss associated with inner ear morphological anomaly even in the absence of a thyroid goiter..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The type of somatic mutation at APC in familial adenomatous polyposis is determined by the site of the germline mutation: a new facet to Knudson's 'two-hit' hypothesis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>APC is often cited as a prime example of a tumor suppressor gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Truncating germline and somatic mutations (or, infrequently, allelic loss) occur in tumors in FAP (familial adenomatous polyposis).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Most sporadic colorectal cancers also have two APC mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Clues from attenuated polyposis, missense germline variants with mild disease and the somatic mutation cluster region (codons 1, 250-1, 450) indicate, however, that APC mutations might not result in simple loss of protein function.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have found that FAP patients with germline APC mutations within a small region (codons 1, 194-1, 392 at most) mainly show allelic loss in their colorectal adenomas, in contrast to other FAP patients, whose second hits tend to occur by truncating mutations in the mutation cluster region.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our results indicate that different APC mutations provide cells with different selective advantages, with mutations close to codon 1, 300 providing the greatest advantage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Allelic loss is selected strongly in cells with one mutation near codon 1, 300.</Disease>
<Disease>A different germline-somatic APC mutation association exists in FAP desmoids.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>APC is not, therefore, a classical tumor suppressor.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our findings also indicate a new mechanism for disease severity  if a broader spectrum of mutations is selected in tumors, the somatic mutation rate is effectively higher and more tumors grow..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Purification of human very-long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase and characterization of its deficiency in seven patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Mitochondrial very-long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (VLCAD) was purified from human liver.</Disease>
<Disease>The molecular masses of the native enzyme and the subunit were estimated to be 154 and 70 kD, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>The enzyme was found to catalyze the major part of mitochondrial palmitoylcoenzyme A dehydrogenation in liver, heart, skeletal muscle, and skin fibroblasts (89-97, 86-99, 96-99, and 78-87%, respectively).</Disease>

<Disease>Skin fibroblasts from 26 patients suspected of having a disorder of mitochondrial beta-oxidation were analyzed for VLCAD protein using immunoblotting, and 7 of them contained undetectable or trace levels of the enzyme.</Disease>

<Disease>The seven deficient fibroblast lines were characterized by measuring acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenation activities, overall palmitic acid oxidation, and VLCAD protein synthesis using pulse-chase, further confirming the diagnosis of VLCAD deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggested the heterogenous nature of the mutations causing the deficiency in the seven patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Clinically, all patients with VLCAD deficiency exhibited cardiac disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>At least four of them presented with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This frequency (> 57%) was much higher than that observed in patients with other disorders of mitochondrial long-chain fatty acid oxidation that may be accompanied by cardiac disease in infants..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A germ line mutation within the coding sequence for the putative 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate binding site of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) in a Lesch-Nyhan patient: missense mutations within a functionally important region probably cause disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Lesch-Nyhan syndrome caused by a complete deficiency of hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) is the result of a heterogeneous group of germ line mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of each mutant gene provides valuable information as to the type of mutation that occurs spontaneously.</Disease>
<Disease>We report here a newly identified HPRT mutation in a Japanese patient with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This gene, designated HPRT Tokyo, had a single nucleotide change from G to A, as identified by sequencing cDNA amplified by the polymerase chain reaction.</Disease>
<Disease>Allele specific oligonucleotide hybridization analysis using amplified genomic DNA showed that the mutant gene was transmitted from the maternal germ line.</Disease>

<Disease>This mutation would lead to an amino acid substitution of Asp for Gly at the amino acid position 140 located within the putative 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP) binding region.</Disease>
<Disease>Missense mutations in human HPRT deficient patients thus far reported tend to accumulate in this functionally active region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, a comparison of the data suggested that both missense and synonymous mutations can occur at any coding sequence of the human germ line HPRT gene, but that a limited percentage of all the missense mutations cause disease.</Disease>
<Disease>The probability that a mutation will cause disease tends to be higher when the missense mutation is within a functionally important sequence..</Disease>
<Disease>In vitro and in vivo correlations for I65T and M1V mutations at the phenylalanine hydroxylase locus.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations at the phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) locus are the major cause of hyperphenylalaninemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have previously described four mutations (M1V, IVS12nt1, R408W, and S349P) at the PAH locus in French Canadians with ancestry in eastern Quebec.</Disease>

<Disease>Here we report (1) identification of another mutation, on a haplotype 9 chromosome, which converts codon 65 from isoleucine (ATT) to threonine (ACT), (2) expression analysis of the I65T mutation in COS cells demonstrating 75% loss of both immunoreactive protein and enzyme activity, and (3) expression analysis of the most prevalent PKU allele (M1V) in eastern Quebec, showing nondetectable levels of PAH protein and activity, a finding compatible with a mutation in the translation initiation codon.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Homozygosity for M1V and codominant inheritance of I65T/R408W were both associated with classical phenylketonuria..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Experimental hemochromatosis due to MHC class I HFE deficiency: immune status and iron metabolism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The puzzling linkage between genetic hemochromatosis and histocompatibility loci became even more so when the gene involved, HFE, was identified.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Indeed, within the well defined, mainly peptide-binding, MHC class I family of molecules, HFE seems to perform an unusual yet essential function.</Disease>
<Disease>As yet, our understanding of HFE function in iron homeostasis is only partial; an even more open question is its possible role in the immune system.</Disease>
<Disease>To advance on both of these avenues, we report the deletion of HFE alpha1 and alpha2 putative ligand binding domains in vivo.</Disease>
<Disease>HFE-deficient animals were analyzed for a comprehensive set of metabolic and immune parameters.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Faithfully mimicking human hemochromatosis, mice homozygous for this deletion develop iron overload, characterized by a higher plasma iron content and a raised transferrin saturation as well as an elevated hepatic iron load.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The primary defect could, indeed, be traced to an augmented duodenal iron absorption.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Gd- frequency, calculated from the data obtained (7. 7%), may be compared to neighbouring regions frequencies (6-30%).</Disease>

<Disease>Determination of carrier status for the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome by flow cytometric analysis of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein expression in peripheral blood mononuclear cells.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>It was found more frequently in subjects of Irish, Scottish, and Welsh origin compared with English origin (63% and 31% respectively).</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>The murine homologues of the Huntington disease gene (Hdh) and the alpha-adducin gene (Add1) map to mouse chromosome 5 within a region of conserved synteny with human chromosome 4p16.3.</Disease>

label: Disease

<Disease>Both of these genes map in the same position on mouse chromosome 5 in a region associated with ancestral chromosomal rearrangements and show no recombination with D5H4S43, D5H4S115, and D5H4S62, the murine homologues of D4S43, D4S115, and D4S62, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>Linkage analysis of the apolipoprotein C2 gene and myotonic dystrophy on human chromosome 19 reveals linkage disequilibrium in a French-Canadian population.</Disease>

Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Six APOC2 RFLPs (TaqI, BglI, BanI, BamHI, NcoI, and AvaII) have been identified to date.</Disease>
<Disease>We have conducted a comprehensive DM linkage study utilizing all six RFLPs and involving 50 families and 372 individuals.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The most informative RFLPs are, in descending order, NcoI (lod = 6. 64, theta = 0. 05), BglI (lod = 6. 12, theta = 0. 05), AvaII (lod = 6. 02, theta = 0. 03),</Disease>
<Disease>BanI (lod = 5. 76, theta = 0. 04), TaqI (lod = 4. 29, theta = 0. 06), and BamHI (lod = 1. 75, theta = 0. 01).</Disease>

<Disease>A substantial increase in the lod scores over those seen with the individual RFLPs was obtained when the linkage of the entire APOC2 haplotype (composed of the six RFLPs) was studied (lod = 17.</Disease>
<Disease>87, theta = 0. 04).</Disease>
<Disease>We have observed significant inter-APOC2 RFLP linkage disequilibrium.</Disease>
<Disease>Consequently, the three most informative RFLPs have been found to be BanI, TaqI, and either BglI, AvaII, or NcoI polymorphisms.</Disease>

<Disease>We also demonstrate linkage disequilibrium between DM and APOC2 in our French-Canadian population (standardized disequilibrium constant phi =. 22, chi 2 = 5. 12, df = 1, P less than 0. 04).</Disease>
<Disease>This represents the first evidence of linkage disequilibrium between APOC2 and the DM locus.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PKU is a common inborn error of amino-acid metabolism in caucasian populations and approximately 1 in 50 individuals are carriers of a PKU allele.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To define the molecular basis of PKU, we characterized twelve restriction fragment-length polymorphism (RFLP) haplotypes of the PAH locus in the northern European population and observed that 90% of the PKU alleles in this population are confined to four common RFLP haplotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have recently reported a splicing mutation in the PAH gene that is associated with RFLP haplotype 3 which is present at about 40% of mutant alleles.</Disease>

<Disease>The effects of dystrophin gene mutations on the ERG in mice and humans.</Disease>
<Disease>PURPOSE.</Disease>

<Disease>The authors earlier findings of a negative electroretinogram (ERG) in a boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) led them to investigate dystrophin gene deletions and ERGs in five boys with DMD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The authors wanted to determined whether there were similar ERG findings in an animal model for DMD, the mdx mouse.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS.</Disease>
<Disease>Ganzfeld ERGs were recorded in five boys with DMD after a complete ophthalmic examination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The dystrophin gene was analyzed by Southern blot hybridization.</Disease>
<Disease>ERGs were recorded in anesthetized mdx and control mice with a modified Grass photostimulator (Grass Instrument Company, Quincy, MA).</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS.</Disease>
<Disease>Ophthalmic examinations in all five boys had normal findings, yet an abnormal negative ERG was recorded for each subject.</Disease>
<Disease>The subjects gene deletions were variable, ranging from large deletions to no detectable deletions.</Disease>
<Disease>The ERGs of the mdx mice were normal and did not differ significantly from those of the control mice.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS.</Disease>

<Disease>The authors believe the unique ERG recorded for the human subjects is a manifestation of DMD associated with defects at the dystrophin gene locus and represents a new clinical entity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The ERG of the mdx mouse may be spared for several reasons, including milder effects of the mouse gene defect, differences in muscle and retinal gene product, or species differences in the biochemical role of dystrophin.</Disease>
<Disease>The ERG shows promise of becoming a noninvasive diagnostic tool for DMD and its milder allelic forms..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Eight novel inactivating germ line mutations at the APC gene identified by denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a dominantly inherited condition predisposing to colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The recent isolation of the responsible gene (adenomatous polyposis coli or APC) has facilitated the search for germ line mutations in affected individuals.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Previous authors have used the RNase protection assay and the single-strand conformation polymorphisms procedure to screen for mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>In this study we used denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE).</Disease>

<Disease>DGGE analysis of 10 APC exons (4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, and part of 15) in 33 unrelated Dutch FAP patients has led to the identification of eight novel germ line mutations resulting in stop codons or frameshifts.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The results reported here indicate that (1) familial adenomatous polyposis is caused by an extremely heterogeneous spectrum of point mutations; (2) all the mutations found in this study are chain terminating; and (3) DGGE represents a rapid and sensitive technique for the detection of mutations in the unusually large APC gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>An extension of the DGGE analysis to the entire coding region in a sufficient number of clinically well-characterized, unrelated patients will facilitate the establishment of genotype-phenotype correlations.</Disease>

<Disease>On the other hand, the occurrence of an extremely heterogeneous spectrum of mutations spread throughout the entire length of the large APC gene among the FAP patients indicates that this approach may not be useful as a rapid presymptomatic diagnostic procedure in a routine laboratory.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nevertheless, the above DGGE approach has incidentally led to the identification of a common polymorphism in exon 13.</Disease>
<Disease>Such intragenic polymorphisms offer a practical approach to a more rapid procedure for presymptomatic diagnosis of FAP by linkage analysis in informative families..</Disease>

<Disease>Mutations identified in this study include 19 missense mutations, two nonsense mutations, one intragenic deletion, four microdeletions, one insertion, and one intronic sequence substitution that is likely to result in a splice site defect.</Disease>

<Disease>Two novel mutations, c. 38T-- > C (L13P) and c. 667T-- > C (C223R), respectively, present the first genetic evidence for the functional significance of the putative leader peptide sequence and for the functional significance at the carboxyl terminal of the XLRS1 protein beyond the discoidin domain.</Disease>

text: <Disease>To fill this gap, we sequenced the G6PD gene of 43 G6PD-deficient Chinese whose G6PD was well characterized biochemically.</Disease>

<Disease>From these 43 samples, we have identified five different types of nucleotide substitutions in the G6PD gene  at cDNA 1388 from G to A (Arg to His); at cDNA 1376 from G to T (Arg to Leu); at cDNA 1024 from C to T (Leu to Phe); at cDNA 392 from G to T (Gly to Val); at cDNA 95 from A to G (His to Arg).</Disease>

text: <Disease>Treatment of cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis: effects of chenodeoxycholic acid, pravastatin, and combined use.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Treatments by oral administration of chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) alone, 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase inhibitor (pravastatin) alone, and combination of the two drugs were attempted for 7 patients with cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis (CTX).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CDCA treatment at a dose of 300 mg/day reduced serum cholestanol (67. 3% reduction), lathosterol (50. 8%), campesterol (61. 7%) and sitosterol (12. 7%).</Disease>

<Disease>However, the sera of the patients changed to be " atherogenic "; total cholesterol, triglyceride and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) -cholesterol were increased, while high-density lipoprotein (HDL) -cholesterol was decreased.</Disease>

<Disease>Contrarily, pravastatin at a dose of 10 mg/day improved the sera of the patients to be markedly " anti-atherogenic ", but the reductions of cholestanol (30. 4%), lathosterol (44. 0%), campesterol (22. 9%) and sitosterol (9. 6%) were inadequate.</Disease>
<Disease>Combined treatment with CDCA and pravastatin showed good overlapping of the effects of each drug alone.</Disease>
<Disease>The sera of the patients were apparently more " anti-atherogenic " than those after CDCA treatment.</Disease>

<Disease>Serum cholestanol concentration was still 2. 7 times higher than in controls, but the serum lathosterol level was within the normal range, indicating that the enhancement of overall cholesterol synthesis in the patients was sufficiently suppressed.</Disease>
<Disease>Plant sterol levels were also within the normal range.</Disease>

<Disease>The combination of CDCA and pravastatin was a good treatment for CTX, based on the improvement of serum lipoprotein metabolism, the suppression of cholesterol synthesis, and reductions of cholestanol and plant sterol levels.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In all of 7 patients, the progression of disease was arrested, but dramatic effects on clinical manifestations, xanthoma, and electrophysiological findings could not be found after the treatment of these drugs</Disease>

<Disease>These findings suggest the possibility that C6 and C7 may function as a single genetic unit and that the primary transcript copied from the genome includes information for both proteins..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Iron-dependent self-assembly of recombinant yeast frataxin: implications for Friedreich ataxia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Frataxin deficiency is the primary cause of Friedreich ataxia (FRDA), an autosomal recessive cardiodegenerative and neurodegenerative disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Frataxin is a nuclear-encoded mitochondrial protein that is widely conserved among eukaryotes.</Disease>
<Disease>Genetic inactivation of the yeast frataxin homologue (Yfh1p) results in mitochondrial iron accumulation and hypersensitivity to oxidative stress.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Increased iron deposition and evidence of oxidative damage have also been observed in cardiac tissue and cultured fibroblasts from patients with FRDA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings indicate that frataxin is essential for mitochondrial iron homeostasis and protection from iron-induced formation of free radicals.</Disease>
<Disease>The functional mechanism of frataxin, however, is still unknown.</Disease>
<Disease>We have expressed the mature form of Yfh1p (mYfh1p) in Escherichia coli and have analyzed its function in vitro.</Disease>
<Disease>Isolated mYfh1p is a soluble monomer (13, 783 Da) that contains no iron and shows no significant tendency to self-associate.</Disease>

<Disease>Aerobic addition of ferrous iron to mYfh1p results in assembly of regular spherical multimers with a molecular mass of approximately 1. 1 MDa (megadaltons) and a diameter of 13 +/-2 nm.</Disease>
<Disease>Each multimer consists of approximately 60 subunits and can sequester > 3, 000 atoms of iron.</Disease>
<Disease>Titration of mYfh1p with increasing iron concentrations supports a stepwise mechanism of multimer assembly.</Disease>

<Disease>Sequential addition of an iron chelator and a reducing agent results in quantitative iron release with concomitant disassembly of the multimer, indicating that mYfh1p sequesters iron in an available form.</Disease>
<Disease>In yeast mitochondria, native mYfh1p exists as monomer and a higher-order species with a molecular weight > 600, 000.</Disease>
<Disease>After addition of (55) Fe to the medium, immunoprecipitates of this species contain > 16 atoms of (55) Fe per molecule of mYfh1p.</Disease>
<Disease>We propose that iron-dependent self-assembly of recombinant mYfh1p reflects a physiological role for frataxin in mitochondrial iron sequestration and bioavailability..</Disease>
<Disease>Human mutations in glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase reflect evolutionary history.</Disease>

<Disease>Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is a cytosolic enzyme encoded by a housekeeping X-linked gene whose main function is to produce NADPH, a key electron donor in the defense against oxidizing agents and in reductive biosynthetic reactions.</Disease>
<Disease>Inherited G6PD deficiency is associated with either episodic hemolytic anemia (triggered by fava beans or other agents) or life-long hemolytic anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We show here that an evolutionary analysis is a key to understanding the biology of a housekeeping gene.</Disease>

<Disease>From the alignment of the amino acid (aa) sequence of 52 glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) species from 42 different organisms, we found a striking correlation between the aa replacements that cause G6PD deficiency in humans and the sequence conservation of G6PD  two-thirds of such replacements are in highly and moderately conserved (50-99%) aa; relatively few are in fully conserved aa (where they might be lethal) or in poorly conserved aa, where presumably they simply would not cause G6PD deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This is consistent with the notion that all human mutants have residual enzyme activity and that null mutations are lethal at some stage of development.</Disease>

<Disease>Comparing the distribution of mutations in a human housekeeping gene with evolutionary conservation is a useful tool for pinpointing amino acid residues important for the stability or the function of the corresponding protein.</Disease>
<Disease>In view of the current explosive increase in full genome sequencing projects, this tool will become rapidly available for numerous other genes..</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>This compared with 6 of 27 familial cases.</Disease>

<Disease>A 5 bp deletion at codon 1309 reported to occur in 10-15% of unselected APC patients worldwide, was found in 5 of the 18 new mutation cases and 4 of the 27 familial cases  all nine were classed as severe.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A further 3 new mutations and 1 familial mutation were located downstream from codon 1309, these individuals similarly being classed as phenotypically severe.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast all of the APC mutations detected in affected individuals with an average phenotype were located prior to codon 1309.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The frequent association of a severe phenotype with fresh mutation may explain the apparent conflict of a high mutation rate (20-30%) in a condition, which on average, is lethal at a post-reproductive age..</Disease>
<Disease>Analysis of alkaptonuria (AKU) mutations and polymorphisms reveals that the CCC sequence motif is a mutational hot spot in the homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase gene (HGO).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We recently showed that alkaptonuria (AKU) is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the homogentisate 1, 2 dioxygenase gene (HGO).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Herein we describe haplotype and mutational analyses of HGO in seven new AKU pedigrees.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These analyses identified two novel single-nucleotide polymorphisms (INV4 + 31A-- > G and INV11 + 18A-- > G) and six novel AKU mutations (INV1-1G-- > A, W60G, Y62C, A122D, P230T, and D291E), which further illustrates the remarkable allelic heterogeneity found in AKU.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Reexamination of all 29 mutations and polymorphisms thus far described in HGO shows that these nucleotide changes are not randomly distributed; the CCC sequence motif and its inverted complement, GGG, are preferentially mutated.</Disease>

<Disease>These analyses also demonstrated that the nucleotide substitutions in HGO do not involve CpG dinucleotides, which illustrates important differences between HGO and other genes for the occurrence of mutation at specific short-sequence motifs.</Disease>

<Disease>Because the CCC sequence motifs comprise a significant proportion (34. 5%) of all mutated bases that have been observed in HGO, we conclude that the CCC triplet is a mutational hot spot in HGO.</Disease>

<Disease>Here, Luria and Delbrucks classical methods for analysing bacterial cultures are adapted to the study of human isolated founder populations in order to estimate (i) the recombination fraction between a disease locus and a marker; (ii) the expected degree of allelic homogeneity in a population; and (iii) the mutation rate of marker loci.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Inherited defects in the peroxisomal ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter adrenoleukodystrophy protein (ALDP) lead to the lethal peroxisomal disorder X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD), for which no efficient treatment has been established so far.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Three other peroxisomal ABC transporters currently are known  adrenoleukodystrophy-related protein (ALDRP), 70 kDa peroxisomal membrane protein (PMP70) and PMP70- related protein.</Disease>

<Disease>By using transient and stable overexpression of human cDNAs encoding ALDP and its closest relative ALDRP, we could restore the impaired peroxisomal beta-oxidation in fibroblasts of X-ALD patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The pathognomonic accumulation of very long chain fatty acids could also be prevented by overexpression of ALDRP in immortalized X-ALD cells.</Disease>
<Disease>Immunofluorescence analysis demonstrated that the functional replacement of ALDP by ALDRP was not due to stabilization of the mutated ALDP itself.</Disease>

<Disease>Moreover, we were able to restore the peroxisomal beta-oxidation defect in the liver of ALDP-deficient mice by stimulation of ALDRP and PMP70 gene expression through a dietary treatment with the peroxisome proliferator fenofibrate.</Disease>
<Disease>These results suggest that a correction of the biochemical defect in X-ALD could be possible by drug-induced overexpression or ectopic expression of ALDRP..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Synergistic effect of histone hyperacetylation and DNA demethylation in the reactivation of the FMR1 gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Most fragile X syndrome patients have expansion of a (CGG) (n) sequence with > 200 repeats (full mutation) in the FMR1 gene responsible for this condition.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hypermethylation of the expanded repeat and of the FMR1 promoter is almost always present and apparently suppresses transcription, resulting in absence of the FMR1 protein.</Disease>
<Disease>We recently showed that transcriptional reactivation of FMR1 full mutations can be achieved by inducing DNA demethylation with 5-azadeoxycytidine (5-azadC).</Disease>

<Disease>The level of histone acetylation is another important factor in regulating gene expression; therefore, we treated lymphoblastoid cell lines of non-mosaic full mutation patients with three drugs capable of inducing histone hyperacetylation.</Disease>

<Disease>However, we report that combining these drugs with 5-azadC results in a 2- to 5-fold increase in FMR1 mRNA levels obtained with 5-azadC alone, thus showing a marked synergistic effect of histone hyperacetylation and DNA demethylation in the reactivation of FMR1 full mutations..</Disease>

<Disease>Anonymous marker loci within 400 kb of HLA-A generate haplotypes in linkage disequilibrium with the hemochromatosis gene (HFE)</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The hemochromatosis gene (HFE) maps to 6p21. 3 and is less than 1 cM from the HLA class I genes; however, the precise physical location of the gene has remained elusive and controversial.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The unambiguous identification of a crossover event within hemochromatosis families is very difficult; it is particularly hampered by the variability of the phenotypic expression as well as by the sex- and age-related penetrance of the disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>For these practical considerations, traditional linkage analysis could prove of limited value in further refining the extrapolated physical position of HFE.</Disease>
<Disease>We therefore embarked upon a linkage-disequilibrium analysis of HFE and normal chromosomes from the Brittany population.</Disease>

<Disease>In the present report, 66 hemochromatosis families yielding 151 hemochromatosis chromosomes and 182 normal chromosomes were RFLP-typed with a battery of probes, including two newly derived polymorphic markers from the 6. 7 and HLA-F loci located 150 and 250 kb telomeric to HLA-A, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The results suggest a strong peak of existing linkage disequilibrium focused within the i82-to-6.</Disease>
<Disease>7 interval (approximately 250 kb).</Disease>

<Disease>The zone of linkage disequilibrium is flanked by the i97 locus, positioned 30 kb proximal to i82, and the HLA-F gene, found 250 kb distal to HLA-A, markers of which display no significant association with HFE.</Disease>

<Disease>These data support the possibility that HFE resides within the 400-kb expanse of DNA between i97 and HLA-F. Alternatively, the very tight association of HLA-A3 and allele 1 of the 6. 7 locus, both of which are comprised by the major ancestral or founder HFE haplotype in Brittany, supports the possibility that the disease gene may reside immediately telomeric to the 6. 7 locus within the linkage-disequilibrium zone.</Disease>

<Disease>Additionally, hemochromatosis haplotypes possessing HLA-A11 and the low-frequency HLA-F polymorphism (allele 2) are supportive of a separate founder chromosome containing a second, independently arising mutant allele.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Overall, the establishment of a likely " hemochromatosis critical region " centromeric boundary and the identification of a linkage-disequilibrium zone both significantly contribute to a reduction in the amount of DNA required to be searched for novel coding sequences constituting the HFE defect</Disease>

text: <Disease>Natural selection of hemi- and heterozygotes for G6PD deficiency in Africa by resistance to severe malaria.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, the most common enzymopathy of humans, affects over 400 million people.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The geographical correlation of its distribution with the historical endemicity of malaria suggests that this disorder has risen in frequency through natural selection by malaria.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, attempts to confirm that G6PD deficiency is protective in case-control studies of malaria have yielded conflicting results.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hence, for this X-linked disorder, it is unclear whether both male hemizygotes and female heterozygotes are protected or, as frequently suggested, only females.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, how much protection may be afforded is unknown.</Disease>

<Disease>Here we report that, in two large case-control studies of over 2, 000 African children, the common African form of G6PD deficiency (G6PD A-) is associated with a 46-58% reduction in risk of severe malaria for both female heterozygotes and male hemizygotes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A mathematical model incorporating the measured selective advantage against malaria suggests that a counterbalancing selective disadvantage, associated with this enzyme deficiency, has retarded its rise in frequency in malaria-endemic regions.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although G6PD deficiency is now regarded as a generally benign disorder, in earlier environmental conditions it could have been significantly disadvantageous..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>On the other hand, the group of normal karyotype patients is heterogeneous, and their features do not strictly correspond to the clinical definition of PWS.</Disease>
