text: <Disease>However, the hypothesis that PWS is associated with deletion of 15q11-12 can neither explain the apparently balanced translocations of chromosome 15 nor account for the small supernumerary metacentric chromosomes corresponding to an isochromosome 15 for band 15q11 observed in some cases..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular basis of phenylketonuria and related hyperphenylalaninemias: mutations and polymorphisms in the human phenylalanine hydroxylase gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the human phenylalanine hydroxylase gene producing phenylketonuria or hyperphenylalaninemia have now been identified in many patients from various ethnic groups.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These mutations all exhibit a high degree of association with specific restriction fragment-length polymorphism haplotypes at the PAH locus.</Disease>
<Disease>About 50 of these mutations are single-base substitutions, including six nonsense mutations and eight splicing mutations, with the remainder being missense mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>One splicing mutation results in a 3 amino acid in-frame insertion.</Disease>
<Disease>Two or 3 large deletions, 2 single codon deletions, and 2 single base deletions have been found.</Disease>
<Disease>Twelve of the missense mutations apparently result from the methylation and subsequent deamination of highly mutagenic CpG dinucleotides.</Disease>
<Disease>Recurrent mutation has been observed at several of these sites, producing associations with different haplotypes in different populations.</Disease>

<Disease>About half of all missense mutations have been examined by in vitro expression analysis, and a significant correlation has been observed between residual PAH activity and disease phenotype.</Disease>

<Disease>Since continuing advances in molecular methodologies have dramatically accelerated the rate in which new mutations are being identified and characterized, this register of mutations will be updated periodically..</Disease>
<Disease>The intron 7 donor splice site transition: a second Tay-Sachs disease mutation in French Canada.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations at the hexosaminidase A (HEXA) gene which cause Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) have elevated frequency in the Ashkenazi Jewish and French-Canadian populations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report a novel TSD allele in the French-Canadian population associated with the infantile form of the disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation, a G-- ></Disease>
<Disease>A transition at the + 1 position of intron 7, abolishes the donor splice site.</Disease>
<Disease>Cultured human fibroblasts from a compound heterozygote for this transition (and for a deletion mutation) produce no detectable HEXA mRNA.</Disease>
<Disease>The intron 7 + 1 mutation occurs in the base adjacent to the site of the adult-onset TSD mutation (G805A).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In both mutations a restriction site for the endonuclease EcoRII is abolished.</Disease>
<Disease>Unambiguous diagnosis, therefore, requires allele-specific oligonucleotide hybridization to distinguish between these two mutant alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>The intron 7 + 1 mutation has been detected in three unrelated families.</Disease>
<Disease>Obligate heterozygotes for the intron 7 + 1 mutation were born in the Saguenay-Lac-St-Jean region of Quebec.</Disease>
<Disease>The most recent ancestors common to obligate carriers of this mutation were from the Charlevoix region of the province of Quebec.</Disease>
<Disease>This mutation thus has a different geographic centre of diffusion and is probably less common than the exon 1 deletion TSD mutation in French Canadians.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neither mutation has been detected in France, the ancestral homeland of French Canada..</Disease>
<Disease>Recessively inherited multiple epiphyseal dysplasia with normal stature, club foot, and double layered patella caused by a DTDST mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have observed over 25 different mutations in the diastrophic dysplasia sulphate transporter gene (DTDST) in association with the recessive disorders achondrogenesis 1B, atelosteogenesis 2, and diastrophic dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The c862t (R279W) transition is the most common mutation in non-Finnish patients, but in these disorders it is usually combined with other DTDST mutations.</Disease>

<Disease>We had not seen a case of homozygosity for c862t (R279W) until we analysed DNA from a 36 year old male with tall-normal stature (180 cm) who asked for genetic counselling for suspected multiple epiphyseal dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>He was treated for club foot and hip dysplasia at birth.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Skeletal changes consistent with multiple epiphyseal dysplasia, with the peculiar finding of a double layered patella, were recognised during childhood.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cleft palate, swelling of the ear pinna, and hitch hiker thumb were absent.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>He was found to be homozygous, and both healthy parents heterozygous, for the R279W mutation in DTDST, and his fibroblasts showed a sulphate incorporation defect typical of DTDST disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Counselling was given for a recessive disorder, thereby considerably reducing the probability of affected offspring.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Multiple epiphyseal dysplasia is more frequently caused by dominant mutations in the COMP (EDM1, McKusick 132400) and COL9A2 genes (EDM2, McKusick 600204).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A few other patients and families with features similar to our proband have been described previously and considered to have autosomal recessive MED (EDM4, McKusick 226900).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This observation confirms the existence of this entity and assigns it to the phenotypic spectrum associated with mutations at the DTDST locus..</Disease>
<Disease>Myotonic dystrophy: size- and sex-dependent dynamics of CTG meiotic instability, and somatic mosaicism.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is a progressive neuromuscular disorder which results from elongations of an unstable (CTG) n repeat, located in the 3 untranslated region of the DM gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A correlation has been demonstrated between the increase in the repeat number of this sequence and the severity of the disease.</Disease>
<Disease>However, the clinical status of patients cannot be unambiguously ascertained solely on the basis of the number of CTG repeats.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, the exclusive maternal inheritance of the congenital form remains unexplained.</Disease>

<Disease>Our observation of differently sized repeats in various DM tissues from the same individual may explain why the size of the mutation observed in lymphocytes does not necessarily correlate with the severity and nature of symptoms.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Through a molecular and genetic study of 142 families including 418 DM patients, we have investigated the dynamics of the CTG repeat meiotic instability.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A positive correlation between the size of the repeat and the intergenerational enlargement was observed similarly through male and female meioses for < or = 0.</Disease>
<Disease>5-kb CTG sequences.</Disease>

<Disease>Beyond 0. 5 kb, the intergenerational variation was more important through female meioses, whereas a tendency to compression was observed almost exclusively in male meioses, for > or = 1. 5-kb fragments.</Disease>
<Disease>This implies a size- and sex-dependent meiotic instability.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, segregation analysis supports the hypothesis of a maternal as well as a familial predisposition for the occurrence of the congenital form.</Disease>
<Disease>Finally, this analysis reveals a significant excess of transmitting grandfathers partially accounted for by increased fertility in affected males</Disease>
<Disease>Fatal pyoderma gangrenosum in association with C7 deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is often associated with systemic diseases, it has not been reported in association with congenital complement deficiencies.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We describe an aggressive and ultimately fatal case of PG in a patient with a congenital C7 deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Deficiencies of C7 can be associated with decreased neutrophil chemotaxis, phagocytosis, and opsonization, similar to the immunologic abnormalities described in patients with PG.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our patients decreased complement level, if not directly related to the development of PG, may have contributed to the aggressive nature of her disease..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Mutations in the STA gene at the Xq28 locus have been found in patients with X-linked Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EDMD).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This gene encodes a hitherto unknown protein named emerin.</Disease>
<Disease>To elucidate the subcellular localization of emerin, we raised two antisera against synthetic peptide fragments predicted from emerin cDNA.</Disease>

<Disease>Using both antisera, we found positive nuclear membrane staining in skeletal, cardiac and smooth muscles in the normal controls and in patients with neuromuscular diseases other than EDMD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, a deficiency in immunofluorescent staining of skeletal and cardiac muscle from EDMD patients was observed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A 34 kD protein is immunoreactive with the antisera--the protein is equivalent to that predicted for emerin.</Disease>
<Disease>Together, our findings suggest the specific deficiency of emerin in the nuclear membrane of muscle cells in patients with EDMD..</Disease>

text: <Disease>1-restricted autologous cytolytic T lymphocytes (CTLs) in a human melanoma.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Molecular analysis in familial neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus: early diagnosis of an asymptomatic carrier.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus (FNDI) is an inherited deficiency of the hormone arginine vasopressin (AVP) and is transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the present study we have analyzed the AVP-neurophysin II (AVP-NPII) gene in a Spanish kindred.</Disease>
<Disease>Studies were performed on seven members (four clinically affected) of the family.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients were diagnosed at the Hospital Universitario Gregorio Maranon (Madrid, Spain).</Disease>
<Disease>The entire coding region of the AVP-NPII gene of all family members was amplified by PCR and sequenced.</Disease>
<Disease>All affected individuals presented a missense mutation (G1757-- > A) that replaces glycine at position 23 with arginine within the NPII domain.</Disease>
<Disease>The substitution was confirmed by restriction endonuclease analysis and was present in heterozygosis.</Disease>
<Disease>Additionally, one of the asymptomatic relatives (a girl 8 months old at the time of study) was identified as carrier of the same mutation and developed the disease 3 months later.</Disease>

<Disease>The alteration found in the second exon of the gene in this family seems to be responsible for the disease, as all individuals harboring the mutation had been previously diagnosed or have eventually developed FNDI.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of the molecular defect underlying FNDI in affected families is a powerful tool for early asymptomatic diagnosis in infants..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sialophorin, a surface sialoglycoprotein defective in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, is involved in human T lymphocyte proliferation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mAb L10 was used to determine the distribution and the function of sialophorin, the heavily glycosylated surface molecule that is deficient/defective in lymphocytes of patients with the X-linked immunodeficiency Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Dual-parameter FACS analysis indicated that sialophorin is expressed on CD4 + and CD8 + lymphocytes, on a subpopulation of peripheral blood B lymphocytes, on all thymocytes, and on a subpopulation of bone marrow cells.</Disease>
<Disease>Functional studies demonstrated that L10 mAb stimulates the proliferation of peripheral blood T lymphocytes as measured by stimulation of [3H] thymidine incorporation.</Disease>
<Disease>The time course and magnitude of increased [3H] thymidine incorporation by T lymphocytes in response to L10 mAb paralleled that induced by anti-CD3 mAb.</Disease>
<Disease>Effective stimulation was dependent on the presence of monocytes and the Fc portion of L10 mAb.</Disease>

<Disease>Stimulation of lymphocytes by L10, like stimulation by anti-CD3 mAb, involves increased expression of 4F2, HLA-DR, and IL-2-R. These observations suggest that sialophorin functions in T cell activation..</Disease>
<Disease>Characterization of the rat spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Machado-Joseph disease (MJD) belongs to a group of clinically and genetically heterogeneous neurodegenerative disorders characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The disease-causing mutation has recently been identified as an unstable and expanded (CAG) n trinucleotide repeat in a novel gene of unknown function.</Disease>
<Disease>In Caucasians, repeat expansions in the MJD1 gene have also been found in patients with the clinically distinct autosomal dominant spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 (SCA3).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In order to gain insight into the biology of the MJD1/SCA3 gene we cloned the rat homologue and studied its expression.</Disease>
<Disease>The rat and human ataxin-3 genes are highly homologous with an overall sequence identity of approximately 88%.</Disease>
<Disease>However, the C-terminal end of the putative protein differs strongly from the published human sequence.</Disease>

<Disease>The (CAG) n block in the rat cDNA consists of just three interrupted units suggesting that a long polyglutamine stretch is not essential for the normal function of the ataxin-3 protein in rodents.</Disease>
<Disease>The expression pattern of the SCA3 gene in various rat and human tissues was investigated by Northern blot analyses.</Disease>
<Disease>The mature transcript is approximately 6 kb in length.</Disease>
<Disease>In rat testis, a smaller transcript of 1.</Disease>
<Disease>3</Disease>
<Disease>kb was identified.</Disease>
<Disease>Transcription of rsca3 was detected in most rat tissues including brain.</Disease>
<Disease>Analyzing the expression level of the SCA3 gene in several human brain sections revealed no significant higher mRNA level in regions predominantly affected in MJD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus additional molecules and/or regulatory events are necessary to explain the exclusive degeneration of certain brain areas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma PAX3/FKHR fusion protein is a transcriptional activator.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chimeric transcription factors, created by gene fusions as the result of chromosomal translocations, have been implicated in the pathogenesis of several pathologically disparate solid tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The PAX3/FKHR fusion gene, formed by a t (2; 13) (q35; q14) in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, encodes a hybrid protein that contains both PAX3 DNA binding domains, the paired box and homeodomain, linked to the bisected DNA binding domain of FKHR, a member of the forkhead family of transcription factors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here we report that PAX3 and PAX3/FKHR display similar, but not identical transactivation activities when tested with model Pax recognition sequences.</Disease>

<Disease>No functional role could be ascribed solely to the residual FKHR binding domain present in the fusion protein, but FKHR was found to contribute a strong carboxyl terminal activation domain replacing the one located in the unrearranged PAX3 gene.</Disease>
<Disease>We show that the native PAX3/FKHR protein present in tumor cells with this translocation has transcriptional characteristics similar to the in vitro expressed protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The ability of the PAX3/FKHR hybrid protein to bind DNA in a sequence specific manner and to transactivate the expression of artificial reporter genes suggests that its aberrant expression could subvert the transcriptional programs that normally control the growth, differentiation, and survival of primitive myogenic precursors in vivo..</Disease>
<Disease>Myotonia levior is a chloride channel disorder.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The group of dominant non-dystrophic myotonias, comprising disorders characterized by clinically similar forms of myogenic muscle stiffness, is genetically inhomogeneous.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Dominant myotonia congenita (Thomsens disease) is linked to CLCN1, the gene encoding the major muscle chloride channel, localized on chromosome 7q35.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, dominant myotonias sensitive to potassium are caused by point mutations in SCN4A on chromosome 17q, the gene for the alpha subunit of the adult skeletal muscle sodium channel.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No linkage or molecular genetic data are as yet available on myotonia levior characterized by milder symptoms and later onset of myotonia than in Thomsens disease, and absence of muscle hypertrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report a CLCN1 Gln-552-Arg substitution for a family with dominant inheritance previously diagnosed to have myotonia levior.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, this disorder appears as a variant of Thomsens disease due to mutations leading to low clinical expressivity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, we report a novel Ile-290-Met CLCN1 mutation for a typical Thomsen pedigree.</Disease>

<Disease>In another family previously diagnosed as having Thomsens disease, we unexpectedly found a CLCN1 14 bp deletion known to cause recessive myotonia, and a rare Trp-118-Gly polymorphism..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Markedly accelerated catabolism of apolipoprotein A-II (ApoA-II) and high density lipoproteins containing ApoA-II in classic lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase deficiency and fish-eye disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Classic (complete) lecithin  cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) deficiency and Fish-eye disease (partial LCAT deficiency) are genetic syndromes associated with markedly decreased plasma levels of high density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol but not with an increased risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We investigated the metabolism of the HDL apolipoproteins (apo) apoA-I and apoA-II in a total of five patients with LCAT deficiency, one with classic LCAT deficiency and four with Fish-eye disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Plasma levels of apoA-II were decreased to a proportionately greater extent (23% of normal) than apoA-I (30% of normal).</Disease>

<Disease>In addition, plasma concentrations of HDL particles containing both apoA-I and apoA-II (LpA-I  A-II) were much lower (18% of normal) than those of particles containing only apoA-I (LpA-I) (51% of normal).</Disease>

<Disease>The metabolic basis for the low levels of apoA-II and LpA-I  A-II was investigated in all five patients using both exogenous radiotracer and endogenous stable isotope labeling techniques.</Disease>
<Disease>The mean plasma residence time of apoA-I was decreased at 2. 08 +/- 0.</Disease>
<Disease>27 d (controls 4. 74 +/- 0. 65 days); however, the residence time of apoA-II was even shorter at 1.</Disease>
<Disease>66 +/- 0.</Disease>
<Disease>24 d (controls 5. 25 +/- 0. 61 d).</Disease>

<Disease>In addition, the catabolism of apoA-I in LpA-I  A-II was substantially faster than that of apoA-I in LpA-I. In summary, genetic syndromes of either complete or partial LCAT deficiency result in low levels of HDL through preferential hypercatabolism of apoA-II and HDL particles containing apoA-II.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Because LpA-I has been proposed to be more protective than LpA-I  A-II against atherosclerosis, this selective effect on the metabolism of LpA-I  A-II may provide a potential explanation why patients with classic LCAT deficiency and Fish-eye disease are not at increased risk for premature atherosclerosis despite markedly decreased levels of HDL cholesterol and apoA-I</Disease>

text: <Disease>The identical 5' splice-site acceptor mutation in five attenuated APC families from Newfoundland demonstrates a founder effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Inherited mutations of the APC gene predispose carriers to multiple adenomatous polyps of the colon and rectum and to colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations located at the extreme 5 end of the APC gene, however, are associated with a less severe disease known as attenuated adenomatous polyposis coli (AAPC).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Many individuals with AAPC develop relatively few colorectal polyps but are still at high risk for colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report here the identification of a 5 APC germline mutation in five separately ascertained AAPC families from Newfoundland, Canada.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This disease-causing mutation is a single basepair change (G to A) in the splice-acceptor region of APC intron 3 that creates a mutant RNA without exon 4 of APC.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The observation of the same APC mutation in five families from the same geographic area demonstrates a founder effect.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, the identification of this germline mutation strengthens the correlation between the 5 location of an APC disease-causing mutation and the attenuated polyposis phenotype..</Disease>

<Disease>Linkage analysis in X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy and application in post- and prenatal diagnosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have performed linkage analysis with the DNA markers DXS52 and the clotting factor VIII gene (F8C), in several large families with X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The tight linkage to DXS52 could be extended giving a maximal LOD score of 22.</Disease>
<Disease>5</Disease>
<Disease>at 1 cM. F8C was also tightly linked to ALD with a maximal LOD score of 7. 8 without recombination.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Multipoint linkage analysis with the markers DXS304, DXS52, and F8C indicated that both the gene for ALD and for F8C are distal to DXS52.</Disease>

<Disease>Multicentric origin of hemochromatosis gene (HFE) mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Genetic hemochromatosis (GH) is believed to be a disease restricted to those of European ancestry.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In northwestern Europe, > 80% of GH patients are homozygous for one mutation, the substitution of tyrosine for cysteine at position 282 (C282Y) in the unprocessed protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In a proportion of GH patients, two mutations are present, C282Y and H63D.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The clinical significance of this second mutation is such that it appears to predispose 1% -2% of compound heterozygotes to expression of the disease.</Disease>

<Disease>The distribution of the two mutations differ, C282Y being limited to those of northwestern European ancestry and H63D being found at allele frequencies > 5%, in Europe, in countries bordering the Mediterranean, in the Middle East, and in the Indian subcontinent.</Disease>
<Disease>The C282Y mutation occurs on a haplotype that extends </= 6 Mb, suggesting that this mutation has arisen during the past 2, 000 years.</Disease>
<Disease>The H63D mutation is older and does not occur on such a large extended haplotype, the haplotype in this case extending </= 700 kb.</Disease>
<Disease>Here we report the finding of the H63D and C282Y mutations on new haplotypes.</Disease>
<Disease>In Sri Lanka we have found H63D on three new haplotypes and have found C282Y on one new haplotype, demonstrating that these mutations have arisen independently on this island.</Disease>
<Disease>These results suggest that the HFE gene has been the subject of selection pressure.</Disease>
<Disease>These selection pressures could be due to infectious diseases, environmental conditions,  or other genetic disorders such as anemia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Identification and localization of mutations at the Lesch-Nyhan locus by ribonuclease A cleavage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Many mutations leading to human disease are the result of single DNA base pair changes that cannot be identified by Southern analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>This has prompted the development of alternative assays for point mutation detection.</Disease>

<Disease>The recently described ribonuclease A cleavage procedure, with a polyuridylic acid-paper affinity chromatography step, has been used to identify the mutational lesions in the hypoxanthine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) messenger RNAs of patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Distinctive ribonuclease A cleavage patterns were identified in messenger RNA from 5 of 14 Lesch-Nyhan patients who were chosen because no HPRT Southern or Northern blotting pattern changes had been found.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This approach now allows HPRT mutation detection in 50 percent of the cases of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The polyuridylic acid-paper affinity procedure provides a general method for analysis of low abundance messenger RNAs..</Disease>

<Disease>MEFV-Gene analysis in armenian patients with Familial Mediterranean fever: diagnostic value and unfavorable renal prognosis of the M694V homozygous genotype-genetic and therapeutic implications.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a recessively inherited disorder that is common in patients of Armenian ancestry.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To date, its diagnosis, which can be made only retrospectively, is one of exclusion, based entirely on nonspecific clinical signs that result from serosal inflammation and that may lead to unnecessary surgery.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Renal amyloidosis, prevented by colchicine, is the most severe complication of FMF, a disorder associated with mutations in the MEFV gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To evaluate the diagnostic and prognostic value of MEFV-gene analysis, we investigated 90 Armenian FMF patients from 77 unrelated families that were not selected through genetic-linkage analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Eight mutations, one of which (R408Q) is new, were found to account for 93% of the 163 independent FMF alleles, with both FMF alleles identified in 89% of the patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In several instances, family studies provided molecular evidence for pseudodominant transmission and incomplete penetrance of the disease phenotype.</Disease>

<Disease>The M694V homozygous genotype was found to be associated with a higher prevalence of renal amyloidosis and arthritis, compared with other genotypes (P =. 0002 and P =. 006, respectively).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The demonstration of both the diagnostic and prognostic value of MEFV analysis and particular modes of inheritance should lead to new ways for management of FMF-including genetic counseling and therapeutic decisions in affected families.</Disease>
<Disease>Identification and localization of huntingtin in brain and human lymphoblastoid cell lines with anti-fusion protein antibodies.</Disease>
<Disease>The Huntington disease (HD) phenotype is associated with expansion of a trinucleotide repeat in the IT15 gene, which is predicted to encode a 348-kDa protein named huntington.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We used polyclonal and monoclonal anti-fusion protein antibodies to identify native huntingtin in rat, monkey, and human.</Disease>

<Disease>Western blots revealed a protein with the expected molecular weight which is present in the soluble fraction of rat and monkey brain tissues and lymphoblastoid cells from control cases.</Disease>

<Disease>In lymphoblastoid cell lines from juvenile-onset heterozygote HD cases, both normal and mutant huntingtin are expressed, and increasing repeat expansion leads to lower levels of the mutant protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Immunocytochemistry indicates that huntingtin is located in neurons throughout the brain, with the highest levels evident in larger neurons.</Disease>
<Disease>In the human striatum, huntingtin is enriched in a patch-like distribution, potentially corresponding to the first areas affected in HD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Subcellular localization of huntingtin is consistent with a cytosolic protein primarily found in somatodendritic regions.</Disease>
<Disease>Huntingtin appears to particularly associate with microtubules, although some is also associated with synaptic vesicles.</Disease>

<Disease>On the basis of the localization of huntingtin in association with microtubules, we speculate that the mutation impairs the cytoskeletal anchoring or transport of mitochondria, vesicles, or other organelles or molecules..</Disease>
<Disease>Correlation between the location of germ-line mutations in the APC gene and the number of colorectal polyps in familial adenomatous polyposis patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recently we have isolated the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene which causes familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), and its germ-line mutations in a substantial number of FAP patients have been identified.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>On the basis of this information, we compared the location of germ-line mutations in the APC gene in 22 unrelated patients (12 of whom have been reported previously) with the number of colorectal polyps developed in FAP patients; 17 were sparse types and five were profuse types.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All but one of the mutations were considered to cause truncation of the gene product by frame-shift due to deletion (14 cases) or nonsense mutation (seven cases).</Disease>

<Disease>The location of the germ-line mutations seems to correlate with the two clinical types; germ-line mutations in five FAP patients with profuse polyps were observed between codon 1250 and codon 1464, whereas mutations in 17 FAP patients with fewer polyps were observed in the other regions of the APC gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The result suggests that the number of colorectal polyps in FAP patients may be associated with a difference in the stability or biological function of the truncated APC protein..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Duchenne/Becker muscular dystrophy: correlation of phenotype by electroretinography with sites of dystrophin mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The dark-adapted electroretinogram (ERG) of patients with Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy (DMD/BMD) shows a marked reduction in b-wave amplitude.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Genotype-phenotype studies of mouse models for DMD show position-specific effects of the mutations upon the phenotype  mice with 5 defects of dystrophin have normal ERGs, those with defects in the central region have a normal b-wave amplitude associated with prolonged implicit times for both the b-wave and oscillatory potentials, and mice with 3 defects have a phenotype similar to that seen in  DMD/BMD patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mouse studies suggest a key role for the carboxyl terminal dystrophin isoform, Dp260, in retinal electrophysiology.</Disease>

<Disease>We have undertaken a systematic evaluation of DMD/BMD patients through clinical examination and review of the literature in order to determine whether the position-specific effects of mutations noted in the mouse are present in man.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have found that, in man, a wider variation of DMD defects correlate with reductions in the b-wave amplitude.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Individuals with normal ERGs have mutations predominantly located 5 of the transcript initiation site of Dp260.</Disease>
<Disease>Our results suggest that the most important determinant in the ERG b-wave phenotype is the mutation position, rather than muscle disease severity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Forty-six per cent of patients with mutations 5 of the Dp260 transcript start site have abnormal ERGs, as opposed to 94% with more distal mutations.</Disease>

<Disease>The human genotype-phenotype correlations are consistent with a role for Dp260 in normal retinal electrophysiology and may also reflect the expression of other C-terminal dystrophin isoforms and their contributions to retinal signal transmission..</Disease>
<Disease>Molecular characterization of two galactosemia mutations and one polymorphism: implications for structure-function analysis of human galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report here the molecular characterization of two galactosemia mutations, L74P and F171S, and one polymorphism, S135L, in human galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Both galactosemia mutations result in reduced enzymatic activity when reconstructed in the cDNA and overexpressed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The polymorphism, in contrast, has near normal activity.</Disease>

<Disease>Both mutations affect evolutionarily conserved residues, suggesting that they are functionally important, while the polymorphism occurs in a nonconserved domain which is presumably not critical for enzymatic function.</Disease>
<Disease>The F171S mutation is close to the putative active-site nucleophile.</Disease>

<Disease>Our data further support the notion of molecular heterogeneity of galactosemia and suggest that galactosemia mutations and GALT polymorphisms may be useful tools in highlighting different functional domains in human GALT..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Gaucher disease: the origins of the Ashkenazi Jewish N370S and 84GG acid beta-glucosidase mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Type 1 Gaucher disease (GD), a non-neuronopathic lysosomal storage disorder, results from the deficient activity of acid beta-glucosidase (GBA).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Type 1 disease is panethnic but is more prevalent in individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish (AJ) descent.</Disease>
<Disease>Of the causative GBA mutations, N370S is particularly frequent in the AJ population, (q approximately.</Disease>
<Disease>03), whereas the 84GG insertion (q approximately. 003) occurs exclusively in the Ashkenazim.</Disease>

<Disease>To investigate the genetic history of these mutations in the AJ population, short tandem repeat (STR) markers were used to map a 9. 3-cM region containing the GBA locus and to genotype 261 AJ N370S chromosomes, 60 European non-Jewish N370S chromosomes, and 62 AJ 84GG chromosomes.</Disease>

<Disease>A highly conserved haplotype at four markers flanking GBA (PKLR, D1S1595, D1S2721, and D1S2777) was observed on both the AJ chromosomes and the non-Jewish N370S chromosomes, suggesting the occurrence of a founder common to both populations.</Disease>
<Disease>Of note, the presence of different divergent haplotypes suggested the occurrence of de novo, recurrent N370S mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, a different conserved haplotype at these markers was identified on the 84GG chromosomes, which was unique to the AJ population.</Disease>

<Disease>On the basis of the linkage disequilibrium (LD) delta values, the non-Jewish European N370S chromosomes had greater haplotype diversity and less LD at the markers flanking the conserved haplotype than did the AJ N370S chromosomes.</Disease>
<Disease>This finding is consistent with the presence of the N370S mutation in the non-Jewish European population prior to the founding of the AJ population.</Disease>
<Disease>Coalescence analyses for the N370S and 84GG mutations estimated similar coalescence times, of 48 and 55.5 generations ago, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>The results of these studies are consistent with a significant bottleneck occurring in the AJ population during the first millennium, when the population became established in Europe.</Disease>
<Disease>Investigation of thermoregulatory characteristics in patients with Prader-Willi syndrome.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A survey instrument is used to assess temperature regulation characteristics in children with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) compared to 3 control groups  sibs of PWS patients (SIB), neurodevelopmentally handicapped children (ND), and age and gender matched well children (WC).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Significant differences were found between PWS patients, SIB controls, and WC controls in the prevalence of febrile convulsions, fever-associated symptoms, and temperature less than 94 degrees F.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No differences were noted in any variable between the PWS patients and the ND controls, suggesting that these abnormalities are not unique to PWS, but can occur in any neurodevelopmentally handicapped individual, further suggesting these do not necessarily reflect syndrome-specific hypothalamic abnormalities..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Abnormal high density lipoproteins in cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The plasma lipoprotein profiles and high density lipoproteins (HDL) were characterized in patients with the genetic disease cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis (CTX).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Abnormalities in the HDL may contribute to their increased atherogenesis and excessive deposits of tissue sterols in the presence of low or low-normal concentrations of plasma cholesterol (165 +/- 25 mg/dl) and low density lipoproteins (LDL).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mean HDL-cholesterol concentration in the CTX plasmas was 14.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>5 +/- 3. 2 mg/dl, about one-third the normal value.</Disease>
<Disease>The low HDL-cholesterol reflects a low concentration and an abnormal lipid composition of the plasma HDL.</Disease>
<Disease>Relative to normal HDL, the cholesteryl esters are low, free cholesterol and phospholipids essentially normal, and triglycerides increased.</Disease>
<Disease>The ratio of apoprotein (apo) to total cholesterol in the HDL of CTX was two to three times greater than normal.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the CTX HDL, the ratio of apoAI to apoAII was high, the proportion of apoC low, and a normally minor form of apoAI increased relative to other forms.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The HDL in electron micrographs appeared normal morphologically and in particle size.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>As a consequence, it is probable that the normal functions of the HDL, possibly including modulation of LDL-cholesterol uptake and the removal of excess cholesterol from peripheral tissues, are perturbed significantly in this disease.</Disease>
<Disease>Splicing defects in the ataxia-telangiectasia gene, ATM: underlying mutations and consequences.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations resulting in defective splicing constitute a significant proportion (30/62 [48%]) of a new series of mutations in the ATM gene in patients with ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) that were detected by the protein-truncation assay followed by sequence analysis of genomic DNA.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Fewer than half of the splicing mutations involved the canonical AG splice-acceptor site or GT splice-donor site.</Disease>

<Disease>A higher percentage of mutations occurred at less stringently conserved sites, including silent mutations of the last nucleotide of exons, mutations in nucleotides other than the conserved AG and GT in the consensus splice sites, and creation of splice-acceptor or splice-donor sites in either introns or exons.</Disease>

<Disease>These splicing mutations led to a variety of consequences, including exon skipping and, to a lesser degree, intron retention, activation of cryptic splice sites, or creation of new splice sites.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, 5 of 12 nonsense mutations and 1 missense mutation were associated with deletion in the cDNA of the exons in which the mutations occurred.</Disease>
<Disease>No ATM protein was detected by western blotting in any AT cell line in which splicing mutations were identified.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Several cases of exon skipping in both normal controls and patients for whom no underlying defect could be found in genomic DNA were also observed, suggesting caution in the interpretation of exon deletions observed in ATM cDNA when there is no accompanying identification of genomic mutations..</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A major gene locus for PLS has been mapped to a 2. 8 cM interval on chromosome 11q14.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Correlation of physical and genetic maps of this interval indicate it includes at least 40 ESTs and six known genes including the lysosomal protease cathepsin C gene (CTSC).</Disease>

text: <Disease>The 4. 7 kb CTSC gene consists of two exons.</Disease>

text: <Disease>An exon 1 nonsense mutation (856C-- > T) introduces a premature stop codon at amino acid 286.</Disease>

<Disease>A substitution in codon 429 (2931G-- > A) introducing a premature termination codon.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Identification of a single nucleotide change in the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase gene (HPRTYale) responsible for Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Previous characterization of a mutant form of HPRT, HPRTYale, from a subject with the Lesch-Nyhan syndrome revealed normal mRNA and protein concentrations, no residual catalytic activity, and cathodal migration upon PAGE.</Disease>

<Disease>Inclusion of the bulky arginine side chain in place of glycine probably disrupts protein folding as well.</Disease>

<Disease>Molecular detection of chromosomal translocations that disrupt the putative retinoblastoma susceptibility locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A candidate DNA sequence with many of the properties predicted for the retinoblastoma susceptibility (RB1) locus has been cloned (S. H. Friend, R. Bernards, S. Rogelj, R. A. Weinberg, J. M. Rapaport, D. M. Albert, and T. P. Dryja, Nature [London] 323  643-645, 1986).</Disease>

text: <Disease>The large size of this gene (ca.</Disease>
<Disease>200 kilobases [kb]) and its multiple dispersed exons (Wiggs et al., N. Engl.</Disease>
<Disease>J. Med. 318  151-157, 1988) complicate molecular screening strategies important in prenatal and presymptomatic diagnosis and in carrier detection.</Disease>

<Disease>Here we used field inversion gel electrophoresis (FIGE) to construct a restriction map of approximately 1, 000 kb of DNA surrounding the RB1 locus and to detect the translocation breakpoints in three retinoblastoma patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DNA probes from either the 5 or 3 end of the gene were used to detect a 250-kb EagI restriction fragment in DNA from unaffected individuals.</Disease>

<Disease>Analysis of the breakpoint in one translocation cell line allowed the RB1 gene to be oriented with its 5 end toward the centromere.</Disease>

<Disease>The 5 end of the gene also appeared to be associated with a clustering of sites for several infrequently cleaving restriction enzymes, indicating the presence of an HpaII tiny fragment island.</Disease>

<Disease>The detection and mapping of the translocation breakpoints of all three retinoblastoma patients to within the putative RB1 gene substantiated the authenticity of this candidate sequence and demonstrated the utility of FIGE in detecting chromosomal rearrangements affecting this locus.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A candidate Wilms tumor gene, WT1, from the 11p13 chromosome region has recently been cloned.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Macular dystrophy associated with mutations at codon 172 in the human retinal degeneration slow gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
