text: <Disease>BACKGROUND  Recently, mutations in the retinal degeneration slow (rds) gene which codes for peripherin-rds have been implicated as a cause of autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Because this gene is expressed in both rods and cones, mutations in the rds gene might be expected to cause degeneration affecting either the scotopic or photopic systems.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations at codon 172 of the rds gene have been identified in three families with autosomal dominantly inherited, progressive macular dystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  Affected individuals underwent ophthalmic examination, scotopic perimetry, dark adaptometry, measurement of color-contrast sensitivity, and electroretinography to characterize the photoreceptor dysfunction.</Disease>

<Disease>RESULTS  In all but one affected member, symptoms of progressive central visual loss developed in the third or fourth decade of life accompanied by central scotoma and well-demarcated atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium and choriocapillaris of the macula.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In general, cone and rod thresholds were elevated, and color-contrast sensitivity was absent in the central visual field.</Disease>
<Disease>Peripherally, the scotopic sensitivities were normal, as was the recovery from bleach.</Disease>
<Disease>Cone electroretinograms were diminished in amplitude, and delayed in all affected adults except one.</Disease>
<Disease>Rod electroretinograms were normal or near normal in amplitude, and had normal implicit times.</Disease>
<Disease>Affected asymptomatic children had macular changes, abnormal color-contrast sensitivity, and reduced pattern and cone electroretinograms.</Disease>

<Disease>CONCLUSION  These results indicate that mutations in the rds gene can be expressed as a macular dystrophy, with evidence of primary cone dysfunction and preservation of peripheral rod function..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase variants: Gd (+) Alexandra associated with neonatal jaundice and Gd (-) Camperdown in a young man with lamellar cataracts.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Two male subjects are described, with unusual clinical presentations and with hitherto undescribed G6PD variants.</Disease>

<Disease>The first, of Italian extraction, suffered from severe neonatal jaundice following maternal ingestion of fresh broad beans (Vicia fava) both prenatally and postnatally  the expression of the enzymatic defect was much more severe in the neonatal period than on retesting in adolescence, when biochemical characterization showed unique features which justify designation as a new variant Gd (+) Alexandra.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The second patient, a boy of Maltese extraction who was found to have bilateral lamellar cataracts at the age of 4 years, was identified as G6PD deficient only as a result of a survey of children of Mediterranean origin with unexplained cataract formation; he has approximately 15% of normal enzyme activity, with another unique combination of biochemical characteristics which has led to its designation as Gd (-) Camperdown.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although this association may be coincidental, it prompts further attention to the possibility that under certain circumstances G6PD deficiency may favor cataract formation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The two cases illustrate the value of characterization of the mutant enzyme whenever unexpected clinical or laboratory results are obtained..</Disease>
<Disease>DNA restriction fragments associated with alpha 1-antitrypsin indicate a single origin for deficiency allele PI Z.</Disease>

<Disease>The alpha 1-protease inhibitor, or alpha-antitrypsin (AAT), a major plasma inhibitor of leukocyte elastase and bacterial proteases, is encoded at the PI locus on chromosome 14 (14q24. 3-q32.</Disease>
<Disease>1)</Disease>
<Disease>.</Disease>

<Disease>A deficiency of AAT in individuals homozygous for the PI Z allele occurs in about 1 in 2, 000-8, 000 caucasians and is associated with an increased risk of early adult onset emphysema and liver disease in childhood.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have now used DNA polymorphisms associated with the AAT gene to investigate the origin of the PI Z allele.</Disease>
<Disease>Using two genomic probes extending into the 5 and 3 flanking regions, respectively, we have identified eight polymorphic restriction sites.</Disease>
<Disease>Extensive linkage disequilibrium occurs throughout the probed region with the PI Z allele, but not with normal PI M alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>The Z allele occurs mainly with one haplotype, indicating a single, relatively recent, origin in caucasians</Disease>
<Disease>Myotonic dystrophy in transgenic mice expressing an expanded CUG repeat.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM), the most common form of muscular dystrophy in adult humans, results from expansion of a CTG repeat in the 3 untranslated region of the DMPK gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mutant DMPK messenger RNA (mRNA) contains an expanded CUG repeat and is retained in the nucleus.</Disease>
<Disease>We have expressed an untranslated CUG repeat in an unrelated mRNA in transgenic mice.</Disease>
<Disease>Mice that expressed expanded CUG repeats developed myotonia and myopathy, whereas mice expressing a nonexpanded repeat did not.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, transcripts with expanded CUG repeats are sufficient to generate a DM phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This result supports a role for RNA gain of function in disease pathogenesis..</Disease>
<Disease>Submicroscopic deletion in cousins with Prader-Willi syndrome causes a grandmatrilineal inheritance pattern: effects of imprinting.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) critical region on 15q11-q13 is subject to imprinting.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PWS becomes apparent when genes on the paternally inherited chromosome are not expressed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial PWS is rare.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report on a family in which a male and a female paternal first cousin both have PWS with cytogenetically normal karyotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis shows a submicroscopic deletion of SNRPN, but not the closely associated loci D15S10, D15S11, D15S63, and GABRB3.</Disease>
<Disease>The cousins fathers and two paternal aunts have the same deletion and are clinically normal.</Disease>
<Disease>The grandmother of the cousins is deceased and not available for study, and their grandfather is not deleted for SNRPN.</Disease>
<Disease>DNA methylation analysis of D15S63 is consistent with an abnormality of the imprinting center associated with PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>"</Disease>
<Disease>Grandmatrilineal " inheritance occurs when a woman with deletion of an imprinted, paternally expressed gene is at risk of having affected grandchildren through her sons.</Disease>
<Disease>In this case, PWS does not become evident as long as the deletion is passed through the matrilineal line.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This represents a unique inheritance pattern due to imprinting..</Disease>
<Disease>Expression and imprinting of MAGEL2 suggest a role in Prader-willi syndrome and the homologous murine imprinting phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is caused by the loss of expression of imprinted genes in chromosome 15q11-q13.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Affected individuals exhibit neonatal hypotonia, developmental delay and childhood-onset obesity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Necdin, a protein implicated in the terminal differentiation of neurons, is the only PWS candidate gene to reduce viability when disrupted in a mouse model.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In this study, we have characterized MAGEL2 (also known as NDNL1), a gene with 51% amino acid sequence similarity to necdin and located 41 kb distal to NDN in the PWS deletion region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MAGEL2 is expressed predominantly in brain, the primary tissue affected in PWS and in several fetal tissues as shown by northern blot analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MAGEL2 is imprinted with monoallelic expression in control brain, and paternal-only expression in the central nervous system as demonstrated by its lack of expression in brain from a PWS-affected individual.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The orthologous mouse gene (Magel2) is located within 150 kb of NDN , is imprinted with paternal-only expression and is expressed predominantly in late developmental stages and adult brain as shown by northern blotting, RT-PCR and whole-mount RNA in situ hybridization.</Disease>
<Disease>Magel2 distribution partially overlaps that of NDN , with strong expression being detected in the central nervous system in mid-gestation mouse embryos by in situ hybridization.</Disease>

<Disease>We hypothesize that, although loss of necdin expression may be important in the neonatal presentation of PWS, loss of MAGEL2 may be critical to abnormalities in brain development and dysmorphic features in individuals with PWS..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A single origin of phenylketonuria in Yemenite Jews.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a metabolic disease caused by recessive mutations of the gene encoding the hepatic enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The incidence of PKU varies widely across different geographic areas, and is highest (about 1 in 5, 000 live births) in Ireland and western Scotland, and among Yemenite Jews.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A limited number of point mutations account for most of the PKU cases in the European population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here we report that a single molecular defect--a deletion spanning the third exon of the PAH gene--is responsible for all the PKU cases among the Yemenite Jews.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Examination of a random sample of Yemenite Jews using a molecular probe that detects the carriers of this deletion indicated a high frequency of the defective gene in this community.</Disease>

<Disease>Although the deleted PAH gene was traced to 25 different locations throughout Yemen, family histories and official documents of the Yemenite Jewish community showed that the common ancestor of all the carriers of this genetic defect lived in Sana, the capital of Yemen, before the eighteenth century..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>High resolution genetic analysis suggests one ancestral predisposing haplotype for the origin of the myotonic dystrophy mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation causing myotonic dystrophy (DM) has been identified as an amplification of an unstable trinucleotide (CTG) n repeat in over 99% of the global DM population.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It is in complete linkage disequilibrium with an Alu element polymorphism within the DM kinase gene, suggesting that DM is a consequence of one or few ancestral mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A recent analysis utilizing this polymorphism as well as a flanking dinucleotide marker, suggested that similar to Fragile X syndrome, DM exhibited a founder effect (Imbert et al., 1993 Nature Genet. 4, 72-76).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, the low reproductive fitness of individuals with congenital DM (the endpoint of genetic anticipation in myotonic dystrophy) suggests a higher rate of new mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We present a high resolution genetic analysis of the DM locus using PCR based assays of nine polymorphisms, spanning a physical distance of 30 kb, within and immediately flanking the DM kinase gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The persistent complete allelic association of the DM mutation with all these polymorphisms provides further support to previous observations and suggests more strongly that the DM mutation occurred on the background of a particular haplotype in which the (CTG) n repeat became inherently unstable and therefore predisposed to amplification.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Identification and rapid detection of three Tay-Sachs mutations in the Moroccan Jewish population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Infantile Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) is caused by mutations in the HEXA gene that result in the complete absence of beta-hexosaminidase A activity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It is well known that an elevated frequency of TSD mutations exists among Ashkenazi Jews.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>More recently it has become apparent that elevated carrier frequencies for TSD also occur in several other ethnic groups, including Moroccan Jews, a subgroup of Sephardic Jews.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Elsewhere we reported an in-frame deletion of one of the two adjacent phenylalanine codons at position 304 or 305 (delta F304/305) in one HEXA allele of a Moroccan Jewish TSD patient and in three obligate carriers from six unrelated Moroccan Jewish families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have now identified two additional mutations within exon 5 of the HEXA gene that account for the remaining TSD alleles in the patient and carriers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One of the mutations is a novel C-to-G transversion, resulting in a replacement of Tyr180 by a stop codon.</Disease>
<Disease>The other mutation is a G-to-A transition resulting in an Arg170-to-Gln substitution.</Disease>
<Disease>This mutation is at a CpG site in a Japanese infant with Tay-Sachs disease and was described elsewhere.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Analysis of nine obligate carriers from seven unrelated families showed that four harbor the delta F304/305 mutation, two the Arg170----Gln mutation, and one the Tyr180----Stop mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>We also have developed rapid, nonradioactive assays for the detection of each mutation, which should be helpful for carrier screening..</Disease>
<Disease>Mapping of the mouse homologue of the Wilson disease gene to mouse chromosome 8.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>ATP7B, the gene altered in Wilson disease (WD) patients, lies in a block of homology shared between human chromosome 13q14 and the central region of mouse chromosome 14.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, we have mapped the murine homologue of ATP7B (Atp7b) to mouse chromosome 8 by somatic cell hybrid analysis.</Disease>

<Disease>Analysis of 80 interspecific backcross offspring was used to position Atp7b close to D8Mit3 and another ATPase locus, Atp4b, on mouse chromosome 8. ATP4B lies in 13q34 and is separated from ATP7B by several loci whose mouse homologues map to mouse chromosome 14.</Disease>
<Disease>The assignment of Atp7b to mouse chromosome 8 identifies a previously unrecognized region of homology between this chromosome and human chromosome 13.</Disease>
<Disease>This assignment suggests a possible location for the toxic milk mutation in the mouse, which has been proposed as a homologue of WD..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Characteristics of intergenerational contractions of the CTG repeat in myotonic dystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In myotonic dystrophy (DM), the size of a CTG repeat in the DM kinase gene generally increases in successive generations with clinical evidence of anticipation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, there have also been cases with an intergenerational contraction of the repeat.</Disease>
<Disease>We examined 1, 489 DM parent-offspring pairs, of which 95 (6. 4%) showed such contractions in peripheral blood leukocytes (PBL).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In 56 of the 95 pairs, clinical data allowed an analysis of their anticipation status.</Disease>
<Disease>It is surprising that anticipation occurred in 27 (48%) of these 56 pairs, while none clearly showed a later onset of DM in the symptomatic offspring.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The contraction occurred in 76 (10%) of 753 paternal transmissions and in 19 (3%) of 736 maternal transmissions.</Disease>
<Disease>Anticipation was observed more frequently in maternal (85%) than in paternal (37%) transmissions (P <. 001).</Disease>

<Disease>The parental repeat size correlated with the size of intergenerational contraction (r2 =. 50, P < <. 001), and the slope of linear regression was steeper in paternal (-. 62) than in maternal (-. 30) transmissions (P < <. 001).</Disease>
<Disease>Sixteen DM parents had multiple DM offspring with the CTG repeat contractions.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This frequency was higher than the frequency expected from the probability of the repeat contractions (6. 4%) and the size of DM sib population (1. 54 DM offspring per DM parent, in 968 DM parents).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that (1) intergenerational contractions of the CTG repeat in leukocyte DNA frequently accompanies apparent anticipation, especially when DM is maternally transmitted, and (2) the paternal origin of the repeat and the presence of the repeat contraction in a sibling increase the probability of the CTG repeat contraction</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Splice-site mutation in the PDS gene may result in intrafamilial variability for deafness in Pendred syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pendred syndrome is a recessive inherited disorder that consists of developmental abnormalities of the cochlea, sensorineural hearing loss, and diffuse thyroid enlargement (goiter).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This disorder may account for up to 10% of cases of hereditary deafness.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The disease gene (PDS) has been mapped to chromosome 7q22-q31, and encodes a chloride-iodide transport protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We performed mutation analysis of individual exons of the PDS gene in one Spanish family that shows intrafamilial variability of the deafness phenotype (two patients with profound and one with moderate-severe deafness).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We identified a new splice-site mutation affecting intron 4 of the PDS gene, at nucleotide position 639 + 7.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RNA analysis from lymphocytes of the affected patients showed that mutation 639 +</Disease>
<Disease>7A-- ></Disease>
<Disease>G generates a new donor splice site, leading to an mRNA with an insertion of six nucleotides from intron 4 of PDS.</Disease>

<Disease>Since the newly created donor splice site is likely to compete with the normal one, variations of the levels of normal and aberrant transcripts of the PDS gene in the cochlea may explain the variability in the deafness presentation..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Heterozygous loss of Six5 in mice is sufficient to cause ocular cataracts.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by skeletal muscle wasting, myotonia, cardiac arrhythmia, hyperinsulinaemia, mental retardation and ocular cataracts.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The genetic defect in DM is a CTG repeat expansion located in the 3 untranslated region of DMPK and 5 of a homeodomain-encoding gene, SIX5 (formerly DMAHP; refs 2-5).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There are three mechanisms by which CTG expansion can result in DM.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>First, repeat expansion may alter the processing or transport of the mutant DMPK mRNA and consequently reduce DMPK levels.</Disease>
<Disease>Second, CTG expansion may establish a region of heterochromatin 3 of the repeat sequence and decrease SIX5 transcription.</Disease>
<Disease>Third, toxic effects of the repeat expansion may be intrinsic to the repeated elements at the level of DNA or RNA (refs 10, 11).</Disease>

<Disease>Previous studies have demonstrated that a dose-dependent loss of Dm15 (the mouse DMPK homologue) in mice produces a partial DM phenotype characterized by decreased development of skeletal muscle force and cardiac conduction disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To test the role of Six5 loss in DM, we have analysed a strain of mice in which Six5 was deleted.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our results demonstrate that the rate and severity of cataract formation is inversely related to Six5 dosage and is temporally progressive.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Six5 +/- and Six5-/- mice show increased steady-state levels of the Na +/K +</Disease>
<Disease>-ATPase alpha-1 subunit and decreased Dm15 mRNA levels.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, altered ion homeostasis within the lens may contribute to cataract formation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>As ocular cataracts are a characteristic feature of DM, these results demonstrate that decreased SIX5 transcription is important in the aetiology of DM.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our data support the hypothesis that DM is a contiguous gene syndrome associated with the partial loss of both DMPK and SIX5..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cis and trans effects of the myotonic dystrophy (DM) mutation in a cell culture model.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation causing myotonic dystrophy (DM) has been identified as a CTG expansion in the 3-untranslated region (3-UTR) of the DM protein kinase gene (DMPK), but the mechanism (s) of pathogenesis remain unknown.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Studies using DM patient materials have often produced confusing results.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, to study the effects of the DM mutation in a controlled environment, we have established a cell culture model system using C2C12 mouse myoblasts.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>By expressing chimeric reporter constructs containing a reporter gene fused to a human DMPK 3-UTR, we identified both cis and trans effects that are mediated by the DM mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our data show that a mutant DMPK 3-UTR, with as few as 57 CTGs, had a negative cis effect on protein expression and resulted in the aggregation of reporter transcripts into discrete nuclear foci.</Disease>
<Disease>We determined by deletion analysis that an expanded (CTG) (n) tract alone was sufficient to mediate these cis effects.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, in contrast to the normal DMPK 3-UTR mRNA, a mutant DMPK 3-UTR mRNA with (CUG) (200) selectively inhibited myogenic differentiation of C2C12 myoblasts.</Disease>

<Disease>Genetic analysis and the Cre- loxP system were used to clearly demonstrate that the myoblast fusion defect could be rescued by eliminating the expression of the mutant DMPK 3-UTR transcript.</Disease>
<Disease>Characterization of spontaneous deletion events mapped the inhibitory effect to the (CTG) (n) expansion and/or the 3 end of the DMPK 3-UTR.</Disease>

<Disease>These results provide evidence that the DM mutation acts in cis to reduce protein production (consistent with DMPK haploinsufficiency) and in trans as a riboregulator to inhibit myogenesis..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Intelligence quotient profile in myotonic dystrophy, intergenerational deficit, and correlation with CTG amplification.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An abbreviated Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale Revised (WAIS-R) was used to assess verbal and arithmetical cognitive performance in 55 subjects with myotonic dystrophy (DM), covering all grades of disease severity, and 31 controls at 50% risk of inheriting DM.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Scaled scores from the assessment were converted into an intelligence quotient (IQ) estimation on each person.</Disease>

<Disease>Significant IQ differences were found between  (1) all 55 DM subjects (mean 90. 2, SD 16. 1) and 31 controls (102. 6, SD 9. 4), with no sex differences in either group; (2) 15 affected parents (99. 3, SD 12. 2) and their affected children (88. 1, SD 17. 2), where significance was dependent on parental sex being female; and (3) 15 pairs of affected sibs (89. 6, SD 13. 2) and their normal sibs (100. 2, SD 7. 6).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>IQ steadily declined as (1) the age of onset of signs and symptoms decreased, and (2) the CTG expansion size increased.</Disease>
<Disease>The correlation appeared to be more linear with age of onset.</Disease>

<Disease>The correlation of IQ difference and CTG expansion difference in both the DM parent-child pairs and normal sib-affected sib pairs was poor, indicating that CTG expansion is not a reliable predictor of IQ either in individual persons or families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Further analysis of cognitive function in DM is required to clarify specific deficits characteristic of this patient group</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Complement factor 2 deficiency: a clinical and serological family study.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Inherited complement deficiencies are associated with a variety of connective tissue diseases.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A family with inherited deficiency of complement factor 2 (C2) is described in which two family members with homozygous C2 deficiency developed cutaneous vasculitis and sicca syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The other family members had heterozygous C2 deficiency and each member had the HLA-A25, B18, DR2 (w15) haplotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mother had seropositive rheumatoid arthritis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Further studies showed the presence of cryoglobulins, antibodies against endothelial cells, and anticardiolipin antibodies..</Disease>
<Disease>Oncogenic point mutations in exon 20 of the RB1 gene in families showing incomplete penetrance and mild expression of the retinoblastoma phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The retinoblastoma-predisposition gene, RB1, segregates as an autosomal dominant trait with high (90%) penetrance.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Certain families, however, show an unusual low-penetrance phenotype with many individuals being unaffected, unilaterally affected, or with evidence of spontaneously regressed tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have used single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis and PCR sequencing to study two such families.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations were found in exon 20 of RB1 in both cases.</Disease>
<Disease>In one family a C----T transition in codon 661 converts an arginine (CGG) to a tryptophan (TGG) codon.</Disease>

<Disease>In this family, incomplete penetrance and mild phenotypic expression were observed in virtually all patients, possibly indicating that single amino acid changes may modify protein structure/function such that tumorigenesis is not inevitable.</Disease>
<Disease>In the second family the mutation in codon 675 is a G----T transversion that converts a glutamine (GAA) to a stop (TAA) codon.</Disease>
<Disease>However, this mutation also occurs near a potential cryptic splice acceptor site, raising the possibility of alternative splicing resulting in a less severely disrupted protein..</Disease>
<Disease>Identification of a novel R21X mutation in the liver-type arginase gene (ARG1) in four Portuguese patients with argininemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Argininemia is a rare autossomal recessive disorder caused by deficiency in the cytosolic liver-type arginase enzyme (L-arginine urea-hydrolase; E. C. 3. 5. 3. 1).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In order to investigate the molecular basis for argininemia in four unrelated Portuguese patients (two from northern Portugal and two from Madeira Island) we performed a DNA sequence analysis of all the exons and exon/intron boundaries of the liver-type arginase gene (ARG1).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All patients were found to be homozygous for a newly identified C - > T transition in codon 21 (exon 2) substituting arginine for a premature stop codon (R21X  CGA to TGA) and generating a NlaIII restriction site.</Disease>
<Disease>Restriction digestion following PCR amplification of ARG1 exon 2 confirmed the presence of the mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>A mutation in the pleckstrin homology (PH) domain of the FGD1 gene in an Italian family with faciogenital dysplasia (Aarskog-Scott syndrome).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Aarskog-Scott Syndrome (AAS) is an X-linked disorder characterised by short stature and multiple facial, limb and genital abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A gene, FGD1, altered in a patient with AAS phenotype, has been identified and found to encode a protein with homology to Rho/Rac guanine nucleotide exchange factors (Rho/Rac GEF).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, since this original report on identification of a mutated FGD1 gene in an AAS patient, no additional mutations in the FGD1 gene have been described.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We analysed 13 independent patients with clinical diagnosis of AAS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One patient presented a mutation that results in a nucleotide change in exon 10 of the FGD1 gene (G2559 > A) substituting a Gln for Arg in position 610.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutation was found to segregate with the AAS phenotype in affected males and carrier females in the family of this patient.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Interestingly, Arg-610 is located within one of the two pleckstrin homology (PH) domains of the FGD1 gene and it corresponds to a highly conserved residue which has been involved in InsP binding in PH domains of other proteins.</Disease>
<Disease>The same residue is often mutated in the Brutons tyrosine kinase (Btk) gene in patients with an X-linked agammaglobulinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Arg610Gln mutation represents the first case of a mutation in the PH domain of the FGD1 gene and additional evidence that mutations in PH domains can be associated to human diseases..</Disease>
<Disease>Localization of histidase to human chromosome region 12q22----q24.1 and mouse chromosome region 10C2----D1.</Disease>

<Disease>The human gene for histidase (histidine ammonia-lyase; HAL), the enzyme deficient in histidinemia, was assigned to human chromosome 12 by Southern blot analysis of human X mouse somatic cell hybrid DNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The gene was sublocalized to region 12q22----q24. 1 by in situ hybridization, using a human histidase cDNA.</Disease>
<Disease>The homologous locus in the mouse (Hal) was mapped to region 10C2----D1 by in situ hybridization, using a cell line from a mouse homozygous for a 1. 10 Robertsonian translocation.</Disease>

<Disease>These assignments extend the conserved syntenic region between human chromosome 12 and mouse chromosome 10 that includes the genes for phenylalanine hydroxylase, gamma interferon, peptidase, and citrate synthase.</Disease>

<Disease>The localization of histidase to mouse chromosome 10 suggests that the histidase regulatory locus (Hsd) and the histidinemia mutation (his), which are both known to be on chromosome 10, may be alleles of the histidase structural gene locus.</Disease>
<Disease>Noninvasive test for fragile X syndrome, using hair root analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of the FMR1 gene and the repeat-amplification mechanism causing fragile X syndrome led to development of reliable DNA-based diagnostic methods, including Southern blot hybridization and PCR.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Both methods are performed on DNA isolated from peripheral blood cells and measure the repeat size in FMR1.</Disease>
<Disease>Using an immunocytochemical technique on blood smears, we recently developed a novel test for identification of patients with fragile X syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This method, also called " antibody test, " uses monoclonal antibodies against the FMR1 gene product (FMRP) and is based on absence of FMRP in patients cells.</Disease>
<Disease>Here we describe a new diagnostic test to identify male patients with fragile X syndrome, on the basis of lack of FMRP in their hair roots.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Expression of FMRP in hair roots was studied by use of an FMRP-specific antibody test, and the percentage of FMRP-expressing hair roots in controls and in male fragile X patients was determined.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Control individuals showed clear expression of FMRP in nearly every hair root, whereas male fragile X patients lacked expression of FMRP in almost all their hair roots.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mentally retarded female patients with a full mutation showed FMRP expression in only some of their hair roots (< 55%), and no overlap with normal female controls was observed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The advantages of this test are (1) plucking of hair follicles does no appreciable harm to the mentally retarded patient, (2) hairs can be sent in a simple envelope to a diagnostic center, and (3) the result of the test is available within 5 h of plucking.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, this test enabled us to identify two fragile X patients who did not show the full mutation by analysis of DNA isolated from blood cells..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease: detection of mutations Thr181----Pro and Leu223----Pro in the proteolipid protein gene, and prenatal diagnosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A family with an apparent history of X-linked Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease presented for genetic counseling, requesting carrier detection and prenatal diagnosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RFLP analysis using the proteolipid protein (PLP) gene probe was uninformative in this family.</Disease>
<Disease>A prenatal diagnosis on a chorionic villus sample (CVS) was carried out using single-strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) analysis of a variant in exon 4 of the PLP gene.</Disease>
<Disease>The fetus was predicted to be unaffected.</Disease>

<Disease>Sequencing of the exon from the CVS, the predicted-carrier mother, and the obligate-carrier grandmother revealed an A-to-C change at nucleotide 541 in the two women but not in the fetus.</Disease>

<Disease>As this change results in a Thr-to-Pro change at amino acid 181 in a region of the gene predicted to be part of a transmembrane segment, it was concluded that this was the mutation causing the disease in this family.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, in a second family, an exon 5 variant band pattern on SSCP analysis was shown by sequencing to be due to a T-to-C change at nucleotide 668.</Disease>
<Disease>This results in a Leu-to-Pro change in a carrier mother and in her two affected sons.</Disease>
<Disease>These results provide further examples of mutations in PLP that cause Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease and illustrate the value of SSCP in genetic analysis..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A normal male with an inherited deletion of one exon within the DMD gene.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results have implications for genetic counselling and prenatal diagnosis in families with Becker muscular dystrophy..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Small deletions in the type II collagen triple helix produce kniest dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Kniest dysplasia is a moderately severe type II collagenopathy, characterized by short trunk and limbs, kyphoscoliosis, midface hypoplasia, severe myopia, and hearing loss.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the gene that encodes type II collagen (COL2A1), the predominant protein of cartilage, have been identified in a number of individuals with Kniest dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All but two of these previously described mutations cause in-frame deletions in type II collagen, either by small deletions in the gene or splice site alterations.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, all but one of these mutations is located between exons 12 and 24 in the COL2A1 gene.</Disease>
<Disease>We used heteroduplex analysis to identify sequence anomalies in five individuals with Kniest dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sequencing of the index patients genomic DNA identified four new dominant mutations in COL2A1 that result in Kniest dysplasia  a 21-bp deletion in exon 16, an 18-bp deletion in exon 19, and 4-bp deletions in the splice donor sites of introns 14 and 20.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A previously described 28-bp deletion at the COL2A1 exon 12-intron 12 junction, deleting the splice donor site, was identified in the fifth case.</Disease>
<Disease>The latter three mutations are predicted to result in exon skipping in the mRNA encoded from the mutant allele.</Disease>

<Disease>These data suggest that Kniest dysplasia results from shorter type II collagen monomers, and support the hypothesis that alteration of a specific COL2A1 domain, which may span from exons 12 to 24, leads to the Kniest dysplasia phenotype..</Disease>

text: <Disease>She was profoundly mentally retarded, autistic, and had minor dysmorphic features consistent with those of previous patients with similar deletions.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The deletion arose as a result of recombination within the small insertion loop formed at meiosis by the direct insertion (dir ins (5) (q22.</Disease>

<Disease>Somatic mutations of the APC gene in colorectal tumors: mutation cluster region in the APC gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We examined somatic mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene in 63 colorectal tumors (16 adenomas and 47 carcinomas) developed in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and non-FAP patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition to loss of heterozygosity (LOH) at the APC locus in 30 tumors, 43 other somatic mutations were detected.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Twenty-one of them were point mutations; 16 nonsense and two missense mutations, and three occurred in introns at the splicing site.</Disease>
<Disease>Twenty-two tumors had frameshift mutations due to deletion or insertion; nineteen of them were deletions of one to 31 bp and three were a 1-bp insertion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One tumor had a 1-bp deletion in an intron near the splicing site.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hence, 41 (95%) of 43 mutations resulted in truncation of the APC protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Over 60% of the somatic mutations in the APC gene were clustered within a small region of exon 15, designated as MCR (mutation cluster region), which accounted for less than 10% of the coding region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Combining these data and the results of LOH, more than 80% of tumors (14 adenomas and 39 carcinomas) had at least one mutation in the APC gene, of which more than 60% (9 adenomas and 23 carcinomas) had two mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These results strongly suggest that somatic mutations of the APC gene are associated with development of a great majority of colorectal tumors..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of an altered splice site in Ashkenazi Tay-Sachs disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder resulting from mutation of the HEXA gene encoding the alpha-subunit of the lysosomal enzyme, beta-N-acetylhexosaminidase A (ref. 1).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A relatively high frequency of carriers (1/27) of a lethal, infantile form of the disease is found in the Ashkenazi Jewish population, but it is not yet evident whether this has resulted from a founder effect and random genetic drift or from a selective advantage of heterozygotes.</Disease>
<Disease>We have identified a single-base mutation in a cloned fragment of the HEXA gene from an Ashkenazi Jewish patient.</Disease>
<Disease>This change, the substitution of a C for G in the first nucleotide of intron 12 is expected to result in defective splicing of the messenger RNA.</Disease>

<Disease>A test for the mutant allele based on amplification of DNA by the polymerase chain rection and cleavage of a DdeI restriction site generated by the mutation revealed that this case and two other cases of the Ashkenazi, infantile form of Tay-Sachs disease are heterozygous for two different mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The occurrence of multiple mutant alleles warrants further examination of the selective advantage hypothesis..</Disease>
<Disease>Coats' disease of the retina (unilateral retinal telangiectasis) caused by somatic mutation in the NDP gene: a role for norrin in retinal angiogenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Coats disease is characterized by abnormal retinal vascular development (so-called retinal telangiectasis) which results in massive intraretinal and subretinal lipid accumulation (exudative retinal detachment).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The classical form of Coats disease is almost invariably isolated, unilateral and seen in males.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A female with a unilateral variant of Coats disease gave birth to a son affected by Norrie disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Both carried a missense mutation within the NDP gene on chromosome Xp11.</Disease>
<Disease>2 2.</Disease>

<Disease>Subsequently analysis of the retinas of nine enucleated eyes from males with Coats disease demonstrated in one a somatic mutation in the NDP gene which was not present within non-retinal tissue.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We suggest that Coats telangiectasis is secondary to somatic mutation in the NDP gene which results in a deficiency of norrin (the protein product of the NDP gene) within the developing retina.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This supports recent observations that the protein is critical for normal retinal vasculogenesis.</Disease>
<Disease>Trisomy 15 with loss of the paternal 15 as a cause of Prader-Willi syndrome due to maternal disomy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Uniparental disomy has recently been recognized to cause human disorders, including Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We describe a particularly instructive case which raises important issues concerning the mechanisms producing uniparental disomy and whose evaluation provides evidence that trisomy may precede uniparental disomy in a fetus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Chorionic villus sampling performed for advanced maternal age revealed trisomy 15 in all direct and cultured cells, though the fetus appeared normal.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chromosome analysis of amniocytes obtained at 15 wk was normal in over 100 cells studied.</Disease>
<Disease>The child was hypotonic at birth, and high-resolution banding failed to reveal the deletion of 15q11-13, a deletion which is found in 50% -70% of patients with PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Over time, typical features of PWS developed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular genetic analysis using probes for chromosome 15 revealed maternal disomy.</Disease>

<Disease>Maternal nondisjunction with fertilization of a disomic egg by a normal sperm, followed by loss of the paternal 15, is a likely cause of confined placental mosaicism and uniparental disomy in this case of PWS, and advanced maternal age may be a predisposing factor..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Genetic defect in secretion of complement C5 in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A genetic deficiency of the fifth (C5) component of complement1-3, a serum glycoprotein of molecular weight (MW) 220, 000 (ref. 4), has been found in 39% of inbred strains of mice3.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sera of deficient mice lack detectable C5 activity and protein2, 3.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition deficient mice produce antibody to mouse C5 when injected with sera from C5 sufficient (normal) strains.</Disease>

<Disease>Levy et al. 5 showed that somatic cell hybrids between C5 deficient (B10. D2/old line) macrophages and either C5 sufficient (B10. D2/new line) mouse kidney or chicken erythroblasts secreted haemolytically active mouse C5 in vitro.</Disease>
<Disease>Several possible molecular mechanisms to account for the findings were considered, but insufficient direct data were available to choose among them.</Disease>

<Disease>We recently reported that mouse (CD. 1 strain) peritoneal cells in culture synthesise and secrete a single chain precursor, pro-C5 (MW approximately 210, 000), of the two-chain (alpha chain, 125, 000 and beta chain 83, 000 MW) C5 protein6.</Disease>
<Disease>Radiolabelled precursor C5 was contained within the cells and was secreted into the tissue culture media.</Disease>

<Disease>Using similar methods, we now find that C5 deficiency in each of five different mouse strains (AKR, SWR, DBA/2J8 A/HeJ and B10. D2/old line) is due to a failure in secretion of C5 protein and not to a failure in biosynthesis of pro-C5</Disease>

text: <Disease>WASP gene mutations in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome and X-linked thrombocytopenia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The WASP gene has been recently cloned from Xp11.</Disease>
<Disease>23 and shown to be mutated in three patients with the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have developed a screening protocol for identifying WASP gene alterations in genomic DNA and have identified a spectrum of novel mutations in 12 additional unrelated families.</Disease>
<Disease>These missense, nonsense and frameshift mutations involve eight of the 12 exons of the gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Two mutations creating premature termination codons were associated with lack of detectable mRNA on Northern blots.</Disease>

<Disease>Four amino acid substitutions, Leu27Phe, Thr48Ile, Val75Met and Arg477Lys, were found in patients with congenital thrombocytopenia and no clinically evident immune defect indicating that the WASP gene is the site for mutations in X-linked thrombocytopenia as well as in WAS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A T-cell line from a WAS patient contained two independent DNA alterations, a constitutional frameshift mutation, also present in peripheral blood leukocytes from the patient, and compensatory splice site mutation unique to the cell line.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The distribution of eight missense mutations provides valuable information on amino acids which are essential for normal protein function, and suggests that sites in the first two exons are hot-spots for mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>Detection of a nonsense mutation in the dystrophin gene by multiple SSCP.</Disease>
<Disease>A combination of multiplex PCR with the single strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) technique was employed to screen for point mutations in the human dystrophin gene.</Disease>

<Disease>Co-amplification of 11 exons from genomic DNA of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy (DMD/BMD) patients with no deletion or duplication was performed and the samples subjected to multiple SSCP analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report the case of a nonsense mutation in a Duchenne patient identified by this approach.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation introduces a termination codon within exon 8 of the dystrophin gene.</Disease>
<Disease>It is predicted to cause a very premature translational termination accounting for the severe phenotype observed.</Disease>
<Disease>The patient inherited this mutation from his mother.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition the analysis revealed 5 polymorphisms useful for internal control..</Disease>
<Disease>Molecular mechanisms of oncogenic mutations in tumors from patients with bilateral and unilateral retinoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The RB1 gene from 12 human retinoblastoma tumors has been analyzed exon-by-exon with the single-strand conformation polymorphism technique.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations were found in all tumors, and one-third of the tumors had independent mutations in both alleles neither of which were found in the germ line, confirming their true sporadic nature.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the remaining two-thirds of the tumors only one mutation was found, consistent with the loss-of-heterozygosity theory of tumorigenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Point mutations, the majority of which were C-- > T transitions, were the most common abnormality and usually resulted in the conversion of an arginine codon to a stop codon.</Disease>
<Disease>Small deletions were the second most common abnormality and most often created a downstream stop codon as the result of a reading frameshift.</Disease>
<Disease>Deletions and point mutations also affected splice junctions.</Disease>
<Disease>Direct repeats were present at the breakpoint junctions in the majority of deletions, supporting a slipped-mispairing mechanism.</Disease>
<Disease>Point mutations generally produced DNA sequences which resulted in perfect homology with endogenous sequences which lay within 14 bp..</Disease>
<Disease>PAX6 gene dosage effect in a family with congenital cataracts, aniridia, anophthalmia and central nervous system defects.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The human eye malformation aniridia results from haploinsufficiency of PAX6, a paired box DNA-binding protein.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To study this dosage effect, we characterized two PAX6 mutations in a family segregating aniridia and a milder syndrome consisting of congenital cataracts and late onset corneal dystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The nonsense mutations, at codons 103 and 353, truncate PAX6 within the N-terminal paired and C-terminal PST domains, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>The wild-type PST domain activates transcription autonomously and the mutant form has partial activity.</Disease>
<Disease>A compound heterozygote had severe craniofacial and central nervous system defects and no eyes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The pattern of malformations is similar to that in homozygous Sey mice and suggests a critical role for PAX6 in controlling the migration and differentiation of specific neuronal progenitor cells in the brain..</Disease>
<Disease>Hereditary C7 deficiency. Diagnosis and HLA studies in a French-Canadian family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The serum of a 44-yr-old woman of French-Canadian descent having a B-27 positive ankylosing spondylitis was deficient in the seventh component of complement (C7) as determined by hemolytic and immunochemical methods.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No inhibitor against C7 was detected, and the levels of all other complement components were normal.</Disease>
<Disease>No deficiency in the opsonic activity of the serum was found, and the results of basic coagulation studies of the plasma were normal.</Disease>
<Disease>On investigation of the patients family, two sisters were found to have the same deficiency but were otherwise in good health.</Disease>
<Disease>The seven other siblings were heterozygous for C7 deficiency, while the paternal aunt had a normal C7 level.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the third generation, six children of the three homozygous sisters and five children of heterozygotes were available for testing.</Disease>
<Disease>Studies of the HLA antigens in all the 22 subjects and in three spouses indicated no close linkage between the CM deficienty and the HLA system.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, the simultaneous occurrence of two hereditary complement deficiencies (C2 and C7) was discovered in one family of this remarkable kindred..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Alstrom syndrome: further evidence for linkage to human chromosome 2p13.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Alstrom syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by retinal degeneration, sensorineural hearing loss, early-onset obesity, and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The gene for Alstrom syndrome (ALMS1) has been previously localized to human chromosome 2p13 by homozygosity mapping in two distinct isolated populations - French Acadian and North African.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pair-wise analyses resulted in maximum lod (logarithm of the odds ratio) scores of 3. 84 and 2. 9, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>To confirm these findings, a large linkage study was performed in twelve additional families segregating for Alstrom syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A maximum two-point lod score of 7. 13 (theta = 0. 00) for marker D2S2110 and a maximum cumulative multipoint lod score of 9. 16 for marker D2S2110 were observed, further supporting linkage to chromosome 2p13.</Disease>
<Disease>No evidence of genetic heterogeneity was observed in these families.</Disease>
<Disease>Meiotic recombination events have localized the critical region containing ALMS1 to a 6. 1-cM interval flanked by markers D2S327 and D2S286.</Disease>
<Disease>A fine resolution radiation hybrid map of 31 genes and markers has been constructed.</Disease>
<Disease>Haplotype and multipoint linkage analysis in Finnish choroideremia families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Multipoint linkage analysis of choroideremia (TCD) and seven X chromosomal restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLPs) was carried out in 18 Finnish TCD families.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The data place TCD distal to PGK and DXS72, very close to DXYS1 and DXYS5 (Zmax = 24 at theta = 0) and proximal to DXYS4 and DXYS12.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This agrees with the data obtained from other linkage studies and from physical mapping.</Disease>
<Disease>All the TCD males and carrier females studied have the same DXYS1 allele in coupling with TCD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In Northeastern Finland, 66/69 chromosomes carrying TCD had the same haplotype at loci DXS72, DXYS1, DXYS4, and DXYS12.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The same haplotype is seen in only 15/99 chromosomes not carrying TCD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Moreover, in 71/104 non-TCD chromosomes, the haplotype at six marker loci is different from those seen in any of the 76 TCD chromosomes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This supports the previously described hypothesis that the large Northern Finnish choroideremia pedigrees, comprising a total of over 80 living patients representing more than a fifth of all TCD patients described worldwide, carry the same mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These linkage and haplotype data provide improved opportunities for prenatal diagnosis based on RFLP studies..</Disease>
<Disease>Genetic heterogeneity at the glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase locus in southern Italy: a study on a population from the Matera district.</Disease>

<Disease>Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) has been analyzed by gel electrophoresis and by quantitative assay in an unselected sample of 1524 schoolboys from the province of Matera (Lucania) in southern Italy.</Disease>
<Disease>We have identified 43 subjects with a G6PD variant.</Disease>
<Disease>Of these, 31 had severe G6PD deficiency, nine had mild to moderate deficiency, and three had a non-deficient electrophoretic variant.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The overall rate of G6PD deficiency was 2. 6%.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The frequency of G6PD deficiency, ranging from 7. 2% on the Ionian Coast to zero on the eastern side of the Lucanian Apennines, appears to be inversely related to the distance of each town examined from the Ionian Coast, suggesting that this geographic distribution may reflect, at least in part, gene flow from Greek settlers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Biochemical characterization has shown that most of the G6PD deficiency in this population is accounted for by G6PD Mediterranean.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, we have found several examples of two other known polymorphic variants (G6PD Cagliari and G6PD A-); three new polymorphic variants, G6PD Metaponto (class III), G6PD Montalbano (class III), and G6PD Pisticci (class IV); and two sporadic variants, G6PD Tursi (class III) and G6PD Ferrandina (class II).</Disease>

<Disease>These data provide further evidence for the marked genetic heterogeneity of G6PD deficiency within a relatively narrow geographic area and they prove the presence in the Italian peninsula of a gene (GdA-) regarded as characteristically African.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Defective CTLA-4 cycling pathway in Chediak-Higashi syndrome: a possible mechanism for deregulation of T lymphocyte activation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cytotoxic T lymphocyte-associated antigen 4 (CTLA-4, also known as CD152) has been shown to play a major role in the regulation of T cell activation.</Disease>
<Disease>Its membrane expression is highly regulated by endocytosis and trafficking through the secretory lysosome pathway.</Disease>
<Disease>Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS) is an inherited disorder caused by mutations in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene, LYST.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It results in defective membrane targeting of the proteins present in secretory lysosomes, and it is associated with a variety of features, including a lymphoproliferative syndrome with hemophagocytosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The murine equivalent of CHS, beige mice, present similar characteristics but do not develop the lymphoproliferative syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We show herein that CTLA-4 is present in enlarged, abnormal vesicles in CHS T cells and is not properly expressed at the cell surface after T cell activation, whereas its surface expression is not impaired.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is therefore proposed that the defective surface expression of CTLA-4 by CHS T cells is involved in the generation of lymphoproliferative disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This observation may provide insight into the role of CTLA-4 in humans..</Disease>
<Disease>Beta-catenin accumulation and mutation of the CTNNB1 gene in hepatoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hepatoblastoma is a rare malignant tumor of the liver that occurs in children at an average age of 2 to 3 years.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Epidemiologic studies have shown an increased frequency of this tumor type in families affected by adenomatous polyposis coli.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition to the epidemiologic data, molecular genetic studies suggest that inactivation of the APC tumor suppressor may be involved in hepatoblastoma tumorigenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A major function of APC is the downregulation of beta-catenin, a transcription-activating protein with oncogenic potential.</Disease>

<Disease>In an ongoing immunohistochemical study of beta-catenin expression in sporadic cases of tumor types that are associated with adenomatous polyposis coli, we observed increased beta-catenin levels in the cytoplasm and in the nuclei of three investigated hepatoblastomas.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Sequencing of exon 3 of the beta-catenin gene (CTNNB1) revealed an activating mutation in one of the tumor samples.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our data indicate for the first time that beta-catenin accumulation may play a role in the development of hepatoblastoma and that activating mutations of the beta-catenin gene may substitute biallelic APC inactivation in this tumor type.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Genes Chromosomes Cancer 25  399-402, 1999..</Disease>
<Disease>Sequence of DNA flanking the exons of the HEXA gene, and identification of mutations in Tay-Sachs disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The rapid identification of mutations causing Tay-Sachs disease requires the capacity to readily screen the regions of the HEXA gene most likely to be affected by mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have sequenced the portions of the introns flanking each of the 14 HEXA exons in order to specify oligonucleotide primers for the PCR-dependent amplification of each exon and splice-junction sequence.</Disease>

<Disease>The amplified products were analyzed, by electrophoresis in nondenaturing polyacrylamide gels, for the presence of either heteroduplexes, derived from the annealing of normal and mutant DNA strands, or single-strand conformational polymorphisms (SSCP), derived from the renaturation of single-stranded DNA.</Disease>

<Disease>Five novel mutations from Tay-Sachs disease patients were detected  a 5-bp deletion of TCTCC in IVS-9; a 2-bp deletion of TG in exon 5; G78 to A, giving a stop codon in exon 1; G533 to T in exon 5, producing the third amino acid substitution detected at this site; and G to C at position 1 of IVS-2, expected to produce abnormal splicing.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, two mutations, (G1496 to A in exon 13 and a 4-bp insertion in exon 11) that have previously been reported were identified..</Disease>
<Disease>In vivo modulation of Hmgic reduces obesity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The HMGI family of proteins consists of three members, HMGIC, HMGI and HMGI (Y), that function as architectural factors and are essential components of the enhancesome.</Disease>
<Disease>HMGIC is predominantly expressed in proliferating, undifferentiated mesenchymal cells and is not detected in adult tissues.</Disease>
<Disease>It is disrupted and misexpressed in a number of mesenchymal tumour cell types, including fat-cell tumours (lipomas).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition Hmgic-/- mice have a deficiency in fat tissue.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We have detected chromosomally anomalous clones of lymphocytes in eight patients with this disorder.</Disease>

<Disease>A translocation involving 14q was found in clones obtained from seven of the eight patients whereas a ring 14 chromosome was found in a clone obtained from the other.</Disease>

<Disease>These findings as well as data obtained by others for patients with ataxia-telangiectasia suggest that structural rearrangement of 14q is the initial chromosomal change in lymphocyte clones of patients with this disorder.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Before leukemia was diagnosed, the patient had a lymphocyte clone with a 14q translocation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This clone appears to have given rise to the leukemic cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We hypothesize that structural rearrangement of 14q is directly related to abnormal growth of lymphocytes and that it may be a step toward the development of lymphoid malignancies.</Disease>
label: Disease

<Disease>Two dinucleotide (CT) and one trinucleotide intronic polymorphism in Hdh and an intronic CA polymorphism in the HD gene were identified.</Disease>
