text: <Disease>Comparison of 940-bp sequence 5 to the putative translation start site reveals a highly conserved region (78. 8% nucleotide identity) between Hdh and the HD gene from nucleotide -56 to -206 (of Hdh).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neither Hdh nor the HD gene have typical TATA or CCAAT elements, but both show one putative AP2 binding site and numerous potential Sp1 binding sites.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The high sequence identity between Hdh and the HD gene for approximately 200 bp 5 to the putative translation start site indicates that these sequences may play a role in regulating expression of the Huntington disease gene</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Complement deficiency and nephritis. A report of a family.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A family is described in which three children had homozygous deficiency of C3 and in which both parents and two other children were heterozygous for the C3 null gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One child with heterozygous C3 deficiency was found to have membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; proteinuria and/or microscopical haematuria was present in all three homozygous C3-deficient children.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All children with homozygous or heterozygous C3 deficiency were, to a varying degree, susceptible to infection.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The only child of the family with normal complement had no increased risk of infection and no renal disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This family study provides further support for the proposal that C3 deficiency predisposes to nephritis..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cytogenetic investigations in families with ataxia-telangiectasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chromosomal studies were performed on peripheral blood lymphocytes and cultured skin fibroblasts from five Israeli-Moroccan families with ataxia-telangiectasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A total of 24 individuals, including seven propositi, was investigated.</Disease>
<Disease>Among the probands, significantly elevated rates of chromosome damage were observed in both blood and skin.</Disease>
<Disease>Skin fibroblasts of affected individuals showed several orders of magnitude more chromosome breakage than lymphocytes.</Disease>

<Disease>Increased rates of chromosome damage were also observed in the fibroblasts of some phenotypically normal family members (obligate heterozygotes and sibs) when compared to normal controls.</Disease>

<Disease>An apparent abnormal clone of cells, possessing a large acrocentric marker chromosome (14q +), was observed in varying proportions among cells of all the propositi (2-5% of lymphocytes; 1-9% of fibroblasts)..</Disease>
<Disease>Predominance of the adrenomyeloneuropathy phenotype of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy in The Netherlands: a survey of 30 kindreds.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD) is an inherited disorder of peroxisomal beta-oxidation associated with accumulation of saturated very long-chain fatty acids, which results in central and peripheral demyelination and in impaired function of adrenal cortex and testes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The phenotypic expression is highly variable, childhood cerebral ALD (CCALD) and adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) being the main variants.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We explored the 30 Dutch kindreds well known to the Dutch X-ALD/AMN Study Group and phenotyped 77 male patients  35 (46%) had AMN and 24 (31%) CCALD or adolescent cerebral ALD (AdolCALD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These percentages differ significantly from previous reports, in which 25 to 28% of the patients developed AMN and 53 to 57% CCALD or AdolCALD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our findings indicate that--at least in the Netherlands--AMN may be the most frequent phenotype of X-ALD..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Three novel aniridia mutations in the human PAX6 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aniridia (iris hypoplasia) is an autosomal dominant congenital disorder of the eye.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the human aniridia (PAX6) gene have now been identified in many patients from various ethnic groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the study reported here we describe PAX6 mutations in one sporadic and five familial cases with aniridia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of the four different mutations identified, one was identical to a previously reported mutation (C-- > T transition at codon 240), and three were novel  two in the glycine-rich region and one in the proline/serine/threonine-rich (PST) region.</Disease>
<Disease>One PAX6 mutation found in the PST region was associated with cataracts in an aniridia family.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Another splice mutation in the PST domain occurred in an aniridia patient with anosmia (inability to smell).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The six new aniridia cases reported here have mutations predicted to generate incomplete PAX6 proteins.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results support the theory that human aniridia is caused by haploinsufficiency of PAX6..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hepatoblastoma, pigmented ocular fundus lesions and jaw lesions in Gardner syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hepatoblastoma is a rare neoplasm of infants and children only recently documented in association with hereditary adenomatous polyposis of the colon [Kingston et al., 1983].</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report four children with hepatoblastoma from four unrelated families with Gardner syndrome (GS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>One child, now 19 years old, survived after a resection of a hepatoblastoma in infancy and recently was found to have GS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>He has an associated odontoma and pigmented ocular fundus lesions, both of which have been shown to be clinical markers of GS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Many individuals in these four GS families, both affected and at risk, have osteomatous jaw lesions and pigmented ocular fundus lesions.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A search for colonic polyps should be made in families of infants and children with hepatoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>If the child survives, he or she should be monitored for the later appearance of colonic polyps.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The finding of jaw lesions and/or pigmented ocular fundus lesions in relatives at risk are indications of the possible presence of the GS gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation spectrum in the CHM gene of Danish and Swedish choroideremia patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The recent isolation of the complete open reading frame of the choroideremia (CHM) gene and the characterization of the exon-intron boundaries has paved the way to mutation detection in patients with classical choroideremia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have performed mutation screening in patients from 15 Danish and Swedish families by using Southern blot hybridization and the polymerase chain reaction single-strand conformation polymorphism (PCR-SSCP) technique.</Disease>
<Disease>Causative mutations in the CHM gene were detected in at least 12 families, indicating that a substantial part of the mutations can be identified by this approach.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In four of these families deletions of different sizes were found.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, in one patient, the deletion resulted in the absence of only one exon, while in another the deletion comprised the entire CHM gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mapping of the deletion endpoints in these four patients and in another 11 male patients with sizeable deletions enabled us to construct a very detailed map of intervals 2 and 3 of Xq21.</Disease>
<Disease>In the remaining 11 Danish and Swedish families at least 8 causative mutations were found by PCR-SSCP analysis and direct sequencing.</Disease>
<Disease>Interestingly, all CHM gene mutations detected thus far in choroideremia patients give rise to the introduction of a premature stop codon..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Diverse point mutations result in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) polymorphism in Taiwan.</Disease>
<Disease>Glucose-6-PHOSPHATE dehydrogenase (G6PD; EC 1.1. 1. 49) deficiency is the most common human enzymopathy, affecting more than 200 million people worldwide.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although greater than 400 variants have been described based on clinical and biochemical criteria, little is known about the molecular basis of these G6PD deficiencies.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, the gene that encodes human G6PD has been cloned and sequenced, which enables us to examine directly the heterogeneity of G6PD at the DNA level.</Disease>

<Disease>During the past 10 years, we examined the G6PD activity in 21, 271 newborn Chinese infants (11, 400 males and 9, 871 females) and identified 314 (2. 8%) males and 246 (2. 5%) females having low G6PD activity.</Disease>
<Disease>The G6PD gene from 10 randomly selected affected individuals and their relatives was polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplified, subcloned, and sequenced.</Disease>
<Disease>Our results indicate that at least four types of mutation are responsible for the G6PD polymorphism in Taiwan.</Disease>
<Disease>The first type of mutation (487 G----A) was found in an affected Chinese with a G to A change at nucleotide 487, which results in a (163)</Disease>
<Disease>Gly to Ser substitution.</Disease>
<Disease>The second type of mutation (493 A----G) is a novel mutation that has not been reported in any other ethnic group and was identified in two affected Chinese.</Disease>
<Disease>This mutation causes an A to G change at nucleotide position 493, producing an (165) Asn to Asp substitution.</Disease>

<Disease>Interestingly, the 487 G----A and 493 A----G mutations create Alu I and Ava II recognition sites, respectively, which enabled us to rapidly detect these two mutations by PCR/restriction enzyme (RE) digestion method.</Disease>
<Disease>The third mutation (1376 G----T) was found in four affected Chinese.</Disease>
<Disease>This mutation causes a G to T change at nucleotide position 1376 that results in an (459)</Disease>
<Disease>Arg to Leu substitution.</Disease>
<Disease>The 1376 G----T mutation seems to be the dominant allele that causes G6PD deficiency in Taiwan.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Finally, two affected Chinese were identified as having the fourth mutation (1388 G----A).</Disease>
<Disease>This mutation causes a G to A change at nucleotide 1388 that produces an (463) Arg to His substitution.</Disease>

<Disease>Our studies provide the direct proof of the genetic heterogeneity of G6PD deficiency in the Chinese populations of Taiwan and the PCR/RE digestion method is suitable for simultaneous detection of the 487 G----A and 493 A----G mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fas preassociation required for apoptosis signaling and dominant inhibition by pathogenic mutations.</Disease>

<Disease>Heterozygous mutations encoding abnormal forms of the death receptor Fas dominantly interfere with Fas-induced lymphocyte apoptosis in human autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This effect, rather than depending on ligand-induced receptor oligomerization, was found to stem from ligand- independent interaction of wild-type and mutant Fas receptors through a specific region in the extracellular domain.</Disease>
<Disease>Preassociated Fas complexes were found in living cells by means of fluorescence resonance energy transfer between variants of green fluorescent protein.</Disease>
<Disease>These results show that formation of preassociated receptor complexes is necessary for Fas signaling and dominant interference in human disease..</Disease>
<Disease>Familial Mediterranean fever in the colchicine era: the fate of one family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In order to demonstrate the effect of prophylactic colchicine treatment on the natural history of familial Mediterranean fever (FMF), a family is presented with 6 out of 9 siblings affected by FMF.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Each patient represents a different stage of the amyloidotic kidney disease of FMF and the effect of continuous colchicine treatment on its course.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Considered together, the members of this family present an almost complete clinical, genetic, and behavioral picture of the disease..</Disease>
<Disease>Two new arylsulfatase A (ARSA) mutations in a juvenile metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) patient.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Fragments of the arylsulfatase A (ARSA) gene from a patient with juvenile-onset metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) were amplified by PCR and ligated into MP13 cloning vectors.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Clones hybridizing with cDNA for human ARSA were selected, examined for appropriate size inserts, and used to prepare single-stranded phage DNA.</Disease>
<Disease>Examination of the entire coding and most of the intronic sequence revealed two putative disease-related mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>One, a point mutation in exon 3, resulted in the substitution of isoleucine by serine.</Disease>

<Disease>Introduction of this alteration into the normal ARSA cDNA sequence resulted in a substantial decrease in ARSA activity on transient expression in cultured baby hamster kidney cells.</Disease>
<Disease>About 5% of the control expression was observed, suggesting a small residual activity in the mutated ARSA.</Disease>
<Disease>The second mutation, a G-to-A transition, occurred in the other allele and resulted in an altered splice-recognition sequence between exon 7 and the following intron.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutation also resulted in the loss of a restriction site.</Disease>
<Disease>Apparently normal levels of mRNA were generated from this allele, but no ARSA activity or immuno-cross-reactive material could be detected.</Disease>
<Disease>A collection of DNA samples from known or suspected MLD patients, members of their families, and normal controls was screened for these mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Four additional individuals carrying each of the mutations were found among the nearly 100 MLD patients in the sample.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Gene segregation in the original patients family was consistent with available clinical and biochemical data.</Disease>
<Disease>No individuals homozygous for either of these two mutations were identified.</Disease>

<Disease>However, combinations with other MLD mutations suggest that the point mutation in exon 3 does result in some residual enzyme activity and is associated with late-onset forms of the disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The splice-site mutation following exon 7 produces late-infantile MLD when combined with other enzyme-null mutations, implying that it is completely silent enzymatically..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Null mutation of the murine ATP7B (Wilson disease) gene results in intracellular copper accumulation and late-onset hepatic nodular transformation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The Atp7b protein is a copper-transporting ATPase expressed predominantly in the liver and to a lesser extent in most other tissues.</Disease>

<Disease>Mutations in the ATP7B gene lead to Wilson disease, a copper toxicity disorder characterized by dramatic build-up of intracellular hepatic copper with subsequent hepatic and neuro-logical abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Using homologous recombination to disrupt the normal translation of ATP7B, we have generated a strain of mice that are homozygous mutants (null) for the Wilson disease gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The ATP7B null mice display a gradual accumulation of hepatic copper that increases to a level 60-fold greater than normal by 5 months of age.</Disease>

<Disease>An increase in copper concentration was also observed in the kidney, brain, placenta and lactating mammary glands of homo-zygous mutants, although milk from the mutant glands was copper deficient.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Morphological abnormalities resembling cirrhosis developed in the majority of the livers from homozygous mutants older than 7 months of age.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Progeny of the homozygous mutant females demonstrated neurological abnormalities and growth retardation characteristic of copper deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Copper concentration in the livers of the newborn homozygous null mutants was decreased dramatically.</Disease>
<Disease>In summary, inactivation of the murine ATP7B gene produces a form of cirrhotic liver disease that resembles Wilson disease in humans and the toxic milk phenotype in the mouse..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Adrenoleukodystrophy and adrenomyeloneuropathy associated with partial adrenal insufficiency in three generations of a kindred.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Four cases of adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) and one case of adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) have developed in a kindred over three generations demonstrating that AMN is a clinical variant of ALD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pituitary-adrenal function studies were performed in 10 family members, including two affected males and four females identified as carriers of ALD/AMN.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No pituitary-adrenal abnormality was found in the carriers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, basal morning plasma adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) levels were markedly elevated in the two males with ALD and AMN, despite the fact that they had no clinical signs of adrenal insufficiency and that morning plasma cortisol levels and their response to maximal exogenous ACTH stimulation appeared to be normal.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, the integrated 24-hour response to the administration were also subnormal in these two cases.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, people with ALD and AMN may have subclinical partial adrenocrotical insufficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No other endocrinologic dysfunction was identified..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of mutations in the ALD-gene of 20 families with adrenoleukodystrophy/adrenomyeloneuropathy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), an X-linked inherited metabolic disorder, is the most frequent inborn peroxisomal disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It leads to demyelination in the central and peripheral nervous system.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Defective beta-oxidation of saturated very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs; C22  0-C26  0) in peroxisomes has been shown to lead to an accumulation of VLCFAs in leukoid areas of the central nervous system, peripheral nerves, adrenal gland, and blood.</Disease>
<Disease>The ALD gene has been recently identified and encodes a 745-amino-acid protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We screened patients with adrenoleukodystrophy/adrenomyeloneuropathy (ALD/AMN) from 20 kindreds for mutations in the ALD gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Eleven missense and two nonsense mutations, five deletions, and one insertion were detected by direct sequencing of eight reverse transcribed fragments of the ALD-gene mRNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Four mutations could be shown to be de novo.</Disease>
<Disease>All mutations could be confirmed in carriers by sequencing genomic DNA.</Disease>
<Disease>No correlation between the type of mutation and the severity of the phenotype could be observed.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutations were not detected in the ALD gene of 30 healthy persons..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Gonosomal mosaicism in myotonic dystrophy patients: involvement of mitotic events in (CTG)n repeat variation and selection against extreme expansion in sperm.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is caused by abnormal expansion of a polymorphic (CTG) n repeat, located in the DM protein kinase gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We determined the (CTG) n repeat lengths in a broad range of tissue DNAs from patients with mild, classical, or congenital manifestation of DM.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Differences in the repeat length were seen in somatic tissues from single DM individuals and twins.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Repeats appeared to expand to a similar extent in tissues originating from the same embryonal origin.</Disease>
<Disease>In most male patients carrying intermediate- or small-sized expansions in blood, the repeat lengths covered a markedly wider range in sperm.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, male patients with large allele expansions in blood (> 700 CTGs) had similar or smaller repeats in sperm, when detectable.</Disease>
<Disease>Sperm alleles with > 1, 000</Disease>
<Disease>CTGs were not seen.</Disease>
<Disease>We conclude that DM patients can be considered gonosomal mosaics, i. e e., combined somatic and germ-line tissue mosaics.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Most remarkably, we observed multiple cases where the length distributions of intermediate- or small-sized alleles in fathers sperm were significantly different from that in their offsprings blood.</Disease>

<Disease>Our combined findings indicate that intergenerational length changes in the unstable CTG repeat are most likely to occur during early embryonic mitotic divisions in both somatic and germ-line tissue formation.</Disease>

<Disease>Both the initial CTG length, the overall number of cell divisions involved in tissue formation, and perhaps a specific selection process in spermatogenesis may influence the dynamics of this process.</Disease>
<Disease>A model explaining mitotic instability and sex-dependent segregation phenomena in DM manifestation is discussed</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Combined analysis of hereditary prostate cancer linkage to 1q24-25: results from 772 hereditary prostate cancer families from the International Consortium for Prostate Cancer Genetics.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A previous linkage study provided evidence for a prostate cancer-susceptibility locus at 1q24-25.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Subsequent reports in additional collections of families have yielded conflicting results.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, evidence for locus heterogeneity has been provided by the identification of other putative hereditary prostate cancer loci on Xq27-28, 1q42-43, and 1p36.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The present study describes a combined analysis for six markers in the 1q24-25 region in 772 families affected by hereditary prostate cancer and ascertained by the members of the International Consortium for Prostate Cancer Genetics (ICPCG) from North America, Australia, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and the United Kingdom.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Overall, there was some evidence for linkage, with a peak parametric multipoint LOD score assuming heterogeneity (HLOD) of 1. 40 (P =. 01) at D1S212.</Disease>
<Disease>The estimated proportion of families (alpha) linked to the locus was.</Disease>
<Disease>06 (1-LOD support interval.</Disease>
<Disease>01-. 12).</Disease>
<Disease>This evidence was not observed by a nonparametric approach, presumably because of the extensive heterogeneity.</Disease>
<Disease>Further parametric analysis revealed a significant effect of the presence of male-to-male disease transmission within the families.</Disease>
<Disease>In the subset of 491 such families, the peak HLOD was 2.</Disease>
<Disease>In the subset of 491 such families, the peak HLOD was 2. 56 (P =. 0006) and alpha =. 11 (1-LOD support interval.</Disease>
<Disease>04-. 19), compared with HLODs of 0 in the remaining 281 families.</Disease>
<Disease>Within the families with male-to-male disease transmission, alpha increased with the early mean age at diagnosis (< 65 years, alpha =. 19, with 1-LOD support interval.</Disease>
<Disease>06-. 34) and the number of affected family members (five or more family members, alpha =. 15, with 1-LOD support interval.</Disease>
<Disease>04-. 28).</Disease>
<Disease>The highest value of alpha was observed for the 48 families that met all three criteria (peak HLOD = 2. 25, P =. 001, alpha =. 29, with 1-LOD support interval.</Disease>
<Disease>08-. 53).</Disease>
<Disease>These results support the finding of a prostate cancer-susceptibility gene linked to 1q24-25, albeit in a defined subset of prostate cancer families.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although HPC1 accounts for only a small proportion of all families affected by hereditary prostate cancer, it appears to play a more prominent role in the subset of families with several members affected at an early age and with male-to-male disease transmission.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A novel disease with deficiency of mitochondrial very-long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Palmitoyl-CoA dehydrogenase activity in skin fibroblasts from seven patients with unidentified defects of fatty acid oxidation was measured in the presence and absence of antibodies against medium-chain, long-chain, and very-long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenases (VLCAD).</Disease>

<Disease>Two of the patients, 4-5 month old boys, were found to have a novel disease, VLCAD deficiency, as judged from the results of very low palmitoyl-CoA dehydrogenase activity and the lack of immunoreactivity toward antibody raised to purified VLCAD..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Inherited WT1 mutation in Denys-Drash syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Patients with the Denys-Drash syndrome (Wilms tumor, genital anomalies, and nephropathy) have been demonstrated to carry de novo constitutional mutations in WT1, the Wilms tumor gene at chromosome 11p13.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report three new cases, two carrying a previously described WT1 exon 9 mutation and one with a novel WT1 exon 8 mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>However, unlike patients in previous reports, one of our three patients inherited the affected allele from his phenotypically unaffected father.</Disease>

<Disease>This observation indicates that the WT1 exon 9 mutation affecting 394Arg demonstrated in over one-half of the patients with the Denys-Drash syndrome may exhibit incomplete penetrance.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Consequently, familial studies in patients affected by this syndrome are recommended..</Disease>
<Disease>Glucose/galactose malabsorption caused by a defect in the Na+/glucose cotransporter.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Glucose/galactose malabsorption (GGM) is an autosomal recessive disease manifesting within the first weeks of life and characterized by a selective failure to absorb dietary glucose and galactose from the intestine.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The consequent severe diarrhoea and dehydration are usually fatal unless these sugars are eliminated from the diet.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Intestinal biopsies of GGM patients have revealed a specific defect in Na (+) -dependent absorption of glucose in the brush border.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Normal glucose absorption is mediated by the Na +/glucose cotransporter in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelium.</Disease>

<Disease>Cellular influx is driven by the transmembrane Na + electrochemical potential gradient; thereafter the sugar moves to the blood across the basolateral membrane via the facilitated glucose carrier.</Disease>
<Disease>We have previously cloned and sequenced a Na +/glucose cotransporter from normal human ileum and shown that this gene, SGLT1, resides on the distal q arm of chromosome 22.</Disease>
<Disease>We have now amplified SGLT1 complementary DNA and genomic DNA from members of a family affected with GGM by the polymerase chain reaction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sequence analysis of the amplified products has revealed a single missense mutation in SGLT1 which cosegregates with the GGM phenotype and results in a complete loss of Na (+) -dependent glucose transport in Xenopus oocytes injected with this complementary RNA..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Atm and Bax cooperate in ionizing radiation-induced apoptosis in the central nervous system.</Disease>

<Disease>Ataxia-telangiectasia is a hereditary multisystemic disease resulting from mutations of ataxia telangiectasia, mutated (ATM) and is characterized by neurodegeneration, cancer, immune defects, and hypersensitivity to ionizing radiation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The molecular details of ATM function in the nervous system are unclear, although the neurological lesion in ataxia-telangiectasia becomes apparent early in life, suggesting a developmental origin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The central nervous system (CNS) of Atm-null mice shows a pronounced defect in apoptosis induced by genotoxic stress, suggesting ATM functions to eliminate neurons with excessive genomic damage.</Disease>
<Disease>Here, we report that the death effector Bax is required for a large proportion of Atm-dependent apoptosis in the developing CNS after ionizing radiation (IR).</Disease>

<Disease>Although many of the same regions of the CNS in both Bax-/- and Atm-/- mice were radioresistant, mice nullizygous for both Bax and Atm showed additional reduction in IR-induced apoptosis in the CNS.</Disease>

<Disease>Therefore, although the major IR-induced apoptotic pathway in the CNS requires Atm and Bax, a p53-dependent collateral pathway exists that has both Atm- and Bax-independent branches.</Disease>
<Disease>Further, Atm- and Bax-dependent apoptosis in the CNS also required caspase-3 activation.</Disease>
<Disease>These data implicate Bax and caspase-3 as death effectors in neurodegenerative pathways..</Disease>
<Disease>Novel Tay-Sachs disease mutations from China.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We describe three HEXA mutations associated with infantile Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) in three unrelated nonconsanguineous Chinese families.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Novel mutations were found in two of these families.</Disease>
<Disease>The third is a previously reported mutation (G-- ></Disease>
<Disease>A transition at nt 1444) (Nakano et al., 1988).</Disease>
<Disease>Direct sequencing of PCR products identified a novel insertion of an A after nt 547 in family 1.</Disease>
<Disease>This change generates an early termination codon 6 bp downstream from the insertion site.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The exon 13 duplication in the BRCA1 gene is a founder mutation present in geographically diverse populations. The BRCA1 Exon 13 Duplication Screening Group.</Disease>

<Disease>Recently, a 6-kb duplication of exon 13, which creates a frameshift in the coding sequence of the BRCA1 gene, has been described in three unrelated U. S S. families of European ancestry and in one Portuguese family.</Disease>
<Disease>Here, our goal was to estimate the frequency and geographic diversity of carriers of this duplication.</Disease>

<Disease>To do this, a collaborative screening study was set up that involved 39 institutions from 19 countries and included 3, 580 unrelated individuals with a family history of the disease and 934 early-onset breast and/or ovarian cancer cases.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A total of 11 additional families carrying this mutation were identified in Australia (1), Belgium (1), Canada (1), Great Britain (6), and the United States (2).</Disease>
<Disease>Haplotyping showed that they are likely to derive from a common ancestor, possibly of northern British origin.</Disease>

<Disease>Our results demonstrate that it is strongly advisable, for laboratories carrying out screening either in English-speaking countries or in countries with historical links with Britain, to include within their BRCA1 screening protocols the polymerase chain reaction-based assay described in this report.</Disease>
<Disease>Germline mutations of the BRCA1 gene in breast and ovarian cancer families provide evidence for a genotype-phenotype correlation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the BRCA1 gene, discovered in 1994, are associated with an 80-90% lifetime risk of breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have analysed 60 families with a history of breast and/or ovarian cancer for germline mutations in BRCA1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Twenty-two different mutations were detected in 32 families (53%), of which 14 are previously unreported.</Disease>
<Disease>We observed a significant correlation between the location of the mutation in the gene and the ratio of breast to ovarian cancer incidence within each family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our data suggest a transition in risk such that mutations in the 3 third of the gene are associated with a lower proportion of ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Haplotype analysis supports previous data which suggest some BRCA1 mutation carriers have common ancestors; however, we have found at least two examples where recurrent mutations appear to have arisen independently..</Disease>
<Disease>Inactivation of the Friedreich ataxia mouse gene leads to early embryonic lethality without iron accumulation.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Friedreich ataxia (FRDA), the most common autosomal recessive ataxia, is caused in almost all cases by homozygous intronic expansions resulting in the loss of frataxin, a mitochondrial protein conserved through evolution, and involved in mitochondrial iron homeostasis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Yeast knockout models, and histological and biochemical data from patient heart biopsies or autopsies indicate that the frataxin defect causes a specific iron-sulfur protein deficiency and mitochondrial iron accumulation leading to the pathological changes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Affected human tissues are rarely available to further examine this hypothesis.</Disease>
<Disease>To study the mechanism of the disease, we generated a mouse model by deletion of exon 4 leading to inactivation of the Frda gene product.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We show that homozygous deletions cause embryonic lethality a few days after implantation, demonstrating an important role for frataxin during early development.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggest that the milder phenotype in humans is due to residual frataxin expression associated with the expansion mutations.</Disease>

<Disease>Surprisingly, in the frataxin knockout mouse, no iron accumulation was observed during embryonic resorption, suggesting that cell death could be due to a mechanism independent of iron accumulation..</Disease>

<Disease>In order to test the effect of this substitution, an in vitro mutagenized cDNA construct was introduced into a mammalian expression vector and transfected into monkey Cos-1 cells separately or along with a beta-cDNA expression vector.</Disease>

<Disease>This allowed the detection of some residual activity (12% of the positive control) when the mutant alpha-cDNA replaced its wild-type counterpart.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>For this reason, we compared the incidence of death from malignant neoplasms in 2 families of patients with A-T to that expected in a random sample of the general population.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A highly accurate, low cost test for BRCA1 mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>The hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome is associated with a high frequency of BRCA1 mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the widespread use of BRCA1 testing has been limited to date by three principal concerns  the fear of loss of health and life insurance, the uncertain clinical value of a positive test result, and the current lack of an inexpensive and sensitive screening test for BRCA1 mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>We have developed an inexpensive system for gene mutational scanning, based on a combination of extensive multiplex PCR amplification and two dimensional electrophoresis.</Disease>

<Disease>The efficiency of this system, as a screening test for BRCA1 mutations, was evaluated in a panel of 60 samples from high risk women, 14 of which contained a previously identified mutation in BRCA1.</Disease>
<Disease>All 14 mutations were identified, as well as an additional five that had previously escaped detection.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition to the 19 mutations, a total of 15 different polymorphic variants were scored, most of which were recurring.</Disease>
<Disease>All were confirmed by nucleotide sequencing.</Disease>

<Disease>The cost of screening per sample was calculated to be approximately US $ 70 for the manual technique used in this study, and may be reduced to approximately US $ 10 with the introduction of commercially available PCR robotics and fluorescent imaging.</Disease>

<Disease>Implementation of this method of mutation screening in the research and clinical setting should permit rapid accrual of quantitative data on genotype-phenotype associations for the evaluation of diagnostic testing..</Disease>

text: <Disease>In the initial 48 patients, SSCP analysis was followed by PTT for those patients for whom no detectable mutations were found by SSCP.</Disease>

<Disease>This mutation is the result of an internal duplication of 16-20 kilobases of the gene.</Disease>
<Disease>The structure of the mutant gene suggests that the duplication was not generated by a single unequal crossing-over event between two normal HPRT alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>Growth of Epstein-Barr virus-transformed lymphoblasts from this patient in selective medium has permitted isolation of spontaneous HPRT +</Disease>

text: <Disease>revertants of this mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>The reversion event involves a second major HPRT gene rearrangement where most or all of the duplicated portion of the mutant gene is deleted.</Disease>
<Disease>The original mutation therefore has the potential for spontaneous somatic reversion.</Disease>
<Disease>This may explain the relatively mild symptoms of the Lesch-Nyhan syndrome exhibited by this patient..</Disease>

text: <Disease>In two patients, decreased renal function appeared very soon after the administration of TF.</Disease>
<Disease>One patient showed gradually decreasing renal function beginning after two years of TF therapy.</Disease>
<Disease>An additional patient was identified who died with renal failure without having received TF.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The results suggest that renal failure occurs in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome more frequently than generally recognized and that administration of TF may precipitate or accelerate the renal disease in patients with this syndrome..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Aniridia-associated cytogenetic rearrangements suggest that a position effect may cause the mutant phenotype.</Disease>

<Disease>Genetic cholesteryl ester transfer protein deficiency caused by two prevalent mutations as a major determinant of increased levels of high density lipoprotein cholesterol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Genetic determinants of HDL cholesterol (HDL-C) levels in the general population are poorly understood.</Disease>

<Disease>We previously described plasma cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) deficiency due to an intron 14 G (+ 1) -to-A mutation (Int14 A) in several families with very high HDL-C levels in Japan.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Subjects with HDL-C > or = 100 mg/dl (n = 130) were screened by PCR single strand conformational polymorphism analysis of the CETP gene.</Disease>

<Disease>Two other mutations were identified by DNA sequencing or primer-mediated restriction map modification of PCR products  a novel intron 14 splice donor site mutation caused by a T insertion at position + 3 from the exon14/intron14 boundary (Int14 T) and a missense mutation (Asp442 to Gly) within exon 15 (D442G).</Disease>
<Disease>The Int14 T mutation was only found in one family.</Disease>

<Disease>However, the D442G and Int14 A mutations were highly prevalent in subjects with HDL-C > or = 60 mg/dl, with combined allele frequencies of 9%, 12%, 21% and 43% for HDL-C 60-79, 80-99, 100-119, and > or = 120 mg/dl, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>Furthermore, prevalences of the D442G and Int14 A mutations were extremely high in a general sample of Japanese men (n = 236), with heterozygote frequencies of 7% and 2%, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>These two mutations accounted for about 10% of the total variance of HDL-C in this population.</Disease>

<Disease>The phenotype in a genetic compound heterozygote (Int14 T and Int14 A) was similar to that of Int14 A homozygotes (no detectable CETP and markedly increased HDL-C), indicating that the Int14 T produces a null allele.</Disease>
<Disease>In four D442G homozygotes, mean HDL-C levels (86 +/- 26 mg/dl) were lower than in Int14 A homozygotes (158 +/- 35 mg/dl), reflecting residual CETP activity in plasma.</Disease>

<Disease>In 47 D442G heterozygotes, mean HDL-C levels were 91 +/- 23 mg/dl, similar to the level in D442G homozygotes, and significantly greater than mean HDL-C levels in Int14 A heterozygotes (69 +/- 15 mg/dl).</Disease>

<Disease>Thus, the D442G mutation acts differently to the null mutations with weaker effects on HDL in the homozygous state and stronger effects in the heterozygotes, suggesting dominant expression of a partially defective allele.</Disease>

<Disease>CETP deficiency, reflecting two prevalent mutations (D442G and Int14 A), is the first example of a genetic deficiency state which is sufficiently common to explain a significant fraction of the variation in HDL-C in the general population..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Human glycine decarboxylase gene (GLDC) and its highly conserved processed pseudogene (psiGLDC): their structure and expression, and the identification of a large deletion in a family with nonketotic hyperglycinemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the glycine decarboxylase gene (GLDC) cause nonketotic hyperglycinemia (NKH), an in-born error of metabolism characterized by severe neurological disturbance.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have determined the structure of GLDC and of its pseudogene (psiGLDC) and studied their expression for a molecular analysis of NKH.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The GLDC gene spans at least 135 kb and consists of 25 exons.</Disease>
<Disease>All donor and acceptor sites adhere to the canonical GT-AG rule, except for the donor site of intron 21, where a variant form GC is used instead of GT.</Disease>
<Disease>The transcription initiation site has been assigned to a residue 163 bp upstream from the translation initiation triplet by primer extension analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>The psiGLDC gene has no intron and shares 97.</Disease>
<Disease>5% homology with the coding region of functional GLDC, suggesting that psiGLDC is a processed pseudogene that arose from the GLDC transcript about 4-8 million years ago.</Disease>
<Disease>RNA blotting analysis has revealed that GLDC is expressed in human liver, kidney, brain, and placenta.</Disease>
<Disease>We have also examined a patient with NKH with no detectable GLDC mRNA in his lymphoblasts.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Exons 1-3 of the functional GLDC gene from this patient are not amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR), whereas those from control subjects are.</Disease>
<Disease>These results suggest a large homozygous deletion (at least 30 kb) in the patient.</Disease>

<Disease>Furthermore, we have devised a semi-quantitative PCR to estimate the number of GLDC alleles by using psiGLDC as an internal control and have confirmed the homozygosity and heterozygosity of the deletion in the patient and his parents, respectively.</Disease>
<Disease>Structural information of GLDC and psiGLDC should facilitate the molecular analysis of NKH.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Striking prevalence of ankylosing spondylitis in "healthy" w27 positive males and females.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Ankylosing spondylitis is diagnosed once or twice in each 1000 males and one tenth as frequently in females, but the true prevalence is unknown.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>The prevalence was similar in both sexes.</Disease>
<Disease>One hundred and twenty-six W27-negative controls matched for race, sex, and age failed to yield a single case.</Disease>
<Disease>For a person of either sex with HL-A W27, there appears to be about a 20 per cent chance that ankylosing spondylitis will develop, suggesting a prevalence of 10 to 15 per thousand.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Hitherto accepted figures may underestimate the frequency by a factor of 10 to 20..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T) is characterized by a markedly increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation, increased incidence of cancer, and neurodegeneration, especially of the cerebellar Purkinje cells.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Hereditary deficiency of the fifth component of complement in man. II. Biological properties of C5-deficient human serum.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The first known human kindred with hereditary deficiency of the fifth component of complement (C5) was documented in the accompanying report.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study examines several biological properties of C5-deficient (C5D) human serum, particularly sera obtained from two C5D homozygotes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The proband, who has inactive systemic lupus erythematosus is completely lacking C5, while her healthy half-sister has 1-2% of normal levels.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Both sera were severely impaired in their ability to generate chemotactic activity for normal human neutrophils upon incubation with aggregated human gamma-globulin or Escherichia coli endotoxin.</Disease>

<Disease>The gene for familial Mediterranean fever, MEFV, is expressed in early leukocyte development and is regulated in response to inflammatory mediators.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a recessive disorder characterized by episodes of fever and neutrophil-mediated serosal inflammation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We recently identified the gene causing FMF, designated MEFV, and found it to be expressed in mature neutrophils, suggesting that it functions as an inflammatory regulator.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To facilitate our understanding of the normal function of MEFV, we extended our previous studies.</Disease>

<Disease>MEFV messenger RNA was detected by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction in bone marrow leukocytes, with differential expression observed among cells by in situ hybridization.</Disease>
<Disease>CD34 hematopoietic stem-cell cultures induced toward the granulocytic lineage expressed MEFV at the myelocyte stage, concurrently with lineage commitment.</Disease>
<Disease>The prepromyelocytic cell line HL60 expressed MEFV only at granulocytic and monocytic differentiation.</Disease>
<Disease>MEFV was also expressed in the monocytic cell lines U937 and THP-1.</Disease>
<Disease>Among peripheral blood leukocytes, MEFV expression was detected in neutrophils, eosinophils, and to varying degrees, monocytes.</Disease>

<Disease>Consistent with the tissue specificity of expression, complete sequencing and analysis of upstream regulatory regions of MEFV revealed homology to myeloid-specific promoters and to more broadly expressed inflammatory promoter elements.</Disease>

<Disease>In vitro stimulation of monocytes with the proinflammatory agents interferon (IFN) gamma, tumor necrosis factor, and lipopolysaccharide induced MEFV expression, whereas the antiinflammatory cytokines interleukin (IL) 4, IL-10, and transforming growth factor beta inhibited such expression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Induction by IFN-gamma occurred rapidly and was resistant to cycloheximide.</Disease>
<Disease>IFN-alpha also induced MEFV expression.</Disease>
<Disease>In granulocytes, MEFV was up-regulated by IFN-gamma and the combination of IFN-alpha and colchicine.</Disease>
<Disease>These results refine understanding of MEFV by placing the gene in the myelomonocytic-specific proinflammatory pathway and identifying it as an IFN-gamma immediate early gene..</Disease>
<Disease>Spectrum of hSNF5/INI1 somatic mutations in human cancer and genotype-phenotype correlations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The hSNF5/INI1 gene which encodes a member of the SWI/SNF chromatin ATP-dependent remodeling complex, is a new tumor suppressor gene localized on chromosome 22q11.</Disease>

<Disease>Mutations were retrieved in most rhabdoid tumors, whatever their sites of occurrence, indicating the common pathogenetic origin of these tumors.</Disease>

text: <Disease>In contrast, hSNF5/INI1 point mutations were not detected in breast cancers, Wilms tumors, gliomas, ependymomas, sarcomas and other tumor types, even though most analyzed cases harbored loss of heterozygosity at 22q11.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Heterogeneity of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency in Algeria. Study in Northern Algeria with description of five new variants.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency was found in 3. 2% of the male population living in the urban area of Algiers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The deficient subjects originated from multiple geographic regions of Northern Algeria, with prevalence of individuals of Berber-Kabyle origin.</Disease>
<Disease>Red blood cell G6PD was partially purified and characterized in deficient males from 17 families, and six different variants were found.</Disease>
<Disease>Among them, only one, the Gd (-) Kabyle variant, had been previously described.</Disease>
<Disease>It was detected in nine families.</Disease>
<Disease>The other five variants were new  Gd (-) Laghouat (four cases), Gd (-) Blida (one case), Gd (-) Thenia (one case), Gd (-) Titteri (one case), and Gd (-) Alger (two brothers).</Disease>
<Disease>Strikingly, the common Mediterranean variant was not found.</Disease>
<Disease>G6PD deficiency is heterogeneous in northern Algeria where autochtonous variants seem to prevail.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Kabyle variant may be common in this country.</Disease>
<Disease>Fragile X syndrome without CCG amplification has an FMR1 deletion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We describe a patient with typical clinical features of the fragile X syndrome, but without cytogenetic expression of the fragile X or an amplified CCG trinucleotide repeat fragment.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The patient has a previously uncharacterized submicroscopic deletion encompassing the CCG repeat, the entire FMR1 gene and about 2. 5 megabases of flanking sequences.</Disease>

<Disease>This finding confirms that the fragile X phenotype can exist, without amplification of the CCG repeat or cytogenetic expression of the fragile X, and that fragile X syndrome is a genetically homogeneous disorder involving FMR1.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We also found random X-inactivation in the mother of the patient who was shown to be a carrier of this deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>Confirmation of linkage of Van der Woude syndrome to chromosome 1q32: evidence of association with STR alleles suggests possible unique origin of the disease mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Van der Woude syndrome (VWS) is an autosomal dominant craniofacial disorder with high penetrance and variable expression.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Its clinical features are variably expressed, but include cleft lip and/or cleft palate, lip pits and hypodontia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All VWS families studied to date map the disease gene to a < 2 cM region of chromosome 1q32, with no evidence of locus heterogeneity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The aim of this study is to refine the localization of the VWS gene and to further assess possible heterogeneity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We analyzed four multiplex VWS families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All available members were clinically assessed and genotyped for 19 short tandem repeat markers on chromosome 1 in the VWS candidate gene region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We performed two-point and multipoint limit of detection (LOD) score analyses using a high penetrance autosomal dominant model.</Disease>
<Disease>All families showed positive LOD scores without any recombination in the candidate region.</Disease>
<Disease>The largest two-point LOD score was 5. 87 87.</Disease>

<Disease>Our assay method for short tandem repeat (STR) markers provided highly accurate size estimation of marker allele fragment sizes, and therefore enabled us to determine the specific alleles segregating with the VWS gene in each of our four families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We observed a striking pattern of STR allele sharing at several closely linked loci among our four Caucasian VWS families recruited at three different locations in the US.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggest the possibility of a unique origin for a mutation responsible for many or most cases of VWS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The carrier frequency of the BRCA1 185delAG mutation is approximately 1 percent in Ashkenazi Jewish individuals.</Disease>

<Disease>Since BRCA1, the first major gene responsible for inherited breast cancer, was cloned, more than 50 unique mutations have been detected in the germline of individuals with breast and ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In high-risk pedigrees, female carriers of BRCA1 mutations have an 80-90% lifetime risk of breast cancer, and a 40-50% risk of ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, the mutation stats of individuals unselected for breast or ovarian cancer has not been determined, and it is not known whether mutations in such individuals confer the same risk of cancer as in individuals from the high-risk families studied so far.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Following the finding of a 185delAG frameshift mutation in several Ashkenazi Jewish breast/ovarian families, we have determined the frequency of this mutation in 858 Ashkenazim seeking genetic testing for conditions unrelated to cancer, and in 815 reference individuals not selected for ethnic origin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We observed the 185delAG mutation in 0.</Disease>
<Disease>9% of Ashkenazim (95% confidence limit, 0.</Disease>
<Disease>4-1. 8%) and in none of the reference samples.</Disease>
<Disease>Our results suggest that one in a hundred women of Ashkenazi descent may be at especially high risk of developing breast and/or ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Targeted modification of the apolipoprotein B gene results in hypobetalipoproteinemia and developmental abnormalities in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Familial hypobetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal codominant disorder resulting in a dramatic reduction in plasma concentrations of apolipoprotein (apo) B, cholesterol, and beta-migrating lipoproteins.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A benefit of hypobetalipoproteinemia is that mildly affected individuals may be protected from coronary vascular disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have used gene targeting to generate mice with a modified Apob allele.</Disease>

<Disease>Mice containing this allele display all of the hallmarks of human hypobetalipoproteinemia  they produce a truncated apoB protein, apoB70, and have markedly decreased plasma concentrations of apoB, beta-lipoproteins, and total cholesterol.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, the mice manifest several characteristics that are occasionally observed in human hypobetalipoproteinemia, including reduced plasma triglyceride concentrations, fasting chylomicronemia, and reduced high density lipoprotein cholesterol.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>An unexpected finding is that the modified Apob allele is strongly associated with exencephalus and hydrocephalus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These mice should help increase our understanding of hypobetalipoproteinemia, atherogenesis, and the etiology of exencephalus and hydrocephalus..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Common mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 do not contribute to early prostate cancer in Jewish men.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND  Families with a high incidence of hereditary breast cancer, and subsequently shown to have terminating mutations in BRCA1 or BRCA2, appear to have a higher incidence of prostate cancer among male relatives.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We aimed to determine whether the common germline mutations of BRCA1 or BRCA2 in Ashkenazi Jewish men predisposed them to prostate cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  </Disease>
<Disease>We examined genomic DNA from 83 (for BRCA1 185delAG) or 82 (for BRCA2 6174delT)</Disease>
<Disease>Ashkenazi Jewish prostate cancer patients, most of whom were treated at a relatively young age, for the most common germline mutation in each gene seen in the Ashkenazi population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS  Our study should have been able to detect a 4-5-fold increase in the risk of prostate cancer due to mutation of BRCA1 or BRCA2.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, only one (1. 15%; 95% confidence interval, 0-3. 6%) of the patients was heterozygous for the BRCA1 mutant allele, and only two were heterozygous for the BRCA2 mutation (2. 4%; 95% confidence interval, 0-6. 2%).</Disease>

<Disease>CONCLUSIONS  The incidence of each of the germline mutations in these prostate cancer patients closely matched their incidence (about 1%) in the general Ashkenazi Jewish population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This suggests that unlike cases of breast and ovarian cancers, mutations in BRCA1 or BRCA2 do not significantly predispose men to prostate cancer</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two new variants of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase associated with hereditary non-spherocytic hemolytic anemia: G6PD Wayne and G6PD Huron.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two new deficient variants of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) causing hereditary nonspherocytic hemolytic anemia (HNSHA) are described.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Both of these are unique and they have been named G6PD Wayne and G6PD Huron.</Disease>
<Disease>Patients with G6PD Wayne underwent splenectomy and no objective improvement was noted.</Disease>

<Disease>The patients with G6PD Huron were under medical observation for a considerable period of time without the diagnosis of G6PD deficiency being entertained because the family was of Northern European origin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Since sporadic variants of G6PD causing HNSHA show no special racial predilection, the diagnosis of G6PD deficiency should always be considered in patients with this syndrome..</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>From data collected in a North American Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) heterozygote screening program, the TSD carrier frequency among 46, 304 Jewish individuals was found to be.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>0324 (1 in 31 individuals).</Disease>
<Disease>This frequency is consistent with earlier estimates based on TSD incidence data.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>TSD carrier frequencies were then examined by single country and single region of origin in 28, 029 Jews within this sample for whom such data were available for analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Jews with Polish and/or Russian ancestry constituted 88% of this sample and had a TSD carrier frequency of. 0327.</Disease>

text: <Disease>These findings suggest that the TSD gene proliferated among the antecedents of modern Ashkenazi Jewry after the Second Diaspora (70 A. D.) and before their major migrations to regions of Poland and Russia (before 1100 A. D.).  </Disease>

text: <Disease>Novel inherited mutations and variable expressivity of BRCA1 alleles, including the founder mutation 185delAG in Ashkenazi Jewish families.</Disease>
<Disease>Thirty-seven families with four or more cases of breast cancer or breast and ovarian cancer were analyzed for mutations in BRCA1.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Twelve different germ-line mutations, four novel and eight previously observed, were detected in 16 families.</Disease>
<Disease>Five families of Ashkenazi Jewish descent carried the 185delAG mutation and shared the same haplotype at eight polymorphic markers spanning approximately 850 kb at BRCA1.</Disease>
<Disease>Expressivity of 185delAG in these families varied, from early-onset breast cancer without ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation 4184delTCAA occurred independently in two families.</Disease>

<Disease>In one family, penetrance was complete, with females developing early-onset breast cancer or ovarian cancer and the male carrier developing prostatic cancer, whereas, in the other family, penetrance was incomplete and only breast cancer occurred, diagnosed at ages 38-81 years.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A 665-nt segment of the BRCA1 3-UTR and 1. 3 kb of genomic sequence including the putative promoter region were invariant by single-strand conformation analysis in 13 families without coding-sequence mutations.</Disease>

<Disease>Overall in our series, BRCA1 mutations have been detected in 26 families  16 with positive BRCA1 lod scores, 7 with negative lod scores (reflecting multiple sporadic breast cancers), and 3 not tested for linkage.</Disease>

<Disease>Transgenic mice carrying large human genomic sequences with expanded CTG repeat mimic closely the DM CTG repeat intergenerational and somatic instability.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is caused by a CTG repeat expansion in the 3UTR of the DM protein kinase (DMPK) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A very high level of instability is observed through successive generations and the size of the repeat is generally correlated with the severity of the disease and with age at onset.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, tissues from DM patients exhibit somatic mosaicism that increases with age.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We generated transgenic mice carrying large human genomic sequences with 20, 55 or > 300 CTG, cloned from patients from the same affected DM family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Using large human flanking sequences and a large amplification, we demonstrate that the intergenerational CTG repeat instability is reproduced in mice, with a strong bias towards expansions and with the same sex-</Disease>
<Disease>and size-dependent characteristics as in humans.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, a high level of instability, increasing with age, can be observed in tissues and in sperm.</Disease>

<Disease>Although we did not observe dramatic expansions (or big jumps over several hundred CTG repeats) as in congenital forms of DM, our model carrying > 300 CTG is the first to show instability so close to the human DM situation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our three models carrying different sizes of CTG repeat provide insight on the different factors modulating the CTG repeat instability..</Disease>

<Disease>Age of onset in Huntington disease : sex specific influence of apolipoprotein E genotype and normal CAG repeat length.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Age of onset (AO) of Huntington disease (HD) is known to be correlated with the length of an expanded CAG repeat in the HD gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype, in turn, is known to influence AO in Alzheimer disease, rendering the APOE gene a likely candidate to affect AO in other neurological diseases too.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We therefore determined APOE genotype and normal CAG repeat length in the HD gene for 138 HD patients who were previously analysed with respect to CAG repeat length.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Genotyping for APOE was performed blind to clinical information.</Disease>

<Disease>In addition to highlighting the effect of the normal repeat length upon AO in maternally inherited HD and in male patients, we show that the APOE epsilon2epsilon3 genotype is associated with significantly earlier AO in males than in females.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Such a sex difference in AO was not apparent for any of the other APOE genotypes.</Disease>
<Disease>Our findings suggest that subtle differences in the course of the neurodegeneration  in HD  may allow interacting genes to exert gender specific effects upon AO.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Detection of a novel arginine vasopressin defect by dideoxy fingerprinting.</Disease>
<Disease>Autosomal dominant neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus is a familial form of diabetes insipidus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This disorder is associated with variable levels of arginine vasopressin (AVP) and diabetes insipidus of varying severity, which responds to exogenous AVP.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To determine the molecular basis of autosomal dominant neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus, the AVP genes of members of a large kindred were analyzed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A new method, called dideoxy fingerprinting, was used to detect an AVP mutation that was characterized by DNA sequencing.</Disease>

<Disease>The novel defect found changes the last codon of the AVP signal peptide from alanine to threonine, which should perturb cleavage of mature AVP from its precursor protein and inhibit its secretion or action..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Mutations of APC appear to initiate sporadic and inherited forms of human colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although these mutations have been well characterized, little is known about the function of the APC gene product.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two cellular proteins that associate with APC were identified by nucleotide sequence analysis and peptide mapping as the E-cadherin-associated proteins alpha- and beta-catenin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A 27-residue fragment of APC containing a 15-amino acid repeat was sufficient for the interaction with the catenins.</Disease>
<Disease>These results suggest an important link between tumor initiation and cell adhesion..</Disease>

text: <Disease>von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is an autosomal dominantly inherited cancer syndrome predisposing to a variety of tumor types that include retinal hemangioblastomas, hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system, renal cell carcinomas, pancreatic cysts and tumors, pheochromocytomas, endolymphatic sac tumors, and epididymal cystadenomas [W. text: <Disease>Med.</Disease>

<Disease>The VHL gene was localized to chromosome 3p25-26 and cloned [F. Latif et al., Science (Washington DC), 260  1317-1320, 1993].</Disease>

<Disease>Mutat., 12  417-423, 1998).</Disease>
<Disease>In the present study, we report the use of fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) as a method to detect and characterize VHL germline deletions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We reexamined a group of VHL patients shown previously by single-strand conformation and sequencing analysis not to harbor point mutations in the VHL locus.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We found constitutional deletions in 29 of 30 VHL patients in this group using cosmid and P1 probes that cover the VHL locus.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We then tested six phenotypically normal offspring from four of these VHL families  two were found to carry the deletion and the other four were deletion-free.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>In sum, FISH was found to be a simple and reliable method to detect VHL germline deletions and practically useful in cases where other methods of screening have failed to detect a VHL gene abnormality</Disease>

text: <Disease>Aberrant subcellular localization of BRCA1 in breast cancer.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The BRCA1 gene product was identified as a 220-kilodalton nuclear phosphoprotein in normal cells, including breast ductal epithelial cells, and in 18 of 20 tumor cell lines derived from tissues other than breast and ovary.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In 16 of 17 breast and ovarian cancer lines and 17 of 17 samples of cells obtained from malignant effusions, however, BRCA1 localized mainly in cytoplasm.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Absence of BRCA1 or aberrant subcellular location was also observed to a variable extent in histological sections of many breast cancer biopsies.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings suggest that BRCA1 abnormalities may be involved in the pathogenesis of many breast cancers, sporadic as well as familial..</Disease>

text: <Disease>HLA B27 and the genetics of ankylosing spondylitis.</Disease>

text: <Disease>One hundred and twenty-eight of 145 patients with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) were found to be HLA B27 positive.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Five patients had evidence of a sero-negative peripheral arthritis resembling peripheral psoriatic arthritis and 3 of these were B27 negative.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>One further B27 negative patients had a sister with ankylosing spondylitis and ulcerative colitis and a mother with ulcerative colitis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There was evidence of a somewhat later age of onset of symptoms in B27 negative patients.</Disease>

<Disease>These findings are interpreted as suggesting some degree of clinical and genetic heterogeneity in ankylosing spondylitis with genes for psoriasis and inflammatory bowel disease being important in some individuals, particularly those who are B27 negative.</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>Twenty-five first-degree relatives with ankylosing spondylitis were all B27 positive.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The only instance of disassociation of B27 and spondylitis in a family was where the proband had ulcerative colitis as well as spondylitis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Of 13 B27 positive fathers 3 could be diagnosed as having definite ankylosing spondylitis (23%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings are thought to provide evidence against the concept that the gene for ankylosing spondylitis is not B27 but a closely linked gene and favour the occurrence of an environmental event affecting approximately one-fifth of B27 positive males to result in disease..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Late infantile metachromatic leukodystrophy in Israel.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Metachromatic Leukodystrophy (MLD) is a neurodegenerative disease in which the lysosomal enzyme, Aryl sulfatase A (ARSA) is deficient.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The disease is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait and its frequency is estimated to be 1/40, 000 live births.</Disease>
<Disease>The gene of ARSA has been cloned and up to now eight mutations causing MLD have been reported.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Another mutation, PD, leads to the deficiency of the enzyme in vitro (pseudodeficiency) without any known clinical effect.</Disease>
<Disease>The PD mutation is frequent in all populations.</Disease>
<Disease>In Israel, late infantile MLD was found to be very frequent in a small Jewish isolate, the Habbanite Jews (1/75 live births).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The molecular analysis demonstrated that in the Habbanite population, the mutation occurred on an allele with the PD mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>The loss of ARSA activity is due to a point mutation C > T leading to a change of proline to leucine.</Disease>
<Disease>MLD is also frequent among Moslem Arabs in Jerusalem.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation is a transition G ></Disease>
<Disease>A destroying the splice donor site of exon 2.</Disease>
<Disease>This mutation has been reported in patients with the late infantile MLD from different ethnic groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Christian Arabs in Israel also have a high incidence of the disease (1/10, 000 live births); the mutation in this population is still unknown.</Disease>

<Disease>Knowledge of the different mutations causing MLD in these defined populations will allow a carrier screening program to be carried out and prevent the birth of additional affected children..</Disease>
