text: <Disease>Genomic rearrangements of the APC tumor-suppressor gene in familial adenomatous polyposis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Germline mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor gene result in the hereditary colorectal cancer syndrome familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Almost all APC mutations that have been identified are single-nucleotide alterations, small insertions, or small deletions that would truncate the protein product of the gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No well-characterized intragenic rearrangement of APC has been described, and the prevalence of this type of mutation in FAP patients is not clear.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We screened 49 potential FAP families and identified 26 different germline APC mutations in 30 families.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Four of these mutations were genomic rearrangements resulting from homologous and nonhomologous recombinations mediated by Alu elements.</Disease>
<Disease>Two of these four rearrangements were complex, involving deletion and insertion of nucleotides.</Disease>
<Disease>Of these four rearrangements, one resulted in the deletion of exons 11 and 12 and two others resulted in either complete or partial deletion of exon 14.</Disease>
<Disease>The fourth rearrangement grossly altered the sequence within intron 14.</Disease>
<Disease>Although this rearrangement did not affect any coding sequence of APC at the genomic DNA level, it caused inappropriate splicing of exon 14.</Disease>
<Disease>These rearrangements were initially revealed by analyzing cDNAs and could not have been identified by using mutation detection methods that screened each exon individually.</Disease>
<Disease>The identification of a rearrangement that did not alter any coding exons yet affected the splicing further underscores the importance of using cDNA for mutation analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>The identification of four genomic rearrangements among 30 mutations suggests that genomic rearrangements are frequent germline APC mutations..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial male breast cancer is not linked to the BRCA1 locus on chromosome 17q.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Breast cancer in men is about a hundredfold less common than in women and this has hindered research into its genetic basis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have examined 22 families with at least one case of male breast cancer for linkage to the hereditary breast and ovarian cancer locus, BRCA1, on chromosome 17q.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We found strong evidence against linkage to BRCA1 (lod score-16. 63) and the best estimate of the proportion of linked families was 0% (95% CI 0-18%).</Disease>
<Disease>Our results indicate that there is a gene (s) other than BRCA1 which predisposes to early-onset breast cancer in women and which confers a higher risk of male breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of additional pedigrees that include cases of male breast cancer may therefore facilitate the mapping and isolation of this gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Evidence for inter-generational instability in the CAG repeat in the MJD1 gene and for conserved haplotypes at flanking markers amongst Japanese and Caucasian subjects with Machado-Joseph disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The size of the (CAG)n repeat array in the 3' end of the MJD1 gene and the haplotype at a series of microsatellite markers surrounding the MJD1 gene were examined in a large cohort of Japanese and Caucasian subjects affected with Machado-Joseph disease (MJD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our data provide five novel observations.</Disease>

<Disease>First, MJD is associated with expansion fo the array from the normal range of 14-37 repeats to 68-84 repeats in most Japanese and Caucasian subjects, but no subjects were observed with expansions intermediate in size between those of the normal and MJD affected groups.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Second, the expanded allele associated with MJD displays inter-generational instability, particularly in male meioses, and this instability was associated with the clinical phenomenon of anticipation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Third, the size of the expanded allele is not only inversely correlated with the age-of-onset of MJD (r = -0.738, p < 0.001), but is also correlated with the frequency of other clinical features [e.g. pseudoexophthalmos and pyramidal signs were more frequent in subjects with large repeats (p < 0.001 and</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>p < 0.05 respectively)].</Disease>

<Disease>Fourth, the disease phenotype is significantly more severe and had an early age of onset (16 years) in a subject homozygous for the expanded allele, which contrasts with Huntington disease and suggests that the expanded allele in the MJD1 gene could exert its effect either by a dominant negative effect (putatively excluded in HD) or by a gain of function effect as proposed for HD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Finally, Japanese and Caucasian subjects affected with MJD share haplotypes at several markers surrounding the MJD1 gene, which are uncommon in the normal Japanese and Caucasian population, and which suggests the existence either of common founders in these populations or of chromosomes susceptible to pathologic expansion of the CAG repeat in the MJD1 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial Prader-Willi syndrome with apparently normal chromosomes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report on 4 sibs (2F, 2M) with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Diagnosis was made clinically on the basis of history, behavior, and physical findings in 3 of the sibs.</Disease>
<Disease>The other child had died at age 10 months with a history and clinical findings typical of first phase of PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Results of chromosome studies on the parents and surviving sibs were normal.</Disease>
<Disease>The implications of this unusual familial occurrence for our understanding of PWS are discussed..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Age at diagnosis as an indicator of eligibility for BRCA1 DNA testing in familial breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We searched for criteria that could indicate breast cancer families with a high prior probability of being caused by the breast/ovarian cancer susceptibility locus BRCA1 on chromosome 17.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To this end, we performed a linkage study with 59 consecutively collected Dutch breast cancer families, including 16 with at least one case of ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We used an intake cut-off of at least three first-degree relatives with breast and/or ovarian cancer at any age.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Significant evidence for linkage was found only among the 13 breast cancer families with a mean age at diagnosis of less than 45 years.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An unexpectedly low proportion of the breast-ovarian cancer families were estimated to be linked to BRCA1, which could be due to a founder effect in the Dutch population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Given the expected logistical problems in clinical management now that BRCA1 has been identified, we propose an interim period in which only families with a strong positive family history for early onset breast and/or ovarian cancer will be offered BRCA1 mutation testing..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Some Mexican glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase variants revisited.</Disease>
<Disease>Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency appears to be fairly common in Mexico.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have now examined the DNA of three previously reported electrophoretically fast Mexican G6PD variants, -G6PD Distrito Federal, G6PD Tepic, and G6PD Castilla.</Disease>

<Disease>All three of these variants, believed on the basis of biochemical characterization and population origin to be unique, have the G----A transition at nucleotide 202 and the A----G transition at nucleotide 376, mutations that we now recognize to be characteristic of G6PD A-.</Disease>
<Disease>Two other Mexican males with G6PD deficiency were found to have the same mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All five have the (NlaIII/FokI/PvuII/PstI) haplotype characteristic of G6PD A -in Africa.</Disease>

<Disease>Since the PvuII + genotype seems to be rare in Europe, we conclude that all of these G6PD A - genes had their ancient origin in Africa, although in many of the Mexican patients with G6PD A -202A/376G the gene may have been imported more recently from Spain, where this variant, formerly known as G6PD Betica, is also prevalent..</Disease>
<Disease>Inactivation of germline mutant APC alleles by attenuated somatic mutations: a molecular genetic mechanism for attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Germline mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor gene result in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Patients with FAP typically develop hundreds to thousands of benign colorectal tumors and early-onset colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A subset of germline APC mutations results in an attenuated FAP (AFAP) phenotype, in which patients develop fewer tumors and develop them at an older age.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although a genotype-phenotype correlation between the locations of APC germline mutations and the development of AFAP has been well documented, the mechanism for AFAP has not been well defined.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We investigated the mechanism for AFAP in patients carrying a mutant APC allele (APC (AS9)) that has a mutation in the alternatively spliced region of exon 9.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>APC (AS9) was found to down-regulate beta-catenin-regulated transcription, the major tumor-suppressor function of APC, as did the wild-type APC.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation analysis showed that both APC (AS9) and the wild-type APC alleles were somatically mutated in most colorectal tumors from these patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Functional analysis showed that 4666insA, a common somatic mutation in APC (AS9) in these tumors, did not inactivate the wild-type APC.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our results indicate that carriers of APC (AS9) develop fewer colorectal tumors than do typical patients with FAP because somatic inactivation of both APC alleles is necessary for colorectal tumorigenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, these patients develop colorectal tumors more frequently than does the general population because APC (AS9) is inactivated by mutations that do not inactivate the wild-type APC..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Submicroscopic deletions at the WAGR locus, revealed by nonradioactive in situ hybridization.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) with biotin-labeled probes mapping to 11p13 has been used for the molecular analysis of deletions of the WAGR (Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, and mental retardation) locus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have detected a submicroscopic 11p13 deletion in a child with inherited aniridia who subsequently presented with Wilms tumor in a horseshoe kidney, only revealed at surgery.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mother, who has aniridia, was also found to carry a deletion including both the aniridia candidate gene (AN2) and the Wilms tumor predisposition gene (WT1).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This is therefore a rare case of an inherited WAGR deletion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Wilms tumor has so far only been associated with sporadic de novo aniridia cases.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have shown that a cosmid probe for a candidate aniridia gene, homologous to the mouse Pax-6 gene, is deleted in cell lines from aniridia patients with previously characterized deletions at 11p13, while another cosmid marker mapping between two aniridia-associated translocation breakpoints (and hence a second candidate marker) is present on both chromosomes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These results support the Pax-6 homologue as a strong candidate for the AN2 gene.</Disease>
<Disease>FISH with cosmid probes has proved to be a fast and reliable technique for the molecular analysis of deletions.</Disease>
<Disease>It can be used with limited amounts of material and has strong potential for clinical applications..</Disease>
<Disease>Haplotype studies in Wilson disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In 51 families with Wilson disease, we have studied DNA haplotypes of dinucleotide repeat polymorphisms (CA repeats) in the 13q14.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>3 region, to examine these markers for association with the Wilson disease gene (WND).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition to a marker (D13S133) described elsewhere, we have developed three new highly polymorphic markers (D13S314, D13S315, and D13S316) close to the WND locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have examined the distribution of marker alleles at the loci studied and have found that D13S314, D13S133, and D13S316 each show nonrandom distribution on chromosomes carrying the WND mutation.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Growth hormone treatment increases CO(2) response, ventilation and central inspiratory drive in children with Prader-Willi syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We studied whether the beneficial effects of growth hormone (GH) treatment on growth and body composition in PWS are accompanied by an improvement in respiratory function.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We measured resting ventilation, airway occlusion pressure (P (0. 1)) and ventilatory response to CO (2) in nine children, aged 7-14 years, before and 6-9 months after the start of GH treatment.</Disease>
<Disease>During GH treatment, resting ventilation increased by 26%, P (0. 1) by 72% and the response to CO (2) by 65% (P < 0. 002, < 0.</Disease>
<Disease>04 and < 0. 02, respectively).</Disease>
<Disease>This observed increase in ventilatory output was not correlated to changes in body mass index.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION  Treatment of children with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) seems to have a stimulatory effect on central respiratory structures.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The observed increase in ventilation and inspiratory drive may contribute to the improved activity level reported by parents of PWS children during growth hormone therapy</Disease>

text: <Disease>Somatic von Hippel-Lindau mutation in clear cell papillary cystadenoma of the epididymis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Papillary cystadenoma of the epididymis is an uncommon benign lesion that may occur sporadically or as a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Neither immunohistochemical studies nor molecular genetic analyses of the VHL gene have been reported previously for this lesion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The authors describe two cases of clear cell papillary cystadenoma of the epididymis, both of which were initially confused with metastatic renal cell carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Both lesions showed positive immunohistochemical staining for low and intermediate molecular weight keratins (Cam 5. 2 and AE1/AE3), EMA, vimentin, alpha 1-antitrypsin, and alpha 1-antichymotrypsin.</Disease>
<Disease>Each was negative for CEA.</Disease>

<Disease>Because clear cell papillary cystadenoma is similar to renal cell carcinoma histologically, and because both occur as components of the von Hippel-Lindau disease complex, the authors analyzed both cases for the presence of mutations in the VHL gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A somatic VHL gene mutation was detected in one of the two tumors by polymerase chain reaction followed by single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Direct sequencing revealed a cytosine to thymine transition at nucleotide 694, resulting in the replacement of an arginine with a stop codon after the sixth amino acid of exon 3.</Disease>

<Disease>As the VHL gene is believed to function as a tumor suppressor gene, VHL gene mutations may play a role in the initiation of tumorigenesis in sporadic cystadenomas of the epididymis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An evaluation of genetic heterogeneity in 145 breast-ovarian cancer families. Breast Cancer Linkage Consortium.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The breast-ovary cancer-family syndrome is a dominant predisposition to cancer of the breast and ovaries which has been mapped to chromosome region 17q12-q21.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The majority, but not all, of breast-ovary cancer families show linkage to this susceptibility locus, designated BRCA1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report here the results of a linkage analysis of 145 families with both breast and ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These families contain either a total of three or more cases of early-onset (before age 60 years) breast cancer or ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All families contained at least one case of ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Overall, an estimated 76% of the 145 families are linked to the BRCA1 locus.</Disease>

<Disease>None of the 13 families with cases of male breast cancer appear to be linked, but it is estimated that 92% (95% confidence interval 76% -100%) of families with no male breast cancer and with two or more ovarian cancers are linked to BRCA1.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These data suggest that the breast-ovarian cancer-family syndrome is genetically heterogeneous.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the large majority of families with early-onset breast cancer and with two or more cases of ovarian cancer are likely to be due to BRCA1 mutations..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Genetic analysis in families with van der Woude syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have brought together information on 864 affected individuals in 164 families (including three new pedigrees) reported in the 137 year period since 1845 when Demarquay first described a family with what was later called van der Woude syndrome (VWS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Both types of oral cleft, cleft palate (CP) and cleft lip with or without CP (CLP), segregate in these families together with lower lip pits or fistulae in an autosomal dominant mode with high penetrance estimated to be K =. 89 and.</Disease>

text: <Disease>99 by different methods.</Disease>

label: Disease

Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>On the other hand, we do not find the usually observed excess of females with CP and excess of males with CLP; in VWS the sex ratios are more nearly equal.</Disease>

<Disease>The expression of VWS is significantly modified by the genetic background  More extreme phenotypes in parents tend to produce more extreme expression in their children.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Molecular and phenotypic analysis of patients with deletions within the deletion-rich region of the Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Eighty unrelated individuals with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)or Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) were found to have deletions in the major deletion-rich region of the DMD locus.</Disease>

text: <Disease>This region includes the last five exons detected by cDNA5b-7, all exons detected by cDNA8, and the first two exons detected by cDNA9.</Disease>
<Disease>These 80 individuals account for approximately 75% of 109 deletions of the gene, detected among 181 patients analyzed with the entire dystrophin cDNA.</Disease>
<Disease>Endpoints for many of these deletions were further characterized using two genomic probes, p20 (DXS269; Wapenaar et al.)</Disease>
<Disease>and GMGX11 (DXS239; present paper).</Disease>

text: <Disease>Thus, with two exceptions, frameshift deletions of the gene resulted in more severe phenotype than did in-frame deletions.</Disease>

<Disease>Proteolipoprotein gene analysis in 82 patients with sporadic Pelizaeus-Merzbacher Disease: duplications, the major cause of the disease, originate more frequently in male germ cells, but point mutations do not. The Clinical European Network on Brain Dysmyelinating Disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Pelizaeus-Merzbacher Disease (PMD) is an X-linked developmental defect of myelination affecting the central nervous system and segregating with the proteolipoprotein (PLP) locus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Investigating 82 strictly selected sporadic cases of PMD, we found PLP mutations in 77%; complete PLP-gene duplications were the most frequent abnormality (62%), whereas point mutations in coding or splice-site regions of the gene were involved less frequently (38%).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We analyzed the maternal status of 56 cases to determine the origin of both types of PLP mutation, since this is relevant to genetic counseling.</Disease>

<Disease>In the 22 point mutations, 68% of mothers were heterozygous for the mutation, a value identical to the two-thirds of carrier mothers that would be expected if there were an equal mutation rate in male and female germ cells.</Disease>

<Disease>In sharp contrast, among the 34 duplicated cases, 91% of mothers were carriers, a value significantly (chi2 = 9. 20, P <. 01) in favor of a male bias, with an estimation of the male/female mutation frequency (k) of 9. 3 3.</Disease>

<Disease>Moreover, we observed the occurrence of de novo mutations between parental and grandparental generations in 17 three-generation families, which allowed a direct estimation of the k value (k = 11).</Disease>
<Disease>Again, a significant male mutation imbalance was observed only for the duplications.</Disease>
<Disease>Haplotype analysis of the phenylalanine hydroxylase gene in Turkish phenylketonuria families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have estimated the haplotype distribution of mutant and normal phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) alleles for 17 Turkish phenylketonuria (PKU) families  20 normal and 27 mutated PAH alleles could be identified.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Of the latter, the most prevalent were associated with haplotype 6 (29. 6%), 1 (18. 5%) and 36 (11. 1%), while the normal alleles were preferentially associated with haplotype 1 (20%).</Disease>
<Disease>Of the 19 different haplotypes observed, 5 have not been described previously.</Disease>
<Disease>The haplotype distribution differed significantly from that of the Northern European population.</Disease>
<Disease>Two of the eight polymorphic sites were in association with PKU.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No deletions of exon sequences were found in the families analysed.</Disease>
<Disease>Cloning of human very-long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase and molecular characterization of its deficiency in two patients.</Disease>

<Disease>Two overlapping cDNA clones (1, 991 bp and 736 bp, respectively) encoding the precursor of human mitochondrial very-long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (VLCAD) were cloned and sequenced.</Disease>

<Disease>The cDNA inserts of these clones together encompass a region of 2, 177 bases, encoding the entire protein of 655 amino acids, including a 40-amino acid leader peptide and a 615-amino acid mature polypeptide.</Disease>
<Disease>PCR-amplified VLCAD cDNAs were sequenced in cultured fibroblasts from two VLCAD-deficient patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In both patients, a 105-bp deletion encompassing bases 1078-1182 in VLCAD cDNA was identified.</Disease>
<Disease>The deletion seems to occur due to exon skipping during processing of VLCAD pre-mRNA.</Disease>
<Disease>This is the first demonstration of a mutation causing VLCAD deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Quantitative cDNA expression of normal human VLCAD was performed in the patients fibroblasts, using vaccinia viral system, which demonstrated that the deficiency of the normal VLCAD protein causes impaired long-chain fatty acid beta-oxidation activity in the patients fibroblasts.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In patient fibroblasts, raising VLCAD activity to approximately 20% of normal control fibroblast activity raised palmitic acid beta-oxidation flux to the level found in control fibroblasts, which may offer important information for the rational design of future somatic gene therapy for VLCAD deficiency..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Mutations in the RB1 gene and their effects on transcription.</Disease>
<Disease>Inactivation of both alleles of the RB1 gene during normal retinal development initiates the formation of a retinoblastoma (RB) tumor.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To identify the mutations which inactivate RB1, 21 RB tumors isolated from 19 patients were analyzed with the polymerase chain reaction or an RNase protection assay or both.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations were identified in 13 of 21 RB tumors; in 8 tumors, the precise errors in nucleotide sequence were characterized.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Each of four germ line mutations involved a small deletion or duplication, while three somatic mutations were point mutations leading to splice alterations and loss of an exon from the mature RB1 mRNA.</Disease>

<Disease>We were unable to detect expression of the mutant allele in lymphoblasts of three bilaterally affected patients, although the mutation was present in the genomic DNA and transcripts containing the mutations were obvious in the RB tumors in the absence of a normal RB1 allele.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The variations in the level of expression of mutant transcripts suggest deregulation of RB1 transcription in the absence of a functional RB1 gene product..</Disease>
<Disease>Resolution of the two loci for autosomal dominant aniridia, AN1 and AN2, to a single locus on chromosome 11p13.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two distinct loci have been proposed for aniridia; AN1 for autosomal dominant aniridia on chromosome 2p and AN2 for the aniridia in the WAGR contiguous gene syndrome on chromosome 11p13.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this report, the kindred segregating for autosomal dominant aniridia, which suggested linkage to acid phosphatase-1 (ACP1) and led to the assignment of the AN1 locus on chromosome 2p, has been updated and expanded.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Linkage analysis between the aniridia phenotype and ACP1 does not support the original linkage results, excluding linkage up to theta = 0. 17 with Z = -2.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Tests for linkage to other chromosome 2p markers.</Disease>
<Disease>APOB, D2S71, D2S5, and D2S1, also excluded linkage to aniridia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Markers that have been isolated from the chromosome 11p13 region were then analyzed in this aniridia family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two RFLPs at the D11S323 locus give significant evidence for linkage.</Disease>
<Disease>The PvuII polymorphism detected by probe p5S1. 6 detects no recombinants, with a maximum lod score of Z = 6. 97 at theta = 0. 00 00.</Disease>

text: <Disease>GT to AT transition at a splice donor site causes skipping of the preceding exon in phenylketonuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Classical Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive human genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We isolated several mutant PAH cDNA clones from a PKU carrier individual and showed that they contained an internal 116 base pair deletion, corresponding precisely to exon 12 of the human chromosomal PAH gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The deletion causes the synthesis of a truncated protein lacking the C-terminal 52 amino acids.</Disease>
<Disease>Gene transfer and expression studies using the mutant PAH cDNA indicated that the deletion abolishes PAH activity in the cell as a result of protein instability.</Disease>

<Disease>To determine the molecular basis of the deletion, the mutant chromosomal PAH gene was isolated from this individual and shown to contain a GT-- greater than AT substitution at the 5 splice donor site of intron 12.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, the consequence of the splice donor site mutation in the human liver is the skipping of the preceding exon during RNA splicing..</Disease>
<Disease>Clinical and molecular genetic analysis of 19 Wolfram syndrome kindreds demonstrating a wide spectrum of mutations in WFS1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Wolfram syndrome is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by juvenile-onset diabetes mellitus and progressive optic atrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>mtDNA deletions have been described, and a gene (WFS1) recently has been identified, on chromosome 4p16, encoding a predicted 890 amino acid transmembrane protein.</Disease>
<Disease>Direct DNA sequencing was done to screen the entire coding region of the WFS1 gene in 30 patients from 19 British kindreds with Wolfram syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DNA was also screened for structural rearrangements (deletions and duplications) and point mutations in mtDNA.</Disease>
<Disease>No pathogenic mtDNA mutations were found in our cohort.</Disease>
<Disease>We identified 24 mutations in the WFS1 gene  8 nonsense mutations, 8 missense mutations, 3 in-frame deletions, 1 in-frame insertion, and 4 frameshift mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>Of these, 23 were novel mutations, and most occurred in exon 8.</Disease>
<Disease>The majority of patients were compound heterozygotes for two mutations, and there was no common founder mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>The data were also analyzed for genotype-phenotype relationships.</Disease>

<Disease>Although some interesting cases were noted, consideration of the small sample size and frequency of each mutation indicated no clear-cut correlations between any of the observed mutations and disease severity.</Disease>
<Disease>There were no obvious mutation hot spots or clusters.</Disease>

<Disease>Hence, molecular screening for Wolfram syndrome in affected families and for Wolfram syndrome-carrier status in subjects with psychiatric disorders or diabetes mellitus will require complete analysis of exon 8 and upstream exons..</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>At 7 years of age he was referred to us by the paediatrician because of symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS).</Disease>

text: <Disease>Two years later he was re-examined because we thought his features fitted the PWS-like phenotype associated with maternal UPD (14).</Disease>

text: <Disease>At that time precocious puberty was evident.</Disease>
<Disease>DNA analysis showed maternal heterodisomy for chromosome 14.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Variant SSCP bands were subcloned and sequenced.</Disease>
<Disease>Allele-specific oligonucleotide hybridization was used to verify sequence changes and to screen DNA from control individuals.</Disease>

<Disease>A frameshift mutation was detected in a male proband affected with both breast and prostate cancer.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A 40-bp deletion was detected in a patient who developed intra-abdominal carcinomatosis 1 year after prophylactic oophorectomy.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Mutations were detected throughout the gene, and only one was detected in more than a single family.</Disease>

text: <Disease>These results suggests that development of a screening test for BRCA1 mutations will be technically challenging.</Disease>

Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have undertaken a hospital-based study, to identify possible BRCA1 and BRCA2 founder mutations in the Polish population.</Disease>

<Disease>The study group consisted of 66 Polish families with cancer who have at least three related females affected with breast or ovarian cancer and who had cancer diagnosed, in at least one of the three affected females, at age <</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>50 years.</Disease>
<Disease>A total of 26 families had both breast and ovarian cancers, 4 families had ovarian cancers only, and 36 families had breast cancers only.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Genomic DNA was prepared from the peripheral blood leukocytes of at least one affected woman from each family.</Disease>
<Disease>The entire coding region of BRCA1 and BRCA2 was screened for the presence of germline mutations, by use of SSCP followed by direct sequencing of observed variants.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations were found in 35 (53%) of the 66 families studied.</Disease>
<Disease>All but one of the mutations were detected within the BRCA1 gene.</Disease>

<Disease>BRCA1 abnormalities were identified in all four families with ovarian cancer only, in 67% of 27 families with both breast and ovarian cancer, and in 34% of 35 families with breast cancer only.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The single family with a BRCA2 mutation had the breast-ovarian cancer syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Seven distinct mutations were identified; five of these occurred in two or more families.</Disease>
<Disease>In total, recurrent mutations were found in 33 (94%) of the 35 families with detected mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>Three BRCA1 abnormalities - 5382insC, C61G, and 4153delA - accounted for 51%, 20%, and 11% of the identified mutations, respectively..</Disease>

text: <Disease>New founder haplotypes at the myotonic dystrophy locus in southern Africa.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The association between normal alleles at the CTG repeat and two nearby polymorphisms in the myotonin protein kinase gene, the Alu insertion/deletion polymorphism and the myotonic dystrophy kinase (DMK) (G/T) intron 9/HinfI polymorphism, has been analyzed in South African Negroids, a population in which myotonic dystrophy (DM) has not been described.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>South African Negroids have a CTG allelic distribution that is significantly different from that in Caucasoids and Japanese  the CTG repeat lengths of > or = 19 are very rare.</Disease>

<Disease>The striking linkage disequilibrium between specific alleles at the Alu polymorphism (Alu (ins) and Alu (del)), the HinfI polymorphism (HinfI-1 and HinfI-2), and the CTG repeat polymorphism seen in Caucasoid (Europeans and Canadians) populations was also found in the South African Negroid population.</Disease>
<Disease>Numerous haplotypes, not previously described in Europeans, were, however, found.</Disease>
<Disease>It thus seems likely that only a small number of these " African " chromosomes were present in the progenitors of all non-African peoples.</Disease>

<Disease>These data provide support for the " out of Africa " model for the origin of modern humans and suggest that the rare ancestral DM mutation event may have occurred after the migration from Africa, hence the absence of DM in sub-Saharan Negroid peoples..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Marked phenotypic heterogeneity associated with expansion of a CAG repeat sequence at the spinocerebellar ataxia 3/Machado-Joseph disease locus.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The spinocerebellar ataxia 3 locus (SCA3) for type I autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia (ADCA type I), a clinically and genetically heterogeneous group of neurodegenerative disorders, has been mapped to chromosome 14q32.</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>1 1. ADCA type I patients from families segregating SCA3 share clinical features in common with those with Machado-Joseph disease (MJD), the gene of which maps to the same region.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We show here that the disease gene segregating in each of three French ADCA type I kindreds and in a French family with neuropathological findings suggesting the ataxochoreic form of dentatorubropallidoluysian atrophy carries an expanded CAG repeat sequence located at the same locus as that for MJD.</Disease>

<Disease>Instability of the expanded triplet repeat was not found to be affected by sex of the parent transmitting the mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>Evidence was found for somatic and gonadal mosaicism for alleles carrying expanded trinucleotide repeats.</Disease>
<Disease>The red-green visual pigment gene region in adrenoleukodystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although recent data established that a specific very-long-chain fatty acyl-CoA synthetase is defective in X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), the ALD gene is still unidentified.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The ALD locus has been mapped to Xq28, like the red and green color pigment genes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Abnormal color vision has been observed in 12 of 27 patients with adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN), a milder form of ALD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, rearrangements of the color vision gene cluster were found in four of eight ALD kindreds.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This led us to propose that a single DNA rearrangement could underlie both ALD and abnormal color vision in these patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Study of 34 French ALD patients failed to reveal a higher than expected frequency of green/red visual pigment rearrangements 3 to the red/green color vision gene complex.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The previous report of such rearrangements was based on small numbers and lack of knowledge that the frequency of " abnormal " color vision arrays on molecular analysis was twice as high as expected on the basis of the frequency of phenotypic color vision defects.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The red/green color pigment (R/GCP) region was studied by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis in 14 of these patients, and we did not find any fragment size difference between the patients and normal individuals who have the same number of pigment genes.</Disease>

<Disease>The R/GCP region was also analyzed in 29 French and seven North American ALD patients by using six genomic DNA probes, isolated from a cosmid walk, that flank the color vision genes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No deletions were found with probes that lie 3 of the green pigment genes.</Disease>
<Disease>One of the eight previously reported ALD individuals has a long deletion 5 of the red pigment gene, a deletion causing blue cone monochromacy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This finding and the previous findings of a 45% frequency of phenotypic color vision defects in patients with AMN may suggest that the ALD/AMN gene lies 5 to the red pigment gene and that the frequent phenotypic color vision anomalies owe their origin to deleted DNA that includes regulatory genes for color vision.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It is possible, however, that phenotypic color vision anomalies in AMN may be phenocopies secondary to retinal or neural involvement by the disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The single case of blue cone monochromacy may therefore be a fortuitous coincidence of two diseases..</Disease>
<Disease>Haim-Munk syndrome and Papillon-Lefevre syndrome are allelic mutations in cathepsin C.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Of the many palmoplantar keratoderma (PPK) conditions, only Papillon-Lefevre syndrome (PLS) and Haim-Munk syndrome (HMS) are associated with premature periodontal destruction.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although both PLS and HMS share the cardinal features of PPK and severe periodontitis, a number of additional findings are reported in HMS including arachnodactyly, acro-osteolysis, atrophic changes of the nails, and a radiographic deformity of the fingers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>While PLS cases have been identified throughout the world, HMS has only been described among descendants of a religious isolate originally from Cochin, India.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Parental consanguinity is a characteristic of many cases of both conditions.</Disease>

<Disease>Although autosomal recessive transmission of PLS is evident, a more " complex " autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance with phenotypic influences from a closely linked modifying locus has been hypothesised for HMS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, mutations of the cathepsin C gene have been identified as the underlying genetic defect in PLS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To determine if a cathepsin C mutation is also responsible for HMS, we sequenced the gene in affected and unaffected subjects from the Cochin isolate in which both the PLS and HMS phenotypes appear.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here we report identification of a mutation of cathepsin C (exon 6, 2127A-- ></Disease>
<Disease>G) that changes a highly conserved amino acid in the cathepsin C peptide.</Disease>
<Disease>This mutation segregates with HMS in four nuclear families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Additionally, the existence of a shared common haplotype for genetic loci flanking the cathepsin C gene suggests that affected subjects descended from the Cochin isolate are homozygous for a mutation inherited " identical by descent " from a common ancestor.</Disease>
<Disease>This finding supports simple autosomal recessive inheritance for HMS in these families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We also report a mutation of the same exon 6 CTSC codon (2126C-- > T) in a Turkish family with classical PLS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings provide evidence that PLS and HMS are allelic variants of cathepsin C gene mutations..</Disease>

text: <Disease>X inactivation and somatic cell selection rescue female mice carrying a Piga-null mutation.</Disease>

<Disease>A somatic mutation in the X linked PIGA gene is responsible for the deficiency of glycosyl phosphatidylinositol (GPI) -anchored proteins on blood cells from patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No inherited form of GPI-anchor deficiency has been described.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Because conventional Piga gene knockout is associated with high embryonic lethality in chimeric mice, we used the Cre/loxP system.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We generated mice in which two loxP sites flank part of Piga exon 2.</Disease>
<Disease>After crossbreeding with female mice of the EIIa-cre strain, the floxed allele undergoes Cre-mediated recombination with high efficiency during early embryonic development.</Disease>
<Disease>Because of X chromosome inactivation, female offspring are mosaic for cells that express or lack GPI-linked proteins.</Disease>
<Disease>Analysis of mosaic mice showed that in heart, lung, kidney, brain, and liver, mainly wild-type Piga is active, suggesting that these tissues require GPI-linked proteins.</Disease>

<Disease>The salient exceptions were spleen, thymus, and red blood cells, which had almost equal numbers of cells expressing the wild-type or the recombined allele, implying that GPI-linked proteins are not essential for the derivation of these tissues.</Disease>
<Disease>PIGA (-) cells had no growth advantage, suggesting that other factors are needed for their clonal dominance in patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria..</Disease>

text: <Disease>The Norrie disease gene maps to a 150 kb region on chromosome Xp11.3.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Norrie disease is a human X-linked recessive disorder of unknown etiology characterized by congenital blindness, sensory neural deafness and mental retardation.</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This disease gene was previously linked to the DXS7 (L1. 28) locus and the MAO genes in band Xp11.</Disease>

<Disease>Together these data define the obligate region containing the NDP gene to a chromosomal segment less than 150 kb.</Disease>
<Disease>Molecular genetics of the glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) Mediterranean variant and description of a new G6PD mutant, G6PD Andalus1361A.</Disease>

<Disease>Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD; E. C. 1. 1. 1. 49) deficiency is the most common human enzymopathy; more than 300 different biochemical variants of the enzyme have been described.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In many parts of the world the Mediterranean type of G6PD deficiency is prevalent.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, G6PD Mediterranean has come to be regarded as a generic term applied to similar G6PD mutations thought, however, to represent a somewhat heterogeneous group.</Disease>
<Disease>A C----T mutation at nucleotide 563 of G6PD Mediterranean has been identified by Vulliamy et al., and the same mutation has been found by De Vita et al.</Disease>
<Disease>in G6PD Mediterranean, G6PD Sassari, and G6PD Cagliari.</Disease>
<Disease>The latter subjects had an additional mutation, at nucleotide 1311, that did not produce a coding change.</Disease>
<Disease>We have examined genomic DNA of five patients--four of Spanish origin and one of Jewish origin--having enzymatically documented G6PD Mediterranean.</Disease>
<Disease>All had both the mutation at nucleotide 563 and that at nucleotide 1311.</Disease>

<Disease>A sixth sample, resembling G6PD Mediterranean kinetically but with a slightly rapid electrophoretic mobility, was designated G6PD Andalus and was found to have a different mutation, a G----A transition at nucleotide 1361, producing an arginine-to-histidine substitution.</Disease>
<Disease>These studies suggest that G6PD Mediterranean is, after all, relatively homogeneous.</Disease>
<Disease>Small nuclear ribonucleoprotein polypeptide N (SNRPN), an expressed gene in the Prader-Willi syndrome critical region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is associated with paternally derived chromosomal deletions in region 15q11-13 or with maternal disomy for chromosome 15.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, loss of the expressed paternal alleles of maternally imprinted genes must be responsible for the PWS phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have mapped the gene encoding the small nuclear RNA associated polypeptide SmN (SNRPN) to human chromosome 15q12 and a processed pseudogene SNRPNP1 to chromosome region 6pter-p21.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, SNRPN was mapped to the minimal deletion interval that is critical for PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Increased incidence of cancer in patients with cartilage-hair hypoplasia.</Disease>
