text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE  Previous reports have suggested an increased risk of cancer among patients with cartilage-hair hypoplasia (CHH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This study was carried out to further evaluate this risk among patients with CHH and their first-degree relatives.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>STUDY DESIGN  One hundred twenty-two patients with CHH were identified through 2 countrywide epidemiologic surveys in 1974 and in 1986.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Their parents and nonaffected siblings were identified through the Population Register Center.</Disease>
<Disease>This cohort underwent follow-up for cancer incidence through the Finnish Cancer Registry to the end of 1995.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS  A statistically significant excess risk of cancer was seen among the patients with CHH (standardized incidence ratio 6. 9, 95% confidence interval 2. 3 to 16), which was mainly attributable to non-Hodgkins lymphoma  (standardized incidence ratio 90, 95% confidence interval 18 to 264).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, a significant excess risk of basal cell carcinoma was seen (standardized incidence ratio 35, 95% confidence interval 7. 2 to 102).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The cancer incidence among the siblings or the parents did not differ from the average cancer incidence in the Finnish population.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS  This study confirms an increased risk of cancer, especially non-Hodgkins lymphoma, probably attributable to defective immunity, among patients with CHH.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Genetic polymorphism of G6PD in a Bulgarian population.</Disease>
<Disease>Considerable genetic heterogeneity in G6PD was found in the Bulgarian population-14 G6PD variants isolated from 117 hemizygous carriers of G6PD deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of these, G6PD Mediterranean type was a polymorphic variant and G6PD Corinth occurred with high frequency.</Disease>
<Disease>Two new variants were identified-G6PD Rudosem and G6PD Nedelino.</Disease>
<Disease>In a selected group of 78 subjects with clinical manifestations, four variants were established  G6PD Mediterranian, G6PD Corinth, G6PD Seattle and G6PD Ohut II..</Disease>
<Disease>A genetic etiology for DiGeorge syndrome: consistent deletions and microdeletions of 22q11.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DiGeorge syndrome (DGS), a developmental field defect of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, is characterized by aplasia or hypoplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands and by conotruncal cardiac malformations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cytogenetic studies support the presence of a DGS critical region in band 22q11.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the present study, we report the results of clinical, cytogenetic, and molecular studies of 14 patients with DGS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chromosome analysis, utilizing high-resolution banding techniques, detected interstitial deletions in five probands and was inconclusive for a deletion in three probands.</Disease>
<Disease>The remaining six patients had normal karyotypes.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, molecular analysis detected DNA deletions in all 14 probands.</Disease>
<Disease>Two of 10 loci tested, D22S75 and D22S259, are deleted in all 14 patients.</Disease>
<Disease>A third locus, D22S66, is deleted in the eight DGS probands tested.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Physical mapping using somatic cell hybrids places D22S66 between D22S75 and D22S259, suggesting that it should be deleted in the remaining six cases.</Disease>
<Disease>Parent-of-origin studies were performed in five families.</Disease>
<Disease>Four probands failed to inherit a maternal allele, and one failed to inherit a paternal allele.</Disease>

<Disease>On the basis of these families, and of six maternally and five paternally derived unbalanced-translocation DGS probands in the literature, parent of origin or imprinting does not appear to play an important role in the pathogenesis of DGS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Deletion of the same three loci in all 14 DGS probands begins to delineate the region of chromosome 22 critical for DGS and confirms the hypothesis that submicroscopic deletions of 22q11 are etiologic in the vast majority of cases..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Characterisation of a new rare fragile site easily confused with the fragile X.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A new fragile site (FRAXE) in Xq28 is described.</Disease>
<Disease>It appears to be a typical folate sensitive fragile site.</Disease>

<Disease>The fragile site is not associated with mental retardation, it does not give abnormal results when subjected to Southern analysis with probe pfxa3 which detects the unstable DNA sequence characteristic of fragile X syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In situ hybridization mapping locates the fragile site between 150 kb and 600 kb distal to FRAXA.</Disease>

<Disease>The distinction between the two fragile sites is important clinically since cytogenetic detection of FRAXE, without molecular analysis, could result in misdiagnosis of fragile X syndrome..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BRCA1 mutations in primary breast and ovarian carcinomas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Loss of heterozygosity data from familial tumors suggest that BRCA1, a gene that confers susceptibility to ovarian and early-onset breast cancer, encodes a tumor suppressor.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The BRCA1 region is also subject to allelic loss in sporadic breast and ovarian cancers, an indication that BRCA1 mutations may occur somatically in these tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The BRCA1 coding region was examined for mutations in primary breast and ovarian tumors that show allele loss at the BRCA1 locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations were detected in 3 of 32 breast and 1 of 12 ovarian carcinomas; all four mutations were germline alterations and occurred in early-onset cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggest that mutation of BRCA1 may not be critical in the development of the majority of breast and ovarian cancers that arise in the absence of a mutant germline allele..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Genomic structure of the EWS gene and its relationship to EWSR1, a site of tumor-associated chromosome translocation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The EWS gene has been identified based on its location at the chromosome 22 breakpoint of the t (11; 22) (q24; q12) translocation that characterizes Ewing sarcoma and related neuroectodermal tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The EWS gene spans about 40 kb of DNA and is encoded by 17 exons.</Disease>
<Disease>The nucleotide sequence of the exons is identical to that of the previously described cDNA.</Disease>

<Disease>The first 7 exons encode the N-terminal domain of EWS, which consists of a repeated degenerated polypeptide of 7 to 12 residues rich in tyrosine, serine, threonine, glycine, and glutamine.</Disease>
<Disease>Exons 11, 12, and 13 encode the putative RNA binding domain.</Disease>
<Disease>The three glycine- and arginine-rich motifs of the gene are mainly encoded by exons 8-9, 14, and 16.</Disease>
<Disease>The DNA sequence in the 5 region of the gene has features of a CpG-rich island and lacks canonical promoter elements, such as TATA and CCAAT consensus sequences.</Disease>
<Disease>Positions of the chromosome 22 breakpoints were determined for 19 Ewing tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>They were localized in introns 7 or 8 in 18 cases and in intron 10 in 1 case..</Disease>
<Disease>PAX6 mutations in aniridia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aniridia is a congenital malformation of the eye, chiefly characterised by iris hypoplasia, which can cause blindness.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The PAX6 gene was isolated as a candidate aniridia gene by positional cloning from the smallest region of overlap of aniridia-associated deletions.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Subsequently PAX6 intragenic mutations were demonstrated in Smalleye, a mouse mutant which is an animal model for aniridia, and six human aniridia patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this paper we describe four additional PAX6 point mutations in aniridia patients, both sporadic and familial.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These mutations highlight regions of the gene which are essential for normal PAX6 function.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, the frequency at which we have found PAX6 mutations suggests that lesions in PAX6 will account for most cases of aniridia..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the PAX6 gene in patients with hereditary aniridia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The 14 exons of the PAX6 gene have been analysed exon-by-exon using SSCP in 6 aniridia families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In each family band shifts were observed on the SSCP gels for only one exon and direct PCR-sequencing revealed mutations in each case.</Disease>
<Disease>Two mutations involved C-- > T transitions in CGAarg codons in exons 9 and 11.</Disease>
<Disease>Another C-- > T transition converted a CAG-glutamine to a TAG-stop in exon 7.</Disease>

<Disease>Small insertions created frameshifts which produced downstream stop codons in another two patients and an A-- > T mutation disrupted the splice donor site of exon 5 in the remaining family.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, complete inactivation of the PAX6 gene is predicted in all cases.</Disease>
<Disease>Analysis of other affected members of the families showed that, in each case, all affected individuals carried the same family-specific mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>One polymorphism was found in exon 7.</Disease>
<Disease>This data strongly supports the candidature of PAX6 as the gene responsible for hereditary aniridia..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Locus heterogeneity in Friedreich ataxia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Friedreich ataxia (FRDA) is the most common form of autosomal recessive ataxia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The disease locus was assigned to chromosome 9 and the disease gene, STM7/X25, has been isolated.</Disease>
<Disease>To date most data suggest locus homogeneity in FRDA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We now provide strong evidence of a second FRDA locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Studying two siblings with FRDA from two families we did not detect a mutation in STM7/X25.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Haplotype analysis of the STM7/X25 region of chromosome 9 demonstrated that the relevant portion of chromosome 9 differs in the patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Although the patients studied had typical FRDA, one sibpair had the uncommon symptom of retained tendon reflexes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In order to investigate whether retained tendon reflexes are characteristic of FRDA caused by the second locus, FRDA2, we studied an unrelated FRDA patient with retained tendon reflexes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The observation of typical mutations in STM7/X25 (GAA expansions) in this patient demonstrates that the two genetically different forms of FRDA cannot be distinguished clinically..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Haploinsufficiency of the transcription factors FOXC1 and FOXC2 results in aberrant ocular development.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Anterior segment developmental disorders, including Axenfeld-Rieger anomaly (ARA), variably associate with harmfully elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), which causes glaucoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Clinically observed dysgenesis does not correlate with IOP, however, and the etiology of glaucoma development is not understood.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The forkhead transcription factor genes Foxc1 (formerly Mf1) and Foxc2 (formerly Mfh1) are expressed in the mesenchyme from which the ocular drainage structures derive.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations in the human homolog of Foxc1, FKHL7, cause dominant anterior segment defects and glaucoma in various families.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We show that Foxc1 (+/-) mice have anterior segment abnormalities similar to those reported in human patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These abnormalities include small or absent Schlemms canal, aberrantly developed trabecular meshwork, iris hypoplasia, severely eccentric pupils and displaced Schwalbes line.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The penetrance of clinically obvious abnormalities varies with genetic background.</Disease>
<Disease>In some affected eyes, collagen bundles were half normal diameter, or collagen and elastic tissue were very sparse.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, abnormalities in extracellular matrix synthesis or organization may contribute to development of the ocular phenotypes.</Disease>
<Disease>Despite the abnormalities in ocular drainage structures in Foxc1 (+/-) mice, IOP was normal in almost all mice analyzed, on all genetic backgrounds and at all ages.</Disease>
<Disease>Similar abnormalities were found in Foxc2 (+/-) mice, but no disease-associated mutations were identified in the human homolog FKHL14 in 32 ARA patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Foxc1 (+/-) and Foxc2 (+/-)</Disease>

<Disease>mice are useful models for studying anterior segment development and its anomalies, and may allow identification of genes that interact with Foxc1 and Foxc2 (or FKHL7 and FKHL14) to produce a phenotype with elevated IOP and glaucoma..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans-associated collagen type Ialpha1/platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) B-chain fusion gene generates a transforming protein that is processed to functional PDGF-BB.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) displays chromosomal rearrangements involving chromosome 17 and 22, which fuse the collagen type Ialpha1 (COLIA1) gene to the platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) B-chain (PDGFB) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To characterize the functional and structural properties of the COLIA1/PDGFB fusion protein, we generated a stable NIH3T3 cell line that contained a tumor-derived chimeric gene resulting from a COIA1 intron 7-PDGFB intron 1 fusion.</Disease>
<Disease>Expression of the fusion protein led to morphological transformation and increased growth rate of these cells.</Disease>
<Disease>The PDGF receptor kinase inhibitor CGP57148B reversed the transformed phenotype and reduced the growth rate of COLIA1/PDGFB-expressing cells but had no effects on control cells.</Disease>

<Disease>The presence of dimeric COLIA1/PDGFB precursors was demonstrated through PDGFB immunoprecipitations of metabolically labeled cells and also by PDGFB immunoprecipitations followed by immunoblotting with COLIA1 antibodies.</Disease>
<Disease>Pulse-chase studies demonstrated that the COLIA1/PDGFB precursor was processed to an end product that was indistinguishable from wild-type PDGF-BB.</Disease>
<Disease>Finally, COLIA1/PDGFB-expressing cells generated tumors after s. c c. injection into nude mice, and tumor growth was reduced by treatment with CGP57148B.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that the COLIA1/PDGFB fusion associated with DFSP contributes to tumor development through ectopic production of PDGF-BB and the formation of an autocrine loop.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our findings, thus, suggest that PDGF receptors could be a target for pharmacological treatment of DFSP and giant cell fibroblastoma, e. g., through the use of PDGF receptor kinase inhibitors such as CGP57148B.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Founder effect of a prevalent phenylketonuria mutation in the Oriental population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A missense mutation has been identified in the human phenylalanine hydroxylase</Disease>
<Disease>[PAH; phenylalanine 4-monooxygenase; L-phenylalanine, tetrahydrobiopterin  oxygen oxidoreductase (4-hydroxylating), EC 1. 14.</Disease>
<Disease>16. 1] gene in a Chinese patient with classic phenylketonuria (PKU).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A G-to-C transition at the second base of codon 413 in exon 12 of the gene results in the substitution of Pro413 for Arg413 in the mutant protein.</Disease>
<Disease>This mutation (R413P) results in negligible enzymatic activity when expressed in heterologous mammalian cells and is compatible with a classic PKU phenotype in the patient.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Population genetic studies reveal that this mutation is tightly linked to restriction fragment length polymorphism haplotype 4, which is the predominant haplotype of the PAH locus in the Oriental population.</Disease>
<Disease>It accounts for 13.</Disease>
<Disease>8% of northern Chinese and 27% of Japanese PKU alleles, but it is rare in southern Chinese (2. 2%) and is absent in the Caucasian population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The data demonstrate unambiguously that the mutation occurred after racial divergence of Orientals and Caucasians and suggest that the allele has spread throughout the Orient by a founder effect.</Disease>
<Disease>Previous protein polymorphism studies in eastern Asia have led to the hypothesis that " northern Mongoloids " represented a founding population in Asia.</Disease>
<Disease>Our results are compatible with this hypothesis in that the PKU mutation might have occurred in northern Mongoloids and subsequently spread to the Chinese and Japanese populations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Late-onset familial Mediterranean fever (FMF): a subset with distinct clinical, demographic, and molecular genetic characteristics.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To determine the prevalence and characterize demographic, clinical, and genetic features of familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) of late onset, all patients experiencing their first FMF attack at age 40 years or more were identified using the computerized registry of our FMF clinic, and then thoroughly interviewed and examined.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The control group consisted of 40 consecutive FMF patients, who arrived at the FMF clinic for their regular follow-up visit and were 40 years of age or older at the time of the examination.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The severity of the disease in patients and controls was determined using a modified score, developed previously.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutational analysis in the FMF gene was performed using a commercial kit.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Only 20 of 4000 (0. 5%) patients had late-onset FMF.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These patients were mostly men, of non-North African origin, P < 0. 05</Disease>
<Disease>compared to controls.</Disease>
<Disease>All had abdominal attacks and in most these were the only manifestation of their disease, P < 0.</Disease>
<Disease>001 001.</Disease>
<Disease>None had chronic or prolonged manifestations of FMF, for example, amyloidosis, chronic arthritis, or protracted myalgia, P < 0. 001.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The response to treatment was good despite using low colchicine dose, P < 0. 05.</Disease>
<Disease>The overall severity score indicated a mild disease, P < 0. 001.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutational analysis revealed absence of M694V homozygosity, P < 0. 01, compared to our regular FMF population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that the onset of FMF in a late age defines a milder form of disease with typical clinical, demographic, and molecular genetic characteristics</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Structure of the human Na+/glucose cotransporter gene SGLT1.</Disease>
<Disease>Intestinal uptake of dietary glucose and galactose is mediated by the SGLT1 Na +/glucose cotransporter of the brush border.</Disease>

<Disease>An SGLT1 missense mutation underlies hereditary glucose/galactose malabsorption, characterized by potentially fatal diarrhea; conversely, oral rehydration therapy exploits normal transport to alleviate life-threatening diarrhea of infectious origin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have mapped the entire human SGLT1 Na +/glucose cotransporter gene from cosmid and lambda phage clones representing a genomic region of 112 kilobases.</Disease>
<Disease>Transcription initiation occurred from a site 27 base pairs 3 of a TATAA sequence.</Disease>
<Disease>All exon-flanking regions were sequenced, and the entire 112-kilobase region mapped with four restriction enzymes.</Disease>

<Disease>SGLT1 is comprised of 15 exons (spanning 72 kilobases); a possible evolutionary origin from a six-membrane-span ancestral precursor via a gene duplication event is suggested from comparison of exons against protein secondary structure and from sequence considerations.</Disease>
<Disease>A new missense mutation in exon 1 causing glucose/galactose malabsorption is also described.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This is the first Na (+) -dependent cotransporter gene structure reported.</Disease>

<Disease>These data facilitate the search for new glucose/galactose malabsorption-related mutations in this important gene and provide a basis for future evolutionary comparisons with other Na (+) -dependent cotransporters..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>ATM phosphorylates p95/nbs1 in an S-phase checkpoint pathway.</Disease>

<Disease>The rare diseases ataxia-telangiectasia (AT), caused by mutations in the ATM gene, and Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS), with mutations in the p95/nbs1 gene, share a variety of phenotypic abnormalities such as chromosomal instability, radiation sensitivity and defects in cell-cycle checkpoints in response to ionizing radiation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The ATM gene encodes a protein kinase that is activated by ionizing radiation or radiomimetic drugs, whereas p95/nbs1 is part of a protein complex that is involved in responses to DNA double-strand breaks.</Disease>
<Disease>Here, because of the similarities between AT and NBS, we evaluated the functional interactions between ATM and p95/nbs1.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Activation of the ATM kinase by ionizing radiation and induction of ATM-dependent responses in NBS cells indicated that p95/nbs1 may not be required for signalling to ATM after ionizing radiation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, p95/nbs1 was phosphorylated on serine 343 in an ATM-dependent manner in vitro and in vivo after ionizing radiation.</Disease>

<Disease>A p95/nbs1 construct mutated at the ATM phosphorylation site abrogated an S-phase checkpoint induced by ionizing radiation in normal cells and failed to compensate for this functional deficiency in NBS cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These observations link ATM and p95/nbs1 in a common signalling pathway and provide an explanation for phenotypic similarities in these two diseases..</Disease>
<Disease>Two distinct mutations at a single BamHI site in phenylketonuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Classical phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disease caused by a deficiency of hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The abolition of an invariant BamHI site located in the coding sequence of the PAH gene (exon 7) led to the recognition of two new point mutations at codon 272 and 273 (272gly----stop and 273ser----phe, respectively).</Disease>
<Disease>Both mutations were detected in north eastern France or Belgium and occurred on the background of RFLP haplotype 7 alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>The present study supports the view that the clinical heterogeneity in PKU is accounted for by the large variety of mutant genotypes associated with PAH deficiencies..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Functional link between ataxia-telangiectasia and Nijmegen breakage syndrome gene products.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T) and Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS) are recessive genetic disorders with susceptibility to cancer and similar cellular phenotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The protein product of the gene responsible for A-T, designated ATM, is a member of a family of kinases characterized by a carboxy-terminal phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase-like domain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The NBS1 protein is specifically mutated in patients with Nijmegen breakage syndrome and forms a complex with the DNA repair proteins Rad50 and Mrel1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here we show that phosphorylation of NBS1, induced by ionizing radiation, requires catalytically active ATM.</Disease>
<Disease>Complexes containing ATM and NBS1 exist in vivo in both untreated cells and cells treated with ionizing radiation.</Disease>

<Disease>We have identified two residues of NBS1, Ser 278 and Ser 343 that are phosphorylated in vitro by ATM and whose modification in vivo is essential for the cellular response to DNA damage.</Disease>
<Disease>This response includes S-phase checkpoint activation, formation of the NBS1/Mrel1/Rad50 nuclear foci and rescue of hypersensitivity to ionizing radiation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Together, these results demonstrate a biochemical link between cell-cycle checkpoints activated by DNA damage and DNA repair in two genetic diseases with overlapping phenotypes..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Structure and genomic sequence of the myotonic dystrophy (DM kinase) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation causing myotonic dystrophy (DM) has recently been identified as an unstable CTG trinucleotide repeat located in the 3 untranslated region of a gene encoding for a protein with putative serine-threonine protein kinase activity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this report we present the genomic sequences of the human and murine DM kinase gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A comparison of these sequences with each other and with known cDNA sequences from both species, led us to predict a translation initiation codon, as well as determine the organization of the DM kinase gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Several polymorphisms within the human DM kinase gene have been identified, and PCR assays to detect two of these are described.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The complete sequence and characterization of the structure of the DM kinase gene, as well as the identification of novel polymorphisms within the gene, represent an important step in a further understanding of the genetics of myotonic dystrophy and the molecular biology of the gene..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of novel imprinted transcripts in the Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome deletion region: further evidence for regional imprinting control.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Deletions and other abnormalities of human chromosome 15q11-q13 are associated with two developmental disorders, Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) and Angelman syndrome (AS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Loss of expression of imprinted, paternally expressed genes has been implicated in PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the number of imprinted genes that contribute to PWS, and the range over which the imprinting signal acts to silence one copy of the gene in a parent-of-origin-specific manner, are unknown.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To identify additional imprinted genes that could contribute to the PWS phenotype and to understand the regional control of imprinting in 15q11-q13, we have constructed an imprinted transcript map of the PWS-AS deletion interval.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The imprinting status of 22 expressed sequence tags derived from the radiation-hybrid human transcript maps or physical maps was determined in a reverse transcriptase-PCR assay and correlated with the position of the transcripts on the physical map.</Disease>

<Disease>Seven new paternally expressed transcripts localize to an approximately 1. 5-Mb domain surrounding the SNRPN-associated imprinting center, which already includes four imprinted, paternally expressed genes.</Disease>
<Disease>All other tested new transcripts in the deletion region were expressed from both alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>A domain of exclusive paternal expression surrounding the imprinting center suggests strong regional control of the imprinting process.</Disease>
<Disease>This study provides the means for further investigation of additional genes that cause or modify the phenotypes associated with rearrangements of 15q11-q13.</Disease>
<Disease>Penetrances of BRCA1 1675delA and 1135insA with respect to breast cancer and ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>For genetic counseling and predictive testing in families with inherited breast-ovarian cancer, penetrances and expressions of the underlying mutations should be known.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have previously reported two BRCA1 founder mutations in the Norwegian population.</Disease>
<Disease>Index cases for the present study were found two different ways  through a series of consecutive ovarian cancers (n = 16) and through our family cancer clinic (n = 14).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Altogether, 20 of the patients had BRCA1 1675delA, and 10 had 1135insA. Their relatives were described with respect to absence/presence of breast and/or ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Of 133 living female relatives, 83 (62%) were tested for the presence of a mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>No difference, in penetrance and expression, between the two mutations were found, whereas differences according to method of ascertainment were seen.</Disease>
<Disease>The overall findings were that disease started to occur at age 30 years and that by age 50 years 48% of the mutation-carrying women had experienced breast and/or ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>More ovarian cancers than breast cancers were recorded.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Both penetrance and expression (breast cancer vs. ovarian cancer) were different from those in reports of the Ashkenazi founder mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Whether the reported differences reflect true differences and/or methodological problems is discussed.</Disease>
<Disease>An observed excess of mutation carriers could not be accounted for by methodological problems; possible explanations were a " true " low penetrance or preferential segregation..</Disease>
<Disease>Molecular basis of subtotal complement C6 deficiency. A carboxy-terminally truncated but functionally active C6.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Individuals with subtotal complement C6 deficiency possess a C6 molecule that is 14% shorter than normal C6 and present in low but detectable concentrations (1-2% of the normal mean).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We now show that this dysmorphic C6 is bactericidally active and lacks an epitope that was mapped to the most carboxy-terminal part of C6 using C6 cDNA fragments expressed as fusion proteins in the pUEX expression system.</Disease>

<Disease>We thus predicted that the abnormal C6 molecule might be carboxy-terminally truncated and sought a mutation in an area approximately 14% from the carboxy-terminal end of the coding sequence.</Disease>
<Disease>By sequencing PCR-amplified products from this region, we found, in three individuals from two families, a mutation that might plausibly be responsible for the defect.</Disease>
<Disease>All three have an abnormal 5 splice donor site of intron 15, which would probably prevent splicing.</Disease>
<Disease>An in-frame stop codon is found 17 codons downstream from the intron boundary, which would lead to a truncated polypeptide 13.</Disease>
<Disease>5% smaller than normal C6.</Disease>
<Disease>This result was unexpected, as earlier studies mapped the C5b binding site, or a putative enzymatic region, to this part of C6.</Disease>
<Disease>Interestingly, all three subjects were probably heterozygous for both subtotal C6 and complete C6 deficiency.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Mutations of the VHL gene in sporadic renal cell carcinoma: definition of a risk factor for VHL patients to develop an RCC.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To investigate the nature of somatic von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) mutations, we analyzed 173 primary sporadic human renal cell carcinomas for mutations of the VHL tumor suppressor gene, using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and single-strand conformational polymorphism analysis (SSCP) of DNA.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We detected abnormal SSCP pattern in 73 samples.</Disease>
<Disease>After sequencing, we identified microdeletions in 58% of cases, microinsertions in 17%, nonsense mutations in 8%, and missense mutations in 17%.</Disease>
<Disease>Among these mutations, 50% correspond to new mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>VHL mutations were found only in the nonpapillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) subtype, as previously reported.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To compare somatic and germline mutations, we used the VHL database, which includes 507 mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The study of mutational events revealed a significant difference between somatic and germline mutations with mutations leading to truncated proteins observed in 78% of somatic mutations vs only 37% in germline mutations (P < 0. 001).</Disease>
<Disease>We postulated that a specific pattern of VHL mutations is associated with sporadic RCC.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This pattern corresponds to mutations leading mainly to truncated proteins with few specific missense mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>We then analyzed the occurrence of RCC in VHL families, based on the nature of mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We observed RCC in at least one member of the VHL families in 77% of cases with mutations leading to truncated proteins versus 55% in cases with missense mutations (P < 0. 05).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, mutations resulting in truncated proteins may lead to a higher risk of RCC in VHL patients</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Evidence for inter-generational instability in the CAG repeat in the MJD1 gene and for conserved haplotypes at flanking markers amongst Japanese and Caucasian subjects with Machado-Joseph disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The size of the (CAG)n repeat array in the 3' end of the MJD1 gene and the haplotype at a series of microsatellite markers surrounding the MJD1 gene were examined in a large cohort of Japanese and Caucasian subjects affected with Machado-Joseph disease (MJD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our data provide five novel observations.</Disease>

<Disease>First, MJD is associated with expansion fo the array from the normal range of 14-37 repeats to 68-84 repeats in most Japanese and Caucasian subjects, but no subjects were observed with expansions intermediate in size between those of the normal and MJD affected groups.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Second, the expanded allele associated with MJD displays inter-generational instability, particularly in male meioses, and this instability was associated with the clinical phenomenon of anticipation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Third, the size of the expanded allele is not only inversely correlated with the age-of-onset of MJD (r = -0.738, p < 0.001), but is also correlated with the frequency of other clinical features [e.g. pseudoexophthalmos and pyramidal signs were more frequent in subjects with large repeats (p < 0.001 and</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>p < 0.05 respectively)].</Disease>

<Disease>Fourth, the disease phenotype is significantly more severe and had an early age of onset (16 years) in a subject homozygous for the expanded allele, which contrasts with Huntington disease and suggests that the expanded allele in the MJD1 gene could exert its effect either by a dominant negative effect (putatively excluded in HD) or by a gain of function effect as proposed for HD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Finally, Japanese and Caucasian subjects affected with MJD share haplotypes at several markers surrounding the MJD1 gene, which are uncommon in the normal Japanese and Caucasian population, and which suggests the existence either of common founders in these populations or of chromosomes susceptible to pathologic expansion of the CAG repeat in the MJD1 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy: the role of the CUG triplet repeats in splicing of a novel DMPK exon and altered cytoplasmic DMPK mRNA isoform ratios.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mechanism by which (CTG) n expansion in the 3 UTR of the DMPK gene causes myotonic dystrophy (DM) is unknown.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We identified four RNA splicing factors--hnRNP C, U2AF (U2 auxiliary factor), PTB (polypyrimidine tract binding protein), and PSF (PTB associated splicing factor) --that bind to two short regions 3 of the (CUG) n, and found a novel 3 DMPK exon resulting in an mRNA lacking the repeats.</Disease>
<Disease>We propose that the (CUG) n is an essential cis acting element for this splicing event.</Disease>

<Disease>In contrast to (CUG) n containing mRNAs, the novel isoform is not retained in the nucleus in DM cells, resulting in imbalances in relative levels of cytoplasmic DMPK mRNA isoforms and a new dominant effect of the mutation on DMPK..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Mechanism of increased iron absorption in murine model of hereditary hemochromatosis : increased duodenal expression of the iron transporter DMT1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hereditary hemochromatosis (HH) is a common autosomal recessive disorder characterized by tissue iron deposition secondary to excessive dietary iron absorption.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We recently reported that HFE, the protein defective in HH, was physically associated with the transferrin receptor (TfR) in duodenal crypt cells and proposed that mutations in HFE attenuate the uptake of transferrin-bound iron from plasma by duodenal crypt cells, leading to up-regulation of transporters for dietary iron.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here, we tested the hypothesis that HFE-/- mice have increased duodenal expression of the divalent metal transporter (DMT1).</Disease>

<Disease>By 4 weeks of age, the HFE-/- mice demonstrated iron loading when compared with HFE +/+ littermates, with elevated transferrin saturations (68. 4% vs. 49. 8%) and elevated liver iron concentrations (985 micrograms vs. 381 micrograms).</Disease>

<Disease>By using Northern blot analyses, we quantitated duodenal expression of both classes of DMT1 transcripts  one containing an iron responsive element (IRE), called DMT1 (IRE), and one containing no IRE, called DMT1 (non-IRE).</Disease>
<Disease>The positive control for DMT1 up-regulation was a murine model of dietary iron deficiency that demonstrated greatly increased levels of duodenal DMT1 (IRE) mRNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>HFE-/- mice also demonstrated an increase in duodenal DMT1 (IRE) mRNA (average 7.</Disease>
<Disease>7-fold), despite their elevated transferrin saturation and hepatic iron content.</Disease>
<Disease>Duodenal expression of DMT1 (non-IRE) was not increased, nor was hepatic expression of DMT1 increased.</Disease>

<Disease>These data support the model for HH in which HFE mutations lead to inappropriately low crypt cell iron, with resultant stabilization of DMT1 (IRE) mRNA, up-regulation of DMT1, and increased absorption of dietary iron.</Disease>
<Disease>Yeast artificial chromosomes for the molecular analysis of the familial polyposis APC gene region.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Two yeast artificial chromosomes (YACs) spanning a total distance of 1. 1 megabase pairs of DNA around the MCC (for mutated in colorectal carcinoma) and APC (for adenomatous polyposis coli) genes at 5q21 have been isolated and characterized.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Starting from the MCC gene, a strategy was undertaken to identify constitutional submicroscopic deletions in familial adenomatous polyposis patients that might considerably narrow down the position of the APC gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To this end, YACs identified by the MCC gene were screened across a chromosome 5-specific cosmid library to provide a source of DNA probes for genomic scanning.</Disease>

<Disease>The cosmids isolated from these experiments were used to screen a panel of somatic cell hybrids containing chromosome 5 segregated from patients suspected to carry putative interstitial deletions.</Disease>
<Disease>This screening approach led to the confirmation of a small heterozygous deletion in a polyposis patient that overlaps one of the two isolated YACs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This YAC has been shown to contain the entire APC gene, in addition to a significant portion of DNA flanking the 5 end of the gene, and should therefore prove a valuable resource for functional studies by transfer to colorectal tumor-derived cell lines.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy with growth hormone inhibitors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A controlled, double-blind therapeutic trial with the drug mazindol, a growth hormone inhibitor, was performed in a pair of 7 1/2 year-old monozygotic twins, with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The rationale for this trial was based on a patient (reported previously) affected simultaneously with DMD and growth hormone (GH) deficiency, who is showing a benign course of the dystrophic process and is still walking at 18 years.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>One of the twins received 2 mg of mazindol daily, while the other received a placebo.</Disease>
<Disease>The assessment, repeated every 2 months, included weight and height measurements, functional and motor ability tests, ergometry and determinations of serum enzymes and GH levels.</Disease>

<Disease>After one year of trial the code was broken and it was seen that the twin under placebo treatment was strikingly worse than his brother, the progression of whose condition was practically arrested.</Disease>
<Disease>These results strongly suggest that treatment with a GH inhibitor is beneficial for DMD patients..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Identification of WASP mutations in patients with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome and isolated thrombocytopenia reveals allelic heterogeneity at the WAS locus.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To elucidate the range of WASP mutations responsible for WAS, we used PCR-SSCP analysis to screen for WASP gene mutation in 19 unrelated boys with the diagnosis of classical or attenuated WAS or isolated thrombocytopenia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All 19 patients had WASP mutations, each of which localized to the initial three or terminal three exons of the gene, and the majority of which were unique in each case.</Disease>

<Disease>However, a missense mutation which results in substitution of the arginine at WAS codon 86 was identified in three boys with severe WAS as well as in one boy presenting with thrombocytopenia alone.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>While the three mutations found in the isolated thrombocytopenia patients leave the reading frame intact, about one-half of the gene alterations detected in both severe and attenuated WAS patients result in frameshifted transcript and premature translation termination.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These findings therefore confirm the association of WAS with WASP mutation and identify WASP mutation as a cause for isolated congenital thrombocytopenia in males.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>While the WASP gene defects responsible for isolated thrombocytopenia and other mild presentations of WAS do not appear distinct from those resulting in severe WAS, these data indicate that analysis of WASP gene mutation provides a valuable tool for distinguishing the spectrum of WAS patients and the subset of males with isolated thrombocytopenia who represent mild cases of WAS..</Disease>

text: <Disease>With her it became possible to determine whether allelic exclusion occurs in particular cell-types of the WAS carrier.</Disease>

text: <Disease>If so, the remaining cells of a particular cell-type would express only the normal X chromosome and only one glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase isoenzyme would be demonstrable.</Disease>

<Disease>It is now possible to use gene diagnostics of this unique NIS mutation to identify patients with congenital hypothyroidism due to an iodide transport defect in this family and to determine the carrier state of potential parents for genetic counseling and arranging rapid and early diagnosis of their infants.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>Of all the inherited thrombophilic conditions, it remains the most difficult to diagnose because of phenotypic variability, which can lead to inconclusive results.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We have overcome this problem by studying a cohort of patients from a single center where the diagnosis was confirmed at the genetic level.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>To avoid selection bias, we confined analysis of total and free protein S levels and thrombotic risk to the patients relatives.</Disease>

text: <Disease>8) than those with a normal PROS1 gene and no other recognized thrombophilic defect.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that persons with PROS1 gene defects and protein S deficiency are at increased risk of thrombosis and that free protein S estimation offers the most reliable way of diagnosing the deficiency.</Disease>

<Disease>The protein deficient in Lowe syndrome is a phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate 5-phosphatase.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Lowe syndrome, also known as oculocerebrorenal syndrome, is caused by mutations in the X chromosome-encoded OCRL gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The OCRL protein is 51% identical to inositol polyphosphate 5-phosphatase II (5-phosphatase II) from human platelets over a span of 744 aa, suggesting that OCRL may be a similar enzyme.</Disease>
<Disease>We engineered a construct of the OCRL cDNA that encodes amino acids homologous to the platelet 5-phosphatase for expression in baculovirus-infected Sf9 insect cells.</Disease>
<Disease>This cDNA encodes aa 264-968 of the OCRL protein.</Disease>
<Disease>The recombinant protein was found to catalyze the reactions also carried out by platelet 5-phosphatase II.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus OCRL converts inositol 1, 4, 5-trisphosphate to inositol 1, 4-bisphosphate, and it converts inositol 1, 3, 4, 5-tetrakisphosphate to inositol 1, 3, 4-trisphosphate.</Disease>
<Disease>Most important, the enzyme converts phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate to phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate.</Disease>

<Disease>The relative ability of OCRL to catalyze the three reactions is different from that of 5-phosphatase II and from that of another 5-phosphatase isoenzyme from platelets, 5-phosphatase I.</Disease>
<Disease>The recombinant OCRL protein hydrolyzes the phospholipid substrate 10- to 30-fold better than 5-phosphatase II, and 5-phosphatase I does not cleave the lipid at all.</Disease>
<Disease>We also show that OCRL functions as a phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate 5-phosphatase in OCRL-expressing Sf9 cells.</Disease>
<Disease>These results suggest that OCRL is mainly a lipid phosphatase that may control cellular levels of a critical metabolite, phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate.</Disease>
<Disease>Deficiency of this enzyme apparently causes the protean manifestations of Lowe syndrome..</Disease>

<Disease>A point mutation Thr(799)Met on the alpha(2) integrin leads to the formation of new human platelet alloantigen Sit(a) and affects collagen-induced aggregation.</Disease>
<Disease>A new platelet-specific alloantigen, termed Sit (a), was identified in a severe case of neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Sit (a) alloantigen is of low frequency (1/400) in the German population.</Disease>

<Disease>Immunochemical studies demonstrated that the Sit (a) epitopes reside on platelet glycoprotein (GP) Ia. Nucleotide sequence analysis of GPIa cDNA derived from Sit (a) -positive platelets showed C (2531) --</Disease>
<Disease>> T (2531) point mutation, resulting in Thr (799)</Disease>
<Disease>Met dimorphism.</Disease>
<Disease>Analysis of genomic DNA from 22 Sit (a) -negative normal individuals showed that the Thr (799) is encoded by ACG (2532) (90. 9%) or ACA (2532) (9. 1%).</Disease>
<Disease>To establish a DNA typing technique, we elucidated the organization of the GPIa gene adjacent to the polymorphic bases.</Disease>
<Disease>The introns (421 bp and 1. 2 kb) encompass a 142-bp exon with the 2 polymorphic bases 2531 and 2532.</Disease>

<Disease>Polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis on DNA derived from 100 donors using the restriction enzyme Mae III showed that the Met (799) form of GPIa is restricted to Sit (a) (+) phenotype.</Disease>

<Disease>Analysis of stable Chinese hamster ovary transfectants expressing allele-specific recombinant forms of GPIa showed that anti-Sit (a) exclusively reacted with the Glu (505) Met (799), but not with the Glu (505) Thr (799) and the Lys (505) Thr (799) isoforms.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, anti-Br (a) (HPA-5b) only recognized the Lys (505) Thr (799) form, whereas anti-Br (b) (HPA-5a) reacted with both Glu (505) Thr (799) and Glu (505) Met (799) isoforms.</Disease>

<Disease>These results demonstrated that the Met (799) is responsible for formation of the Sit (a) alloantigenic determinants, whereas amino acid 505 (Lys or Glu) specifically controls the expression of Br (a) and Br (b) epitopes, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>Platelet aggregation responses of Sit (a) (+) individuals were diminished in response to collagen, indicating that the Thr (799) Met mutation affects the function of the GPIa/IIa complex</Disease>
<Disease>Estimation of the male to female ratio of mutation rates from the segregation of X-chromosomal DNA haplotypes in Duchenne muscular dystrophy families.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To better understand the function of the EWS protein, we cloned the EWS cDNA.</Disease>

<Disease>Both alternatively spliced transcripts, EWS and EWS-b, are expressed in a variety of cells.</Disease>
<Disease>Because EWS proteins contain putative conserved RNA binding motifs, we studied the RNA binding properties of the EWS protein.</Disease>
<Disease>The EWS-b protein binds to RNA in vitro and, specifically, to poly G and poly U.</Disease>
<Disease>The RNA binding activity was localized to the carboxy terminal 86 amino acids, which constitute RGG box.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus the amino terminal domain of EWS (NTD-EWS), which is involved in chromosome translocation may regulate the specificity of RNA binding activity of EWS.</Disease>

<Disease>Most of those carrying the allele trace their origins to the United Kingdom, Ireland, or Western Europe.</Disease>

text: <Disease>BRCA1 is associated with a human SWI/SNF-related complex: linking chromatin remodeling to breast cancer.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Using a combination of affinity- and conventional chromatographic techniques, we have isolated a predominant form of a multiprotein BRCA1-containing complex from human cells displaying chromatin-remodeling activity.</Disease>
<Disease>Mass spectrometric sequencing of components of this complex indicated that BRCA1 is associated with a SWI/SNF-related complex.</Disease>

<Disease>Moreover, p53-mediated stimulation of transcription by BRCA1 was completely abrogated by either a dominant-negative mutant of BRG1 or the cancer-causing deletion in exon 11 of BRCA1.</Disease>

<Disease>Germinal mosaicism in a Duchenne muscular dystrophy family: implications for genetic counselling.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In this study we describe a three-generation family in which two siblings were affected by Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Immunohistochemical analysis of muscle dystrophin and haplotype analysis of the DMD locus revealed that the X chromosome carrying the DMD gene was transmitted from the healthy maternal grandfather to his three daughters, including the probands mother.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These findings indicate that the grandfather was a germinal mosaic for the DMD gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The definition of the carrier status in two possible carriers led us to give accurate genetic counselling and to prevent the birth of an affected boy.</Disease>

<Disease>The results of this study demonstrate the usefulness of haplotype analysis and immunohistochemical muscle dystrophin studies to detect hidden germinal mosaicism and to improve genetic counselling..</Disease>
<Disease>Centrosome amplification and a defective G2-M cell cycle checkpoint induce genetic instability in BRCA1 exon 11 isoform-deficient cells.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To study mechanisms underlying BRCA1-related tumorigenesis, we derived mouse embryonic fibroblast cells carrying a targeted deletion of exon 11 of the Brca1 gene.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Mutant fibroblasts contain multiple, functional centrosomes, which lead to unequal chromosome segregation, abnormal nuclear division, and aneuploidy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These data uncover an essential role of BRCA1 in maintaining genetic stability through the regulation of centrosome duplication and the G2-M checkpoint and provide a molecular basis for the role of BRCA1 in tumorigenesis..</Disease>

text: <Disease>We report a mutation within the phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) gene that causes aberrant splicing of the mRNA and that is in tight association with chromosomal haplotypes 6, 10, and 36.</Disease>

<Disease>Because of the high frequency of these particular haplotypes in Bulgaria, Italy, and Turkey, it appears to be one of the more frequent defects in the PAH gene causing classical phenylketonuria in this part of Europe.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation is a G to A transition at position 546 in intron 10 of the PAH gene, 11 bp upstream from the intron 10/exon 11 boundary.</Disease>
<Disease>It activates a cryptic splice site and results in an in-frame insertion of 9 nucleotides between exon 10 and exon 11 of the processed mRNA.</Disease>
<Disease>Normal amounts of liver PAH protein are present in homozygous patients, but no catalytic activity can be detected.</Disease>

<Disease>This loss of enzyme activity is probably caused by conformational changes resulting from the insertion of three additional amino acids (Gly-Leu-Gln) between the normal sequences encoded by exon 10 and exon 11..</Disease>
<Disease>Biochemical and structural analysis of missense mutations in N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulfate sulfatase causing mucopolysaccharidosis IVA phenotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mucopolysaccharidosis IVA (MPS IVA; OMIM # 253000), a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of N -acetylgalactosamine-6-sulfate sulfatase (GALNS), has variable clinical phenotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To date we have identified 65 missense mutations in the GALNS gene from MPS IVA patients, but the correlation between genotype and phenotype has remained unclear.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We studied 17 missense mutations using biochemical approaches and 32 missense mutations, using structural analyses.</Disease>
<Disease>Fifteen missense mutations and two newly engineered active site mutations (C79S, C79T) were characterized by transient expression analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutant proteins, except for C79S and C79T, were destabilized and detected as insoluble precursor forms while the C79S and C79T mutants were of a soluble mature size.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutants found in the severe phenotype had no activity.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutants found in the mild phenotype had a considerable residual activity (1. 3-13.</Disease>
<Disease>3% of wild-type GALNS activity).</Disease>
<Disease>Sulfatases, including GALNS, are members of a highly conserved gene family sharing an extensive sequence homology.</Disease>

<Disease>Thus, a tertiary structural model of human GALNS was constructed from the X-ray crystal structure of N -acetylgalacto-samine-4-sulfatase and arylsulfatase A, using homology modeling, and 32 missense mutations were investigated.</Disease>

<Disease>Consequently, we propose that there are at least three different reasons for the severe phenotype  (i) destruction of the hydrophobic core or modification of the packing; (ii) removal of a salt bridge to destabilize the entire conformation; (iii) modification of the active site.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, mild mutations were mostly located on the surface of the GALNS protein.</Disease>
<Disease>These studies shed further light on the genotype-phenotype correlation of MPS IVA and structure-function relationship in the sulfatase family.</Disease>

<Disease>One missense mutation (which occurred independently in two families) leads to loss of a cysteine in the zinc binding domain.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Genetic instability in human ovarian cancer cell lines.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We have analyzed the stability of microsatellites in cell lines derived from human ovarian cancers and found that 5 out of 10 of the ovarian tumor cell lines are genetically unstable at the majority of the loci analyzed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In clones and subclones derived serially from one of these cell lines (2774; serous cystadenocarcinoma), a very high proportion of microsatellites distributed in many different regions of the genome change their size in a mercurial fashion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that genomic instability in ovarian tumors is a dynamic and ongoing process whose high frequency may have been previously underestimated by PCR-based allelotyping of bulk tumor tissue.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have identified the source of the genetic instability in one ovarian tumor as a point mutation (R524P) in the human mismatch-repair gene MSH2 (Salmonella MutS homologue), which has recently been shown to be involved in hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Patient 2774 was a 38-year-old heterozygote, and her normal tissue carried both mutant and wild-type alleles of the human MSH2 gene.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>The genetic instability observed in the tumor and cell line DNA, together with the germ-line mutation in a mismatch-repair gene, suggest that the MSH2 gene is involved in the onset and/or progression in a subset of ovarian cancer..</Disease>

text: <Disease>On the basis of this homology and the presence of a slightly modified sulfate-transporter signature sequence comprising its putative second transmembrane domain, pendrin has been proposed to function as a sulfate transporter.</Disease>

text: <Disease>mmol/liter) and demonstrated an X-linked pattern of inheritance.</Disease>

label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We previously identified the first causative mutations in a nonconsanguineous Swiss family; the 4 affected persons have homozygous deletions of approximately 11 kb of the fibrinogen alpha (FGA) gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Haplotype data implied that these deletions occurred on distinct ancestral chromosomes, suggesting that this region may be susceptible to deletion by a common mechanism.</Disease>
<Disease>We subsequently showed that all the deletions were identical to the base pair and probably resulted from a nonhomologous recombination mediated by 7-bp direct repeats.</Disease>
<Disease>In this study, we have collected data on 13 additional unrelated patients to identify the causative mutations and to determine the prevalence of the 11-kb deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>A common recurrent mutation, at the donor splice site of FGA intron 4 (IVS4 + 1 G > T), accounted for 14 of the 26 (54%) alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>One patient was heterozygous for the previously identified deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>Three more frameshift mutations, 2 nonsense mutations, and a second splice site mutation were also identified.</Disease>

<Disease>Consequently, 86% of afibrinogenemia alleles analyzed to date have truncating mutations of FGA, though mutations in all 3 fibrinogen genes, FGG, FGA, and FGB, might be predicted to cause congenital afibrinogenemia..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Utilization of purines by an HPRT variant in an intelligent, nonmutilative patient with features of the Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We describe five families for which direct sequencing of the coding region of the VHL gene had failed to identify the family-specific mutation.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Further molecular analysis revealed deletions involving the VHL gene in each of these families.</Disease>

<Disease>In the fifth family, FISH analysis demonstrated the deletion of the entire VHL gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our results show that (quantitative) Southern blot analysis is a sensitive method for detecting germline deletions of the VHL gene and should be implemented in routine DNA diagnosis for VHL disease.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Understanding the molecular basis of fragile X syndrome.</Disease>

label: Disease

<Disease>Heterogeneity of type I von Willebrand disease: evidence for a subgroup with an abnormal von Willebrand factor.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Type I von Willebrand disease (vWD) is characterized by equally low plasma concentrations of von Willebrand factor antigen (vWF  Ag) and ristocetin cofactor (RiCof) and by the presence of all vWF multimers in sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) -agarose gel electrophoresis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>For 17 patients (13 kindreds) diagnosed with these criteria, we have studied the platelet contents of vWF  Ag and RiCof and the changes of these in plasma after DDAVP infusion.</Disease>

<Disease>Platelet vWF  Ag and RiCof were normal in four kindreds (called " platelet normal " subgroup); following 1-deamino-8-D-arginine vasopressin; plasma vWF  Ag, RiCof and the bleeding time (BT) became normal.</Disease>
<Disease>In six kindreds, platelet vWF  Ag and RiCof were equally low (platelet low); after DDAVP, plasma vWF  Ag and RiCof remained low, and the BT was prolonged.</Disease>

<Disease>In three additional kindreds, platelets contained normal concentrations of vWF  Ag, but RiCof was very low (platelet discordant); even though a complete set of multimers was found in plasma and platelets, there was a relatively small amount of large multimers.</Disease>
<Disease>After DDAVP, plasma vWF  Ag became normal, but RiCof remained low and the BT was very prolonged.</Disease>

<Disease>These findings demonstrated that there can be an abnormal vWF (RiCof less than vWF  Ag) even in type I vWD, coexisting with a complete set of vWF multimers (platelet discordant); that the abnormal vWF can be shown more clearly in platelets than in plasma or else in plasma after DDAVP infusion; and that DDAVP normalizes the BT only in those patients with normal platelet levels of both vWF  Ag and RiCof (platelet normal)..</Disease>

<Disease>Fibroblast growth factor homologous factor 2 (FHF2): gene structure, expression and mapping to the Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome region in Xq26 delineated by a duplication breakpoint in a BFLS-like patient.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome (BFLS) is a syndromal X-linked mental retardation, which maps by linkage to the q26 region of the human X chromosome.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We have identified a male patient with BFLS-like features and a duplication, 46, Y, dup (X) (q26q28), inherited from his phenotypically normal mother.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fluorescence in situ hybridisation using yeast artificial chromosome clones from Xq26 localised the duplication breakpoint to an approximately 400-kb interval in the Xq26.</Disease>
<Disease>3 region between DXS155 and DXS294/DXS730.</Disease>

<Disease>Database searches and analysis of available genomic DNA sequence from the region revealed the presence of the fibroblast growth factor homologous factor gene, FHF2, within the duplication breakpoint interval.</Disease>
<Disease>The gene structure of FHF2 was determined and two new exons were identified, including a new 5 end exon, 1B. FHF2 is a large gene extending over approximately 200 kb in Xq26.</Disease>
<Disease>3 and is composed of at least seven exons.</Disease>
<Disease>It shows tissue-specific alternative splicing and alternative transcription starts.</Disease>
<Disease>Northern blot hybridisation showed highest expression in brain and skeletal muscle.</Disease>

<Disease>The FHF2 gene localisation and tissue-specific expression pattern suggest it to be a candidate gene for familial cases of the BFLS syndrome and other syndromal and non-specific forms of X-linked mental retardation mapping to the region.</Disease>

Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, small platelets, eczema, recurrent infections, and immunodeficiency.</Disease>

label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>Using a fingerprinting screening technique, we determined the approximate location of the mutation in 13 unrelated WAS patients with mild to severe clinical symptoms.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A 3-base pair in-frame deletion of the phenylalanine hydroxylase gene results in a kinetic variant of phenylketonuria.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disease due to deficiency of a hepatic enzyme, phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The absence of PAH activity results in typical PKU while persistence of a residual enzyme activity gives rise to variant forms of the disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report here a 3-base pair in-frame deletion of the PAH gene (delta 194) in a mild variant, with markedly reduced affinity of the enzyme for phenylalanine (Km = 160 nM), and we provide functional evidence for responsibility of the deletion in the mutant phenotype.</Disease>

<Disease>Since the deletion was located in the third exon of the gene, which presents no homology with other hydroxylases, we suggest that exon 3 is involved in the specificity of the enzyme for phenylalanine.</Disease>

<Disease>Finally, since none of the 98 PKU patients tested were found to carry this particular deletion, our study suggests that this molecular event probably occurred recently on the background of a haplotype 2 gene in Portugal..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Friedreich ataxia: an overview.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Friedreich ataxia, an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disease, is the most common of the inherited ataxias.</Disease>

Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The recent discovery of the gene that is mutated in this condition, FRDA, has led to rapid advances in the understanding of the pathogenesis of Friedreich ataxia.</Disease>

text: <Disease>About 98% of mutant alleles have an expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in intron 1 of the gene.</Disease>
<Disease>This leads to reduced levels of the protein, frataxin.</Disease>

<Disease>There is mounting evidence to suggest that Friedreich ataxia is the result of accumulation of iron in mitochondria leading to excess production of free radicals, which then results in cellular damage and death.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Currently there is no known treatment that alters the natural course of the disease.</Disease>
<Disease>The discovery of the FRDA gene and its possible function has raised hope that rational therapeutic strategies will be developed..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Clinical and molecular genetics of primary dystonias.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Primary dystonias are movement disorders with dystonia as a major symptom.</Disease>
