Disease

text: <Disease>They are frequently inherited as Mendelian traits.</Disease>
<Disease>There are at least eight clinically distinct autosomal dominant and two X-linked recessive forms.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, pedigree analyses suggest the occurrence of an autosomal recessive variant.</Disease>
<Disease>The clinical classification is increasingly being replaced by a genetic one.</Disease>

<Disease>To date gene loci have been identified in at least six autosomal dominant forms, i. e., in idiopathic torsion dystonia (9q34), focal dystonia (18p), adult-onset idiopathic torsion dystonia of mixed type (8p21-q22), dopa-responsive dystonia (14q22. 1-q22. 2), and paroxysmal dystonic choreoathetosis (2q25-q33; 1p21-p13. 3).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Gene loci in the X-linked recessive  forms have been assigned to Xq13. 1 in the X-linked dystonia parkinsonism syndrome and to Xq22 in X-linked sensorineural deafness, dystonia, and mental retardation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The disease genes have been identified in two autosomal dominant forms and in one X-linked recessive form.</Disease>

<Disease>Mutations in a gene coding for an ATP-binding protein were detected in idiopathic torsion dystonia (DYT1), and the GTP cyclohydrolase 1 gene is mutated in dopa-responsive dystonia (DYT5).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In sensorineural deafness, dystonia, and mental retardation , mutations were found in the gene DDP coding for a polypeptide of unknown function.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This article reviews the clinical and molecular genetics of primary dystonias, critically discusses present findings, and proposes referring to the known forms, most of which can be distinguished by genetic criteria, as dystonias 1-12.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Clinical and genetic study of Friedreich ataxia in an Australian population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the FRDA gene that encodes a 210-amino acid protein called frataxin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>An expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in intron 1 of the gene is present in more than 95% of mutant alleles.</Disease>

<Disease>Of the 83 people we studied who have mutations in FRDA, 78 are homozygous for an expanded GAA repeat; the other five patients have an expansion in one allele and a point mutation in the other.</Disease>
<Disease>Here we present a detailed clinical and genetic study of a subset of 51 patients homozygous for an expansion of the GAA repeat.</Disease>

<Disease>We found a correlation between the size of the smaller of the two expanded alleles and age at onset, age into wheelchair, scoliosis, impaired vibration sense, and the presence of foot deformity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>There was no significant correlation between the size of the smaller allele and cardiomyopathy, diabetes mellitus, loss of proprioception, or bladder symptoms.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The larger allele size correlated with bladder symptoms and the presence of foot deformity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The duration of disease is correlated with wheelchair use and the presence of diabetes, scoliosis, bladder symptoms and impaired proprioception, and vibration sense but no other complications studied..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recurrent meningococcal meningitis with absence of the sixth component of complement: an evaluation of underlying immunologic mechanisms.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A 51/2-year-old black girl with recurrent meningococcal meningitis and absence of the sixth component of complement (C6) is reported.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To explore the pathogenesis of recurrent neisserial infections in C6 deficiency, a detailed analysis of her immune competence was conducted.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Her serum had normal chemotactic, opsonic, alternative complement pathway, and specific antibody activity, but lacked complement-mediated bacteriolytic activity.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, her C6-deficient serum was indistinguishable from normal serum in a complement-dependent assay of phagocyte bactericidal activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Absent bacteriolysis remains the only consistent defect associated with recurrent neisserial infections and absence of one of the late-acting complement components..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation of the sterol 27-hydroxylase gene (CYP27) results in truncation of mRNA expressed in leucocytes in a Japanese family with cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVES  A Japanese family with cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis (CTX) was investigated for a sequence alteration in the sterol 27-hydroxylase gene (CYP27).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The expression of CYP27 has been mostly explored using cultured fibroblasts, prompting the examination of the transcripts from blood leucocytes as a simple and rapid technique.</Disease>
<Disease>METHODS  </Disease>
<Disease>An alteration in CYP27 of the proband was searched for by polymerase chain reaction-single strand conformation polymorphism (PCR-SSCP) analysis and subsequent sequencing.</Disease>
<Disease>Samples of RNA were subjected to reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) and the product of the proband was amplified with nested primers and sequenced.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS  A homozygous G to A transition at the 5 end of intron 7 was detected in the patient.</Disease>
<Disease>In RT-PCR analysis, only a truncated transcript was detected in the patient, whereas both normal and truncated transcripts were detected in the siblings.</Disease>
<Disease>The sequencing of the patients cDNA fragment disclosed a direct conjuction of exon 6 and exon 8.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION  The mutation at splice donor site and the truncation of mRNA were identical with those of a recently reported Italian patient, although different in symptomatology.</Disease>
<Disease>The application of blood leucocytes can be a simple technique on analysing a constructive abnormality of CYP27 mRNA..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Frequent detection of codon 877 mutation in the androgen receptor gene in advanced prostate cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prostatic tissue specimens derived from transurethral resections of patients with metastatic prostate cancer were analyzed for genetic alterations in the hormone-binding domain of the androgen receptor (AR) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Direct sequencing of the polymerase chain reaction-derived DNAs of 6 of 24 specimens revealed a codon 877 mutation (ACT-- > GCT, Thr-- > Ala) in the hormone-binding domain of the AR gene.</Disease>

<Disease>This same AR mutation has been reported previously in a metastatic prostate cancer cell line, LNCaP, where this mutation confers upon the AR an altered ligand-binding specificity which is stimulated by estrogens, progestagens, and antiandrogens.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is possible that analogous to an activated/altered growth factor receptor oncogene, codon 877 mutant AR with altered ligand binding may provide a selective growth advantage in the genesis of a subset of advanced prostate cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although estrogens are used infrequently, antiandrogens are used increasingly in hormonal therapy for patients with advanced prostate cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The stimulatory effect of these therapeutic agents on the codon 877 mutant AR further suggests that this frequently observed AR mutation may contribute to the treatment refractory disease..</Disease>
<Disease>ATM-dependent phosphorylation of nibrin in response to radiation exposure.</Disease>

<Disease>Mutations in the gene ATM are responsible for the genetic disorder ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), which is characterized by cerebellar dysfunction, radiosensitivity, chromosomal instability and cancer predisposition.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Both the A-T phenotype and the similarity of the ATM protein to other DNA-damage sensors suggests a role for ATM in biochemical pathways involved in the recognition, signalling and repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>There are strong parallels between the pattern of radiosensitivity, chromosomal instability and cancer predisposition in A-T patients and that in patients with Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The protein defective in NBS, nibrin (encoded by NBS1), forms a complex with MRE11 and RAD50 (refs 1, 2).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This complex localizes to DSBs within 30 minutes after cellular exposure to ionizing radiation (IR) and is observed in brightly staining nuclear foci after a longer period of time.</Disease>
<Disease>The overlap between clinical and cellular phenotypes in A-T and NBS suggests that ATM and nibrin may function in the same biochemical pathway.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here we demonstrate that nibrin is phosphorylated within one hour of treatment of cells with IR.</Disease>
<Disease>This response is abrogated in A-T cells that either do not express ATM protein or express near full-length mutant protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We also show that ATM physically interacts with and phosphorylates nibrin on serine 343 both in vivo and in vitro.</Disease>
<Disease>Phosphorylation of this site appears to be functionally important because mutated nibrin (S343A) does not completely complement radiosensitivity in NBS cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>ATM phosphorylation of nibrin does not affect nibrin-MRE11-RAD50 association as revealed by radiation-induced foci formation.</Disease>
<Disease>Our data provide a biochemical explanation for the similarity in phenotype between A-T and NBS..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Detection of an unstable fragment of DNA specific to individuals with myotonic dystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is the most common form of adult muscular dystrophy, with a prevalence of 2-14 per 100, 000 individuals.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The disease is characterized by progressive muscle weakness and sustained muscle contraction, often with a wide range of accompanying symptoms.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The age at onset and severity of the disease show extreme variation, both within and between families.</Disease>
<Disease>Despite its clinical variability, this dominant condition segregates as a single locus at chromosome 19q13.</Disease>
<Disease>3 in every population studied.</Disease>
<Disease>It is flanked by the tightly linked genetic markers ERCC1 proximally and D19S51 distally; these define the DM critical region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report the isolation of an expressed sequence from this region which detects a DNA fragment that is larger in affected individuals than in normal siblings or unaffected controls.</Disease>
<Disease>The size of this fragment varies between affected siblings, and increases in size through generations in parallel with increasing severity of the disease.</Disease>
<Disease>We postulate that this unstable DNA sequence is the molecular feature that underlies DM.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Detection of a novel missense mutation and second recurrent mutation in the CACNA1A gene in individuals with EA-2 and FHM.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the brain specific P/Q type Ca2 + channel alpha1 subunit gene, CACNA1A, have been identified in three clinically distinct disorders, viz.</Disease>
<Disease>episodic ataxia type 2 (EA-2), familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM) and spinocerebellar ataxia 6 (SCA6).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>For individuals with EA-2, the mutations described thus far are presumed to result in a truncated protein product.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Several different missense mutations have been identified in patients with FHM.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>At least two of these mutations have been identified on two different chromosome 19p13 haplotypes and thus represent recurrent mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>In the present study, we have screened several individuals for mutations in all 47 exons in the CACNA1A gene by single-strand conformation analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>We have characterised a novel missense mutation, G5260A, in exon 32 in a family segregating for EA-2.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The consequence of this mutation is an amino acid substitution at a highly conserved position within the CACNA1A gene.</Disease>
<Disease>This represents the first point mutation not resulting in a proposed truncated protein.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, this mutation has been detected in a family member with mild clinical signs including only migraine.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Additionally, a second previously identified recurrent muta tion, C2272T, in exon 16 has been discovered in a patient with FHM..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Dominant negative effect of the APC1309 mutation: a possible explanation for genotype-phenotype correlations in familial adenomatous polyposis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Inactivation of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene product initiates colorectal tumorigenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Patients with familial APC (FAP) carry germ-line mutations in the APC gene and develop multiple colorectal adenomas and subsequent carcinomas early in life.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The severity of the disease correlates with the position of the inherited APC mutation (genotype-phenotype correlation).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Together with the fact that both germ-line and sporadic APC mutations cluster in the central region of the APC gene, this points to a dominant negative effect of certain APC mutants.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Loss of APC function was recently shown to result in enhanced beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription in colon epithelial cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here, we provide experimental evidence for a dominant negative effect of APC gene products associated with severe polyposis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Wild-type APC activity in beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription was strongly inhibited by a mutant APC that is truncated at codon 1309.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, mutant APC gene products that are associated with attenuated polyposis (codon 386 or 1465) interfered only weakly with wild-type APC activity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggest a molecular explanation for the genotype-phenotype correlation in FAP patients and support the idea that colorectal tumor growth might be, in part, driven by selection for a mutation in the mutation cluster region..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation of the KIT (mast/stem cell growth factor receptor) protooncogene in human piebaldism.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Piebaldism is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by cogenital patches of skin and hair from which melanocytes are completely absent.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A similar disorder of mouse, dominant white spotting (W), results from mutations of the c-Kit protooncogene, which encodes and receptor for mast/stem cell growth factor.</Disease>
<Disease>We identified a KIT gene mutation in a proband with classic autosomal dominant piebaldism.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This mutation results in a Gly----Arg substitution at codon 664, within the tyrosine kinase domain.</Disease>
<Disease>This substitution was not seen in any normal individuals and was completely linked to the piebald phenotype in the probands family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Piebaldism in this family thus appears to be the human homologue to dominant white spotting (W) of the mouse..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An arylsulfatase A (ARSA) missense mutation (T274M) causing late-infantile metachromatic leukodystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of arylsulfatase A (ARSA; EC 3. 1. 6. 8).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The 8 ARSA exons and adjacent intron boundaries from a patient with late-infantile metachromatic leukodystrophy were polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplified in seven discrete reactions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Amplified ARSA exons were analysed for the presence of sequence alterations by single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis, followed by direct sequencing of PCR products.</Disease>

<Disease>The patient was found to be homozygous for a C-- > T transition in exon IV that results in the substitution of a highly conserved threonine residue at amino acid 274 with a methionine (T274M).</Disease>

<Disease>Analysis of a further 29 MLD patients revealed the presence of five additional homozygotes for T274M. All 6 T274M homozygotes (representing four families) were of Lebanese descent, and all were known to be the result of consanguineous marriages.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The altered amino acid is rigidly conserved among 10 sulfatases from Escherichia coli to humans; therefore, it is most likely that the resultant mutant protein will have little or no enzyme activity.</Disease>
<Disease>This is consistent with the very low ARSA activity measured in these patients and their uniformly severe clinical presentation</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations in the gene for X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy in patients with different clinical phenotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, the gene for the most common peroxisomal disorder, X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD), has been described encoding a peroxisomal membrane transporter protein.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We analyzed the entire protein-coding sequence of this gene by reverse-transcription PCR, SSCP, and DNA sequencing in five patients with different clinical expression of X-ALD and in their female relatives; these clinical expressions were cerebral childhood ALD, adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN), and " Addison disease only " (ADO) phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the three patients exhibiting the classical picture of severe childhood ALD we identified in the 5 portion of the X-ALD gene a 38-bp deletion that causes a frameshift mutation, a 3-bp deletion leading to a deletion of an amino acid in the ATP-binding domain of the ALD protein, and a missense mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the patient with the clinical phenotype of AMN, a nonsense mutation in codon 212, along with a second site mutation at codon 178, was observed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Analysis of the patient with the ADO phenotype revealed a further missense mutation at a highly conserved position in the ALDP/PMP70 comparison.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The disruptive nature of two mutations (i. e., the frameshift and the nonsense mutation) in patients with biochemically proved childhood ALD and AMN further strongly supports the hypothesis that alterations in this gene play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of X-ALD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Since the current biochemical techniques for X-ALD carrier detection in affected families lack sufficient reliability, our procedure described for systematic mutation scanning is also capable of improving genetic counseling and prenatal diagnosis</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Atelosteogenesis type II is caused by mutations in the diastrophic dysplasia sulfate-transporter gene (DTDST): evidence for a phenotypic series involving three chondrodysplasias.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Atelosteogenesis type II (AO II) is a neonatally lethal chondrodysplasia whose clinical and histological characteristics resemble those of another chondrodysplasia, the much less severe diastrophic dysplasia (DTD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The similarity suggests a shared pathogenesis involving lesions in the same biochemical pathway and perhaps the same gene.</Disease>
<Disease>DTD is caused by mutations in the recently identified diastrophic dysplasia sulfate-transporter gene (DTDST).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here, we report that AOII patients also have DTDST mutations, which lead to defective uptake of inorganic sulfate and insufficient sulfation of macromolecules by patient mesenchymal cells in vitro.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Together with our recent observation that a third even more severe chondrodysplasia, achondrogenesis type IB, is also caused by mutations in DTDST, these results demonstrate a phenotypic series of three chondrodysplasias of increasing severity caused by lesions in a single sulfate-transporter gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The severity of the phenotype appears to be correlated with the predicted effect of the mutations on the residual activity of the DTDST protein..</Disease>
<Disease>Emerin, deficiency of which causes Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy, is localized at the inner nuclear membrane.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>X-linked recessive Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EDMD) is an inherited muscle disorder characterized by the clinical triad of progressive wasting of humero-peroneal muscles, early contractures of the elbows, Achilles tendons and postcervical muscles, and cardiac conduction block with a high risk of sudden death.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The gene for EDMD on Xq28 encodes a novel protein named emerin that localizes at the nuclear membrane of skeletal, cardiac and smooth muscles and some other non-muscle tissues.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To investigate a possible physiological role for emerin, we examined the ultrastructural localization of the protein in human skeletal muscle and HeLa cells, using ultrathin cryosections.</Disease>
<Disease>We found that the immune-labeled colloidal gold particles were localized on the nucleoplasmic surface of the inner nuclear membrane, but not on the nuclear pore.</Disease>
<Disease>Emerin stayed on the cytoplasmic surface of the nuclear lamina, even after detergent treatment that solubilizes membrane lipids and washes out membrane proteins.</Disease>

<Disease>These results suggest that emerin anchors at the inner nuclear membrane through the hydrophobic stretch, and protrudes from the hydrophilic region to the nucleoplasm where it interacts with the nuclear lamina.</Disease>

<Disease>We speculate that emerin contributes to maintain the nuclear structure and stability, as well as nuclear functions, particularly in muscle tissues that have severe stress with rigorous contraction-relaxation movements and calcium flux..</Disease>
<Disease>Identification of a common PEX1 mutation in Zellweger syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Zellweger spectrum of disease, encompassing Zellweger syndrome and the progressively milder phenotypes of neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy and infantile Refsum disease, is due to a failure to form functional peroxisomes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cell fusion complementation studies demonstrated that these diseases are genetically heterogeneous, with two-thirds of all patients lying within a single complementation group, CG1.</Disease>
<Disease>Molecular genetic and cell biology studies have shown that PEX1 is deficient in many CG1 patients.</Disease>
<Disease>However, previous studies have focused on mildly affected patients and there is still no report of two mutant PEX1 alleles in any Zellweger syndrome patient.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, mutations in the PMP70 gene have also been identified in two Zellweger syndrome patients from CG1, raising the possibility that CG1 patients may represent a mixture of PEX1-deficient and PMP70-deficient individuals.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To address the molecular basis of disease in Zellweger syndrome patients from CG1, we examined all 24 PEX1 exons in four patients, including both patients that have mutations in PMP70.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>PEX1 mutations were detected in all four patients, including a 1-bp insertion (c. 2097insT) in exon 13 that was present in three of the four patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Subsequent studies demonstrated that this mutation is present in one-half of all CG1 patients and correlates with the Zellweger syndrome phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>As this mutation leads to a loss of protein function its frequency makes it the most common cause of Zellweger syndrome, helping to explain the high percentage of patients that belong to CG1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Polymorphisms of the CYP2D6 gene increase susceptibility to ankylosing spondylitis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a common and highly familial rheumatic disorder.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The sibling recurrence risk ratio for the disease is 63 and heritability assessed in twins > 90%.</Disease>

<Disease>Although MHC genes, including HLA-B27, contribute only 20-50% of the genetic risk for the disease, no non-MHC gene has yet been convincingly demonstrated to influence either susceptibility to the disease or its phenotypic expression.</Disease>

<Disease>Previous linkage and association studies have suggested the presence of a susceptibility gene for AS close to, or within, the cytochrome P450 2D6 gene (CYP2D6, debrisoquine hydroxylase) located at chromosome 22q13.1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We performed a linkage study of chromosome 22 in 200 families with AS affected sibling-pairs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Association of alleles of the CYP2D6 gene was examined by both case-control and within-family means.</Disease>

<Disease>For case-control studies, 617 unrelated individuals with AS (361 probands from sibling-pair and parent-case trio families and 256 unrelated non-familial sporadic cases) and 402 healthy ethnically matched controls were employed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>For within-family association studies, 361 families including 161 parent-case trios and 200 affected sibling-pair families were employed.</Disease>
<Disease>Homozygosity for poor metabolizer alleles was found to be associated with AS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Heterozygosity for the most frequent poor metabolizer allele (CYP2D6*4) was not associated with increased susceptibility to AS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Significant within-family association of CYP2D6*4 alleles and AS was demonstrated.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Weak linkage was also demonstrated between CYP2D6 and AS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We postulate that altered metabolism of a natural toxin or antigen by the CYP2D6 gene may increase susceptibility to AS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular analysis of the genotype-phenotype relationship in factor X deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Factor X deficiency is a rare haemorrhagic condition, normally inherited as an autosomal recessive trait, in which a variable clinical presentation correlates poorly with laboratory phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The factor X (F10) genes of 14 unrelated individuals with factor X deficiency (12 familial and two sporadic cases) were sequenced yielding a total of 13 novel mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Family studies were performed in order to distinguish the contributions of individual mutant F10 alleles to the clinical and laboratory phenotypes.</Disease>

<Disease>Missense mutations were studied by means of molecular modelling, whereas single basepair substitutions in splice sites and the 5 flanking region were examined by in vitro splicing assay and luciferase reporter gene assay respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>The deletion allele of a novel hexanucleotide insertion/deletion polymorphism in the F10 gene promoter region was shown by reporter gene assay, to reduce promoter activity by approximately 20%.</Disease>

<Disease>One family manifesting an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance possessed three clinically affected members who were heterozygous for a splice-site mutation that was predicted to lead to the production of a truncated protein product.</Disease>
<Disease>A model which accounts for the dominant negative effect of this lesion is presented.</Disease>

<Disease>Variation in the antigen level of heterozygous relatives of probands was found to be significantly higher between families than within families, consistent with the view that the nature of the F10 lesion (s) segregating in a given family is a prime determinant of the laboratory phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>By contrast, no such relationship could be discerned between laboratory phenotype and polymorphism genotype..</Disease>
<Disease>Restoration of photoreceptor ultrastructure and function in retinal degeneration slow mice by gene therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The gene Prph2 encodes a photoreceptor-specific membrane glycoprotein, peripherin-2 (also known as peripherin/rds), which is inserted into the rims of photoreceptor outer segment discs in a complex with rom-1 (ref. 2).</Disease>
<Disease>The complex is necessary for the stabilization of the discs, which are renewed constantly throughout life, and which contain the visual pigments necessary for photon capture.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations in Prph2 have been shown to result in a variety of photoreceptor dystrophies, including autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa and macular dystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A common feature of these diseases is the loss of photoreceptor function, also seen in the retinal degeneration slow (rds or Prph2 Rd2/Rd2) mouse, which is homozygous for a null mutation in Prph2.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is characterized by a complete failure to develop photoreceptor discs and outer segments, downregulation of rhodopsin and apoptotic loss of photoreceptor cells.</Disease>
<Disease>The electroretinograms (ERGs) of Prph2Rd2/Rd2 mice have greatly diminished a-wave and b-wave amplitudes, which decline to virtually undetectable concentrations by two months.</Disease>

<Disease>Subretinal injection of recombinant adeno-associated virus (AAV) encoding a Prph2 transgene results in stable generation of outer segment structures and formation of new stacks of discs containing both perpherin-2 and rhodopsin, which in many cases are morphologically similar to normal outer segments.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, the re-establishment of the structural integrity of the photoreceptor layer also results in electrophysiological correction.</Disease>
<Disease>These studies demonstrate for the first time that a complex ultrastructural cell defect can be corrected both morphologically and functionally by in vivo gene transfer..</Disease>
<Disease>Phenylalanine hydroxylase gene haplotypes in Polynesians: evolutionary origins and absence of alleles associated with severe phenylketonuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A total of 630 haplotypes for the phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) gene locus were established in five groups of Polynesians comprising Samoans, Tongans, Cook Islanders, Maori, and Niueans.</Disease>
<Disease>Considerable genetic continuity was demonstrated between these widely dispersed populations, since three common haplotypes (4, 1, and 7) constituted over 95% of alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>A control group of individuals from Southeast Asia shared the same major haplotypes, 4, 1, and 7, with Polynesians.</Disease>
<Disease>These data provide further support for the theories of genetic homogeneity and of Asian affinities of the Polynesian precursor populations.</Disease>

<Disease>The absence of severe phenylketonuria (PKU) in both Polynesians and Southeast Asians is consistent with the lack of PAH haplotypes 2 and 3, on which the severe PKU mutants have arisen among Caucasians..</Disease>

text: <Disease>cDNA microarrays detect activation of a myogenic transcription program by the PAX3-FKHR fusion oncogene.</Disease>
<Disease>Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma is an aggressive pediatric cancer of striated muscle characterized in 60% of cases by a t (2; 13) (q35; q14).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This results in the fusion of PAX3, a developmental transcription factor required for limb myogenesis, with FKHR, a member of the forkhead family of transcription factors.</Disease>
<Disease>The resultant PAX3-FKHR gene possesses transforming properties; however, the effects of this chimeric oncogene on gene expression are largely unknown.</Disease>

<Disease>To investigate the actions of these transcription factors, both Pax3 and PAX3-FKHR were introduced into NIH 3T3 cells, and the resultant gene expression changes were analyzed with a murine cDNA microarray containing 2, 225 elements.</Disease>

<Disease>We found that PAX3-FKHR but not PAX3 activated a myogenic transcription program including the induction of transcription factors MyoD, Myogenin, Six1, and Slug as well as a battery of genes involved in several aspects of muscle function.</Disease>
<Disease>Notable among this group were the growth factor gene Igf2 and its binding protein Igfbp5.</Disease>
<Disease>Relevance of this model was suggested by verification that three of these genes (IGFBP5, HSIX1, and Slug) were also expressed in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma cell lines.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study utilizes cDNA microarrays to elucidate the pattern of gene expression induced by an oncogenic transcription factor and demonstrates the profound myogenic properties of PAX3-FKHR in NIH 3T3 cells..</Disease>

<Disease>The DNA double-strand break repair gene hMRE11 is mutated in individuals with an ataxia-telangiectasia-like disorder.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The cellular features resulting from these hMRE11 mutations are similar to those seen in A-T as well as NBS and include hypersensitivity to ionizing radiation, radioresistant DNA synthesis, and abrogation of ATM-dependent events, such as the activation of Jun kinase following exposure to gamma irradiation.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The human MAGEL2 gene and its mouse homologue are paternally expressed and mapped to the Prader-Willi region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a complex neurogenetic disorder.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The phenotype is likely to be a contiguous gene syndrome involving genes which are paternally expressed only, located in the human 15q11-q13 region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Four mouse models of PWS have been reported but these do not definitively allow the delineation of the critical region and the associated genes involved in the aetiology of PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Moreover, targeted mutagenesis of mouse homologues of the human candidate PWS genes does not appear to result in any of the features of PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, the isolation of new genes in this region remains crucial for a better understanding of the molecular basis of PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In this manuscript, we report the characterization of MAGEL2 and its mouse homologue Magel2.</Disease>
<Disease>These are located in the human 15q11-q13 and mouse 7C regions, in close proximity to NDN/Ndn.</Disease>
<Disease>By northern blot analysis we did not detect any expression of MAGEL2/Magel2 but by RT-PCR analysis, specific expression was detected in fetal and adult brain and in placenta.</Disease>
<Disease>Both genes are intronless with tandem direct repeat sequences contained within a CpG island in the 5-untranscribed region.</Disease>
<Disease>The transcripts encode putative proteins that are homologous to the MAGE proteins and NDN.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, MAGEL2/Magel2 are expressed only from the paternal allele in brain, suggesting a potential role in the aetiology of PWS and its mouse model, respectively..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Multiple origins for phenylketonuria in Europe.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Phenylketonuria (PKU), a disorder of amino acid metabolism prevalent among Caucasians and other ethnic groups, is caused primarily by a deficiency of the hepatic enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PKU is a highly heterogeneous disorder, with more than 60 molecular lesions identified in the PAH gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The haplotype associations, relative frequencies, and distributions of five prevalent PAH mutations (R158Q, R261Q, IVS10nt546, R408W, and IVS12n1) were established in a comprehensive European sample population and subsequently were examined to determine the potential roles of several genetic mechanisms in explaining the present distribution of the major PKU alleles.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Each of these five mutations was strongly associated with only one of the more than 70 chromosomal haplotypes defined by eight RFLPs in or near the PAH gene.</Disease>

<Disease>These findings suggest that each of these mutations arose through a single founding event that occurred within time periods ranging from several hundred to several thousand years ago.</Disease>

<Disease>From the significant differences observed in the relative frequencies and distributions of these five alleles throughout Europe, four of these putative founding events could be localized to specific ethnic subgroups.</Disease>
<Disease>Together, these data suggest that there were multiple, geographically and ethnically distinct origins for PKU within the European population..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Autoinhibition and activation mechanisms of the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Rho-family GTPase, Cdc42, can regulate the actin cytoskeleton through activation of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) family members.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Activation relieves an autoinhibitory contact between the GTPase-binding domain and the carboxy-terminal region of WASP proteins.</Disease>
<Disease>Here we report the autoinhibited structure of the GTPase-binding domain of WASP, which can be induced by the C-terminal region or by organic co-solvents.</Disease>
<Disease>In the autoinhibited complex, intramolecular interactions with the GTPase-binding domain occlude residues of the C terminus that regulate the Arp2/3 actin-nucleating complex.</Disease>

<Disease>Binding of Cdc42 to the GTPase-binding domain causes a dramatic conformational change, resulting in disruption of the hydrophobic core and release of the C terminus, enabling its interaction with the actin regulatory machinery.</Disease>

<Disease>These data show that intrinsically unstructured peptides such as the GTPase-binding domain of WASP can be induced into distinct structural and functional states depending on context..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Large heterozygous deletion masquerading as homozygous missense mutation: a pitfall in diagnostic mutation analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>The clinical use of molecular analyses in recessive disorders relies on the exact characterization of both mutant alleles in the affected patient.</Disease>

text: <Disease>This can be problematic when only part of the gene is examined or when relevant DNA alterations are not recognized by standard methods.</Disease>
<Disease>We present a child in whom phenylketonuria was apparently caused by homozygosity for the mutation E390G in exon 11 of the phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) gene.</Disease>

text: <Disease>However, the clinical severity of the disease was not quite as mild as expected, the mutation was not identified in the father despite confirmed paternity, and the paternal allele showed a highly unusual pattern of polymorphic markers in the PAH gene.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Recombinations in individuals homozygous by descent localize the Friedreich ataxia locus in a cloned 450-kb interval.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The locus for Friedreich ataxia (FRDA), a severe neurodegenerative disease, is tightly linked to markers D9S5 and D9S15, and analysis of rare recombination events has suggested the order cen-FRDA-D9S5-D9S15-qter.</Disease>

Disease

text: <Disease>We report here the construction of a YAC contig extending 800 kb centromeric to D9S5 and the isolation of five new microsatellite markers from this region.</Disease>

<Disease>In order to map these markers with respect to the FRDA locus, all within a 1-cM confidence interval, we sought to increase the genetic information of available FRDA families by considering homozygosity by descent and association with founder haplotypes in isolated populations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This approach allowed us to identify one phase-known recombination and one probable historic recombination on haplotypes from Reunion Island patients, both of which place three of the five markers proximal to FRDA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This represents the first identification of close FRDA flanking markers on the centromeric side.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Location scores indicate that three contiguous subsegments within the [S144-THY1] segment, as well as three contiguous segments telomeric to THY1, are each unlikely to contain the AT locus, while the more centromeric [STMY-S144] segment is most likely to contain the AT locus.</Disease>

text: <Disease>This report describes the autosomal inheritance of a hemophilia A phenotype due to a mutation of vWF that results in defective factor VIII binding.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The proband was a female patient with low levels of factor VIII activity.</Disease>

<Disease>The mutant vWF was processed and secreted normally, and was functionally equivalent to wild-type vWF in its ability to bind to platelets.</Disease>

text: <Disease>X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD) is the most frequent peroxisomal disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It mainly involves the nervous system white matter, adrenal cortex and testes.</Disease>
<Disease>Several distinct clinical phenotypes are known.</Disease>

<Disease>The principal biochemical abnormality is the accumulation of saturated very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs  > C22  0, mainly C26  0), which is due to impaired capacity for beta-oxidation in peroxisomes.</Disease>
<Disease>Diagnosis is usually based on the VLCFA levels in plasma or cultured skin fibroblasts in both patients and carriers.</Disease>
<Disease>In 0. 1% of affected males, however, the plasma C26  0 level is borderline normal, and 15% of obligate female carriers have normal results.</Disease>
<Disease>Effective mutation detection in these families is therefore fundamental to unambiguously determine the genetic status of each individual at risk.</Disease>
<Disease>Of particular concern are female members of kindreds segregating X-ALD mutations, because normal VLCFA levels do not guarantee lack of carrier status.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We describe a fast method for detection of X-ALD mutations.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A total of eight putative disease-causing alterations were identified  four of these are frameshifts and two are nonsense mutations.</Disease>

<Disease>Screening for carriers of Tay-Sachs disease among Ashkenazi Jews. A comparison of DNA-based and enzyme-based tests.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND AND METHODS.</Disease>
<Disease>The prevention of Tay-Sachs disease (GM2 gangliosidosis, type 1) depends on the identification of carriers of the gene for this autosomal recessive disorder.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We compared the enzyme-based test widely used in screening for Tay-Sachs disease with a test based on analysis of DNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We developed methods to detect the three mutations in the HEXA gene that occur with high frequency among Ashkenazi Jews  two mutations cause infantile Tay-Sachs disease, and the third causes the adult-onset form of the disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>DNA segments containing these mutation sites were amplified with the polymerase chain reaction and analyzed for the presence of the mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS.</Disease>
<Disease>Among 62 Ashkenazi obligate carriers of Tay-Sachs disease, the three specific mutations accounted for all but one of the mutant alleles (98 percent).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In 216 Ashkenazi carriers identified by the enzyme test, DNA analysis showed that 177 (82 percent) had one of the identified mutations.</Disease>

<Disease>Of the 177, 79 percent had the exon 11 insertion mutation, 18 percent had the intron 12 splice-junction mutation, and 3 percent had the less severe exon 7 mutation associated with adult-onset disease.</Disease>

<Disease>The results of the enzyme tests in the 39 subjects (18 percent) who were defined as carriers but in whom DNA analysis did not identify a mutant allele were probably false positive (although there remains some possibility of unidentified mutations).</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, of 152 persons defined as noncarriers by the enzyme-based test, 1 was identified as a carrier by DNA analysis (i. e e., a false negative enzyme-test result).</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS.</Disease>
<Disease>The increased specificity and predictive value of the DNA-based test make it a useful adjunct to the diagnostic tests currently used to screen for carriers of Tay-Sachs disease.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Anticipation resulting in elimination of the myotonic dystrophy gene: a follow up study of one extended family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have re-examined an extended myotonic dystrophy (DM) family, previously described in 1955, in order to study the long term effects of anticipation in DM and in particular the implications for families affected by this disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This follow up study provides data on 35 gene carriers and 46 asymptomatic at risk family members in five generations.</Disease>

<Disease>Clinical anticipation, defined as the cascade of mild, adult, childhood, or congenital disease in subsequent generations, appeared to be a relentless process, occurring in all affected branches of the family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The cascade was found to proceed asynchronously in the different branches, mainly because of an unequal number of generations with mild disease.</Disease>
<Disease>The transition from the mild to the adult type was associated with transmission through a male parent.</Disease>
<Disease>Stable transmission of the asymptomatic/mild phenotype showed a female transmission bias.</Disease>
<Disease>We further examined the extent and causes of gene loss in this pedigree.</Disease>
<Disease>Gene loss in the patient group was complete, owing to infertility of the male patients with adult onset disease and the fact that mentally retarded patients did not procreate.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Out of the 46 at risk subjects in the two youngest generations, only one was found to have a full mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>This is the only subject who may transmit the gene to the sixth generation.</Disease>
<Disease>No protomutation carriers were found in the fourth and fifth generations.</Disease>
<Disease>Therefore it is highly probable that the DM gene will be eliminated from this pedigree within one generation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The high population frequency of DM can at present not be explained by the contribution of asymptomatic cases in the younger generations of known families, but is probably caused by the events in the ancestral generations..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Friedreich ataxia (FRDA), the most common of the inherited ataxias, is an autosomal recessive degenerative disorder, characterized clinically by onset before the age of 25 of progressive gait and limb ataxia, absence of deep tendon reflexes, extensor plantar responses, and loss of position and vibration sense in the lower limbs.</Disease>

<Disease>Clinicopathologic features of BRCA-linked and sporadic ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONTEXT  Most hereditary ovarian cancers are associated with germline mutations in BRCA1 or BRCA2.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Attempts to define the clinical significance of BRCA mutation status in ovarian cancer have produced conflicting results, especially regarding survival.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE  To determine whether hereditary ovarian cancers have distinct clinical and pathological features compared with sporadic (nonhereditary) ovarian cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>DESIGN AND SETTING  Retrospective cohort study of a consecutive series of 933 ovarian cancers diagnosed and treated at our institution, which is a comprehensive cancer center as designated by the National Cancer Institute, over a 12-year period (December 1986 to August 1998).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PATIENTS  The study was restricted to patients of Jewish origin because of the ease of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genotyping in this ethnic group.</Disease>
<Disease>From the 189 patients who identified themselves as Jewish, 88 hereditary cases were identified with the presence of a germline founder mutation in BRCA1 or BRCA2.</Disease>

<Disease>The remaining 101 cases from the same series not associated with a BRCA mutation and 2 additional groups (Gynecologic Oncology Group protocols 52 and 111) with ovarian cancer from clinical trials (for the survival analysis) were included for comparison.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES  Age at diagnosis, surgical stage, histologic cell type and grade, and surgical outcome; and response to chemotherapy and survival for advanced-stage (II and IV) cases.</Disease>

<Disease>RESULTS  Hereditary cancers were rarely diagnosed before age 40 years and were common after age 60 years, with mean age at diagnosis being significantly younger for BRCA1- vs BRCA2-linked patients (54 vs 62 years; P =. 04).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Histology, grade, stage, and success of cytoreductive surgery were similar for hereditary and sporadic cases.</Disease>

<Disease>The hereditary group had a longer disease-free interval following primary chemotherapy in comparison with the nonhereditary group, with a median time to recurrence of 14 months and 7 months, respectively (P <. 001).</Disease>
<Disease>Those with hereditary cancers had improved survival compared with the nonhereditary group (P =. 004).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>For stage III cancers, BRCA mutation status was an independent prognostic variable (P =. 03).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS  Although BRCA-associated hereditary ovarian cancers in this population have surgical and pathological characteristics similar to those of sporadic cancers, advanced-stage hereditary cancer patients survive longer than nonhereditary cancer patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Age penetrance is greater for BRCA1-linked than for BRCA2-linked cancers in this population.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive genetic disorder for which the biochemical defect is as yet unknown.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, two cloned segments of human X-chromosome DNA have been described which detect structural alterations within or near the genetic locus responsible for the disorder.</Disease>
<Disease>Both of these cloned segments were described as tightly linked to the locus and were capable of detecting deletions in the DNA of boys affected with DMD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In an attempt to determine more precisely the occurrence of these deletions within a large population of DMD patients and the accuracy of one of the segments, DXS164 (pERT87), in determining the inheritance of the DMD X chromosome, the subclones 1, 8 and 15 were made available to many investigators throughout the world.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here we describe the combined results of more than 20 research laboratories with respect to the occurrence of deletions at the DXS164 locus in DNA samples isolated from patients with DMD and Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD).</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>The results indicate that the DXS164 locus apparently recombines with DMD 5% of the time, but is probably located between independent sites of mutation which yield DMD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The breakpoints of some deletions are delineated within the DXS164 locus, and it is evident that the deletions at the DMD locus are frequent and extremely large..</Disease>

text: <Disease>A pair of female monozygotic (MZ) twins, heterozygous carriers for a deletion in the DMD gene and discordant for the clinical manifestations of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, were analyzed by molecular studies, in situ hybridization, and methylation pattern of X chromosomes to search for opposite X inactivation as an explanation of their clinical discordance.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Gaucher disease (GD) is an inherited deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase (EC 3. 1. 2. 45, gene symbol GBA).</Disease>

text: <Disease>In type I GD, the CNS is not involved (nonneuronopathic), whereas in type II GD (acute neuronopathic)</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CNS involvement is early and rapidly progressive, while in type III GD (subacute neuronopathic) CNS involvement occurs later and is slowly progressive.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The T6433C (L444P) substitution is prevalent in type GD II.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It may occur alone as a single base-pair mutation but often is found as part of a complex allele containing additional GBA nucleotide substitutions, G6468C (A456P) and G6482C (V460V), without (recNciI) or with (recTL) G5957C (D409H).</Disease>
<Disease>This complex allele is presumed to have formed by recombination (crossover, fusion) of the structural gene with the pseudogene, which contains the mutated sequences.</Disease>
<Disease>Two complex alleles have never been demonstrated to coexist in any individual.</Disease>
<Disease>We devised a selective PCR method for the specific amplification of the normal and/or fusion gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Using this procedure we demonstrated the fusion gene in homozygous form for the first time, in a Macedonian/Ashkenazi Jewish GD type II fetus.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Both parents were carriers of the recombination.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Neonates showing a severe clinical phenotype, analogous to the early neonatal lethal disease occurring in mice homozygous for a null allele produced by targeted disruption of GBA, have been described elsewhere, but the specific mutations in these cases have not yet been characterized.</Disease>

text: <Disease>In this study, we quantified the mRNA level of GCH1 in phytohemagglutinin (PHA) -stimulated mononuclear blood cells from one Japanese family that do not have a mutation in the coding region or splice junctions of the gene.</Disease>
<Disease>The results showed that the amounts of the GCH1 mRNA were decreased to about 40% of the normal level in both patients and carriers.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, we found that the GCH1 mRNA was transcribed from only one allele, indicating that the other allele was in an inactive state.</Disease>

<Disease>These results suggest that some novel mutations should exist on one of the alleles in some unknown region of the GCH1 gene, and may decrease the GCH1 mRNA causing the HPD/DRD symptoms..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Novel mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein gene and their effects on transcriptional, translational, and clinical phenotypes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections, and caused by mutations in the WAS protein (WASP) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>WASP contains several functional domains through which it interacts with proteins involved in intracellular signaling and regulation of the actin cytoskeleton.</Disease>
<Disease>In this report, 17 WASP gene mutations were identified, 12 of which are novel.</Disease>
<Disease>DNA of affected males and obligate carriers was PCR amplified and analyzed by SSCA, heteroduplex analysis, and direct sequencing.</Disease>
<Disease>The effects of the mutations at the mRNA and protein level were ascertained by RT-PCR and Western blot analyses.</Disease>
<Disease>All missense mutations were located in exons 1-4.</Disease>
<Disease>Most of the nonsense, frameshift and splice site mutations were found in exons 6-11.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations that alter splice sites led to the synthesis of several types of mRNAs, a fraction of which represented the normally spliced product.</Disease>
<Disease>The presence of normally spliced transcripts was correlated with a milder phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>When one such case was studied by Western blotting, reduced amounts of normal-size WASP were present.</Disease>
<Disease>In other cases as well, a correlation was found between the amount of normal or mutant WASP present and the phenotypes of the affected individuals.</Disease>
<Disease>No protein was detected in two individuals with severe WAS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Reduced levels of a normal-size WASP with a missense mutation were seen in two individuals with XLT.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It is concluded that mutation analysis at the DNA level is not sufficient for predicting clinical course.</Disease>
<Disease>Studies at the transcript and protein level are needed for a better assessment..</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report on a family in which first cousins are affected by AS and PWS as a result of a familial paracentric inversion of 15q11-q13.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The results of the studies on this family demonstrate the differences in the methylation patterns in the 2 conditions and the phenomenon of genomic imprinting, whereby genetic information is expressed differently dependent on the parent of origin..</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, we and others have isolated a candidate gene for X linked Norrie disease (ND) which was found to be deleted or disrupted in several patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>As a prerequisite for the identification of point mutations in the ND gene we have established the exon-intron structure of this gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In 17 unrelated patients and 15 controls, PCR products derived from the promoter region, exons 1 and 2 as well as the coding part of exon 3 were analysed with the single strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) technique.</Disease>
<Disease>In 12 patients altered PCR fragments were detected which were studied in detail by direct sequencing.</Disease>
<Disease>Eleven different mutations were found, and all but one are likely to give rise to significant structural changes in the predicted protein.</Disease>

<Disease>These findings, and the absence of functionally relevant base changes in healthy controls, emphasize the causal role of this candidate gene in Norrie disease and pave the way for reliable diagnosis and carrier detection..</Disease>

text: <Disease>A single amino acid substitution (G103D) in the type II collagen triple helix produces Kniest dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Kniest dysplasia is a moderately severe chondrodysplasia phenotype that results from mutations in the gene for type II collagen, COL2A1.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Characteristics of the disorder include a short trunk and extremities, mid-face hypoplasia, cleft palate, myopia, retinal detachment, and hearing loss.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, deletions of all or part of exon 12 have been identified in individuals with Kniest dysplasia, suggesting that mutations within this region of the protein may primarily result in the Kniest dysplasia phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We used SSCP to analyze an amplified genomic DNA fragment containing exon 12 from seven individuals with Kniest dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>An abnormality was identified in one patient.</Disease>
<Disease>DNA sequence analysis demonstrated that the patient was heterozygous for a G to A transition that implied substitution of glycine103 of the triple helical domain by aspartate.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutation was not observed in DNA from either of the clinically unaffected parents of the proband.</Disease>
<Disease>Protein microsequencing demonstrated expression of the abnormal allele in cartilage.</Disease>

<Disease>These data demonstrate that point mutations which result in single amino acid substitutions can produce Kniest dysplasia and further support the hypothesis that alteration of a domain, which includes the region encoded by exon 12, in the type II collagen protein leads to this disorder..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Linkage analysis of 5 novel van der Woude syndrome kindreds to 1q32-q41 markers further supports locus homogeneity of the disease trait.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>van der Woude syndrome (vWS, MIM 119300) is a rare autosomal dominant clefting condition with cardinal features of mucous cysts (lower-lip pits) and clefts to the lip and/or palate.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The vWS gene has been assigned to a locus in 1q32-q41 by linkage analysis and physical mapping.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have investigated 5 novel vWS families through probands attended for cleft lip and/or palate repair at the Department of Maxillofacial Surgery of Hopital Trousseau, Paris, in order to tentatively refine the genetic map of the vWS region in 1q32-q41 and possibly identify unlinked pedigrees.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Linkage analysis was carried out to 6 microsatellite markers (D1S249, D1S425, D1S491, D1S205, D1S414, D1S425), yielding a maximum cumulative LOD score of Z = 3. 27 at theta = 0. 00 for D1S245.</Disease>
<Disease>The innermost four markers were found to be tightly linked to one another, with no evidence for recombination.</Disease>
<Disease>Our results support linkage of vWS within a region of tightly linked markers and do not favour locus heterogeneity of the disease trait.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Hypopigmentation in the Prader-Willi syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cutaneous and ocular pigmentation were evaluated in 29 individuals with the Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Criteria for hypopigmentation included the presence of type I or II skin, the lightest skin type in the family by history, and iris translucency on globe transillumination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>On the basis of these criteria, 48% of the PWS individuals were hypopigmented.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The presence of hypopigmentation correlated with a small interstitial deletion on the proximal long arm of chromosome 15; however, this deletion was also found in individuals who did not meet the full criteria for hypopigmentation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hairbulb tyrosinase activity and glutathione content, as well as urine cysteinyldopa excretion, were low in PWS individuals with and without hypopigmentation and did not separate these two groups.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We conclude that hypopigmentation is found in a significant proportion of individuals with PWS and that the hypopigmentation may be associated with a deletion of the long arm of chromosome 15.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The mechanism for the hypopigmentation is unknown..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Deficiency of the fifth component of complement in human subjects. Clinical, genetic and immunologic studies in a large kindred.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The discovery of a large kindred with a heritable deficiency of the fifth component of complement (C5) has permitted the accumulation of new clinical, genetic and immunologic data concerning the role of C5 in human subjects.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The proband, who has had nine episodes of disseminated gonococcal infection, has a hemolytic C5 level of approximately 0.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>5 per cent of normal.</Disease>
<Disease>No C5 protein was detectable, but low levels of functional C5 activity could be found using a sensitive bactericidal assay.</Disease>
<Disease>The probands twin as well as another sister also had extremely low levels of hemolytic C5 (approximately 0.</Disease>
<Disease>5 per cent normal), but both these subjects have been healthy.</Disease>
<Disease>Hemolytic complement and bacteriolytic activity could be restored by the addition of purified C5.</Disease>

<Disease>No chemotactic activity for polymorphonuclear leukocytes could be generated in the C5-deficient serums upon activation of either the classic or alternative pathways, again demonstrating the importance of C5 in human subjects for the production of chemotactic factors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The chemotactic responsiveness of the patients polymorphonuclear leukocytes and monocytes to preformed chemotactic factors was not depressed.</Disease>
<Disease>Twenty-two of 32 other family members from three generations had depressed whole hemolytic complement levels.</Disease>
<Disease>In 19 of 30 family members, levels of hemolytic C5 ranged from 13 to 64 per cent of normal.</Disease>
<Disease>No linkage for C5 deficiency and the A or B loci of the major histocompatibility complex could be found.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These data suggest an autosomal codominant mode of inheritance of C5 deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Deficiency of C5 is compatible with good health, but it can be associated with repeated disseminated gonococcal infection</Disease>

text: <Disease>A new glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase variant, G6PD Orissa (44 Ala-->Gly), is the major polymorphic variant in tribal populations in India.</Disease>
<Disease>Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is usually found at high frequencies in areas of the world where malaria has been endemic.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The frequency and genetic basis of G6PD deficiency have been studied in Africa, around the Mediterranean, and in the Far East, but little such information is available about the situation in India.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To determine the extent of heterogeneity of G6PD, we have studied several different Indian populations by screening for G6PD deficiency, followed by molecular analysis of deficient alleles.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The frequency of G6PD deficiency varies between 3% and 15% in different tribal and urban groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Remarkably, a previously unreported deficient variant, G6PD Orissa (44 Ala-- > Gly), is responsible for most of the G6PD deficiency in tribal Indian populations but is not found in urban populations, where most of the G6PD deficiency is due to the G6PD Mediterranean (188 Ser-- > Phe) variant.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The KmNADP of G6PD Orissa is fivefold higher than that of the normal enzyme.</Disease>
<Disease>This may be due to the fact that the alanine residue that is replaced by glycine is part of a putative coenzyme-binding site..</Disease>
<Disease>Germline mutations in the Wilms' tumor suppressor gene are associated with abnormal urogenital development in Denys-Drash syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Denys-Drash syndrome is a rare human condition in which severe urogenital aberrations result in renal failure, pseudohermaphroditism, and Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To investigate its possible role, we have analyzed the coding exons of the Wilms tumor suppressor gene (WT1) for germline mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In ten independent cases of Denys-Drash syndrome, point mutations in the zinc finger domains of one WT1 gene copy were found.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nine of these mutations are found within exon 9 (zinc finger III); the remaining mutation is in exon 8 (zinc finger II).</Disease>
<Disease>These mutations directly affect DNA sequence recognition.</Disease>
<Disease>In two families analyzed, the mutations were shown to arise de novo.</Disease>
<Disease>Wilms tumors from three individuals and one juvenile granulosa cell tumor demonstrate reduction to homozygosity for the mutated WT1 allele.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our results provide evidence of a direct role for WT1 in Denys-Drash syndrome and thus urogenital system development..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Molecular basis of feline beta-glucuronidase deficiency: an animal model of mucopolysaccharidosis VII.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A family of domestic cats was found that exhibited clinical and biochemical abnormalities consistent with mucopolysaccharidosis VII, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by beta-glucuronidase deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>beta-Glucuronidase activity was undetectable in affected cat fibroblasts and restored by retroviral gene transfer of rat beta-glucuronidase cDNA.</Disease>
<Disease>beta-Glucuronidase mRNA was normal in affected cat testis by Northern blot analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>Normal feline beta-glucuronidase cDNA was cloned and characterized, and amplified from affected cat fibroblasts by reverse transcription coupled polymerase chain reaction.</Disease>
<Disease>There was a G-to-A transition in the affected cat cDNA that predicted an E351K substitution, destroyed a BssSI site, and eliminated GUSB enzymatic activity in expression studies.</Disease>

<Disease>Multiple species comparison and the crystal structure of human beta-glucuronidase indicated that E351 is a highly conserved residue most likely essential in maintenance of the enzymes conformation.</Disease>

<Disease>BssSI digestion of polymerase chain reaction products amplified from genomic DNA indicated that affected cats were homozygous and cats with half-normal beta-glucuronidase activity were heterozygous for the missense mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>Carriers identified in this manner produced affected kittens in prospective breedings, and a feline MPS VII breeding colony has been established..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Loss-of-function mutations in the cathepsin C gene result in periodontal disease and palmoplantar keratosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Papillon-Lefevre syndrome, or keratosis palmoplantaris with periodontopathia (PLS, MIM 245000), is an autosomal recessive disorder that is mainly ascertained by dentists because of the severe periodontitis that afflicts patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Both the deciduous and permanent dentitions are affected, resulting in premature tooth loss.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Palmoplantar keratosis, varying from mild psoriasiform scaly skin to overt hyperkeratosis, typically develops within the first three years of life.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Keratosis also affects other sites such as elbows and knees.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Most PLS patients display both periodontitis and hyperkeratosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Some patients have only palmoplantar keratosis or periodontitis, and in rare individuals the periodontitis is mild and of late onset.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The PLS locus has been mapped to chromosome 11q14-q21 (refs 7, 8, 9).</Disease>
<Disease>Using homozygosity mapping in eight small consanguineous families, we have narrowed the candidate region to a 1. 2-cM interval between D11S4082 and D11S931.</Disease>
<Disease>The gene (CTSC) encoding the lysosomal protease cathepsin C (or dipeptidyl aminopeptidase I) lies within this interval.</Disease>
<Disease>We defined the genomic structure of CTSC and found mutations in all eight families.</Disease>
<Disease>In two of these families we used a functional assay to demonstrate an almost total loss of cathepsin C activity in PLS patients and reduced activity in obligate carriers.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Brca1 deficiency results in early embryonic lethality characterized by neuroepithelial abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility gene, BRCA1, has been cloned and shown to encode a zinc-finger protein of unknown function.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in BRCA1 account for at least 80% of families with both breast and ovarian cancer, as well as some non-familial sporadic ovarian cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The loss of wild-type BRCA1 in tumours of individuals carrying one nonfunctional BRCA1 allele suggests that BRCA1 encodes a tumour suppressor that may inhibit the proliferation of mammary epithelial cells.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To examine the role of BRCA1 in normal tissue growth and differentiation, and to generate a potential model for the cancer susceptibility associated with loss of BRCA1 function, we have created a mouse line carrying a mutation in one Brca1 allele.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Analysis of mice homozygous for the mutant allele indicate that Brca1 is critical for normal development, as these mice died in utero between 10 and 13 days of gestation (E10-E13).</Disease>
<Disease>Abnormalities in Brca1-deficient embryos were most evident in the neural tube, with 40% of the embryos presenting with varying degrees of spina bifida and anencephaly.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, the neuroepithelium in Brca1-deficient embryos appeared disorganized, with signs of both rapid proliferation and excessive cell death..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Because of various features which include the presence of large and normal sized platelets (rather than small platelets) and freedom from significant immune deficiencies, it is likely that the X linked recessive thrombocytopenia in this family is an isolated entity quite distinct from the classical WAS phenotype.</Disease>

text: <Disease>A missense mutation in the cholesteryl ester transfer protein gene with possible dominant effects on plasma high density lipoproteins.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP; 476 amino acids) transfers cholesteryl ester from HDL to other lipoproteins.</Disease>
<Disease>Subjects with homozygous CETP deficiency caused by a gene splicing defect have markedly elevated HDL; however, heterozygotes have only mild increases in HDL.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We describe two probands with a CETP missense mutation (442 D  G).</Disease>

<Disease>Although heterozygous, they have threefold increases in HDL concentration and markedly decreased plasma CETP mass and activity, suggesting that the mutation has dominant effects on CETP and HDL in vivo.</Disease>
<Disease>Cellular expression of mutant cDNA results in secretion of only 30% of wild type CETP activity.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, coexpression of wild type and mutant cDNAs leads to inhibition of wild type secretion and activity.</Disease>

<Disease>The dominant effects of the CETP missense mutation during cellular expression probably explains why the probands have markedly increased HDL in the heterozygous state, and suggests that the active molecular species of CETP may be multimeric..</Disease>
