text: <Disease>Homozygous and heterozygous deletions of the von Willebrand factor gene in patients and carriers of severe von Willebrand disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Severe von Willebrand disease is characterized by undetectable or trace quantities of von Willebrand factor in plasma and tissue stores.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have studied the genomic DNA of 10 affected individuals from six families with this disorder using probes from the 5 and 3 ends of the vWF cDNA and with a probe extending from the 5 end into the central region.</Disease>

<Disease>Southern blots of restriction endonuclease digests and gene dosage analysis measurements carried out with quantitative slot blots of undigested genomic DNA separated these patients into three groups.</Disease>
<Disease>The first group consisted of a family with complete homozygous deletions of the vWF gene in the four probands.</Disease>
<Disease>Gene dosage analysis was consistent with heterozygous deletions in both of the asymptomatic parents and four asymptomatic siblings of this kindred (P less than 0. 01).</Disease>

<Disease>The second group was comprised of a family in which there was a complete heterozygous deletion of the vWF gene in the proband and one asymptomatic parent, suggesting that a different type of genetic abnormality was inherited from the other parent.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, the patient appeared to be doubly heterozygous for interacting genetic abnormalities affecting vWF expression.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the third group, no gene deletions could be detected.</Disease>
<Disease>Alloantibodies developed only in the kindred with homozygous deletions.</Disease>
<Disease>These techniques should prove useful in identifying carriers of severe von Willebrand disease and also in defining patients predictably at risk of developing alloantibodies to vWF.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Spectrum of germline mutations in the RB1 gene: a study of 232 patients with hereditary and non hereditary retinoblastoma.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Germline mutations in the RB1 gene confer hereditary predisposition to retinoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have performed a mutation survey of the RB1 gene in 232 patients with hereditary or non hereditary retinoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We systematically explored all 27 exons and flanking sequences as well as the promotor.</Disease>
<Disease>All types of point mutations are represented and are found unequally distributed along the RB1 gene sequence.</Disease>
<Disease>In the population we studied, exons 3, 8, 18 and 19 are preferentially altered.</Disease>
<Disease>The range of frequency of detection of germline mutations is about 20%, indicating that other mechanisms of inactivation of RB1 should be involved.</Disease>
<Disease>The spectrum of mutations presented here should help to improve the clinical management of retinoblastoma and to understand the molecular mechanisms leading to tumorigenesis..</Disease>

text: <Disease>We describe here a Pelizaeus-Merzbacher pedigree of the classical type, with X-linked inheritance, a typical clinical progression, and a pathologic loss of myelinating cells and myelin in the central nervous system.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To discriminate variants of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease, a set of oligonucleotide primers was constructed to polymerase-chain-reaction (PCR) amplify and sequence the gene encoding proteolipid protein (PLP), a structural protein that comprises half of the protein of the myelin sheath.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The PLP gene in one of two affected males and the carrier mother of this family exhibited a single base difference in the more than 2 kb of the PLP gene sequenced, a C----T transition that would create a serine substitution for proline at the carboxy end of the protein.</Disease>

<Disease>Our results delineate the clinical features of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease, define the possible molecular pathology of this dysmyelinating disorder, and address the molecular classification of inborn errors of myelin metabolism.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Patients with the classical form (type I) and the more severely affected, connatal variant of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (type II) would be predicted to display mutation at the PLP locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The other variants (types III-VI), which have sometimes been categorized as Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease, may represent mutations in genes encoding other structural myelin proteins or proteins critical to myelination..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Deficiency of the murine fifth complement component (C5). A 2-base pair gene deletion in a 5'-exon.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To ascertain the molecular mechanism that causes murine C5 deficiency, genomic and cDNA libraries were constructed from mouse liver DNA and mRNA employing the congenic strains B10. D2/nSnJ and B10. D2/oSnJ that are sufficient and deficient for C5, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Genomic fragments were isolated which correspond to PvuII and HindIII restriction fragment length polymorphisms associated with C5 deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sequence analyses demonstrated that each of these polymorphisms resulted from single base pair substitutions and that neither substitution would probably cause or contribute to the C5 deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sequence analyses of C5 sufficient and deficient cDNAs revealed a 2 base-pair deletion in the deficient cDNAs.</Disease>
<Disease>The " TA " deletion was located near the 5 end of the cDNA.</Disease>
<Disease>This deletion shifts the reading frame of the C5 mRNA so that the termination codon UGA is present 4 base pairs downstream from the deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>Genomic DNA was amplified and sequenced corresponding to the area surrounding the 2-base pair deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>Six C5-deficient strains, A/HeJ, AKR/J, DBA/2J, NZB/B1NJ, SWR/J, and B10. D2/oSnJ, and four C5-sufficient strains, Balb/CJ, C57Bl/6J, DBA/1J, and B10. D2/nSnJ, were analyzed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The sequencing data revealed that the 2 base pairs were deleted from the C5 gene of each deficient mouse tested but not from the C5 gene of any sufficient mouse.</Disease>

<Disease>These data demonstrate that  1) there is an identical 2-base pair deletion in an exon of the C5 gene in several different C5-deficient mouse strains; 2) the mRNA transcribed from the C5D gene retains this deletion; and 3) this mutation should result in C5 protein deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL) is an autosomal dominant disorder with inherited susceptibility to various forms of cancer, including hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system, phaeochromocytomas, pancreatic malignancies, and renal cell carcinomas.</Disease>

Disease
Disease

label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>We report here that the VHL gene is linked to the locus encoding the human homologoue of the RAF1 oncogene, which maps to chromosome 3p25 (ref. 4).</Disease>

text: <Disease>and z = 7. 07.</Disease>
<Disease>Evidence for placing OCRL at Xq25 also comes from a female with Lowe syndrome and an X; 3 translocation.</Disease>

<Disease>The markers DXS10 and DXS42 therefore show tight linkage with OCRL in six families and flank the Xq25 breakpoint in a female patient with an X; 3 translocation.</Disease>

<Disease>Abnormal development of Purkinje cells and lymphocytes in Atm mutant mice.</Disease>

<Disease>Motor incoordination, immune deficiencies, and an increased risk of cancer are the characteristic features of the hereditary disease ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), which is caused by mutations in the ATM gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Through gene targeting, we have generated a line of Atm mutant mice, Atm (y/y) mice.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast to other Atm mutant mice, Atm (y/y) mice show a lower incidence of thymic lymphoma and survive beyond a few months of age.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Atm (y/y) mice exhibit deficits in motor learning indicative of cerebellar dysfunction.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Even though we found no gross cerebellar degeneration in older Atm (y/y) animals, ectopic and abnormally differentiated Purkinje cells were apparent in mutant mice of all ages.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings establish that some neuropathological abnormalities seen in A-T patients also are present in Atm mutant mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, we report a previously unrecognized effect of Atm deficiency on development or maintenance of CD4 (+) 8 (+) thymocytes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We discuss these findings in the context of the hypothesis that abnormal development of Purkinje cells and lymphocytes contributes to the pathogenesis of A-T..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Met and 126 Asn-- ></Disease>
<Disease>Asp.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We have approached this question by producing G6PD B, A, A-, and G6PD 68 Val-- ></Disease>
<Disease>Met in a bacterial expression system and analysing their biochemical properties.</Disease>

<Disease>With each single mutation we found a slight decrease in both the specific activity and the yield of enzyme when compared to G6PD B. When both mutations were introduced together, there was a roughly additive effect on specific activity, but a much more drastic effect on enzyme yield (4% of normal).</Disease>
<Disease>This synergistic effect was also demonstrated on thermal stability, especially at low NADP concentrations.</Disease>

<Disease>Asp.</Disease>

text: <Disease>New mutations, polymorphisms, and rare variants in the ATM gene detected by a novel SSCP strategy.</Disease>
<Disease>The gene for ataxia-telangiectasia, ATM, spans about 150 kb of genomic DNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>ATM mutations are found along the entire gene, with no evidence of a mutational hot spot.</Disease>

<Disease>Using DNA as the starting material, we screened the ATM gene in 92 A-T patients, using an optimized single-strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) technique that detected all previously known mutations in the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) segments being analyzed.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To expedite screening, we sequentially loaded the SSCP gels with three different sets of PCR products that were pretested to avoid overlapping patterns.</Disease>
<Disease>Many of the DNA changes we detected were intragenic polymorphisms.</Disease>

<Disease>Of an expected 177 unknown mutations, we detected approximately 70%, mostly protein truncating mutations (that would have been detectable by protein truncation testing if RNA starting material had been available).</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations have now been defined for every exon of the ATM gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Herein, we present 35 new mutations and 34 new intragenic polymorphisms or rare variants within the ATM gene.</Disease>
<Disease>This is the most comprehensive compilation of ATM polymorphisms assembled to date.</Disease>
<Disease>Defining polymorphic sites as well as mutations in the ATM gene will be of great importance in designing automated methods for detecting mutations..</Disease>
<Disease>Chromosome breakage in the Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes involves recombination between large, transcribed repeats at proximal and distal breakpoints.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) and Angelman syndrome (AS) are distinct neurobehavioral disorders that most often arise from a 4-Mb deletion of chromosome 15q11-q13 during paternal or maternal gametogenesis, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>At a de novo frequency of approximately.</Disease>
<Disease>67-1/10, 000 births, these deletions represent a common structural chromosome change in the human genome.</Disease>
<Disease>To elucidate the mechanism underlying these events, we characterized the regions that contain two proximal breakpoint clusters and a distal cluster.</Disease>
<Disease>Novel DNA sequences potentially associated with the breakpoints were positionally cloned from YACs within or near these regions.</Disease>

<Disease>Analyses of rodent-human somatic-cell hybrids, YAC contigs, and FISH of normal or rearranged chromosomes 15 identified duplicated sequences (the END repeats) at or near the breakpoints.</Disease>
<Disease>The END-repeat units are derived from large genomic duplications of a novel gene (HERC2), many copies of which are transcriptionally active in germline tissues.</Disease>
<Disease>One of five PWS/AS patients analyzed to date has an identifiable, rearranged HERC2 transcript derived from the deletion event.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We postulate that the END repeats flanking 15q11-q13 mediate homologous recombination resulting in deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, we propose that active transcription of these repeats in male and female germ cells may facilitate the homologous recombination process.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy: evidence for a possible dominant-negative RNA mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The trinucleotide expansion mutation causing myotonic dystrophy is in the 3 untranslated region of a protein kinase gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The molecular mechanisms by which the expanded repeat causes the clinically variable and multisystemic disease, myotonic dystrophy, are not understood.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It has been particularly difficult to rationalize the dominant inheritance with the fact that the expansion mutation lies outside of the protein-encoding gene elements, and should not be translated into protein.</Disease>

<Disease>Here we use muscle biopsies from classical adult-onset myotonic dystrophy patients to study the accumulation of transcripts from both the normal and expanded DM kinase genes in patient muscle, and compare the results to normal and myopathic controls.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We found relatively small decreases of DM kinase RNA in the total RNA pool from muscle; however, these reductions were not disease specific.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Analysis of poly (A) +</Disease>
<Disease>RNA showed dramatic decreases of both the mutant and normal DM kinase RNAs, and these changes were disease-specific.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our findings are consistent with a novel molecular pathogenetic mechanism for myotonic dystrophy  both the normal and expanded DM kinase genes are transcribed in patient muscle, but the abnormal expansion-containing RNA has a dominant effect on RNA metabolism by preventing the accumulation of poly (A) + RNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The ability of the expansion mutation to alter accumulation of poly (A) +</Disease>
<Disease>RNA in trans suggests that myotonic dystrophy may be the first example of a dominant-negative mutation manifested at the RNA level..</Disease>

<Disease>All patients had the severe childhood form of VLCAD deficiency with early onset and high mortality.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Immunoblot analysis revealed that VLCAD protein was undetectable in patients 2 and 3, whereas normal-size VLCAD protein and an aberrant form of VLCAD (4kDa smaller) were detected in patient 1.</Disease>

<Disease>As expected, null mutations were found in patients 2 and 3  patient 2 is homozygous for a frameshift mutation, del 4 bp at 798-801, and patient 3 is homozygous for a nonsense mutation 65C ></Disease>
<Disease>A (S22X).</Disease>

<Disease>Patient 1 was homozygous for a complex mutant allele containing two alterations, including a 194C > T transition (P65L) and 739A > C transversion (K247Q); in the case of P65L, the amino acid change does not reduce enzyme activity.</Disease>
<Disease>However, the nucleotide change resulted in exon 3 skipping, whereas the latter K247Q mutation had a drastic effect on enzyme activity.</Disease>
<Disease>We verified these events by in vivo splicing experiments and transient expression analysis of mutant cDNAs.</Disease>
<Disease>The P65L mutation locates 11 bases upstream of a splice donor site of intron 3.</Disease>
<Disease>This is an example of an exonic mutation which affects exon-splicing..</Disease>
<Disease>Amino-terminal fragments of mutant huntingtin show selective accumulation in striatal neurons and synaptic toxicity.</Disease>
<Disease>Huntington disease (HD) is caused by expansion of a glutamine repeat in the amino-terminal region of huntingtin.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Despite its widespread expression, mutant huntingtin induces selective neuronal loss in striatal neurons.</Disease>

<Disease>Here we report that, in mutant mice expressing HD repeats, the production and aggregation of N-terminal huntingtin fragments preferentially occur in HD-affected neurons and their processes and axonal terminals.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>N-terminal fragments of mutant huntingtin form aggregates and induce neuritic degeneration in cultured striatal neurons.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>N-terminal mutant huntingtin also binds to synaptic vesicles and inhibits their glutamate uptake in vitro.</Disease>

<Disease>The specific processing and accumulation of toxic fragments of N-terminal huntingtin in HD-affected striatal neurons, especially in their neuronal processes and axonal terminals, may contribute to the selective neuropathology of HD..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Phenotypic variation including retinitis pigmentosa, pattern dystrophy, and fundus flavimaculatus in a single family with a deletion of codon 153 or 154 of the peripherin/RDS gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES  Mutations of the peripherin/RDS gene have been reported in autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa, pattern macular dystrophy, and retinitis punctata albescens.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report herein the occurrence of three separate phenotypes within a single family with a novel 3-base pair deletion of codon 153 or 154 of the peripherin/RDS gene.</Disease>
<Disease>DESIGN  Case reports with clinical features, fluorescein angiography, kinetic perimetry, electrophysiological studies, and molecular genetics.</Disease>
<Disease>SETTING  University medical centers.</Disease>

<Disease>PATIENTS  A 75-year-old woman, her two daughters (aged 44 and 50 years), and her 49-year-old son were screened for peripherin/RDS mutations because of the presence of multiple phenotypes within the same family.</Disease>

<Disease>RESULTS  The mother presented at age 63 years with a profoundly abnormal electroretinogram (ERG) and adult-onset retinitis pigmentosa that progressed dramatically over 12 years, with marked loss of peripheral visual field.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One daughter developed pattern macular dystrophy at age 31 years.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>At age 44 years, her ERG was moderately abnormal but her clinical disease was limited to the macula.</Disease>
<Disease>Another daughter presented at age 42 years with macular degeneration and over 10 years developed the clinical picture of fundus flavimaculatus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Her peripheral visual field was preserved but her ERG was moderately abnormal.</Disease>
<Disease>The son had onset of macular degeneration at age 44 years.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Pericentral scotomas were present and the ERG was markedly abnormal.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fluorescein angiography revealed punctate pigment epithelial transmission defects.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS  A 3-base pair deletion of codon 153 or 154 of the peripherin/RDS gene can produce clinically disparate phenotypes even within the same family..</Disease>
<Disease>Missense mutation in the alternative splice region of the PAX6 gene in eye anomalies.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The PAX6 gene is involved in ocular morphogenesis, and PAX6 mutations have been detected in various types of ocular anomalies, including aniridia, Peters anomaly, corneal dystrophy, congenital cataract, and foveal hypoplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The gene encodes a transcriptional regulator that recognizes target genes through its paired-type DNA-binding domain.</Disease>

<Disease>The paired domain is composed of two distinct DNA-binding subdomains, the N-terminal subdomain (NTS) and the C-terminal subdomain (CTS), which bind respective consensus DNA sequences.</Disease>
<Disease>The human PAX6 gene produces two alternative splice isoforms that have the distinct structure of the paired domain.</Disease>
<Disease>The insertion, into the NTS, of 14 additional amino acids encoded by exon 5a abolishes the DNA-binding activity of the NTS and unmasks the DNA-binding ability of the CTS.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, exon 5a appears to function as a molecular switch that specifies target genes.</Disease>

<Disease>We ascertained a novel missense mutation in four pedigrees with Peters anomaly, congenital cataract, Axenfeldt anomaly, and/or foveal hypoplasia, which, to our knowledge, is the first mutation identified in the splice-variant region.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A T-- ></Disease>
<Disease>A transition at the 20th nucleotide position of exon 5a results in a Val-- ></Disease>
<Disease>Asp (GTC-- > GAC) substitution at the 7th codon of the alternative splice region.</Disease>
<Disease>Functional analyses demonstrated that the V54D mutation slightly increased NTS binding and decreased CTS transactivation activity to almost half..</Disease>
<Disease>A detailed multipoint map of human chromosome 4 provides evidence for linkage heterogeneity and position-specific recombination rates.</Disease>
<Disease>Utilizing the CEPH reference panel and genotypic data for 53 markers, we have constructed a 20-locus multipoint genetic map of human chromosome 4.</Disease>
<Disease>New RFLPs are reported for four loci.</Disease>
<Disease>The map integrates a high-resolution genetic map of 4p16 into a continuous map extending to 4q31 and an unlinked cluster of three loci at 4q35.</Disease>
<Disease>The 20 linked markers form a continuous linkage group of 152 cM in males and 202 cM in females.</Disease>
<Disease>Likely genetic locations are provided for 25 polymorphic anonymous sequences and 28 gene-specific RFLPs.</Disease>
<Disease>The map was constructed employing the LINKAGE and CRIMAP computational methodologies to build the multipoint map via a stepwise algorithm.</Disease>

<Disease>A detailed 10-point map of the 4p16 region constructed from the CEPH panel provides evidence for heterogeneity in the linkage maps constructed from families segregating for Huntington disease (HD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It additionally provides evidence for position-specific recombination frequencies in the telomeric region of 4p..</Disease>
<Disease>The murine homolog of the human breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility gene Brca1 maps to mouse chromosome 11D.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The recently cloned human breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility gene, BRCA1, is located on human chromosome 17q21.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have isolated murine genomic clones containing Brca1 as a first step in generating a mouse model for the loss of BRCA1 function.</Disease>
<Disease>A mouse genomic library was screened using probes corresponding to exon 11 of the human BRCA1 gene.</Disease>
<Disease>Two overlapping mouse clones were identified that hybridized to human BRCA1 exons 9-12.</Disease>

<Disease>Sequence analysis of 1. 4 kb of the region of these clones corresponding to part of human exon 11 revealed 72% nucleic acid identity but only 50% amino acid identity with the human gene.</Disease>
<Disease>The longest of the mouse Brca1 genomic clones maps to chromosome 11D, as determined by two-color fluorescence in situ hybridization.</Disease>
<Disease>The synteny to human chromosome 17 was confirmed by cohybridization with the mouse probe for the NF1-gene.</Disease>
<Disease>This comparative study confirms that the relative location of the BRCA1 gene has been conserved between mice and humans.</Disease>
<Disease>High residual arylsulfatase A (ARSA) activity in a patient with late-infantile metachromatic leukodystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We identified a patient suffering from late-infantile metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) who has a residual arylsulfatase A (ARSA) activity of about 10%.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Fibroblasts of the patient show significant sulfatide degradation activity exceeding that of adult MLD patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Analysis of the ARSA gene in this patient revealed heterozygosity for two new mutant alleles  in one allele, deletion of C 447 in exon 2 leads to a frameshift and to a premature stop codon at amino acid position 105; in the second allele, a G-- ></Disease>
<Disease>A transition in exon 5 causes a Gly309-- > Ser substitution.</Disease>
<Disease>Transient expression of the mutant Ser309-ARSA resulted in only 13% enzyme activity of that observed in cells expressing normal ARSA.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutant ARSA is correctly targeted to the lysosomes but is unstable.</Disease>
<Disease>These findings are in contrast to previous results showing that the late-infantile type of MLD is always associated with the complete absence of ARSA activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The expression of the mutant ARSA protein may be influenced by particular features of oligodendrocytes, such that the level of mutant enzyme is lower in these cells than in others..</Disease>
<Disease>De novo deletions of SNRPN exon 1 in early human and mouse embryos result in a paternal to maternal imprint switch.</Disease>

<Disease>Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a neurogenetic disease characterized by infantile hypotonia, gonadal hypoplasia, obsessive behaviour and neonatal feeding difficulties followed by hyperphagia, leading to profound obesity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>PWS is due to a lack of paternal genetic information at 15q11-q13 (ref. 2).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Five imprinted, paternally expressed genes map to the PWS region, MKRN3 (ref. 3), NDN (ref. 4), NDNL1 (ref. 5), SNRPN (refs 6-8) and IPW (ref. 9), as well as two poorly characterized framents designated PAR-1 and PAR-5 (ref. 10).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Imprinting of this region involves a bipartite imprinting centre (IC), which overlaps SNRPN (refs 10, 11).</Disease>
<Disease>Deletion of the SNRPN promoter/exon 1 region (the PWS IC element) appears to impair the establishment of the paternal imprint in the male germ line and leads to PWS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here we report a PWS family in which the father is mosaic for an IC deletion on his paternal chromosome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The deletion chromosome has acquired a maternal methylation imprint in his somatic cells.</Disease>
<Disease>We have made identical findings in chimaeric mice generated from two independent embryonic stem (ES) cell lines harbouring a similar deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>Our studies demonstrate that the PWS IC element is not only required for the establishment of the paternal imprint, but also for its postzygotic maintenance..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular characterization of two galactosemia mutations: correlation of mutations with highly conserved domains in galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder of human galactose metabolism caused by deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The molecular basis of this disorder is at present not well understood.</Disease>
<Disease>We report here two missense mutations which result in low or undetectable enzymatic activity.</Disease>
<Disease>First, we identified at nucleotide 591 a transition which substitutes glutamine 188 by arginine.</Disease>

<Disease>The mutated glutamine is not only highly conserved in evolution (conserved also in Escherichia coli and Saccharomyces cerevisiae), but is also two amino acid residues downstream from the active site histidine-proline-histidine triad and results in about 10% of normal enzymatic activity.</Disease>
<Disease>The arginine 188 mutation is the most common galactosemia mutation characterized to date.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>It accounts for one-fourth of the galactosemia alleles studied.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Second, we report the substitution of arginine 333 by tryptophan, caused by a transition at nucleotide 1025.</Disease>

<Disease>The area surrounding this missense mutation is the most highly conserved domain in the homologous enzymes from E. coli, yeast, and humans, and this mutation results in undetectable enzymatic activity, suggesting that this is a severe mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>This second mutation appears to be rare, since it was found only in the patient we sequenced.</Disease>

<Disease>Our data provide further evidence for the heterogeneity of galactosemia at the molecular level, heterogeneity which might be related to the variable clinical outcome observed in this disorder..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neurophysiologic follow-up of long-term dietary treatment in adult-onset adrenoleukodystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE  To monitor the effects of dietary treatment in adult-onset adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) by means of somatosensory evoked potentials (SEPs) and motor evoked potentials (MEPs).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND  SEPs and MEPs have proved useful in revealing signs of progressively severe, central dying-back axonopathy in early stages of adult-onset ALD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  Eight patients with adult-onset ALD underwent clinical examination, brain and spine MRI, and SEP and MEP studies before and after 3 years of Lorenzos oil dietary therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS  Before treatment, brain MRI was normal in five patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Three of these patients had pure spinal SEP abnormalities and in the remaining two patients SEPs showed signs of involvement of both the spinal and cerebral somatosensory tracts.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>After treatment, the three patients with pure spinal abnormalities showed clinical and neurophysiologic worsening, whereas the two patients with a more advanced stage of disease (exhibited by SEPs) showed substantially unchanged clinical and neurophysiologic features.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The patients with abnormal brain MRI at the onset of treatment showed clinical and neurophysiologic worsening.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSIONS  Lorenzos oil therapy had no effect on patients with evidence of inflammatory brain lesions.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Moreover, in patients without clear signs of inflammatory damage, this treatment does not modify significantly the natural course of the disease.</Disease>

<Disease>However, because effective treatments should begin before the onset of severe neurologic symptoms, SEPs and MEPs should be considered to evaluate the effectiveness of other experimental treatments in the patient with a negative brain MRI.</Disease>
<Disease>The molecular basis of Sjogren-Larsson syndrome: mutation analysis of the fatty aldehyde dehydrogenase gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Sjogren-Larsson syndrome (SLS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by ichthyosis, mental retardation, spasticity, and deficient activity of fatty aldehyde dehydrogenase (FALDH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To define the molecular defects causing SLS, we performed mutation analysis of the FALDH gene in probands from 63 kindreds with SLS.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Among these patients, 49 different mutations-including 10 deletions, 2 insertions, 22 amino acid substitutions, 3 nonsense mutations, 9 splice-site defects, and 3 complex mutations-were found.</Disease>
<Disease>All of the patients with SLS were found to carry mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nineteen of the missense mutations resulted in a severe reduction of FALDH enzyme catalytic activity when expressed in mammalian cells, but one mutation (798G-- > C</Disease>
<Disease>[K266N]) seemed to have a greater effect on mRNA stability.</Disease>
<Disease>The splice-site mutations led to exon skipping or utilization of cryptic acceptor-splice sites.</Disease>
<Disease>Thirty-seven mutations were private, and 12 mutations were seen in two or more probands of European or Middle Eastern descent.</Disease>
<Disease>Four single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) were found in the FALDH gene.</Disease>

<Disease>At least four of the common mutations (551C-- > T, 682C-- > T, 733G-- > A, and 798 + 1delG) were associated with multiple SNP haplotypes, suggesting that these mutations originated independently on more than one occasion or were ancient SLS genes that had undergone intragenic recombination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our results demonstrate that SLS is caused by a strikingly heterogeneous group of mutations in the FALDH gene and provide a framework for understanding the genetic basis of SLS and the development of DNA-based diagnostic tests..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Severe-glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency associated with chronic hemolytic anemia, granulocyte dysfunction, and increased susceptibility to infections: description of a new molecular variant (G6PD Barcelona).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular, kinetic, and functional studies were carried out on erythrocytes and leukocytes in a Spanish male with G6PD deficiency, congenital nonspherocytic hemolytic anemia (CNSHA), and increased susceptibility to infections.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>G6PD activity was absent in patients red cells and was about 2% of normal in leukocytes.</Disease>

<Disease>Molecular studies using standard methods (WHO, 1967) showed G6PD in the patient to have a slightly fast electrophoretic mobility at pH 8. 0 with otherwise normal properties (heat stability at 46 degrees C, apparent affinity for substrates, optimum pH, and utilization of substrate analogues).</Disease>

<Disease>Other tests showed the patients granulocytes to engulf latex particles normally, but to have impaired reduction of nitroblue tetrazolium and ferricytochrome-c as well as reduced iodination.</Disease>
<Disease>Chemotaxis and random migration of the patients granulocytes were normal as were myeloperoxidase, leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP), and ultrastructural features.</Disease>

<Disease>The molecular characteristics of G6PD in the patient differed from those of all previously reported variants associated with CNSHA, so the present variant was provisionally called G6PD Barcelona to distinguish it from other G6PD variants previously described.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Possible mechanisms for the severe deficiency of G6PD in erythrocytes and granulocytes was investigated by studies on the immunologic specific activity of the mutant enzyme.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations at the PAX6 locus are found in heterogeneous anterior segment malformations including Peters' anomaly.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation or deletion of the PAX6 gene underlies many cases of aniridia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Three lines of evidence now converge to implicate PAX6 more widely in anterior segment malformations including Peters anomaly.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>First, a child with Peters anomaly is deleted for one copy of PAX6.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Second, affected members of a family with dominantly inherited anterior segment malformations, including Peters anomaly are heterozygous for an R26G mutation in the PAX6 paired box.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Third, a proportion of Sey/+ Smalleye mice, heterozygous for a nonsense mutation in murine Pax-6, have an ocular phenotype resembling Peters anomaly.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We therefore propose that a variety of anterior segment anomalies may be associated with PAX6 mutations..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In Swedish families with hereditary prostate cancer, linkage to the HPC1 locus on chromosome 1q24-25 is restricted to families with early-onset prostate cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Prostate cancer clusters in some families, and an estimated 5% -10% of all cases are estimated to result from inheritance of prostate cancer-susceptibility genes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We previously reported evidence of linkage to the 1q24-25 region (HPC1) in 91 North American and Swedish families each with multiple cases of prostate cancer (Smith et al. 1996).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the present report we analyze 40 (12 original and 28 newly identified) Swedish families with hereditary prostate cancer (HPC) that, on the basis of 40 markers spanning a 25-cM interval within 1q24-25, have evidence of linkage.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the complete set of families, a maximum two-point LOD score of 1. 10 was observed at D1S413 (at a recombination fraction</Disease>
<Disease>[theta] of.</Disease>
<Disease>1), with a maximum NPL (nonparametric linkage) Z score of 1. 64 at D1S202 (P =. 05).</Disease>

<Disease>The evidence of linkage to this region originated almost exclusively from the subset of 12 early-onset (age < 65 years) families, which yielded a maximum LOD score of 2. 38 at D1S413 (straight theta = 0) and an NPL Z score of 1. 95 at D1S422 (P =. 03).</Disease>
<Disease>Estimates from heterogeneity tests suggest that, within Sweden, as many as 50% of early-onset families had evidence of linkage to the HPC1 region.</Disease>
<Disease>These results are consistent with the hypothesis of linkage to HPC1 in a subset of families with prostate cancer, particularly those with an early age at diagnosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Localisation of the myotonic dystrophy locus to 19q13.2-19q13.3 and its relationship to twelve polymorphic loci on 19q.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The order of fourteen polymorphic markers localised to the long arm of human chromosome 19 has been established by multipoint mapping in a set of 40 CEPH (Centre dEtude de Polymorphisme Humain, Paris) reference families.</Disease>
<Disease>We report here the linkage relationship of the myotonic dystrophy (DM) locus to twelve of these markers as studied in 45 families with DM.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The resulting genetic map is supported by the localisation of the DNA markers in a panel of somatic cell hybrids.</Disease>
<Disease>Ten of the twelve markers have been shown to be proximal to the DM gene and two, PRKCG and D19S22, distal but at distances of approximately 25 cM and 15 cM, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The closest proximal markers are APOC2 (apolipoprotein C-II) and CKM (creatine kinase, muscle) approximately 3 cM and 2 cM from the DM gene respectively, in the order APOC2-CKM-DM.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The distance between APOC2, CKM and DM (of the order of 2 million base pairs) and their known orientation should permit directional chromosome walking and jumping.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The data presented here should enable us to determine whether or not new markers are distal to APOC2/CKM and thus potentially flank the DM gene..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A recurrent expansion of a maternal allele with 36 CAG repeats causes Huntington disease in two sisters.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Large intergenerational repeat expansions of the CAG trinucleotide repeat in the HD gene have been well documented for the male germline.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We describe a recurrent large expansion of a maternal allele with 36 CAG repeats (to 66 and 57 repeats, respectively, in two daughters) associated with onset of Huntington disease (HD) in the second and third decade in a family without history of HD.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Our findings give evidence of a gonadal mosaicism in the unaffected mother.</Disease>

<Disease>We hypothesize that large expansions also occur in the female germline and that a negative selection of oocytes with long repeats might explain the different instability behavior of the male and the female germlines..</Disease>
<Disease>Germline E-cadherin gene (CDH1) mutations predispose to familial gastric cancer and colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Inherited mutations in the E-cadherin gene (CDH1) were described recently in three Maori kindreds with familial gastric cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Familial gastric cancer is genetically heterogeneous and it is not clear what proportion of gastric cancer susceptibility in non-Maori populations is due to germline CDH1 mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Therefore, we screened eight familial gastric cancer kindreds of British and Irish origin for germline CDH1 mutations, by SSCP analysis of all 16 exons and flanking sequences.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Each family contained  (i) two cases of gastric cancer in first degree relatives with one affected before age 50 years; or (ii) three or more cases of gastric cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Novel germline CDH1 mutations (a nonsense and a splice site) were detected in two families (25%).</Disease>
<Disease>Both mutations were predicted to truncate the E-cadherin protein in the signal peptide domain.</Disease>

<Disease>In one family there was evidence of non-penetrance and susceptibility to both gastric and colorectal cancer; thus, in addition to six cases of gastric cancer, a CDH1 mutation carrier developed colorectal cancer at age 30 years.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have confirmed that germline mutations in the CDH1 gene cause familial gastric cancer in non-Maori populations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, only a minority of familial gastric cancers can be accounted for by CDH1 mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Loss of E-cadherin function has been implicated in the pathogenesis of sporadic colorectal and other cancers, and our findings provide evidence that germline CDH1 mutations predispose to early onset colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, CDH1 should be investigated as a cause of inherited susceptibility to both gastric and colorectal cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Germinal mosaicism in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have identified a Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) pedigree where the disease is associated with a molecular deletion within the DMD locus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We have examined the meiotic segregation products of the common female ancestor using marker restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLPs) detected by probes that lie within this deletion.</Disease>
<Disease>These studies show that this female has transmitted three distinct types of X chromosome to her offspring.</Disease>
<Disease>This observation may be explained by postulating that the mutation arose as a postzygotic deletion within this common ancestor, who was consequently germinally mosaic..</Disease>
<Disease>Expression of the murine Duchenne muscular dystrophy gene in muscle and brain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Complementary DNA clones were isolated that represent the 5 terminal 2. 5 kilobases of the murine Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Dmd) messenger RNA (mRNA).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mouse Dmd mRNA was detectable in skeletal and cardiac muscle and at a level approximately 90 percent lower in brain.</Disease>
<Disease>Dmd mRNA is also present, but at much lower than normal levels, in both the muscle and brain of three different strains of dystrophic mdx mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The identification of Dmd mRNA in brain raises the possibility of a relation between human Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) gene expression and the mental retardation found in some DMD males.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These results also provide evidence that the mdx mutations are allelic variants of mouse Dmd gene mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>Human peroxisomal targeting signal-1 receptor restores peroxisomal protein import in cells from patients with fatal peroxisomal disorders.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Two peroxisomal targeting signals, PTS1 and PTS2, are involved in the import of proteins into the peroxisome matrix.</Disease>
<Disease>Human patients with fatal generalized peroxisomal deficiency disorders fall into at least nine genetic complementation groups.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cells from many of these patients are deficient in the import of PTS1-containing proteins, but the causes of the protein-import defect in these patients are unknown.</Disease>
<Disease>We have cloned and sequenced the human cDNA homologue (PTS1R) of the Pichia pastoris PAS8 gene, the PTS1 receptor (McCollum, D., E. Monosov, and S. Subramani. 1993.</Disease>
<Disease>J. Cell Biol.</Disease>
<Disease>121  761-774).</Disease>
<Disease>The PTS1R mRNA is expressed in all human tissues examined.</Disease>
<Disease>Antibodies to the human PTS1R recognize this protein in human, monkey, rat, and hamster cells.</Disease>
<Disease>The protein is localized mainly in the cytosol but is also found to be associated with peroxisomes.</Disease>
<Disease>Part of the peroxisomal PTS1R protein is tightly bound to the peroxisomal membrane.</Disease>
<Disease>Antibodies to PTS1R inhibit peroxisomal protein-import of PTS1-containing proteins in a permeabilized CHO cell system.</Disease>
<Disease>In vitro-translated PTS1R protein specifically binds a serine-lysine-leucine-peptide.</Disease>
<Disease>A PAS8-PTS1R fusion protein complements the P. pastoris pas8 mutant.</Disease>

<Disease>The PTS1R cDNA also complements the PTS1 protein-import defect in skin fibroblasts from patients--belonging to complementation group two--diagnosed as having neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy or Zellweger syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The PTS1R gene has been localized to a chromosomal location where no other peroxisomal disorder genes are known to map.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our findings represent the only case in which the molecular basis of the protein-import deficiency in human peroxisomal disorders is understood.</Disease>

text: <Disease>X-linked spastic paraplegia and Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease are allelic disorders at the proteolipid protein locus.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Three forms of X-linked spastic paraplegia (SPG) have been defined.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>One locus (SPG 1) maps to Xq28 while two clinically distinct forms map to Xq22 (SPG2).</Disease>

<Disease>A rare X-linked dysmyelinating disorder of the central nervous system, Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD), has also been mapped to Xq21-q22, and is caused by mutations in the proteolipid protein gene (PLP) which encodes two myelin proteins, PLP and DM20.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>While narrowing the genetic interval containing SPG2 in a large pedigree, we found that PLP was the closest marker to the disease locus, implicating PLP as a possible candidate gene.</Disease>

<Disease>We have found that a point mutation (His139Tyr) in exon 3B of an affected male produces a mutant PLP but a normal DM20, and segregates with the disease (Zmax = 6. 63, theta = 0. 00).</Disease>
<Disease>It appears, therefore, that SPG2 and PMD are allelic disorders</Disease>
label: Disease
