text: <Disease>Somatic-cell selection is a major determinant of the blood-cell phenotype in heterozygotes for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase mutations causing severe enzyme deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>X-chromosome inactivation in mammals is regarded as an essentially random process, but the resulting somatic-cell mosaicism creates the opportunity for cell selection.</Disease>
<Disease>In most people with red-blood-cell glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, the enzyme-deficient phenotype is only moderately expressed in nucleated cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, in a small subset of hemizygous males who suffer from chronic nonspherocytic hemolytic anemia, the underlying mutations (designated class I) cause more-severe G6PD deficiency, and this might provide an opportunity for selection in heterozygous females during development.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In order to test this possibility we have analyzed four heterozygotes for class I G6PD mutations  two with G6PD Portici (1178G-- ></Disease>
<Disease>A) and two with G6PD Bari (1187C-- > T).</Disease>
<Disease>We found that in fractionated blood cell types (including erythroid, myeloid, and lymphoid cell lineages) there was a significant excess of G6PD-normal cells.</Disease>

<Disease>The significant concordance that we have observed in the degree of imbalance in the different blood-cell lineages indicates that a selective mechanism is likely to operate at the level of pluripotent blood stem cells.</Disease>

<Disease>Thus, it appears that severe G6PD deficiency affects adversely the proliferation or the survival of nucleated blood cells and that this phenotypic characteristic is critical during hematopoiesis..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The ataxia-telangiectasia gene product, a constitutively expressed nuclear protein that is not up-regulated following genome damage.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The product of the ataxia-telangiectasia gene (ATM) was identified by using an antiserum developed to a peptide corresponding to the deduced amino acid sequence.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The ATM protein is a single, high-molecular weight protein predominantly confined to the nucleus of human fibroblasts, but is present in both nuclear and microsomal fractions from human lymphoblast cells and peripheral blood lymphocytes.</Disease>
<Disease>ATM protein levels and localization remain constant throughout all stages of the cell cycle.</Disease>
<Disease>Truncated ATM protein was not detected in lymphoblasts from ataxia-telangiectasia patients homozygous for mutations leading to premature protein termination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Exposure of normal human cells to gamma-irradiation and the radiomimetic drug neocarzinostatin had no effect on ATM protein levels, in contrast to a noted rise in p53 levels over the same time interval.</Disease>
<Disease>These findings are consistent with a role for the ATM protein in ensuring the fidelity of DNA repair and cell cycle regulation following genome damage..</Disease>
<Disease>Molecular basis for Duarte and Los Angeles variant galactosemia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Human orythrocytes that are homozygous for the Duarte enzyme variant of galactosemia (D/D) have a characteristic isoform on isoelectric focusing and 50% reduction in galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) enzyme activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Duarte biochemical phenotype has a molecular genotype of N314D/N314D. The characteristic Duarte isoform is also associated with a variant called the " Los Angeles (LA) phenotype, " which has increased GALT enzyme activity.</Disease>
<Disease>We evaluated GALT enzyme activity and screened the GALT genes of 145 patients with one or more N314D-containing alleles.</Disease>
<Disease>We found seven with the LA biochemical phenotype, and all had a 1721C-- ></Disease>
<Disease>T transition in exon 7 in cis with the N314D missense mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>The 1721C-- ></Disease>
<Disease>T transition is a neutral polymorphism for leucine at amino acid 218 (L218L).</Disease>
<Disease>In pedigree analyses, this 1721C-- ></Disease>
<Disease>T transition segregated with the LA phenotype of increased GALT activity in three different biochemical phenotypes (LA/N, LA/G, and LA/D).</Disease>

<Disease>To determine the mechanism for increased activity of the LA variant, we compared GALT mRNA, protein abundance, and enzyme thermal stability in lymphoblast cell lines of D and LA phenotypes with comparable genotypes.</Disease>
<Disease>GALT protein abundance was increased in LA compared to D alleles, but mRNA was similar among all genotypes.</Disease>

<Disease>When LA/D and D/D GALT biochemical phenotypes were compared to N/N GALT phenotypes, both had 50%, as compared to 21%, reduction in GALT activity in the wild type (N/N) after exposure at identical initial enzyme activity to 50 degrees C for 15 min.</Disease>
<Disease>We conclude that the codon change N314D in cis with the base-pair transition 1721C-- ></Disease>

<Disease>T produces the LA variant of galactosemia and that this nucleotide change increases GALT activity by increasing GALT protein abundance without increasing transcription or decreasing thermal lability.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A favorable codon bias for the mutated codon with consequently increased translation rates is postulated as the mechanism..</Disease>
<Disease>An intronic mutation in a lariat branchpoint sequence is a direct cause of an inherited human disorder (fish-eye disease).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The first step in the splicing of an intron from nuclear precursors of mRNA results in the formation of a lariat structure.</Disease>
<Disease>A distinct intronic nucleotide sequence, known as the branchpoint region, plays a central role in this process.</Disease>
<Disease>We here describe a point mutation in such a sequence.</Disease>
<Disease>Three sisters were shown to suffer from fish-eye disease (FED), a disorder which is caused by mutations in the gene coding for lecithin  cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Sequencing of the LCAT gene of all three probands revealed compound heterozygosity for a missense mutation in exon 4 which is reported to underlie the FED phenotype, and a point mutation located in intron 4 (IVS4  T-22C).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>By performing in vitro expression of LCAT minigenes and reverse transcriptase PCR on mRNA isolated from leukocytes of the patient, this gene defect was shown to cause a null allele as the result of complete intron retention.</Disease>
<Disease>In conclusion, we demonstrated that a point mutation in a lariat branchpoint consensus sequence causes a null allele in a patient with FED.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, our finding illustrates the importance of this sequence for normal human mRNA processing.</Disease>
<Disease>Finally, this report provides a widely applicable strategy which ensures fast and effective screening for intronic defects that underlie differential gene expression..</Disease>
<Disease>Genetic heterogeneity in hereditary breast cancer: role of BRCA1 and BRCA2.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The common hereditary forms of breast cancer have been largely attributed to the inheritance of mutations in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, it is not yet clear what proportion of hereditary breast cancer is explained by BRCA1 and BRCA2 or by some other unidentified susceptibility gene (s).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We describe the proportion of hereditary breast cancer explained by BRCA1 or BRCA2 in a sample of North American hereditary breast cancers and assess the evidence for additional susceptibility genes that may confer hereditary breast or ovarian cancer risk.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Twenty-three families were identified through two high-risk breast cancer research programs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Genetic analysis was undertaken to establish linkage between the breast or ovarian cancer cases and markers on chromosomes 17q (BRCA1) and 13q (BRCA2).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation analysis in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes was also undertaken in all families.</Disease>
<Disease>The pattern of hereditary cancer in 14 (61%) of the 23 families studied was attributed to BRCA1 by a combination of linkage and mutation analyses.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No families were attributed to BRCA2.</Disease>
<Disease>Five families (22%) provided evidence against linkage to both BRCA1 and BRCA2.</Disease>
<Disease>No BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations were detected in these five families.</Disease>
<Disease>The BRCA1 or BRCA2 status of four families (17%) could not be determined.</Disease>
<Disease>BRCA1 and BRCA2 probably explain the majority of hereditary breast cancer that exists in the North American population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, one or more additional genes may yet be found that explain some proportion of hereditary breast cancer..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The tumor suppressor gene Brca1 is required for embryonic cellular proliferation in the mouse.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations of the BRCA1 gone in humans are associated with predisposition to breast and ovarian cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We show here that Brca1 +/- mice are normal and fertile and lack tumors by age eleven months.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Homozygous Brca1 (5-6) mutant mice die before day 7. 5 of embryogenesis.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutant embryos are poorly developed, with no evidence of mesoderm formation.</Disease>
<Disease>The extraembryonic region is abnormal, but aggregation with wild-type tetraploid embryos does not rescue the lethality.</Disease>

<Disease>In vivo, mutant embryos do not exhibit increased apoptosis but show reduced cell proliferation accompanied by decreased expression of cyclin E and mdm-2, a regulator of p53 activity.</Disease>
<Disease>The expression of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p21 is dramatically increased in the mutant embryos.</Disease>
<Disease>Buttressing these in vivo observations is the fact that mutant blastocyst growth is grossly impaired in vitro.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, the death of Brca1 (5-6) mutant embryos prior to gastrulation may be due to a failure of the proliferative burst required for the development of the different germ layers.</Disease>
<Disease>Fusion genes resulting from alternative chromosomal translocations are overexpressed by gene-specific mechanisms in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chromosomal translocations identified in hematopoietic and solid tumors result in deregulated expression of protooncogenes or creation of chimeric proteins with tumorigenic potential.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the pediatric solid tumor alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, a consistent t (2; 13) (q35; q14) or variant t (1; 13) (p36; q14) translocation generates PAX3-FKHR or PAX7-FKHR fusion proteins, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In this report, we demonstrate that in addition to functional alterations these translocations are associated with fusion product overexpression.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR overexpression occurs by distinct mechanisms.</Disease>
<Disease>Transcription of PAX3-FKHR is increased relative to wild-type PAX3 by a copy number-independent process.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, PAX7-FKHR overexpression results from fusion gene amplification.</Disease>

<Disease>Thus, gene-specific mechanisms were selected to overexpress PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, presumably due to differences in regulation between the wild-type loci.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We postulate that these overexpression mechanisms ensure a critical level of gene product for the oncogenic effects of these fusions..</Disease>
<Disease>Pleiotropic defects in ataxia-telangiectasia protein-deficient mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have generated a mouse model for ataxia-telangiectasia by using gene targeting to generate mice that do not express the Atm protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Atm-deficient mice are retarded in growth, do not produce mature sperm, and exhibit severe defects in T cell maturation while going on to develop thymomas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Atm-deficient fibroblasts grow poorly in culture and display a high level of double-stranded chromosome breaks.</Disease>
<Disease>Atm-deficient thymocytes undergo spontaneous apoptosis in vitro significantly more than controls.</Disease>
<Disease>Atm-deficient mice then exhibit many of the same symptoms found in ataxia-telangiectasia patients and in cells derived from them.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, we demonstrate that the Atm protein exists as two discrete molecular species, and that loss of one or of both of these can lead to the development of the disease..</Disease>
<Disease>Muscle expression of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency in different variants.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Muscle expression of G6PD deficiency has been investigated in Mediterranean, Seattle-like and A-variants.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>G6PD activity was detected in samples obtained from biopsies on the quadriceps muscle of seven males and one female.</Disease>
<Disease>The type of genetic variant was determined by molecular analysis of DNA, extracted from blood samples.</Disease>
<Disease>All variants showed the enzyme defect in muscle.</Disease>
<Disease>A statistically significant relationship was found in the activity of G6PD between erythrocytes and muscle of the male subjects (r = 0. 968; p = 0. 00008).</Disease>
<Disease>The equation for the best fit line was  Y = 0.</Disease>
<Disease>390X + 0.</Disease>
<Disease>198 198.</Disease>
<Disease>The results suggest that, for a given variant, the extent of the enzyme defect in muscle may be determined, using this equation, from the G6PD activity of erythrocytes</Disease>
<Disease>PTEN, a putative protein tyrosine phosphatase gene mutated in human brain, breast, and prostate cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mapping of homozygous deletions on human chromosome 10q23 has led to the isolation of a candidate tumor suppressor gene, PTEN, that appears to be mutated at considerable frequency in human cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In preliminary screens, mutations of PTEN were detected in 31% (13/42) of glioblastoma cell lines and xenografts, 100% (4/4) of prostate cancer cell lines, 6% (4/65) of breast cancer cell lines and xenografts, and 17% (3/18) of primary glioblastomas.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The predicted PTEN product has a protein tyrosine phosphatase domain and extensive homology to tensin, a protein that interacts with actin filaments at focal adhesions.</Disease>

<Disease>These homologies suggest that PTEN may suppress tumor cell growth by antagonizing protein tyrosine kinases and may regulate tumor cell invasion and metastasis through interactions at focal adhesions..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Somatic alterations of the DPC4 gene in human colorectal cancers in vivo.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND & AIMS  The chromosome region 18q21 has been shown to be frequently deleted in colorectal cancers, and such frequent allelic loss is a hallmark of the presence of a tumor-suppressor gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The DPC4 gene, which is located at 18q21, has been identified as a tumor-suppressor gene from examination of pancreatic cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The aim of the present study was to determine if it might also be altered in colorectal cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  Mutation analyses of the DPC4 gene were performed on complementary DNA samples from 31 primary colorectal cancer specimens using a combination of polymerase chain reaction, single-strand conformation polymorphism, and DNA sequencing.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS  Four missense mutations producing amino acid substitutions and a somatic 12-base pair deletion in the coding region of the DPC4 gene were detected in the 31 cancers (16%; 5 of 31).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS  The DPC4 gene may play a role as a tumor-suppressor gene in a fraction of colorectal cancers; however, while allelic loss at 18q21 is very often seen in colorectal cancers, only a minority show DPC4 mutations, suggesting that there might be another tumor-suppressor gene in this chromosome region..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Complete genomic sequence and analysis of 117 kb of human DNA containing the gene BRCA1.</Disease>
<Disease>Over 100 distinct disease-associated mutations have been identified in the breast-ovarian cancer susceptibility gene BRCA1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Loss of the wild-type allele in > 90% of tumors from patients with inherited BRCA1 mutations indicates tumor suppressive function.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The low incidence of somatic mutations suggests that BRCA1 inactivation in sporadic tumors occurs by alternative mechanisms, such as interstitial chromosomal deletion or reduced transcription.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To identify possible features of the BRCA1 genomic region that may contribute to chromosomal instability as well as potential transcriptional regulatory elements, a 117, 143-bp DNA sequence encompassing BRCA1 was obtained by random sequencing of four cosmids identified from a human chromosome 17 specific library.</Disease>
<Disease>The 24 exons of BRCA1 span an 81-kb region that has an unusually high density of Alu repetitive DNA (41. 5%), but relatively low density (4. 8%) of other repetitive sequences.</Disease>

<Disease>BRCA1 intron lengths range in size from 403 bp to 9. 2 kb and contain the intragenic microsatellite markers D17S1323, D17S1322, and D17S855, which localize to introns 12, 19, and 20, respectively.</Disease>

<Disease>In addition to BRCA1, the contig contains two complete genes  Rho7, a member of the rho family of GTP binding proteins, and VAT1, an abundant membrane protein of cholinergic synaptic vesicles.</Disease>
<Disease>Partial sequences of the 1A1-3B B-box protein pseudogene and IFP 35, an interferon induced leucine zipper protein, reside within the contig.</Disease>
<Disease>An L21 ribosomal protein pseudogene is embedded in BRCA1 intron 13.</Disease>
<Disease>The order of genes on the chromosome is  centromere-1FP 35-VAT1-Rho7-BRCA1-1A1-3B-telomere</Disease>
<Disease>Type II human complement C2 deficiency. Allele-specific amino acid substitutions (Ser189 --> Phe; Gly444 --> Arg) cause impaired C2 secretion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Type II complement protein C2 deficiency is characterized by a selective block in C2 secretion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Type II C2 null allele (C2Q0) is linked to two major histocompatibility haplotypes (MHC) that differ from the MHC of the more common Type I C2 deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To determine the molecular basis of Type II deficiency the two Type II C2Q0 genes were isolated and transfected separately into L-cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Subsequent molecular biology, biosynthetic, and immunofluorescence studies demonstrated that C2 secretion is impaired in Type II C2 deficiency because of different missense mutations at highly conserved residues in each of the C2Q0 alleles.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One is in exon 5 (nucleotide C566 -- > T; Ser189 -- ></Disease>
<Disease>Phe) of the C2Q0 gene linked to the MHC haplotype A11, B35, DRw1, BFS, C4A0B1.</Disease>
<Disease>The other is in exon 11 (G1930 -- > A; Gly444 -- > Arg) of the C2Q0 gene linked to the MHC haplotype A2, B5, DRw4, BFS, C4A3B1.</Disease>
<Disease>Each mutant C2 gene product is retained early in the secretory pathway.</Disease>
<Disease>These mutants provide models for elucidating the C2 secretory pathway..</Disease>
<Disease>Targeted disruption of ATM leads to growth retardation, chromosomal fragmentation during meiosis, immune defects, and thymic lymphoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>ATM, the gene mutated in the inherited human disease ataxia-telangiectasia, is a member of a family of kinases involved in DNA metabolism and cell-cycle checkpoint control.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To help clarify the physiological roles of the ATM protein, we disrupted the ATM gene in mice through homologous recombination.</Disease>
<Disease>Initial evaluation of the ATM knockout animals indicates that inactivation of the mouse ATM gene recreates much of the phenotype of ataxia-telangiectasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The homozygous mutant (ATM-/-) mice are viable, growth-retarded, and infertile.</Disease>
<Disease>The infertility of ATM-/- mice results from meiotic failure.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Meiosis is arrested at the zygotene/pachytene stage of prophase I as a result of abnormal chromosomal synapsis and subsequent chromosome fragmentation.</Disease>
<Disease>Immune defects also are evident in ATM-/- mice, including reduced numbers of B220 +</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CD43- pre-B cells, thymocytes, and peripheral T cells, as well as functional impairment of T-cell-dependent immune responses.</Disease>
<Disease>The cerebella of ATM-/- mice appear normal by histologic examination at 3 to 4 months and the mice have no gross behavioral abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The majority of mutant mice rapidly develop thymic lymphomas and die before 4 months of age.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings indicate that the ATM gene product plays an essential role in a diverse group of cellular processes, including meiosis, the normal growth of somatic tissues, immune development, and tumor suppression..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The 5' end of the BRCA1 gene lies within a duplicated region of human chromosome 17q21.</Disease>

<Disease>To begin to address the hypothesis that abnormal regulation of the breast/ovarian cancer susceptibility gene BRCA1 is a critical step in sporadic breast/ovarian tumorigenesis, we have determined the detailed structure of the BRCA1 genomic region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We show that this region of the genome contains a tandem duplication of approximately 30 kilobases, which results in two copies of BRCA1 exons 1 and 2, of exons 1 and 3 of the adjacent 1A1-3B gene and of the previously reported 295 base pair intergenic region.</Disease>

<Disease>Sequence analysis of the duplicated exons of BRCA1 and 1A1-3B and flanking genomic DNA reveals maintenance of the intron-exon structure and a high degree of nucleotide sequence identity, suggesting that these are non-processed pseudogenes and that the duplication is a recent event in evolutionary terms.</Disease>

<Disease>We also show that a processed pseudogene of the acidic ribosomal phosphoprotein P1 (ARPP1) is inserted directly upstream of pseudo-BRCA1 exon 1A. We believe that these findings could not only confound BRCA1 mutation analysis, but could have implications for the normal and abnormal regulation of BRCA1 transcription, translation and function..</Disease>
<Disease>atm and p53 cooperate in apoptosis and suppression of tumorigenesis, but not in resistance to acute radiation toxicity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in atm and p53 cause the human cancer-associated diseases ataxia-telangiectasia and Li-Fraumeni syndrome, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The two genes are believed to interact in a number of pathways, including regulation of DNA damage-induced cell-cycle checkpoints, apoptosis and radiation sensitivity, and cellular proliferation.</Disease>
<Disease>Atm-null mice, as well as those null for p53, develop mainly T-cell lymphomas, supporting the view that these genes have similar roles in thymocyte development.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To study the interactions of these two genes on an organismal level, we bred mice heterozygous for null alleles of both atm and p53 to produce all genotypic combinations.</Disease>

<Disease>Mice doubly null for atm and p53 exhibited a dramatic acceleration of tumour formation relative to singly null mice, indicating that both genes collaborate in a significant manner to prevent tumorigenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>With respect to their roles in apoptosis, loss of atm rendered thymocytes only partly resistant to irradiation-induced apoptosis, whereas additional loss of p53 engendered complete resistance.</Disease>
<Disease>This implies that the irradiation-induced atm and p53 apoptotic pathways are not completely congruent.</Disease>

<Disease>Finally-and in contrast to prior predictions-atm and p53 do not appear to interact in acute radiation toxicity, suggesting a separate atm effector pathway for this DNA damage response and having implications for the prognosis and treatment of human tumours..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Molecular bases of C7 deficiency: three different defects.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The molecular basis of C7 deficiency has been investigated in two Irish families and a number of Israeli families of Moroccan Sephardic Jewish origin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Exon PCR and sequencing revealed a heterozygous point mutation at the 3 splice acceptor site of intron 1 in one Irish family.</Disease>
<Disease>In the other Irish family, exons 7 and 8 failed to amplify and they were shown to be deleted.</Disease>

<Disease>Marker haplotype studies of the C6 and C7 gene region and Southern blots show that the Irish family with the splice defect also segregate for the deletion, which is not easily detected in heterozygotes.</Disease>
<Disease>The Israeli C7-deficient cases all share a C7 haplotype and are homozygous for a mis-sense mutation in exon 9.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, one individual is heterozygous for markers at adjacent C6 loci, showing that there has been an intergenic recombination and suggesting that the deficiency mutation is of appreciable antiquity..</Disease>
<Disease>Identification of WASP mutations, mutation hotspots and genotype-phenotype disparities in 24 patients with the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), an X-linked immunodeficiency disease caused by mutation in the recently isolated gene encoding WAS protein (WASP), is known to be associated with extensive clinical heterogeneity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Cumulative mutation data have revealed that WASP genotypes are also highly variable among WAS patients, but the relationship of phenotype with genotype in this disease remains unclear.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To address this issue we characterized WASP mutations in 24 unrelated WAS patients, including 18 boys with severe classical WAS and 6 boys expressing mild forms of the disease, and then examined the degree of correlation of these as well as all previously published WASP mutations with disease severity.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>By analysis of these compiled mutation data, we demonstrated clustering of WASP mutations within the four most N-terminal exons of the gene and also identified several sites within this region as hotspots for WASP mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>These characteristics were observed, however, in both severe and mild cases of the disease.</Disease>

<Disease>Similarly, while the cumulative data revealed a predominance of missense mutations among the WASP gene lesions observed in boys with isolated thrombocytopenia, missense mutations were not exclusively associated with milder WAS phenotypes, but also comprised a substantial portion (38%) of the WASP gene defects found in patients with severe disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These findings, as well as the detection of identical WASP mutations in patients with disparate phenotypes, reveal a lack of phenotype concordance with genotype in WAS and thus imply that phenotypic outcome in this disease cannot be reliably predicted solely on the basis of WASP genotypes..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Identification and chromosomal localization of Atm, the mouse homolog of the ataxia-telangiectasia gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Atm, the mouse homolog of the human ATM gene defective in ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), has been identified.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The entire coding sequence of the Atm transcript was cloned and found to contain an open reading frame encoding a protein of 3066 amino acids with 84% overall identity and 91% similarity to the human ATM protein.</Disease>
<Disease>Variable levels of expression of Atm were observed in different tissues.</Disease>

<Disease>Fluorescence in situ hybridization and linkage analysis located the Atm gene on mouse chromosome 9, band 9C, in a region homologous to the ATM region on human chromosome 11q22-q23..</Disease>
<Disease>Mutation of MSH3 in endometrial cancer and evidence for its functional role in heteroduplex repair.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Many human tumours have length alterations in repetitive sequence elements.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although this microsatellite instability has been attributed to mutations in four DNA mismatch repair genes in hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) kindreds, many sporadic tumours exhibit instability but no detectable mutations in these genes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>It is therefore of interest to identify other genes that contribute to this instability.</Disease>
<Disease>In yeast, mutations in several genes, including RTH and MSH3, cause microsatellite instability.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, we screened 16 endometrial carcinomas with microsatellite instability for alterations in FEN1 (the human homolog of RTH) and in MSH3 (refs 12-14).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although we found no FEN1 mutations, a frameshift mutation in MSH3 was observed in an endometrial carcinoma and in an endometrial carcinoma cell line.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Extracts of the cell line were deficient in repair of DNA substrates containing mismatches or extra nucleotides.</Disease>

<Disease>A subsequent search revealed a second gene mutation in HHUA cells, a missense mutation in the MSH6 gene.</Disease>

<Disease>Together the data suggest that the MSH3 gene encodes a product that functions in repair of some but not all pre-mutational intermediates, its mutation in tumours can result in genomic instability and, as in yeast, MSH3 and MSH6 are partially redundant for mismatch repair..</Disease>

<Disease>BRCA1 and BRCA2 are the two major identified causes of inherited breast cancer, with mutations in either gene conferring up to 80-90% lifetime risk of breast cancer in carrier females.</Disease>

text: <Disease>We have conducted a large-scale population study to investigate the prevalence of specific BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations in Ashkenazi Jewish individuals who were unselected for breast cancer.</Disease>

<Disease>This expanded population-based study confirms that the BRCA1 185delAG mutation and the BRCA2 6174delT mutation constitute the two most frequent mutation alleles predisposing to hereditary breast cancer among the Ashkenazim, and suggests a relatively lower penetrance for the 6174delT mutation in BRCA2</Disease>

text: <Disease>Moderate intergenerational and somatic instability of a 55-CTG repeat in transgenic mice.</Disease>
<Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is associated with the expansion of a (CTG) n trinucleotide repeat in the 3 untranslated region (UTR) of the DM protein kinase gene (DMPK).</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>The (CTG) n repeat is polymorphic and varies in size between 5 and 37 repeats in unaffected individuals whereas in affected patients there are between 50 and 4, 000 CTGs.</Disease>
<Disease>The size of the (CTG) n repeat, which increases through generations, generally correlates with clinical severity and age of onset.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Heterogeneity in Schwartz-Jampel chondrodystrophic myotonia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Schwartz-Jampel syndrome (SJS; chondrodystrophic myotonia; McK 255, 800) is a recessively inherited condition defined by myotonia, short stature, and bone dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Genetic linkage between SJS and chromosomal region 1q36-34 has been observed in several families, but the gene has not yet been identified.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We studied the clinical and radiological features in 81 patients from the literature and 5 own patients trying to identify distinct subgroups.</Disease>
<Disease>In addition, we tested genetic linkage to the SJS locus on chromosome 1 in one family with two affected sibs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We found that a group of patients have mild skeletal changes which may be secondary consequences of myotonia, while another group of patients appear to have primary bone dysplasia with myotonia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Within this latter group, there are differences in age of manifestation, clinical course and pattern of bone changes.</Disease>

<Disease>We tentatively isolate three different types of SJS  type 1A, usually recognized in childhood, with moderate bone dysplasia, corresponding to the original descriptions of Schwartz, Jampel and Aberfeld; type 1B, similar to type 1A but recognizable at birth, with more pronounced bone dysplasia resembling Kniest dysplasia; and type 2, manifest at birth, with increased mortality and bone dysplasia resembling Pyle disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Genetic analysis of the family with two sibs affected by SJS type 2 showed evidence against linkage to chromosome 1p36-34.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS  SJS is clinically and radiologically heterogeneous.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The causes of heterogeneity are not known yet but are likely to include both different mutations at the SJS locus on chromosome 1 and the presence of a second SJS locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A tentative clinico-radiological classification can be useful for the characterization of patients and the development of genotype-phenotype correlations..</Disease>

text: <Disease>X-Linked adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) is a genetic disease associated with demyelination of the central nervous system, adrenal insufficiency, and accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in tissue and body fluids.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>ALD is due to mutation of a gene located in Xq28 that encodes a peroxisomal transporter protein of unknown function.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The most common phenotype of ALD is the cerebral form (45%) that develops in boys between 5-12 yr.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) involves the spinal cord and peripheral nerves in young adults (35%).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Adrenal insufficiency (Addisons disease) is frequently associated with AMN or cerebral ALD and may remain the only clinical expression of ALD (8% of cases).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The prevalence of ALD among adults with Addisons disease remains unknown.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To evaluate this prevalence, we performed biochemical analysis of very long chain fatty acids in 14 male patients (age ranging from 12-45 yr at diagnosis) previously diagnosed as having primary idiopathic adrenocortical insufficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In 5 of 14 patients (35%), elevated plasma concentrations of very long chain fatty acids were detected.</Disease>
<Disease>None of these patients had adrenocortical antibodies.</Disease>

<Disease>By electrophysiological tests and magnetic resonance imaging it was determined that two patients had cerebral ALD, one had adrenomyeloneuropathy with cerebral involvement, and two had preclinical AMN.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our data support the hypothesis that ALD is a frequent cause of idiopathic Addisons disease in children and adults..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Inherited mutant alleles of familial tumour suppressor genes predispose individuals to particular types of cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition to an involvement in inherited susceptibility to cancer, these tumour suppressor genes are targets for somatic mutations in sporadic cancers of the same type found in the familial forms.</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>An exception is BRCA1, which contributes to a significant fraction of familial breast and ovarian cancer, but undergoes mutation at very low rates in sporadic breast and ovarian cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This finding suggests that other genes may be the principal targets for somatic mutation in breast carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Like BRCA1, BRCA2 behaves as a dominantly inherited tumour suppressor gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

label: Disease

text: <Disease>The BRCA2 coding sequence is huge, composed of 26 exons that span 10, 443 bp.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Type III collagen is crucial for collagen I fibrillogenesis and for normal cardiovascular development.</Disease>

text: <Disease>To directly study the role of Col3a1 in development and disease, we have inactivated the Col3a1 gene in embryonic stem cells by homologous recombination.</Disease>

<Disease>About 10% of the homozygous mutant animals survived to adulthood but have a much shorter life span compared with wild-type mice.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations were detected in 90% of the cases.</Disease>
<Disease>Three mutation detection techniques were used to determine if one method was superior for this gene.</Disease>
<Disease>The protein truncation test (PTT) was used on RT-PCR products, SSCP on genomic PCR amplifications, and chemical cleavage of mismatch on both RT-PCR and genomic amplifications.</Disease>

<Disease>On genomic products exons 1 to 13 (including 740 bp of the 3 untranslated sequence and all intron/exon boundaries) were screened, as was a neuroretina specific enhancer in intron 4.</Disease>
<Disease>Ten of the possible 12 mutations in the five familial cases and five of the sporadic patients were found, all of which conformed to a functional outcome of haploinsufficiency.</Disease>

<Disease>Five were splice site mutations (one in the donor site of intron 4, two in the donor site of intron 6, one in each of the acceptor sites of introns 8 and 9) and five were nonsense mutations in exons 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12.</Disease>
<Disease>SSCP analysis of individually amplified exons, with which nine of the 10 mutations were seen, was the most useful detection method for PAX6..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Absence of disease phenotype and intergenerational stability of the CAG repeat in transgenic mice expressing the human Huntington disease transcript.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mutation underlying Huntington disease (HD) is CAG expansion in the first exon of the HD gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

Disease

text: <Disease>In order to investigate the role of CAG expansion in the pathogenesis of HD, we have produced transgenic mice containing the full length human HD cDNA with 44 CAG repeats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>By 1 year, these mice have no behavioral abnormalities and morphometric analysis at 6 (one animal) and 9 (two animals) months age revealed no changes.</Disease>

text: <Disease>Rather, translation of the CAG is crucial for the pathogenesis of HD.</Disease>

<Disease>Detection of heterozygous mutations in BRCA1 using high density oligonucleotide arrays and two-colour fluorescence analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>The ability to scan a large gene rapidly and accurately for all possible heterozygous mutations in large numbers of patient samples will be critical for the future of medicine.</Disease>

<Disease>We have designed high-density arrays consisting of over 96, 600 oligonucleotides 20-nucleotides (nt) in length to screen for a wide range of heterozygous mutations in the 3. 45-kilobases (kb) exon 11 of the hereditary breast and ovarian cancer gene BRCA1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Reference and test samples were co-hybridized to these arrays and differences in hybridization patterns quantitated by two-colour analysis.</Disease>
<Disease>Fourteen of fifteen patient samples with known mutations were accurately diagnosed, and no false positive mutations were identified in 20 control samples.</Disease>
<Disease>Eight single nucleotide polymorphisms were also readily detected.</Disease>
<Disease>DNA chip-based assays may provide a valuable new technology for high-throughput cost-efficient detection of genetic alterations.</Disease>
<Disease>Colchicine in breast milk of patients with familial Mediterranean fever.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>OBJECTIVE.</Disease>

<Disease>To clarify whether colchicine is excreted in breast milk, and to compare its concentrations in the serum and breast milk of lactating women who have familial Mediterranean fever (FMF).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS.</Disease>

<Disease>Using a specific radioimmunoassay, we determined colchicine concentrations in the serum and breast milk of 4 patients at various time points, following oral administration of the drug.</Disease>
<Disease>The study evaluated 4 patients with FMF who had been taking colchicine on a long-term basis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS.</Disease>
<Disease>Colchicine was found to be excreted in breast milk.</Disease>
<Disease>Its levels ranged between 1. 9 and 8. 6 ng/ml, which were similar to those found in the serum (parallel concentration time curves).</Disease>

<Disease>However, there appeared to be a considerable variation in colchicine milk concentration among the different patients, which might be related to individual breast milk composition and, possibly, to other nutritional or metabolic factors.</Disease>
<Disease>CONCLUSION.</Disease>
<Disease>The extensive peripheral tissue binding and relatively low concentration of colchicine in breast milk suggests that the amount ingested by the infant is small.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, based on our clinical experience, nursing appears to be safe for lactating women with FMF who continue to take colchicine.</Disease>

text: <Disease>The human complement C9 gene: identification of two mutations causing deficiency and revision of the gene structure.</Disease>

label: Disease

text: <Disease>As a cause of C9 deficiency , we found two different point mutations, both generating TGA stop codons in the coding sequence.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One mutation, a C to A exchange, was detected in exon 2 at cDNA position 166, the other, a C to T exchange, was located in exon 4 (cDNA position 464).</Disease>

text: <Disease>Therefore, these mutations are sufficient to explain the complete deficiency of both the probands studied.</Disease>

<Disease>Molecular heterogeneity of classical and Duarte galactosemia: mutation analysis by denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Classical galactosemia is caused by one common missense mutation (Q188R) and by several rare mutations in the galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The most common variant of GALT, the Duarte variant, occurs as two types, Duarte-1 (D-1) and Duarte-2 (D-2), both of which carry the sequence change N314D. D-1 increases, whereas D-2 decreases GALT activity.</Disease>

<Disease>To study the molecular genetics of classical and Duarte galactosemia, we analyzed the GALT mutations in 30 families with classical galactosemia, in 10 families with the D-2 variant and in 3 individuals carrying the D-1 allele by denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE).</Disease>

text: <Disease>DGGE detected 59 of the 60 classical galactosemia alleles.</Disease>

<Disease>We conclude that the mutations causing galactosemia are highly heterogeneous and that K285N is a second common galactosemia mutation in our population..</Disease>

text: <Disease>The hybrid PAX3-FKHR fusion protein of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma transforms fibroblasts in culture.</Disease>
