<Disease>Consistent with cellular defects of AT patients, the ATM-/- cells are hypersensitive to gamma-irradiation and defective in cell-cycle arrest following radiation, correlating with a defective up-regulation of p53.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, ATM-/- mouse thymocytes are more resistant to apoptosis induced by gamma-irradiation than normal thymocytes.</Disease>
<Disease>ATM-/- fibroblasts are inefficient in G1 to S-phase progression following serum stimulation and senesce after only a few passages in culture.</Disease>
<Disease>They have an increased constitutive level of p21CP1/WAF1.</Disease>
<Disease>The ATM protein is therefore critical both for cellular responses to ionizing radiation and for normal cell-cycle progression.</Disease>

<Disease>ATM +/- fibroblasts and thymocytes showed intermediately defective responses to irradiation but no growth defect, suggesting that the increased cancer risk of AT heterozygotes could be attributable to poor checkpoint function..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Identification and expression of eight novel mutations among non-Jewish patients with Canavan disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Canavan disease is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait that is caused by the deficiency of aspartoacylase (ASPA).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The majority of patients with Canavan disease are from an Ashkenazi Jewish background.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in ASPA that lead to loss of enzymatic activity have been identified, and E285A and Y231X are the two predominant mutations that account for 97% of the mutant chromosomes in Ashkenazi Jewish patients.</Disease>
<Disease>The current study was aimed at finding the molecular basis of Canavan disease in 25 independent patients of non-Jewish background.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Eight novel and three previously characterized mutations accounted for 80% (40/50) of mutant chromosomes.</Disease>

<Disease>The A305E missense mutation accounted for 48% (24/50) of mutant chromosomes in patients of western European descent, while the two predominant Jewish mutations each accounted for a single mutant chromosome.</Disease>
<Disease>The eight novel mutations identified included 1- and 4-bp deletions (32 deltaT and 876 deltaAGAA, respectively) and I16T, G27R, D114E, G123E, C152Y, and R168C missense mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>The homozygous 32 deltaT deletion was identified in the only known patient of African-American origin with Canavan disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The heterozygosity for 876 deltaAGAA mutation was identified in three independent patients from England.</Disease>

<Disease>Six single-base changes leading to missense mutations were identified in patients from Turkey (D114E, R168C), The Netherlands (I16T), Germany (G27R), Ireland (C152Y), and Canada (G123E).</Disease>
<Disease>A PCR-based protocol is described that was used to introduce mutations in wild-type cDNA.</Disease>
<Disease>In vitro expression of mutant cDNA clones demonstrated that all of these mutations led to a deficiency of ASPA and should therefore result in Canavan disease..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>BRCA1 mutations in women attending clinics that evaluate the risk of breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND  To define the incidence of BRCA1 mutations among patients seen in clinics that evaluate the risk of breast cancer, we analyzed DNA samples from women seen in this setting and constructed probability tables to provide estimates of the likelihood of finding a BRCA1 mutation in individual families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  Clinical information, family histories, and blood for DNA analysis were obtained from 263 women with breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Conformation-sensitive gel electrophoresis and DNA sequencing were used to identify BRCA1 mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>RESULTS  BRCA1 mutations were identified in 16 percent of women with a family history of breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Only 7 percent of women from families with a history of breast cancer but not ovarian cancer had BRCA1 mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The rates were higher among women from families with a history of both breast and ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Among family members, an average age of less than 55 years at the diagnosis of breast cancer, the presence of ovarian cancer, the presence of breast and ovarian cancer in the same woman, and Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry were all associated with an increased risk of detecting a BRCA1 mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No association was found between the presence of bilateral breast cancer or the number of breast cancers in a family and the detection of a BRCA1 mutation, or between the position of the mutation in the BRCA1 gene and the presence of ovarian cancer in a family.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS  Among women with breast cancer and a family history of the disease, the percentage with BRCA1 coding-region mutations is less than the 45 percent predicted by genetic-linkage analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These results suggest that even in a referral clinic specializing in screening women from high-risk families, the majority of tests for BRCA1 mutations will be negative and therefore uninformative..</Disease>
<Disease>The von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene product interacts with Sp1 to repress vascular endothelial growth factor promoter activity.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene (VHL) has a critical role in the pathogenesis of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), as VHL mutations have been found in both von Hippel-Lindau disease-associated and sporadic RCCs.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recent studies suggest that vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) mRNA is upregulated in RCC- and von Hippel-Lindau disease-associated tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have therefore assessed the effect of the VHL gene product on VEGF expression.</Disease>
<Disease>VEGF promoter-luciferase constructs were transiently cotransfected with a wild-type VHL (wt-VHL) vector in several cell lines, including 293 embryonic kidney and RCC cell lines.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>wt-VHL protein inhibited VEGF promoter activity in a dose-dependent manner up to 5- to 10-fold.</Disease>
<Disease>Deletion analysis defined a 144-bp region of the VEGF promoter necessary for VHL repression.</Disease>
<Disease>This VHL-responsive element is GC rich and specifically binds the transcription factor Sp1 in crude nuclear extracts.</Disease>
<Disease>In Drosophila cells, cotransfected VHL represses Sp1-mediated activation but not basal activity of the VEGF promoter.</Disease>

<Disease>We next demonstrated in coimmunoprecipitates that VHL and Sp1 were part of the same complex and, by using a glutathione-S-transferase-VHL fusion protein and purified Sp1, that VHL and Sp1 directly interact.</Disease>

<Disease>Furthermore, endogenous VEGF mRNA levels were suppressed in permanent RCC cell lines expressing wt-VHL, and nuclear run-on studies indicated that VHL regulation of VEGF occurs at least partly at the transcriptional level.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These observations support a new mechanism for VHL-mediated transcriptional repression via a direct inhibitory action on Sp1 and suggest that loss of Sp1 inhibition may be important in the pathogenesis of von Hippel-Lindau disease and RCC..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Germline mutations in the RB1 gene in patients with hereditary retinoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have analyzed the 27 exons and the promoter region of the RB1 gene in familial or sporadic bilateral retinoblastoma by using single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>For improvement over previous studies, a new set of primers has been designed, which allow for amplification of the coding and splicing sequences only.</Disease>

<Disease>The positioning of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) primers was such that the resulting PCR products were of different sizes, which enabled us to analyze two different exons simultaneously and still distinguish between the banding profiles for both (biplex analysis).</Disease>
<Disease>By using this approach, we were able to identify mutation in 22 new patients, but the overall efficiency of the procedure when we used a single-pass regimen was only 48%.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutations were small insertions and deletions and point mutations in roughly equal proportions..</Disease>

<Disease>Deletion of small nuclear ribonucleoprotein polypeptide N (SNRPN) in Prader-Willi syndrome detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization: two sibs with the typical phenotype without a cytogenetic deletion in chromosome 15q.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The small nuclear ribonucleoprotein polypeptide N (SNRPN) gene is regarded as one of the candidates for Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We describe two sibs with typical PWS presenting deletion of SNRPN detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Neither a cytogenetically detectable 15q12 deletion nor a deletion for the D15S11, D15S10, and GABRB3 cosmid probes were found in either patient.</Disease>
<Disease>This implies a smaller deletion limited to the PWS critical region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>FISH with a SNRPN probe will permit analysis of PWS patients with limited deletions not detectable with other probes..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mouse homolog of the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) gene is highly conserved and maps near the scurfy (sf) mutation on the X chromosome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The mouse WASP gene, the homolog of the gene mutated in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, has been isolated and sequenced.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>the predicted amino acid sequence is 86% identical to the human WASP sequence.</Disease>

<Disease>A distinct feature of the mouse gene is an expanded polymorphic GGA trinucleotide repeat that codes for polyglycine and varies from 15 to 17 triplets in different Mus musculus strains.</Disease>
<Disease>The genomic structure of the mouse WASP gene is expressed as an approximately 2. 4-kb mRNA in thymus and spleen.</Disease>

<Disease>Chromosomal mapping in an interspecific M. Musculus/M. spretus backcross placed the Wasp locus near the centromere of the mouse X chromosome, inseparable from Gata1, Tcfe3, and scurfy (sf).</Disease>

<Disease>This localization makes Wasp a candidate for involvement in scurfy, a T cell-mediated fatal lymphoreticular disease of mice that has previously been proposed as a mouse homolog of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Northern analysis of sf tissue samples indicated the presence of WASP mRNA in liver and skin, presumably as a consequence of lymphocytic infiltration, but non abnormalities in the amount or size of mRNA present.</Disease>
<Disease>An animal model for Norrie disease (ND): gene targeting of the mouse ND gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In order to elucidate the cellular and molecular processes which are involved in Norrie disease (ND), we have used gene targeting technology to generate ND mutant mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The murine homologue of the ND gene was cloned and shown to encode a polypeptide that shares 94% of the amino acid sequence with its human counterpart.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>RNA in situ hybridization revealed expression in retina, brain and the olfactory bulb and epithelium of 2 week old mice.</Disease>

<Disease>Hemizygous mice carrying a replacement mutation in exon 2 of the ND gene developed retrolental structures in the vitreous body and showed an overall disorganization of the retinal ganglion cell layer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The outer plexiform layer disappears occasionally, resulting in a juxtaposed inner and outer nuclear layer.</Disease>
<Disease>At the same regions, the outer segments of the photoreceptor cell layer are no longer present.</Disease>

<Disease>These ocular findings are consistent with observations in ND patients and the generated mouse line provides a faithful model for study of early pathogenic events in this severe X-linked recessive neurological disorder..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Phenotypic characterization of individuals with 30-40 CAG repeats in the Huntington disease (HD) gene reveals HD cases with 36 repeats and apparently normal elderly individuals with 36-39 repeats.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Abnormal CAG expansions in the IT-15 gene are associated with Huntington disease (HD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the diagnostic setting it is necessary to define the limits of the CAG size ranges on normal and HD-associated chromosomes.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Most large analyses that defined the limits of the normal and pathological size ranges employed PCR assays, which included the CAG repeats and a CCG repeat tract that was thought to be invariant.</Disease>
<Disease>Many of these experiments found an overlap between the normal and disease size ranges.</Disease>

<Disease>Subsequent findings that the CCG repeats vary by 8 trinucleotide lengths suggested that the limits of the normal and disease size ranges should be reevaluated with assays that exclude the CCG polymorphism.</Disease>
<Disease>Since patients with between 30 and 40 repeats are rare, a consortium was assembled to collect such individuals.</Disease>
<Disease>All 178 samples were reanalyzed in Cambridge by using assays specific for the CAG repeats.</Disease>
<Disease>We have optimized methods for reliable sizing of CAG repeats and show cases that demonstrate the dangers of using PCR assays that include both the CAG and CCG polymorphisms.</Disease>
<Disease>Seven HD patients had 36 repeats, which confirms that this allele is associated with disease.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Individuals without apparent symptoms or signs of HD were found at 36 repeats (aged 74, 78, 79, and 87 years), 37 repeats (aged 69 years), 38 repeats (aged 69 and 90 years), and 39 repeats (aged 67, 90, and 95 years).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The detailed case histories of an exceptional case from this series will be presented  a 95-year-old man with 39 repeats who did not have classical features of HD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The apparently healthy survival into old age of some individuals with 36-39 repeats suggests that the HD mutation may not always be fully penetrant..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>HPRT-APRT-deficient mice are not a model for lesch-nyhan syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Complete hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl-transferase (HPRT) deficiency in humans results in the Lesch-Nyhan syndrome which is characterized, among other features, by compulsive self-injurious behavior.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>HPRT-deficient mice generated using mouse embryonic stem cells exhibit none of the behavioral symptoms associated with the Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Administration of drugs that inhibit adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) in HPRT-deficient mice has produced the suggestion that deficiency of APRT in combination with HPRT-deficiency in mice may lead to self-mutilation behavior [C. L. Wu and D. W. Melton (1993)</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nature Genet.</Disease>
<Disease>3, 235-240].</Disease>
<Disease>To test this proposition, we bred HPRT-APRT-deficient mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although the doubly-deficient mice excrete adenine and its highly insoluble derivative, 2, 8-dihydroxyadenine, which are also associated with human APRT deficiency, additional abnormalities or any self-injurious behavior were not detected.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, APRT-HPRT-deficient mice, which are devoid of any purine salvage pathways, show no novel phenotype and are not a model for the behavioral abnormalities associated with the Lesch-Nyhan syndrome as previously suggested</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mice lacking the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase develop a late onset progressive myopathy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is an autosomal dominant disorder resulting from the expansion of a CTG repeat in the 3 untranslated region of a putative protein kinase (DMPK).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To elucidate the role of DMPK in DM pathogenesis we have developed Dmpk deficient (Dmpk-/-) mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Dmpk-/-mice develop a late-onset, progressive skeletal myopathy that shares some pathological features with DM.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Muscles from mature mice show variation in fibre size, increased fibre degeneration and fibrosis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Adult Dmpk-/-mice show ultrastructural changes in muscle and a 50% decrease in force generation compared to young mice.</Disease>

<Disease>Our results indicate that DMPK may be necessary for the maintenance of skeletal muscle structure and function and suggest that a decrease in DMPK levels may contribute to DM pathology..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Rapid detection of regionally clustered germ-line BRCA1 mutations by multiplex heteroduplex analysis. UKCCCR Familial Ovarian Cancer Study Group.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Germ-line mutations of the BRCA1 gene are responsible for a substantial proportion of families with multiple cases of early-onset breast and/or ovarian cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Since the isolation of BRCA1 last year, > 65 distinct mutations scattered throughout the coding region have been detected, making analysis of the gene time consuming and technically challenging.</Disease>

<Disease>We have developed a multiplex heteroduplex analysis that is designed to analyze one-quarter of the coding sequence in a single-step screening procedure and that will detect approximately 50% of all BRCA1 mutations so far reported in breast/ovarian cancer families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have used this technique to analyze BRCA1 in 162 families with a history of breast and/or ovarian cancer and identified 12 distinct mutations in 35 families..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>LPP, the preferred fusion partner gene of HMGIC in lipomas, is a novel member of the LIM protein gene family.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A major cytogenetic subgroup of lipomas is characterized by recurrent chromosome aberrations, mainly translocations, that involve chromosome segment 12q13-q15.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Multiple chromosomes have been found as the translocation partners of chromosome 12 but 3q27-q28 is preferentially involved.</Disease>
<Disease>In previous studies, it has been shown that the high mobility group (HMG) protein gene HMGIC at 12q15 is consistently rearranged as a consequence of these translocations.</Disease>
<Disease>Here, we report the identification and characterization of the chromosome 3-derived translocation partner gene, which we have designated LPP (lipoma preferred partner gene).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Using 3-RACE analysis of HMGIC fusion transcripts in lipoma cell line Li-501/SV40, ectopic genetic sequences were obtained, which by CASH (chromosome assignment using somatic cell hybrids) and FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization) analysis were found to originate from chromosome segment 3q27-q28.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In Northern blot analysis, an mRNA of over 10 kb was detected by these ectopic sequences in a variety of human tissues but not in brain and peripheral blood leukocytes.</Disease>
<Disease>Upon partial cDNA cloning, features of the genetic organization of LPP were established.</Disease>
<Disease>The gene was found to span a genomic region of over 400 kb.</Disease>

<Disease>Nucleotide sequence analysis of a composite cDNA of LPP revealed an open reading frame of 1836 nucleotides encoding a proline-rich protein containing a leucine-zipper motif in its amino-terminal region and three LIM domains in its carboxy-terminal region.</Disease>
<Disease>The LPP-encoded protein should be classified as a novel member of the group 3 proteins of the LIM protein gene family.</Disease>

<Disease>Using reverse transcriptase combined with polymerase chain reactions in the analysis of a number of lipoma cell lines and primary lipomas, it appeared that LPP is frequently rearranged also in cases without a cytogenetically detectable involvement of 3q27-q28.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Two alternative HMGIC/LPP hybrid transcripts have been detected; the difference between them is mainly the presence of either two or three LIM domains in the predicted HMGI-C/LPP fusion proteins..</Disease>
<Disease>Exon-intron structure of the human neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptor alpha 4 subunit (CHRNA4).</Disease>

<Disease>The human neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptor alpha 4 subunit gene (CHRNA4) is located in the candidate region for three different phenotypes  benign familial neonatal convulsions, autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy, and low-voltage EEG.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recently, a missense mutation in transmembrane domain 2 of CHRNA4 was found to be associated with autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy in one extended pedigree.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have determined the genomic organization of CHRNA4, which consists of six exons distributed over approximately 17 kb of genomic DNA.</Disease>

<Disease>The nucleotide sequence obtained from the genomic regions adjacent to the exon boundaries enabled us to develop a set of primer pairs for PCR amplification of the complete coding region.</Disease>
<Disease>The sequence analysis provides the basis for a comprehensive mutation screening of CHRNA4 in the above-mentioned phenotypes and possibly in other types of idiopathic epilepsies..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A novel homeodomain-encoding gene is associated with a large CpG island interrupted by the myotonic dystrophy unstable (CTG)n repeat.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is associated with a (CTG) n trinucleotide repeat expansion in the 3-untranslated region of a protein kinase-encoding gene, DMPK, which maps to chromosome 19q13.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>3. Characterisation of the expression of this gene in patient tissues has thus far generated conflicting data on alterations in the steady state levels of DMPK mRNA, and on the final DMPK protein levels in the presence of the expansion.</Disease>

<Disease>The DM region of chromosome 19 is gene rich, and it is possible that the repeat expansion may lead to dysfunction of a number of transcription units in the vicinity, perhaps as a consequence of chromatin disruption.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have searched for genes associated with a CpG island at the 3 end of DMPK.</Disease>
<Disease>Sequencing of this region shows that the island extends over 3. 5 kb and is interrupted by the (CTG) n repeat.</Disease>
<Disease>Comparison of genomic sequences downstream (centromeric) of the repeat in human and mouse identified regions of significant homology.</Disease>
<Disease>These correspond to exons of a gene predicted to encode a homeodomain protein.</Disease>

<Disease>RT-PCR analysis shows that this gene, which we have called DM locus-associated homeodomain protein (DMAHP), is expressed in a number of human tissues, including skeletal muscle, heart and brain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Missense mutations in the Fas gene resulting in autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome: a molecular and immunological analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Programmed cell death (or apoptosis) is a physiological process essential to the normal development and homeostatic maintenance of the immune system.</Disease>

<Disease>The Fas/Apo-1 receptor plays a crucial role in the regulation of apoptosis, as demonstrated by lymphoproliferation in MRL-lpr/lpr mice and by the recently described autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) in humans, both of which are due to mutations in the Fas gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We describe a novel family with ALPS in which three affected siblings carry two distinct missense mutations on both the Fas gene alleles and show lack of Fas-induced apoptosis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The children share common clinical features including splenomegaly and lymphadenopathy, but only one developed severe autoimmune manifestations.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In all three siblings, we demonstrated the presence of anergic CD3 +</Disease>
<Disease>CD4-CD8- (double negative,</Disease>
<Disease>[DN])</Disease>

<Disease>T cells; moreover, a chronic lymphocyte activation was found, as demonstrated by the presence of high levels of HLA-DR expression on peripheral CD3 + cells and by the presence of high levels of serum activation markers such as soluble interleukin-2 receptor (slL-2R) and soluble CD30 (sCD30)..</Disease>
<Disease>Common BRCA1 variants and susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancer in the general population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Most multiple case families of young onset breast cancer and ovarian cancer are thought to be due to highly penetrant mutations in the predisposing genes BRCA1 and BRCA2.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>However, these mutations are uncommon in the population and they probably account for only a few percent of all breast cancer incidence.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A much larger fraction of breast cancer might, in principle, be due to common variants which confer more modest individual risks.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>There are several common polymorphisms in the BRCA1 gene which generate amino acid substitutions.</Disease>

<Disease>We have examined the frequency of four of these polymorphisms  Gln356Arg, Pro871Leu, Glu1038Gly and Ser1613Gly in large series of breast and ovarian cancer cases and matched controls.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Due to strong linkage disequilibrium, these four sites generate only three haplotypes with a frequency > 1. 3%.</Disease>
<Disease>The most common haplotypes, defined by the alleles Gln356Pro871Glu1038Ser1613 and Gln356Leu871Gly1038Gly1613, have frequencies of 0.</Disease>
<Disease>57 and 0. 32 respectively, and these frequencies do not differ significantly between patient and control groups.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus the most common polymorphisms of the BRCA1 gene do not make a significant contribution to breast or ovarian cancer risk.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, our data suggest that the Arg356 allele may have a different genotype distribution in breast cancer patients from that in controls (Arg356 homozygotes are more frequent in the control groups, P = 0. 01), indicating that it may be protective against breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>If this finding can be confirmed, it may provide an insight into the structural features of the BRCA1 protein that are important for its function.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutation of the VHL gene is associated exclusively with the development of non-papillary renal cell carcinomas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To define the possible role of the VHL gene in the development of sporadic renal cell carcinomas, 91 different parenchymal tumours of the kidney have been investigated for mutation of the VHL gene by single strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) and/or heteroduplex (HD) techniques.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Chromosome 3p deletion was detected in 98 per cent of non-papillary renal cell carcinomas and in 25 per cent of chromophobe renal cell carcinomas.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In 22 of the 43 non-papillary renal cell carcinomas, abnormally migrating DNA bands were detected by SSCP and/or HD analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No mobility shift was seen in any of the 23 chromophobe renal cell carcinomas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, 15 papillary renal cell tumours and ten renal oncocytomas, which are characterized by genetic changes other than loss of chromosome 3p sequences, were analysed for mutation of the VHL gene.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>None of these tumours showed abnormal migration patterns.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The results indicate that mutation of the VHL gene is associated exclusively with the development of non-papillary renal cell carcinoma..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Comparative genome mapping of the ataxia-telangiectasia region in mouse, rat, and Syrian hamster.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Chromosomal locations of the Atm (ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) -mutated) and Acat1 (mitochondrial acetoacetyl-CoA thiolase) genes in mouse, rat, and Syrian hamster were determined by direct R-banding FISH.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Both genes were colocalized to the C-D band of mouse chromosome 9, the proximal end of q24.</Disease>
<Disease>1 of rat chromosome 8, and qa4-qa5 of Syrian hamster chromosome 12.</Disease>
<Disease>The regions in the mouse and rat were homologous to human chromosome 11q.</Disease>
<Disease>Fine genetic linkage mapping of the mouse AT region was performed using the interspecific backcross mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Atm, Acat1, and Npat, which is a new gene isolated from the AT region, and 12 flanking microsatellite DNA markers were examined.</Disease>
<Disease>No recombinations were found among the Atm, Npat, Acat1, and D9Mit6 loci, and these loci were mapped 2. 0 cM distal to D9Mit99 and 1. 3 cM proximal to D9Mit102.</Disease>

<Disease>Comparison of the linkage map of mouse chromosome 9 (MMU9) and that of human chromosome 11 (HSA11) indicates that there is a chromosomal rearrangement due to an inversion between Ets1 and Atm-Npat-Acat1 and that the inversion of MMU9 originated from the chromosomal breakage at the boundary between Gria4 and Atm-Npat-Acat1 on HSA11.</Disease>
<Disease>This type of inversion appeared to be conserved in the three rodent species, mouse, rat, and Syrian hamster, using additional comparative mapping data with the Rck gene</Disease>
<Disease>Tumor suppression and apoptosis of human prostate carcinoma mediated by a genetic locus within human chromosome 10pter-q11.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Prostate cancer is the second leading cause of male cancer deaths in the United States.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Yet, despite a large international effort, little is known about the molecular mechanisms that underlie this devastating disease.</Disease>

<Disease>Prostate secretory epithelial cells and androgen-dependent prostate carcinomas undergo apoptosis in response to androgen deprivation and, furthermore, most prostate carcinomas become androgen independent and refractory to further therapeutic manipulations during disease progression.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Definition of the genetic events that trigger apoptosis in the prostate could provide important insights into critical pathways in normal development as well as elucidate the perturbations of those key pathways in neoplastic transformation.</Disease>

<Disease>We report the functional definition of a novel genetic locus within human chromosome 10pter-q11 that mediates both in vivo tumor suppression and in vitro apoptosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma cells.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A defined fragment of human chromosome 10 was transferred via microcell fusion into a prostate adenocarcinoma cell line.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Microcell hybrids containing only the region 10pter-q11 were suppressed for tumorigenicity following injection of microcell hybrids into nude mice.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, the complemented hybrids undergo programmed cell death in vitro via a mechanism that does not require nuclear localization of p53.</Disease>

<Disease>These data functionally define a novel genetic locus, designated PAC1, for prostate adenocarcinoma 1, involved in tumor suppression of human prostate carcinoma and furthermore strongly suggest that the cell death pathway can be functionally restored in prostatic adenocarcinoma..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Phenotypic and genotypic overlap between atelosteogenesis type 2 and diastrophic dysplasia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations in the diastrophic dysplasia sulfate transporter gene DTDST have been associated with a family of chondrodysplasias that comprises, in order of increasing severity, diastrophic dysplasia (DTD), atelosteogenesis type 2 (AO2), and achondrogenesis type 1B (ACG1B).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To learn more about the molecular basis of DTDST chondrodysplasias and about genotype-phenotype correlations, we studied fibroblast cultures of three new patients  one with AO-2, one with DTD, and one with an intermediate phenotype (AO2/DTD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Reduced incorporation of inorganic sulfate into macromolecules was found in all three.</Disease>
<Disease>Each of the three patients was found to be heterozygous for a c862t transition predicting a R279W substitution in the third extracellular loop of DTDST.</Disease>

<Disease>In two patients (DTD and AO2/DTD), no other structural mutation was found, but polymerase chain reaction amplification and single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis of fibroblast cDNA showed reduced mRNA levels of the wild-type DTDST allele  these two patients may be compound heterozygotes for the " Finnish " mutation (as yet uncharacterized at the DNA level), which causes reduced expression of DTDST.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The third patient (with AO2) had the R279W mutation compounded with a novel mutation, the deletion of cytosine 418 (delta c418), predicting a frameshift with premature termination.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Also the delta c418 allele was underrepresented in the cDNA, in accordance with previous observations that premature stop codons reduce mRNA levels.</Disease>
<Disease>The presence of the DTDST R279W mutation in a total of 11 patients with AO2 or DTD emphasizes the overlap between these conditions.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This mutation has not been found so far in 8 analyzed ACG1B patients, suggesting that it allows some residual activity of the sulfate transporter..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cloning of the homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase gene, the key enzyme of alkaptonuria in mouse.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We determined 48 amino acid residues from five peptides from the homogeneous monomer of homogentisate 1, 2-dioxygenase (HGO; E. C. 1. 13.</Disease>
<Disease>11. 15) of mouse liver.</Disease>
<Disease>After digestion with trypsin, peptides were separated by reversed phase chromatography and amino acid sequenced.</Disease>
<Disease>The deduced codon sequence of three peptides was used to derive degenerated oligomeres.</Disease>
<Disease>By combining these oligos, we were able to amplify fragments from 100 to 300 bases (b) from mouse liver cDNA by polymerase chain reaction after reverse transcription (RT-PCR).</Disease>
<Disease>A fragment of 200 b was cloned and used as a probe to screen a mouse liver cDNA library.</Disease>
<Disease>One clone from this library contained the complete cDNA-insert for HGO as determined by sequencing.</Disease>
<Disease>The cDNA encodes for a protein of 50 kDa, as predicted.</Disease>
<Disease>The cDNA of mouse HGO has an overall identity of 41% to the corresponding gene hmgA from Aspergillus.</Disease>
<Disease>Sequence similarities to human expressed sequence tags (EST) clones ranged from 70% to 20%.</Disease>
<Disease>The positions of 122 conserved amino acids could be determined by multiple sequence alignment.</Disease>
<Disease>We identified one first intron of 928 b in the mouse gene.</Disease>
<Disease>The gene for HGO seems to be expressed in various tissues, as shown by RT-PCR on different cDNAs.</Disease>
<Disease>FISH experiments with the whole murine cDNA as probe clearly revealed signals at the human chromosomal band 3q13.</Disease>
<Disease>3-q21.</Disease>
<Disease>This corresponds well to the previous assignment of the locus for the human alkaptonuria gene (AKU) to the same chromosomal region by multipoint linkage analysis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We therefore conclude that the HGO cDNA encodes the gene responsible for alkaptonuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Abnormal myotonic dystrophy protein kinase levels produce only mild myopathy in mice.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is commonly associated with CTG repeat expansions within the gene for DM-protein kinase (DMPK).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The effect of altered expression levels of DMPK, which is ubiquitously expressed in all muscle cell lineages during development, was examined by disrupting the endogenous Dmpk gene and overexpressing a normal human DMPK transgene in mice.</Disease>

<Disease>Nullizygous (-/-) mice showed only inconsistent and minor size changes in head and neck muscle fibres at older age, animals with the highest DMPK transgene expression showed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and enhanced neonatal mortality.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, both models lack other frequent DM symptoms including the fibre-type dependent atrophy, myotonia, cataract and male-infertility.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These results strengthen the contention that simple loss- or gain-of-expression of DMPK is not the only crucial requirement for development of the disease..</Disease>
<Disease>Molecular bases of combined subtotal deficiencies of C6 and C7: their effects in combination with other C6 and C7 deficiencies.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Combined subtotal deficiency of C6 and C7, in which both proteins are expressed at very low levels, has been observed in homozygous form in two families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A defect at the 5 splice donor site of intron 15 of the C6 gene explains the low molecular weight of the C6 protein and is probably responsible for its low expressed concentration.</Disease>
<Disease>The C7 defect is more enigmatic  the protein is of normal molecular weight, low circulating concentration, and altered isoelectric point.</Disease>
<Disease>An Arg > Ser codon substitution in exon 11 is the only molecular alteration within the mature C7 protein.</Disease>
<Disease>These defects are associated with a characteristic set of polymorphic DNA markers in the C6/C7 region, forming a distinct haplotype.</Disease>
<Disease>The haplotype has been found in combination with a number of other haplotypes containing defective genes that lead either to C6 or C7 deficiency, but with different consequences.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Where it is combined with a C6-deficient gene, the serum C7 levels can be surprisingly high, possibly because there is no C6 generating C56 to consume the C7.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, where the C7 genes are both defective (but still partially functional), there may be a profound deficit of circulating C7 because there is ample C6 to produce C56 and consume the already small amount of C7.</Disease>
<Disease>Each molecular defect has also been found in isolation and has the expected effect..</Disease>
<Disease>Constitutively methylated CpG dinucleotides as mutation hot spots in the retinoblastoma gene (RB1).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A wide spectrum of mutations, ranging from point mutations to large deletions, have been described in the retinoblastoma gene (RB1).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations have been found throughout the gene; however, these genetic alterations do not appear to be homogeneously distributed.</Disease>

<Disease>In particular, a significant proportion of disease-causing mutations results in the premature termination of protein synthesis, and the majority of these mutations occur as C-- > T transitions at CpG dinucleotides (CpGs).</Disease>
<Disease>Such recurrent CpG mutations, including those found in RB1, are likely the result of the deamination of 5-methylcytosine within these CpGs.</Disease>
<Disease>In the present study, we used the sodiumbisulfite conversion method to detect cytosine methylation in representative exons of RB1.</Disease>
<Disease>We analyzed DNA from a variety of tissues and specifically targeted CGA codons in RB1, where recurrent premature termination mutations have been reported.</Disease>
<Disease>We found that DNA methylation within RB1 exons 8, 14, 25, and 27 appeared to be restricted to CpGs, including six CGA codons.</Disease>
<Disease>Other codons containing methylated cytosines have not been reported to be mutated.</Disease>

<Disease>Therefore, disease-causing mutations at CpGs in RB1 appear to be determined by several factors, including the constitutive presence of DNA methylation at cytosines within CpGs, the specific codon within which the methylated cytosine is located, and the particular region of the gene within which that codon resides..</Disease>
<Disease>The TSG101 tumor susceptibility gene is located in chromosome 11 band p15 and is mutated in human breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Recent work has identified a mouse gene (tsg101) whose inactivation in fibroblasts results in cellular transformation and the ability to produce metastatic tumors in nude mice.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here, we report that the human homolog, TSG101, which we isolated and mapped to chromosome 11, bands 15.</Disease>
<Disease>1-15 1-15. 2, a region proposed to contain tumor suppressor gene (s), is mutated at high frequency in human breast cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In 7 of 15 uncultured primary human breast carcinomas, intragenic deletions were shown in TSG101 genomic DNA and transcripts by gel and sequence analysis, and mutations affecting two TSG101 alleles were identified in four of these cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>No TSG101 defects were found in matched normal breast tissue from the breast cancer patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These findings strongly implicate TSG101 mutations in human breast cancer</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy protein, emerin, is a nuclear membrane protein.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A large fragment of emerin cDNA was prepared by PCR and expressed as a recombinant protein in Escherichia coli.</Disease>

<Disease>Using this as immunogen, we prepared a panel of 12 monoclonal antibodies which recognise at least four different epitopes on emerin in order to ensure that emerin can be distinguished from non-specific cross-reacting proteins.</Disease>
<Disease>All the mAbs recognised a 34 kDa protein in all tissues tested, though minor emerin-related bands were also detected in some tissues.</Disease>
<Disease>Immunofluorescence microscopy showed that emerin is located at the nuclear rim in all tissues examined.</Disease>

<Disease>A muscle biopsy from an Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EMDM) patient showed complete absence of emerin by both Western blotting and immunohistochemistry, suggesting a simple diagnostic antibody test for EDMD families.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Biochemical fractionation of brain and liver tissues showed that emerin was present in nuclei purified by centrifugation through 65% sucrose and was absent from soluble fractions (post-100, 000 g).</Disease>

<Disease>From these results, together with sequence and structural homologies between emerin, thymopoietins and the nuclear lamina-associated protein, LAP2, we suggest that emerin will prove to be one member of a family of inner nuclear membrane proteins..</Disease>
<Disease>Influence of PAX6 gene dosage on development: overexpression causes severe eye abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Aniridia in man and Small eye in mice are semidominant developmental disorders caused by mutations within the paired box gene PAX6.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Whereas heterozygotes suffer from iris hypoplasia, homozygous mice lack eyes and nasal cavities and exhibit brain abnormalities.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To investigate the role of gene dosage in more detail, we have generated yeast artificial chromosome transgenic mice carrying the human PAX6 locus.</Disease>
<Disease>When crossed onto the Small eye background, the transgene rescues the mutant phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>Strikingly, mice carrying multiple copies on a wild-type background show specific developmental abnormalities of the eye, but not of other tissues expressing the gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, at least five different eye phenotypes are associated with changes in PAX6 expression.</Disease>
<Disease>We provide evidence that not only reduced, but also increased levels of transcriptional regulators can cause developmental defects..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Founding BRCA1 mutations in hereditary breast and ovarian cancer in southern Sweden.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Nine different germ-line mutations in the BRCA1 breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility gene were identified in 15 of 47 kindreds from southern Sweden, by use of SSCP and heteroduplex analysis of all exons and flanking intron region and by a protein-truncation test for exon 11, followed by direct sequencing.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>All but one of the mutations are predicted to give rise to premature translation termination and include seven frameshift insertions or deletions, a nonsense mutation, and a splice acceptor site mutation.</Disease>
<Disease>The remaining mutation is a missense mutation (Cys61Gly) in the zinc-binding motif.</Disease>

<Disease>Four novel Swedish founding mutations were identified  the nucleotide 2595 deletion A was found in five families, the C 1806 T nonsense mutation in three families, the 3166 insertion TGAGA in three families, and the nucleotide 1201 deletion 11 in two families.</Disease>
<Disease>Analysis of the intragenic polymorphism D17S855 supports common origins of the mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>Eleven of the 15 kindreds manifesting BRCA1 mutations were breast-ovarian cancer families, several of them with a predominant ovarian cancer phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The set of 32 families in which no BRCA1 alterations were detected included 1 breast-ovarian cancer kindred manifesting clear linkage to the BRCA1 region and loss of the wild-type chromosome in associated tumors.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Other tumor types found in BRCA1 mutation/haplotype carriers included prostatic, pancreas, skin, and lung cancer, a malignant melanoma, an oligodendroglioma, and a carcinosarcoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In all, 12 of 16 kindreds manifesting BRCA1 mutation or linkage contained ovarian cancer, as compared with only 6 of the remaining 31 families (P <. 001).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The present study confirms the involvement of BRCA1 in disease predisposition for a subset of hereditary breast cancer families often characterized by ovarian cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The DCC protein and prognosis in colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BACKGROUND  Allelic loss of chromosome 18q predicts a poor outcome in patients with stage II colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although the specific gene inactivated by this allelic loss has not been elucidated, the DCC (deleted in colorectal cancer) gene is a candidate.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We investigated whether the expression of the DCC protein in tumor cells is a prognostic marker in colorectal carcinoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>METHODS  The expression of DCC was evaluated immunohistochemically in 132 paraffin-embedded samples from patients with curatively resected stage II and III colorectal carcinomas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Cox proportional-hazards model was used to adjust for covariates including age, sex, tumor site, degree of tumor differentiation, and use of adjuvant therapy.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>RESULTS  The expression of DCC was a strong positive predictive factor for survival in both stage II and stage III colorectal carcinomas.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In patients with stage II disease whose tumors expressed DCC, the five-year survival rate was 94.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>3 percent, whereas in patients with DCC-negative tumors, the survival rate was 61. 6 percent (P < 0. 001).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In patients with stage III disease, the respective survival rates were 59. 3 percent and 33. 2 percent (P = 0. 03).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>CONCLUSIONS  DCC is a prognostic marker in patients with stage II or stage III colorectal cancer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In stage II colorectal carcinomas, the absence of DCC identifies a subgroup of patients with lesions that behave like stage III cancers.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These findings may thus have therapeutic implications in this group of patients</Disease>
<Disease>Gene therapy for phenylketonuria.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Classical phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Limitations of the current dietary treatment for PKU have led to the development of potential treatments based on somatic gene transfer.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Three different vector systems have been examined.</Disease>

<Disease>Vectors derived from a recombinant retrovirus or a DNA/protein complex can efficiently transduce the PAH cDNA into PAH-deficient hepatocytes in vitro, but the application of these vector systems is presently limited by their low transduction efficiency in vivo.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In contrast, a vector derived from a recombinant adenovirus can restore 10% -80% of normal hepatic PAH activity into PAH-deficient mice, which completely normalizes serum phenylalanine levels.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This treatment is transient and cannot be effectively re-administered due to the presence of neutralizing antibodies directed against the recombinant adenoviral vector.</Disease>
<Disease>However, these findings suggest that PKU can be completely corrected by somatic gene therapy, and provide some direction for the future development of adenoviral vectors..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Identification of a RING protein that can interact in vivo with the BRCA1 gene product.</Disease>

<Disease>The hereditary breast and ovarian cancer gene, BRCA1, encodes a large polypeptide that contains the cysteine-rich RING motif, a zinc-binding domain found in a variety of regulatory proteins.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Here we describe a novel protein that interacts in vivo with the N-terminal region of BRCA1.</Disease>

<Disease>This BRCA1-associated RING domain (BARD1) protein contains an N-terminal RING motif, three tandem ankyrin repeats, and a C-terminal sequence with significant homology to the phylogenetically conserved BRCT domains that lie near the C terminus of BRCA1.</Disease>

<Disease>The BARD1/BRCA1 interaction is disrupted by BRCA1 missense mutations that segregate with breast cancer susceptibility, indicating that BARD1 may be involved in mediating tumour suppression by BRCA1..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: no strict genotype-phenotype correlations but clustering of missense mutations in the amino-terminal part of the WASP gene product.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) gene was found to be mutated in patients presenting with WAS and in patients showing X-linked thrombocytopenia.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Mutation analysis in 19 families of German, Swiss and Turkish descent by single-strand conformation polymorphism and sequencing resulted in the detection of seven novel and 10 known mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>A striking clustering of missense mutations in the first four exons contrasted with a random distribution of nonsense mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>More than 85% of all known missense mutations were localized in the amino-terminal stretch of the WASP gene product; this region contained a mutational hot spot at codon 86.</Disease>
<Disease>No genotype-phenotype correlation emerged after a comparison of the identified mutations with the resulting clinical picture for a classical WAS phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A substitution at codon 86 resulted in an extremely variable expression of the disease in a large Swiss family.</Disease>

<Disease>An extended homology search revealed a distant relationship of this stretch to the vasodilator-stimulated phosphoprotein (VASP), which is involved in the maintenance of cyto-architecture by interacting with actin-like filaments..</Disease>

<Disease>Autosomal dominant primary hyperparathyroidism and jaw tumor syndrome associated with renal hamartomas and cystic kidney disease: linkage to 1q21-q32 and loss of the wild type allele in renal hamartomas.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hereditary hyperparathyroidism-jaw tumor syndrome (HPT-JT) is an autosomal dominant disease (OMIM 145001) that has recently been mapped to chromosomal region 1q21-q32 (HRPT2).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here we report two families with HPT-JT syndrome in which adult renal hamartomas or cystic kidney disease were prominent associated features, possibly representing a new phenotypic variant of the HPT-JT syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the first family, renal lesions were present in five out of six affected individuals, whereas HPT and JT were seen in four and two cases, respectively.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In the second family, JT was found in three of the five affected individuals and two affected members also exhibited polycystic kidney disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The possibility of the latter cosegregating as a separate autosomal dominant gene can not be ruled out.</Disease>
<Disease>A sex-dependent penetrance of primary HPT, resulting in predominantly male-affected cases was evident in the two families.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Twenty microsatellite markers in the HRPT2 region were typed, in addition to markers in the multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) types 1 and 2 regions at 11q13 and 10q11.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The disease in these two kindreds was linked to five markers in the 1q21-q32 region (logarithm-of-odds scores  3. 2-4 2-4. 2), whereas linkage to the MEN1 and MEN2 regions was excluded.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Meiotic recombinations detected in affected individuals placed the locus telomeric of D1S215, thus narrowing the HRPT2 region from > 60 to approximately 34 centimorgans.</Disease>

<Disease>Loss of heterozygosity was studied in seven renal hamartomas from two affected individuals in the first family, as well as in a jaw tumor and a parathyroid tumor from the second family.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>All renal hamartomas showed loss of heterozygosity at the 1q21-q32 region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The losses invariably involved the wild type allele derived from the unaffected parent, suggesting the inactivation of a tumor suppressor gene in this region</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Heterodimer formation and activity in the human enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase.</Disease>

<Disease>One of the fundamental questions concerning expression and function of dimeric enzymes involves the impact of naturally occurring mutations on subunit assembly and heterodimer activity.</Disease>

<Disease>This question is of particular interest for the human enzyme galactose-l-phosphate uridylyl-transferase (GALT), impairment of which results in the inherited metabolic disorder galactosemia, because many if not most patients studied to date are compound heterozygotes rather than true molecular homozygotes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Furthermore, the broad range of phenotypic severity observed in these patients raises the possibility that allelic combination, not just allelic constitution, may play some role in determining outcome.</Disease>

<Disease>In the work described herein, we have selected two distinct naturally occurring null mutations of GALT, Q188R and R333W, and asked the questions (i) what are the impacts of these mutations on subunit assembly, and (ii) if heterodimers do form, are they active ?</Disease>

<Disease>To answer these questions, we have established a yeast system for the coexpression of epitope-tagged alleles of human GALT and investigated both the extent of specific GALT subunit interactions and the activity of defined heterodimer pools.</Disease>
<Disease>We have found that both homodimers and heterodimers do form involving each of the mutant subunits tested and that both heterodimer pools retain substantial enzymatic activity.</Disease>

<Disease>These results are significant not only in terms of their implications for furthering our understanding of galactosemia and GALT holoenzyme structure-function relationships but also because the system described may serve as a model for similar studies of other complexes composed of multiple subunits..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BRCA1 R841W: a strong candidate for a common mutation with moderate phenotype.</Disease>
<Disease>BRCA1 mutations cause increased risk for breast and ovarian cancer, frequently of early onset.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Many different mutations occur in BRCA1, including several examples of recurrent mutations, each of which accounts for a significant number of families with heritable cancer predisposition.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These common mutations have an etiological role in many breast and ovarian cancer cases and provide the opportunity to examine genotype-phenotype correlations and genotype-environment interactions in individuals with the identical BRCA1 lesion.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report a novel missense change in BRCA1, 2640 C-- > T (R841W), found in 3 cases from a subject group of 305 breast and 79 ovarian cancer cases from Orange County, CA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>These are consecutive, population-based cases not selected for age or family history.</Disease>

<Disease>In all three cases, there is a strong family history of breast, ovarian, or other cancers possibly related to a BRCA1 defect and family members showed a high concordance of cancer incidence with the presence of R841W. The age of cancer onset was not always distinct from typical sporadic cases.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Testing of a sample of 413 unrelated individuals to examine the hypothesis that R841W might be a rare polymorphism detected one additional instance in a woman with breast cancer diagnosed at age 77 years, and cancer in one parent.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>R841W is likely to be an etiologically significant lesion with involvement in close to 1% (95% confidence interval of 0-1. 7%) of all breast and ovarian cancers in this population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Independent origin of single and double mutations in the human glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase gene.</Disease>
<Disease>The vast majority of both polymorphic and sporadic G6PD variants are due to single missense mutations.</Disease>

<Disease>In the four polymorphic variants that have two point mutations, one of the mutations is always 376 A-- > G (126 Asn-- > Asp), which on its own gives rise to the nondeficient polymorphic variant, G6PD A. In a study of G6PD deficient patients who presented with clinical favism in Spain, we have found a new polymorphic variant that we have called G6PD Malaga, whose only abnormality is a 542 A-- > T (181 Asp-- > Val) mutation.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This is the same mutation as previously found in association with the mutation of G6PD A in the double mutant, G6PD Santamaria. G6PD Malaga is associated with enzyme deficiency (class III), and the enzymic properties of G6PD Malaga and G6PD Santamaria are quite similar, indicating that in this case the effects of the two mutations are additive rather than synergistic.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>G6PD Santamaria might have been produced by recombination between G6PD A and G6PD Malaga; however haplotype analysis, including the use of a new silent polymorphism, suggests that the same 542 A-- > T mutation has taken place independently in a G6PD B gene to give G6PD Malaga and in a G6PD A gene to give G6PD Santamaria.</Disease>
<Disease>These findings help to outline the relationship and evolution of mutations in the human G6PD locus..</Disease>
<Disease>FISH studies in a patient with sporadic aniridia and t(7;11) (q31.2;p13).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A 2 year old female presenting with bilateral sporadic aniridia was found to have an apparently balanced reciprocal translocation with a chromosome 11 breakpoint within band p13.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH) studies with distal 11p13 specific cosmids showed that the chromosome 11 breakpoint lay between the aniridia (PAX6) locus and a region approximately 100 kb distal to PAX6 defined by the cosmid FO2121.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although this patient did not have a detectable deletion within PAX6, her aniridia may have resulted from a disruption of the distal chromatin domain containing either enhancers or regulators for PAX6.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This case may therefore be another example of aniridia caused by a position effect as recently described in two familial aniridia patients in which the phenotype cosegregated with chromosome abnormalities with 11p13 breakpoints..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Ovarian cancer risk in BRCA1 carriers is modified by the HRAS1 variable number of tandem repeat (VNTR) locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Women who carry a mutation in the BRCA1 gene (on chromosome 17q21), have an 80% risk of breast cancer and a 40% risk of ovarian cancer by the age of 70 (ref. 1).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The variable penetrance of BRCA1 suggests that other genetic and non-genetic factors play a role in tumourigenesis in these individuals.</Disease>
<Disease>The HRAS1 variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) polymorphism, located 1 kilobase (kb) downstream of the HRAS1 proto-oncogene (chromosome 11p15.</Disease>
<Disease>5) is one possible genetic modifier of cancer penetrance.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Individuals who have rare alleles of the VNTR have an increased risk of certain types of cancers, including breast cancer (2-4).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>To investigate whether the presence of rare HRAS1 alleles increases susceptibility to hereditary breast and ovarian cancer, we have typed a panel of 307 female BRCA1 carriers at this locus using a PCR-based technique.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The risk for ovarian cancer was 2. 11 times greater for BRCA1 carriers harbouring one or two rare HRAS1 alleles, compared to carriers with only common alleles (P = 0. 015).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The magnitude of the relative risk associated with a rare HRAS1 allele was not altered by adjusting for the other known risk factors for hereditary ovarian cancer (5).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Susceptibility to breast cancer did not appear to be affected by the presence of rare HRAS1 alleles.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This study is the first to show the effect of a modifying gene on the penetrance of an inherited cancer syndrome</Disease>

text: <Disease>A previously undescribed mutation within the tetramerisation domain of TP53 in a family with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We report details of a family with classic Li-Fraumeni syndrome in which there is a mutation in codon 344 of the tumour suppressor gene TP53.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Codon 344 is a key residue within the tetramerisation domain, and the amino acid substitution of a proline for a leucine is predicted to have profound implications for tetramerisation and potentially DNA binding.</Disease>
<Disease>This is the first report of a mutation at this residue in either sporadic tumours or in the germline and the first report of a germline mutation within the tetramerisation domain.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The family does not appear to be remarkable in the spectrum of tumours, and there is loss of the wild-type allele in a leiomyosarcoma from the proband.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A cell line has been established from the tumour of the proband and cytogenetic and molecular studies carried out, providing an extensive analysis in this family..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Trinucleotide repeat expansion at the myotonic dystrophy locus reduces expression of DMAHP.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Myotonic dystrophy, or dystrophia myotonica (DM), is an autosomal dominant multisystem disorder caused by the expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat in the 3 untranslated region of the DMPK protein kinase gene on chromosome 19q13.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>3 (refs 1-3).</Disease>

<Disease>Although the DM mutation was identified more than five years ago, the pathogenic mechanisms underlying this most prevalent form of hereditary adult neuromuscular disease remain elusive.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Previous work from our laboratory demonstrated that a DNase l-hypersensitive site located adjacent to the repeats on the wild-type allele is eliminated by repeat expansion, indicating that large CTG-repeat arrays may be associated with a local chromatin environment that represses gene expression.</Disease>
<Disease>Here we report that the hypersensitive site contains an enhancer element that regulates transcription of the adjacent DMAHP homeobox gene.</Disease>

<Disease>Analysis of DMAHP expression in the cells of DM patients with loss of the hypersensitive site revealed a two- to fourfold reduction in steady-state DMAHP transcript levels relative to wild-type controls.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Allele-specific analysis of DMAHP expression showed that steady-state transcript levels from the expanded allele were greatly reduced in comparison to those from the wild-type allele.</Disease>
<Disease>Together, these results demonstrate that CTG-repeat expansions can suppress local gene expression and implicate DMAHP in DM pathogenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A mutation in autosomal dominant myotonia congenita affects pore properties of the muscle chloride channel.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Autosomal dominant myotonia congenita is an inherited disorder of skeletal muscle caused by mutations in a voltage-gated Cl- channel gene (CLCN1, 7q35).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Here, we report that a mutation predicting the substitution of Gly 230 by glutamic acid (G230E) between segments D3 and D4 dramatically alters the pore properties of a recombinant human muscle Cl- channel (hCIC-1) expressed in a mammalian cell line (tsA201).</Disease>
<Disease>The G230E mutation causes substantial changes in anion and cation selectivity as well as a fundamental change in rectification of the current-voltage relationship.</Disease>
<Disease>Whereas wild-type channels are characterized by pronounced inward rectification and a Cl > thiocyanate ></Disease>
<Disease>Br ></Disease>
<Disease>NO (3) ></Disease>
<Disease>I > CH (3) SO (3) selectivity, G230E exhibits outward rectification at positive potentials and a thiocyanate ></Disease>
<Disease>NO (3) ></Disease>
<Disease>I ></Disease>
<Disease>Br > Cl > CH (3) SO (3) selectivity.</Disease>
<Disease>Furthermore, the cation-to-anion permeability ratio of the mutant is much greater than that of the wild-type channel.</Disease>
<Disease>Voltage-dependent blocks by intracellular and extracellular iodide help to distinguish two distinct ion binding sites within the hClC-1 conduction pathway.</Disease>
<Disease>Both binding sites are preserved in the mutant but have decreased affinities for iodide.</Disease>
<Disease>These findings suggest that Gly 230 is critical for normal ion conductance in hClC-1 and that this residue resides within the channel pore..</Disease>
<Disease>Mutation analysis of BRCA1 and BRCA2 in a male breast cancer population.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A population-based series of 54 male breast cancer cases from Southern California were analyzed for germ-line mutations in the inherited breast/ovarian cancer genes, BRCA1 and BRCA2.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Nine (17%) of the patients had a family history of breast and/or ovarian cancer in at least one first-degree relative.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A further seven (13%) of the patients reported breast/ovarian cancer in at least one second-degree relative and in no first-degree relatives.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>No germ-line BRCA1 mutations were found.</Disease>
<Disease>Two male breast cancer patients (4% of the total) were found to carry novel truncating mutations in the BRCA2 gene.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Only one of the two male breast cancer patients carrying a BRCA2 mutation had a family history of cancer, with one case of ovarian cancer in a first-degree relative.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The remaining eight cases (89%) of male breast cancer with a family history of breast/ovarian cancer in first-degree relatives remain unaccounted for by mutations in either the BRCA1 gene or the BRCA2 gene..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Expression of the von Hippel-Lindau disease tumour suppressor gene during human embryogenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease product is thought to down-regulate transcription by antagonizing elongin-enhanced transcriptional elongation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Germline VHL gene mutations predispose to the development of retinal, cerebellar and spinal haemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma and phaeochromocytoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In addition, somatic Inactivation of the VHL gene is frequent in sporadic renal cell carcinoma and haemangioblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Regulation of transcript elongation is an important control mechanism for gene expression and the VHL gene might modify the expression of proto-oncogenes and growth suppressor genes during embryogenesis.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We therefore investigated the expression of VHL mRNA during human embryogenesis by in situ hybridization studies at 4, 6 and 10 weeks post conception.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Although VHL mRNA was expressed in all three germ layers, strong expression was noted in the central nervous system, kidneys, testis and lung.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Within the kidney, VHL mRNA was differentially expressed within renal tubules suggesting that the VHL gene product may have a specific role in kidney development.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Two alternatively spliced VHL mRNAs characterized by inclusion (isoform I) or exclusion (isoform II) of exon 2 are transcribed in adult tissues.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To investigate if the two isoforms are differentially expressed during embryogenesis, VHL mRNA was reverse transcribed from 13 fetal tissues (8-10 weeks gestation).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The quantitative distribution of VHL mRNA within fetal tissues reflected that seen by in situ hybridization and the ratio of the two VHL isoforms was similar between tissues.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Although the genes regulated by the VHL gene product have not yet been identified, our findings are compatible with the hypothesis that VHL-mediated control of transcriptional elongation may have a role in normal human development..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Screening for ESR mutations in breast and ovarian cancer patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the present study, leukocyte DNA from 143 patients with familial clustering of breast and/or ovarian cancer and tumour DNA from 96 breast carcinomas were screened for base mutations in the estrogen receptor gene (ESR).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Three patients with a family history of cancer were carrying a Gly160Cys germline substitution.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This alteration was also detected in eight (four females and four males) of 729 controls (366 female, 363 males), indicating that the substitution probably represents a polymorphism.</Disease>
<Disease>However, in the 229 female controls in whom family history of cancer was known, one of two who had a sister with breast cancer was carrying the variant allele.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Hence, a possible clinical significance of the glycine into cysteine cannot be completely ruled out and should be further investigated.</Disease>

<Disease>Somatic mutations were not detected in any of the tumours studied, and the present data do not provide support for somatic ESR base mutations as an important mechanism for hormonal therapy resistance in estrogen receptor-positive breast carcinomas..</Disease>
label: Disease
