text: <Disease>Increased coronary heart disease in Japanese-American men with mutation in the cholesteryl ester transfer protein gene despite increased HDL levels.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Plasma high density lipoprotein (HDL) levels are strongly genetically determined and show a general inverse relationship with coronary heart disease (CHD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) mediates the transfer of cholesteryl esters from HDL to other lipoproteins and is a key participant in the reverse transport of cholesterol from the periphery to the liver.</Disease>

<Disease>A high prevalence of two different CETP gene mutations (D442G, 5. 1%; intron 14G  A, 0. 5%), was found in 3, 469 men of Japanese ancestry in the Honolulu Heart Program and mutations were associated with decreased CETP (-35%) and increased HDL chol levels (+ 10% for D442G).</Disease>
<Disease>However, the overall prevalence of definite CHD was 21% in men with mutations and 16% in men without mutations.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The relative risk (RR) of CHD was 1. 43 in men with mutations (P <. 05); after adjustment for CHD risk factors, the RR was 1. 55 (P =. 02); after additional adjustment for HDL levels, the RR was 1.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>68 (P =. 008).</Disease>
<Disease>Similar RR values were obtained for the D442G mutation alone.</Disease>
<Disease>Increased CHD in men with mutations was primarily observed for HDL chol 41-60 mg/dl; for HDL chol > 60 mg/dl men with and without mutations had low CHD prevalence.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Thus, genetic CETP deficiency appears to be an independent risk factor for CHD, primarily due to increased CHD prevalence in men with the D442G mutation and HDL cholesterol between 41 and 60 mg/dl.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The findings suggest that both HDL concentration and the dynamics of cholesterol transport through HDL (i. e., reverse cholesterol transport) determine the anti-atherogenicity of the HDL fraction.</Disease>
<Disease>Analysis of meiotic segregation, using single-sperm typing: meiotic drive at the myotonic dystrophy locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Meiotic drive at the myotonic dystrophy (DM) locus has recently been suggested as being responsible for maintaining the frequency, in the human population, of DM chromosomes capable of expansion to the disease state.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In order to test this hypothesis, we have studied samples of single sperm from three individuals heterozygous at the DM locus, each with one allele larger and one allele smaller than 19 CTG repeats.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>To guard against the possible problem of differential PCR amplification rates based on the lengths of the alleles, the sperm were also typed at another closely linked marker whose allele size was unrelated to the allele size at the DM locus.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Using statistical models specifically designed to study single-sperm segregation data, we find no evidence of meiotic segregation distortion.</Disease>
<Disease>The upper limit of the two-sided 95% confidence interval for the estimate of the common segregation probability for the three donors is at or below.</Disease>
<Disease>515 for all models considered, and no statistically significant difference from. 5 is detected in any of the models.</Disease>
<Disease>This suggests that any greater amount of segregation distortion at the myotonic dystrophy locus must result from events following sperm ejaculation.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Isolation of full-length ATM cDNA and correction of the ataxia-telangiectasia cellular phenotype.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A gene mutated in the human genetic disorder ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), ATM, was recently identified by positional cloning.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>ATM is a member of the phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase superfamily, some of which are protein kinases and appear to have important roles in cell cycle control and radiation signal transduction.</Disease>

<Disease>We describe herein, to our knowledge, for the first time, the cloning of a full-length cDNA for ATM and correction of multiple aspects of the radio-sensitive phenotype of A-T cells by transfection with this cDNA.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Overexpression of ATM cDNA in A-T cells enhanced the survival of these cells in response to radiation exposure, decreased radiation-induced chromosome aberrations, reduced radio-resistant DNA synthesis, and partially corrected defective cell cycle checkpoints and induction of stress-activated protein kinase.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This correction of the defects in A-T cells provides further evidence of the multiplicity of effector functions of the ATM protein and suggests possible approaches to gene therapy..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The spectrum of RB1 germ-line mutations in hereditary retinoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have searched for germ-line RB1 mutations in 119 patients with hereditary retinoblastoma.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Previous investigations by Southern blot hybridization and PCR fragment-length analysis had revealed mutations in 48 patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Here we report on the analysis of the remaining 71 patients.</Disease>

<Disease>By applying heteroduplex analysis, nonisotopic SSCP, and direct sequencing, we detected germ-line mutations resulting in premature termination codons or disruption of splice signals in 51 (72%) of the 71 patients.</Disease>
<Disease>Four patients also showed rare sequence variants.</Disease>
<Disease>No region of the RB1 gene was preferentially involved in single base substitutions.</Disease>
<Disease>Recurrent transitions were observed at most of the 14 codons within the RB1.</Disease>
<Disease>No mutation was observed in exons 25-27, although this region contains two CGA codons.</Disease>
<Disease>This suggests that mutations within the 3-terminal region of the RB1 gene may not be oncogenic.</Disease>
<Disease>When these data were combined with the results of our previous investigations, mutations were identified in a total of 99 (83%) of 119 patients.</Disease>
<Disease>The spectrum comprises 15% large deletions, 26% small length alterations, and 42% base substitutions.</Disease>

<Disease>No correlation between the location of frameshift or nonsense mutations and phenotypic features, including age at diagnosis, the number of tumor foci, and manifestation of nonocular tumors was observed..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein, a novel effector for the GTPase CDC42Hs, is implicated in actin polymerization.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The Rho family of GTPases control diverse biological processes, including cell morphology and mitogenesis.</Disease>
<Disease>We have identified WASP, the protein that is defective in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), as a novel effector for CDC42Hs, but not for the other Rho family members, Rac and Rho.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This interaction is dependent on the presence of the G protein-binding domain.</Disease>
<Disease>Cellular expression of epitope-tagged WASP produces clusters of WASP that are highly enriched in polymerized actin.</Disease>

<Disease>This clustering is not observed with a C-terminally deleted WASP and is inhibited by coexpression with dominant negative CDC42Hs-N17, but not with dominant negative forms of Rac or Rho.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, WASP provides a novel link between CDC42Hs and the actin cytoskeleton, which suggests a molecular mechanism for many of the cellular abnormalities in WAS.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The WASP sequence contains two novel domains that are homologous to other proteins involved in action organization..</Disease>
<Disease>Adult onset globoid cell leukodystrophy (Krabbe disease): analysis of galactosylceramidase cDNA from four Japanese patients.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We examined galactosylceramidase (GALC) cDNA in four Japanese patients with adult onset globoid cell leukodystrophy (Krabbe disease; AO-GLD) by polymerase chain reaction/single-strand conformation polymorphism (PCR-SSCP) analysis, subsequent sequence determination, and restriction enzyme digestion of PCR products, initial symptoms were the onset of slowly progressive spastic paraplegia from the middle of the second decade, and all patients had diminished GALC activity in their leukocytes.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We identified three missense mutations (I66M, G270D, L618S) and one exon-6 skipping (535-573del).</Disease>
<Disease>Two of the patients had only the I66M mutant mRNA, and one only the G27OD mutant mRNA.</Disease>

<Disease>The fourth patient carried a compound heterozygous mutation of 535-573del and L618S. To determine the enzymatic activities produced by these mutations, we constructed mutated GALC cDNAs and expressed them in COS-1 cells.</Disease>
<Disease>Three mutations, viz., G270D, L618S, and exon-6 skipping (535-573del), produced diminished GALC activity as expected.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The I66M mutation in the wild-type GALC cDNA (I289) had normal activity, but when this mutation and the V289 polymorphism were introduced into the same allele, it had decreased activity.</Disease>
<Disease>Thus, the combination of a unique mutation and polymorphism causes conformational change in the GALC enzyme, resulting in low enzymatic activity.</Disease>

<Disease>AO-GLD mutations, including those found here, are located in the N-terminus (I66M, G270D, 535-573del) or C-terminus (L618S) of the GALC enzyme, whereas the reported mutations in the infantile form (IF-GLD) are in the central domain.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>This difference in mutation sites may affect the clinical features of GLD.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>BRCA1 is secreted and exhibits properties of a granin.</Disease>
<Disease>Germline mutations in BRCA1 are responsible for most cases of inherited breast and ovarian cancer .</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, the function of the BRCA1 protein has remained elusive.</Disease>
<Disease>We now show that BRCA1 encodes a 190-kD protein with sequence homology and biochemical analogy to the granin protein family.</Disease>
<Disease>Interestingly, BRCA2 also includes a motif similar to the granin consensus at the C terminus of the protein.</Disease>
<Disease>Both BRCA1 and the granins localize to secretory vesicles, are secreted by a regulated pathway, are post-translationally glycosylated and are responsive to hormones.</Disease>
<Disease>As a regulated secretory protein, BRCA1 appears to function by a mechanism not previously described for tumour suppressor gene products..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Insulin gene region contributes to genetic susceptibility to, but may not to low incidence of, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus in Japanese.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the Caucasian population, it has been demonstrated that the insulin gene (INS) region contains the insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus locus (IDDM2).</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>In the Japanese population, however, there has been no report demonstrating the contribution of IDDM2 to the pathogenesis of IDDM.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We conducted an association study of IDDM in a large number of Japanese subjects with multiple polymorphisms in INS region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We found a significant association of the INS region with IDDM.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Alleles positively associated with IDDM in INS region were the same as those positively-associated with IDDM in Caucasian population, although positively-associated alleles are very common (allele frequencies > 0. 9) in the Japanese general population.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>These data suggest that IDDM2 is involved in the genetic susceptibility to IDDM in Japanese.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The high frequencies of disease-associated alleles in the general population suggest that IDDM2 locus is not responsible for the low incidence of IDDM in Japanese.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Association of anxiety-related traits with a polymorphism in the serotonin transporter gene regulatory region.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Transporter-facilitated uptake of serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine or 5-HT) has been implicated in anxiety in humans and animal models and is the site of action of widely used uptake-inhibiting antidepressant and antianxiety drugs.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Human 5-HT transporter (5-HTT) gene transcription is modulated by a common polymorphism in its upstream regulatory region.</Disease>
<Disease>The short variant of the polymorphism reduces the transcriptional efficiency of the 5-HTT gene promoter, resulting in decreased 5-HTT expression and 5-HT uptake in lymphoblasts.</Disease>

<Disease>Association studies in two independent samples totaling 505 individuals revealed that the 5-HTT polymorphism accounts for 3 to 4 percent of total variation and 7 to 9 percent of inherited variance in anxiety-related personality traits in individuals as well as sibships..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Cloning and characterization of human very-long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase cDNA, chromosomal assignment of the gene and identification in four patients of nine different mutations within the VLCAD gene.</Disease>

<Disease>Very-long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (VLCAD) is one of four straight-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (ACD) enzymes, which are all nuclear encoded mitochondrial flavoproteins catalyzing the initial step in fatty acid beta-oxidation.</Disease>
<Disease>We have used the very fast, Rapid Amplification of cDNA Ends (RACE) based strategy to obtain the sequence of cDNAs encoding human VLCAD from placenta and fibroblasts.</Disease>
<Disease>Alignment of the predicted amino acid sequence of human VLCAD with those of the other human ACD enzymes revealed extensive sequence homology.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, human VLCAD and human acyl-CoA oxidase showed extensive sequence homology corroborating the notion that these genes are evolutionarily related.</Disease>
<Disease>Southern blot analysis of genomic DNA from hybrid cell lines was used to localize the VLCAD gene to human chromosome 17p11.</Disease>
<Disease>2-p11.</Disease>
<Disease>13105.</Disease>

<Disease>Using Northern and Western blot analysis to investigate the tissue specific distribution of VLCAD mRNA and protein in several human tissues we showed that VLCAD is most abundant in heart and skeletal muscle.</Disease>
<Disease>This agrees well with the fact that cardiac and muscle symptoms are characteristic for patients with VLCAD deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Northern blot analysis and sequencing of cloned PCR amplified VLCAD cDNA from four unrelated patients with VLCAD deficiency showed that VLCAD mRNA was undetectable in one patient and that the other three have mutations in both VLCAD alleles.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Western blot analysis of patient fibroblasts showed that the identified mutations result in severely reduced amounts of VLCAD protein.</Disease>
<Disease>Genetic bases of human complement C7 deficiency.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Complement C7 deficiency (C7D) is associated frequently with recurrent bacterial infections, especially meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>We report in this work the molecular bases of C7D in two unrelated Japanese males.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We used exon-specific PCR/single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis as a screening step for mutations.</Disease>
<Disease>Subsequent direct sequencing of the target exons identified homozygous mutations in exon 16 of case 1 and in exon 15 of case 2.</Disease>
<Disease>The mutation of case 1 was a homozygous T to A transversion at nucleotide 2250, the third nucleotide of the codon TGT for Cys728, leading to a stop codon TGA (C728X).</Disease>
<Disease>In case 2, a homozygous 2-bp deletion (2137delTG/2138delGT/2139delTG) caused a frameshift, generating a premature termination codon 4 to 6 nucleotides downstream.</Disease>
<Disease>Family study in case 1 confirmed the genetic nature of the defect.</Disease>
<Disease>Moreover, we detected a novel polymorphism in intron 11 that presumably is linked to the mutation responsible for C7D in case 1.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Our results indicate that the pathogenesis of C7D is heterogeneous like most of the other deficiencies of complement components..</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Defective dimerization of von Willebrand factor subunits due to a Cys-> Arg mutation in type IID von Willebrand disease.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>The same heterozygous T - > C transition at nt 8567 of the von Willebrand factor (vWF) transcript was found in two unrelated patients with type IID von Willebrand disease, with no other apparent abnormality.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In one family, both alleles were normal in the parents and one sister; thus, the mutation originated de novo in the proposita.</Disease>
<Disease>The second patient also had asymptomatic parents who, however, were not available for study.</Disease>

<Disease>The structural consequences of the identified mutation, resulting in the CyS2010 - > Arg substitution, were evaluated by expression of the vWF carboxyl-terminal domain containing residues 1366-2050.</Disease>

<Disease>Insect cells infected with recombinant baculovirus expressing normal vWF sequence secreted a disulfide linked dimeric molecule with an apparent molecular mass of 150 kDa before reduction, yielding a single band of 80 kDa after disulfide bond reduction.</Disease>
<Disease>In contrast, cells expressing the mutant fragment secreted a monomeric molecule of apparent molecular mass of 80 kDa, which remained unchanged after reduction.</Disease>

<Disease>We conclude that CyS2010 is essential for normal dimerization of vWF subunits through disulfide bonding of carboxyl-terminal domains and that a heterozygous mutation in the corresponding codon is responsible for defective multimer formation in type IID von Willebrand disease..</Disease>

text: <Disease>Ataxia-telangiectasia: founder effect among north African Jews.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The ATM gene is responsible for the autosomal recessive disorder ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), characterized by cerebellar degeneration, immunodeficiency and cancer predisposition.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A-T carriers were reported to be moderately cancer-prone.</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>A wide variety of A-T mutations, most of which are unique to single families, were identified in various ethnic groups, precluding carrier screening with mutation-specific assays.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>However, a single mutation was observed in 32/33 defective ATM alleles in Jewish A-T families of North African origin, coming from various regions of Morocco and Tunisia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>This mutation, 103C-- > T, results in a stop codon at position 35 of the ATM protein.</Disease>
<Disease>In keeping with the nature of this mutation, various antibodies directed against the ATM protein failed to defect this protein in patient cells.</Disease>
<Disease>A rapid carrier detection assay detected this mutation in three out of 488 ATM alleles of Jewish Moroccan or Tunisian origin.</Disease>
<Disease>This founder effect provides a unique opportunity for population-based screening for A-T carriers in a large Jewish community..</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>Mutations associated with variant phenotypes in ataxia-telangiectasia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We have identified 14 families with ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T) in which mutation of the ATM gene is associated with a less severe clinical and cellular phenotype (approximately 10% -15% of A-T families identified in the United Kingdom).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>In 10 of these families, all the homozygotes have a 137-bp insertion in their cDNA caused by a point mutation in a sequence resembling a splice-donor site.</Disease>
<Disease>The second A-T allele has a different mutation in each patient.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>We show that the less severe phenotype in these patients is caused by some degree of normal splicing, which occurs as an alternative product from the insertion-containing allele.</Disease>
<Disease>The level of the 137-bp PCR product containing the insertion was lowest in two patients who showed a later onset of cerebellar ataxia.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>A further four families who do not have this insertion have been identified.</Disease>
<Disease>Mutations detected in two of four of these are missense mutations, normally rare in A-T patients.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The demonstration of mutations giving rise to a slightly milder phenotype in A-T raises the interesting question of what range of phenotypes might occur in individuals in whom both mutations are milder.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>One possibility might be that individuals who are compound heterozygotes for ATM mutations are more common than we realize..</Disease>
<Disease>Cleavage of huntingtin by apopain, a proapoptotic cysteine protease, is modulated by the polyglutamine tract.</Disease>
<Disease>Apoptosis has recently been recognized as a mode of cell death in Huntington disease (HD).</Disease>
label: Disease
Disease

text: <Disease>Apopain, a human counterpart of the nematode cysteine protease death-gene product, CED-3, has a key role in proteolytic events leading to apoptosis.</Disease>
<Disease>Here we show that apoptotic extracts and apopain itself specifically cleave the HD gene product, huntingtin.</Disease>
label: Disease

text: <Disease>The rate of cleavage increases with the length of the huntingtin polyglutamine tract, providing an explanation for the gain-of-function associated with CAG expansion.</Disease>
<Disease>Our results show that huntingtin is cleaved by cysteine proteases and suggest that HD might be a disorder of inappropriate apoptosis..</Disease>
